description: Created by Logical Operations, the CyberSec First Responder certification, which is DoD Directive 8570 compliant, will prepare security professionals to become the first responders in their organization. You will learn how to defend against cyber-attacks, analyze threats, design secure computing and network environments, proactively defend networks, and respond/investigate to cybersecurity incidents.
descriptionMD: Created by [Logical Operations](http://logicaloperations.com/itprotv-cfr/), the CyberSec First Responder certification, which is DoD Directive 8570 compliant, will prepare security professionals to become the first responders in their organization. You will learn how to defend against cyber-attacks, analyze threats, design secure computing and network environments, proactively defend networks, and respond/investigate to cybersecurity incidents.
name: CyberSec First Responder
subtitle: Logical Operations

episodes.description: The CyberSec First Responder program will prepare security professionals to become the first responders in their organization. You will learn how to defend against cyber-attacks analyze threats, design secure computing and network environments, proactively defend networks, and respond/investigate cybersecurity incidents.
episodes.title: Overview

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike start the series by building a foundation of knowledge about specific threats called Threat Profiles. They begin by discussing and defining Threat Actors, which includes Insiders, Script Kiddies, Hackers, and Cyber Criminals.
episodes.title: Threat Profiles
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.023 --> 00:00:02.764
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.764 --> 00:00:07.774
[CROSSTALK]
[SOUND] You're

3
00:00:07.774 --> 00:00:11.831
watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:11.831 --> 00:00:13.666
>> All right, greetings everyone, and

5
00:00:13.666 --> 00:00:16.450
welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:16.450 --> 00:00:19.570
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, and
in today's episode we are kicking off

7
00:00:19.570 --> 00:00:24.820
our series for The Logical operations
cyber security first responders.

8
00:00:24.820 --> 00:00:26.670
Yes, that is a mouthful.

9
00:00:26.670 --> 00:00:29.380
And of course,
joining us to make that happen,

10
00:00:29.380 --> 00:00:33.400
Security Master himself our resident
security Guru, Mr. Mike Rodrick.

11
00:00:33.400 --> 00:00:36.830
Mike welcome to the show, so glad to
have you today Thanks, how's it going?

12
00:00:36.830 --> 00:00:39.910
>> It's going great thanks for
having me here, I am excited as well.

13
00:00:39.910 --> 00:00:41.960
Got this great course
from Logical Operations.

14
00:00:41.960 --> 00:00:44.430
Good old cyber security first responder.

15
00:00:44.430 --> 00:00:47.750
And so
we're gonna start off today's episode.

16
00:00:47.750 --> 00:00:53.310
We're gonna start laying some framework or
some baseline knowledge, right?

17
00:00:53.310 --> 00:00:57.840
We've got to start, we're gonna
start by looking at comparing and

18
00:00:57.840 --> 00:01:00.730
contrasting different threats
that we might face, and

19
00:01:00.730 --> 00:01:04.210
classifying what we call threat profiles,
all right.

20
00:01:04.210 --> 00:01:08.570
When we look at attacks and
threats that our organizations and

21
00:01:08.570 --> 00:01:10.640
our information faces.

22
00:01:10.640 --> 00:01:15.170
It can sometimes be beneficial
if we can create a profile.

23
00:01:15.170 --> 00:01:18.160
Because there's different types of
attacks, there's different types of

24
00:01:18.160 --> 00:01:24.580
attackers, different methodologies,
different reasons for doing the attack.

25
00:01:24.580 --> 00:01:29.280
The end result that the attacker
wants to accomplish is different.

26
00:01:29.280 --> 00:01:31.820
And you might think, what does it matter?

27
00:01:31.820 --> 00:01:35.960
Why don't we just deal with the aftermath,
the results of the attack.

28
00:01:35.960 --> 00:01:40.100
What does it matter why we're
trying to model the actual threats.

29
00:01:40.100 --> 00:01:44.430
And it's because we can start
to recognize patterns and

30
00:01:44.430 --> 00:01:46.410
we can start to understand our opposition.

31
00:01:47.480 --> 00:01:51.400
Depending on the type of data that we're
protecting or what our organization is,

32
00:01:51.400 --> 00:01:54.360
where it sits in the grand
scheme of things,

33
00:01:54.360 --> 00:01:58.920
can change who is more likely
to be our foe, be the attacker.

34
00:01:58.920 --> 00:02:04.730
What they're trying to do and
it will help us focus our security,

35
00:02:04.730 --> 00:02:09.000
or mitigation, or how we go about
defending our information, right.

36
00:02:09.000 --> 00:02:11.570
Base on the types of
attack that we might face,

37
00:02:11.570 --> 00:02:15.470
base on the types of attackers
that we might have to face.

38
00:02:15.470 --> 00:02:18.550
Like different organizations are gonna
have different threats if they have to

39
00:02:18.550 --> 00:02:21.770
face and we need to understand what
those are, so we can effectively apply.

40
00:02:21.770 --> 00:02:24.230
Because we can protect against everything,
all right.

41
00:02:24.230 --> 00:02:28.190
I mean we'll just be It's an uphill
battle and you're never gonna win it.

42
00:02:28.190 --> 00:02:32.170
But you can figure out what
the most likely things are and

43
00:02:32.170 --> 00:02:33.080
I can put my money there.

44
00:02:33.080 --> 00:02:37.190
And I can put my efforts there and
hopefully keep our information, and

45
00:02:37.190 --> 00:02:39.330
our company, and our organization, safe.

46
00:02:39.330 --> 00:02:42.460
So being able to create
these threat profiles,

47
00:02:42.460 --> 00:02:46.920
being able to understand what types
of threats that we're gonna face

48
00:02:46.920 --> 00:02:52.170
more often than not is a big help
in focusing our security efforts,

49
00:02:52.170 --> 00:02:56.070
and our investments that we're
putting into security, right?

50
00:02:56.070 --> 00:02:57.760
Understanding that for

51
00:02:57.760 --> 00:03:02.760
a very simple example, if I don't
have wireless networks then why would

52
00:03:02.760 --> 00:03:07.520
I focus on securing wireless information
or, threats, wireless type of attacks.

53
00:03:07.520 --> 00:03:11.160
Where people are outside my building,
but they're able to get

54
00:03:11.160 --> 00:03:14.640
access because my wireless coverage,
maybe extends outside my building.

55
00:03:14.640 --> 00:03:17.490
So I've got people out there that
are trying to connect to my network that

56
00:03:17.490 --> 00:03:18.010
I don't know about.

57
00:03:18.010 --> 00:03:19.840
If I don't have wireless networks,

58
00:03:19.840 --> 00:03:21.900
I don't have to do wireless surveys and
things like that.

59
00:03:21.900 --> 00:03:25.550
So those are the kind of things that
we can gain by taking a minute,

60
00:03:25.550 --> 00:03:30.480
taking some time to really analyze
what it is we've gotta face.

61
00:03:30.480 --> 00:03:31.480
>> It's a really good point.

62
00:03:31.480 --> 00:03:35.290
And Mike,
I thought it was interesting you said that

63
00:03:35.290 --> 00:03:38.640
not only are there types of attacks,
but there is also types of attackers.

64
00:03:38.640 --> 00:03:41.070
And that broadens the scope a whole lot.

65
00:03:41.070 --> 00:03:44.510
Because you might not think in that way,
can we start there?

66
00:03:44.510 --> 00:03:49.310
The type of attackers that we might
encounter as a security first responder.

67
00:03:49.310 --> 00:03:51.560
>> Absolutely,
that's a great place to kick it off.

68
00:03:51.560 --> 00:03:57.210
Sp when we talk about different books
we're going to use different terminology.

69
00:03:57.210 --> 00:04:01.550
You know we've always called them hackers,
but technically,

70
00:04:01.550 --> 00:04:06.100
you know if people want to get
technical a hacker is a good thing.

71
00:04:06.100 --> 00:04:07.830
Well, it used to be, right?

72
00:04:07.830 --> 00:04:10.950
Back before all of this
kinda got rolled into

73
00:04:10.950 --> 00:04:13.910
a hacker was somebody that you
wanted to have in your organization.

74
00:04:13.910 --> 00:04:17.030
Back when computer networks and
software were relatively new,

75
00:04:17.030 --> 00:04:19.840
a hacker was somebody that
could reverse engineer product.

76
00:04:19.840 --> 00:04:23.440
We might buy some software or
get some software, or

77
00:04:23.440 --> 00:04:25.150
some kind of have application in it.

78
00:04:25.150 --> 00:04:27.480
It doesn't do quite what we want it to do.

79
00:04:27.480 --> 00:04:30.110
A hacker, one of the guys or
gals on my network,

80
00:04:30.110 --> 00:04:34.370
on my administration that was good with
code, could maybe reverse engineer that.

81
00:04:34.370 --> 00:04:35.950
Figure out how it worked, and

82
00:04:35.950 --> 00:04:39.190
maybe add some functionality or
fix some functionality.

83
00:04:39.190 --> 00:04:41.260
That was the definition of a hacker.

84
00:04:41.260 --> 00:04:44.290
A cracker was the bad guy, right?

85
00:04:44.290 --> 00:04:46.085
Not a guy from Florida.

86
00:04:46.085 --> 00:04:47.170
>> [LAUGH]
>> But

87
00:04:47.170 --> 00:04:51.660
somebody that did with bad intent or
malicious intent.

88
00:04:51.660 --> 00:04:54.620
But then with the movies and the news and

89
00:04:54.620 --> 00:04:58.620
all of this,
hacker became synonymous with a bad guy.

90
00:04:58.620 --> 00:05:05.060
>> Yeah, the media really seemed to have
driven or drove that terminology to be

91
00:05:05.060 --> 00:05:10.090
ubiquitous across anyone that does
cyber security for malicious purposes

92
00:05:10.090 --> 00:05:14.060
when it never really came from that and it
was the crackers were the bad guys, right.

93
00:05:14.060 --> 00:05:17.200
They were the malicious ones,
trying to do things that were malicious,

94
00:05:17.200 --> 00:05:20.600
just evil intentions,
where hackers were good guys.

95
00:05:20.600 --> 00:05:24.079
And now everybody just says hacker and
I remember watching.

96
00:05:25.140 --> 00:05:26.570
Cuz I used to call myself a hacker.

97
00:05:26.570 --> 00:05:29.420
And then everybody thinks you're
a bad guy when you do that.

98
00:05:29.420 --> 00:05:30.080
And you're well no.

99
00:05:30.080 --> 00:05:33.380
And you get sick of trying
to correct everyone.

100
00:05:33.380 --> 00:05:35.660
So you just start going with
whatever the terminology is.

101
00:05:35.660 --> 00:05:38.330
And now, just hackers are bad guys.

102
00:05:38.330 --> 00:05:40.290
>> Yeah exactly, and we can try to fix it.

103
00:05:40.290 --> 00:05:44.590
I know a lot of security vendors
are trying to change the perception, but

104
00:05:44.590 --> 00:05:45.140
I don't know.

105
00:05:46.210 --> 00:05:48.280
>> That train has done left the station.

106
00:05:48.280 --> 00:05:49.090
>> Yeah.
Exactly.

107
00:05:49.090 --> 00:05:51.940
You aren't going to convince those
people that are hackers to do a thing.

108
00:05:51.940 --> 00:05:53.260
But anyway.

109
00:05:53.260 --> 00:05:58.480
So terminology wise, hacker,
cracker, attacker, threat,

110
00:05:58.480 --> 00:06:01.880
threat actor, bad actor, if those

111
00:06:01.880 --> 00:06:06.800
are the kinds of terms we typically
talk about and logical operations.

112
00:06:06.800 --> 00:06:09.710
Really we're talking about threat
actors in their terminology.

113
00:06:09.710 --> 00:06:13.280
So when I say a threat actor,
we're talking about the bad guy.

114
00:06:13.280 --> 00:06:15.960
The one that's going to be implementing or

115
00:06:15.960 --> 00:06:19.120
taking part in the cyber attack,
all right?

116
00:06:19.120 --> 00:06:20.930
So threat actors.

117
00:06:20.930 --> 00:06:21.990
And we can classify these.

118
00:06:21.990 --> 00:06:26.240
As Daniel was saying,
we can classify threat actors.

119
00:06:26.240 --> 00:06:27.470
They're not all the same.

120
00:06:27.470 --> 00:06:32.010
They don't have the same skill set,
they don't have the same intentions,

121
00:06:32.010 --> 00:06:35.210
the same end goals,
the same techniques, all right?

122
00:06:35.210 --> 00:06:37.000
So we can start classifying them.

123
00:06:37.000 --> 00:06:39.500
And we start classifying them,
it helps us,

124
00:06:39.500 --> 00:06:43.900
again, to implement better security and
to be ready, right?

125
00:06:43.900 --> 00:06:46.360
Depending on what type
of threat we're facing

126
00:06:46.360 --> 00:06:50.730
could change what we're going to be
implementing as far as security goes.

127
00:06:50.730 --> 00:06:54.150
So when we talk about threat actors,
and if we want to classify these guys,

128
00:06:54.150 --> 00:06:56.510
just keep in mind that these
are not black and white.

129
00:06:56.510 --> 00:07:00.350
There's no set of rules that
says this is what this is and

130
00:07:00.350 --> 00:07:04.210
this is what this is and will always
be and that's just the way it is.

131
00:07:04.210 --> 00:07:09.750
These are really kind of grey definitions
or they're flexible definitions.

132
00:07:09.750 --> 00:07:14.190
And not everything is gonna fit nice and
neat into one of these categories.

133
00:07:14.190 --> 00:07:19.460
You might have some that kind of overlap
in a couple of those different areas.

134
00:07:19.460 --> 00:07:23.642
It just makes it easier for
security professionals like you and

135
00:07:23.642 --> 00:07:26.570
I to talk about it, to communicate
with other security professionals, or

136
00:07:26.570 --> 00:07:30.480
to communicate with the higher
ups that we need to go to in

137
00:07:30.480 --> 00:07:34.020
order to get the money we need to
implement our security system, right?

138
00:07:34.020 --> 00:07:37.630
We have to have some way to
intelligently talk about it, and

139
00:07:37.630 --> 00:07:42.350
by creating these categories, we can
kind of all get on the same page, and

140
00:07:42.350 --> 00:07:44.300
make it a little bit
easier to communicate.

141
00:07:45.350 --> 00:07:48.677
So let's talk about what different
categories we have when we talk about

142
00:07:48.677 --> 00:07:50.101
threat actors of the bad guys.

143
00:07:50.101 --> 00:07:53.768
These are the ones that
are implementing the attack, right, and

144
00:07:53.768 --> 00:07:56.843
the first one we'll talk
about are gonna be insiders.

145
00:07:56.843 --> 00:07:59.683
And an insider is a anyone or person or

146
00:07:59.683 --> 00:08:05.590
group of people that have a close
business relationship with the target.

147
00:08:05.590 --> 00:08:08.540
That's how we're gonna define that one.

148
00:08:08.540 --> 00:08:12.570
But an insider might be
a current employee, right?

149
00:08:12.570 --> 00:08:15.800
Or it could be a disgruntled employee.

150
00:08:15.800 --> 00:08:18.870
Or it even could be an ex-employee

151
00:08:18.870 --> 00:08:23.390
could still be considered an insider
because of the knowledge they have.

152
00:08:23.390 --> 00:08:28.580
That's really what differentiates this
category from all the other categories

153
00:08:28.580 --> 00:08:32.390
is the information they have
about the network already.

154
00:08:32.390 --> 00:08:36.480
As an employee of your organization,
you're gonna be privy to information

155
00:08:36.480 --> 00:08:40.180
that the rest of the world might not know
or is gonna have to somehow discover.

156
00:08:40.180 --> 00:08:42.898
You already know what
the usernames are gonna be,

157
00:08:42.898 --> 00:08:45.660
right, because you have an account there.

158
00:08:45.660 --> 00:08:48.740
And for me, for example,
I know that my account is Mrodrick.

159
00:08:48.740 --> 00:08:52.830
So, if I wanna mess with Daniel,
or I know that Daniel has access

160
00:08:52.830 --> 00:08:56.970
to information that I want access to,
I wanna compromise his account.

161
00:08:56.970 --> 00:09:01.370
I'm pretty sure that his account's
gonna be Dlowry, because my account was

162
00:09:01.370 --> 00:09:05.030
Mrodrick first initial,
last name most likely his as well right?

163
00:09:05.030 --> 00:09:07.210
Because there's some
kind of standardization.

164
00:09:07.210 --> 00:09:10.180
So as an insider I have that information.

165
00:09:10.180 --> 00:09:13.320
I know how often our
passwords need to be changed.

166
00:09:13.320 --> 00:09:17.840
I know what the complexity
requirements are of the passwords.

167
00:09:17.840 --> 00:09:21.223
I know the shares that include
the documents that I can't get access to.

168
00:09:21.223 --> 00:09:25.356
This is the kind of information that
an insider would have that a person on

169
00:09:25.356 --> 00:09:27.850
the outside wouldn't have.

170
00:09:27.850 --> 00:09:31.060
And it doesn't mean that that
information is not obtainable

171
00:09:31.060 --> 00:09:33.320
by another class of hackers.

172
00:09:33.320 --> 00:09:36.780
But it's one less step you've gotta
go through and that's the key and

173
00:09:36.780 --> 00:09:39.690
that's where the real
danger is from insiders.

174
00:09:39.690 --> 00:09:43.010
Insiders are one of the more
dangerous categories.

175
00:09:43.010 --> 00:09:44.890
It's not what people think, right?

176
00:09:44.890 --> 00:09:48.320
When we romanticize about hackers and
attacking, if you can.

177
00:09:48.320 --> 00:09:49.519
I don't know if you can.

178
00:09:49.519 --> 00:09:52.140
But as security professionals,
we can, right?

179
00:09:52.140 --> 00:09:56.100
We can see the good and
the bad even though it's typically bad.

180
00:09:56.100 --> 00:09:59.690
These are the ones that we have to worry
about the most, I think in my opinion, and

181
00:09:59.690 --> 00:10:01.480
a lot of folks will agree with me,

182
00:10:01.480 --> 00:10:04.400
because of the fact that they've
already got that inside information.

183
00:10:04.400 --> 00:10:08.030
They don't have to worry about
getting into the network,

184
00:10:08.030 --> 00:10:10.340
they can walk into work and
plug into the wall.

185
00:10:10.340 --> 00:10:12.330
Or they can connect to
the wireless network.

186
00:10:12.330 --> 00:10:16.260
They already have an account
that's valid on that network.

187
00:10:16.260 --> 00:10:18.650
So really,
they've already made that first step,

188
00:10:18.650 --> 00:10:21.370
now all they have to do is
escalate their credentials.

189
00:10:21.370 --> 00:10:25.777
Try to get them to where they can get to
access information maybe they shouldn't

190
00:10:25.777 --> 00:10:27.176
have access to, right.

191
00:10:27.176 --> 00:10:30.727
So current employees, disgruntled
employees, people that have been,

192
00:10:30.727 --> 00:10:32.150
you know they get angry.

193
00:10:32.150 --> 00:10:35.470
Somebody parked in my parking spot
this morning that I always park in

194
00:10:35.470 --> 00:10:36.120
and now I'm angry.

195
00:10:36.120 --> 00:10:40.600
>> That's right, and never forget that
there, a corporation is large enough,

196
00:10:40.600 --> 00:10:42.810
there's such a thing as
corporate espionage, right.

197
00:10:42.810 --> 00:10:47.580
People are trying to get insiders to
work for them as a quote, unquote,

198
00:10:47.580 --> 00:10:48.880
double agent.

199
00:10:48.880 --> 00:10:50.610
Maybe they have a gambling problem.

200
00:10:50.610 --> 00:10:54.780
Maybe they have financial problems and
they're a little disgruntled at their job.

201
00:10:54.780 --> 00:10:58.320
Now all a competitor has to
do is find that person and

202
00:10:58.320 --> 00:11:02.670
go, hey, I'll make it worth your while
even if you get caught or fired.

203
00:11:02.670 --> 00:11:05.810
And just get me that information and
you got to worry about this.

204
00:11:05.810 --> 00:11:07.960
This is a real thing that could happen.

205
00:11:07.960 --> 00:11:12.170
>> Absolutely, you see it in
the movies but it's very true.

206
00:11:12.170 --> 00:11:16.630
If I need to get into that organization
I can't get in myself maybe or

207
00:11:16.630 --> 00:11:19.070
I'm having difficulty from the outside.

208
00:11:19.070 --> 00:11:21.320
I can find an employee that,
like you said,

209
00:11:21.320 --> 00:11:25.740
this is just right out of the movies, has
a gambling problem or has a ton of debt or

210
00:11:25.740 --> 00:11:30.050
has two children that he's trying to get
into school and needs money very badly.

211
00:11:30.050 --> 00:11:31.500
That's the guy I might approach and say,

212
00:11:31.500 --> 00:11:35.090
hey, look, I can make it worth your while
if you can slip out some information.

213
00:11:35.090 --> 00:11:37.040
Here's a thumb drive,
whatever the case may be.

214
00:11:37.040 --> 00:11:38.710
Or what's your password?

215
00:11:38.710 --> 00:11:39.772
So absolutely.

216
00:11:39.772 --> 00:11:43.660
Insiders play are a big threat
that organizations face and

217
00:11:43.660 --> 00:11:47.850
unfortunately it's something that
a lot of organizations don't consider.

218
00:11:47.850 --> 00:11:49.630
That's not their first thought.

219
00:11:49.630 --> 00:11:54.690
We always think about the outside guys,
the people from some other country.

220
00:11:54.690 --> 00:11:58.860
We won't mention any specific ones but
that are constantly attacking.

221
00:11:58.860 --> 00:11:59.850

00:23:18.370 --> 00:23:21.550
As a professional hacker,
Somebody's paying me to do this.

454
00:23:21.550 --> 00:23:27.200
Somebody's saying, hey I will give you x
amount of dollars, or whatever the payment

455
00:23:27.200 --> 00:23:32.290
might be, if you can get me this
information from this organization, right?

456
00:23:32.290 --> 00:23:36.100
So somebody that's paid
by an entity to do a job.

457
00:23:36.100 --> 00:23:39.760
Professional hackers
are typically very skilled,

458
00:23:39.760 --> 00:23:42.160
because they're getting paid, right?

459
00:23:42.160 --> 00:23:45.510
Daniel is not gonna pay me if I tell him
I can break in and get that email list of

460
00:23:45.510 --> 00:23:48.644
this organization, and I can't do it,
probably not gonna pay me, right.

461
00:23:50.040 --> 00:23:53.920
NFL player if he is no good,
he is gonna benched, and eventually cut,

462
00:23:53.920 --> 00:23:56.540
and he is no longer gonna
be a professional athlete.

463
00:23:56.540 --> 00:23:57.125
Same thing here.

464
00:23:57.125 --> 00:24:00.197
So your professional hackers
are really good at what they do,

465
00:24:00.197 --> 00:24:02.575
these are people that
have honed their skills.

466
00:24:02.575 --> 00:24:06.440
And they're now offering those
skills as a service, right?

467
00:24:08.260 --> 00:24:10.040
So, they're very, very skilled.

468
00:24:10.040 --> 00:24:13.660
They're also typically more devoted
than a recreational hacker.

469
00:24:13.660 --> 00:24:16.550
That's another thing I didn't really
talk about with recreational.

470
00:24:16.550 --> 00:24:20.200
As a recreational hacker, I get home
in the afternoon, the yard is mowed,

471
00:24:20.200 --> 00:24:23.300
the kids are fed, I got an hour to spare.

472
00:24:23.300 --> 00:24:26.110
Hey, let me fire up my virtual machines,
and practice fire walking, or

473
00:24:26.110 --> 00:24:27.319
something like that, right?

474
00:24:27.319 --> 00:24:29.972
And then, the wife calls and
says hey, we need blah, blah, blah.

475
00:24:29.972 --> 00:24:32.380
And I close my laptop and
I go working on it.

476
00:24:32.380 --> 00:24:34.500
No big deal,
maybe I'll get back to it tomorrow,

477
00:24:34.500 --> 00:24:38.740
maybe I'll get back to it next week,
whenever I find time.

478
00:24:38.740 --> 00:24:41.560
A professional hacker is
trying to get that job done,

479
00:24:41.560 --> 00:24:43.150
because that's how he gets paid.

480
00:24:43.150 --> 00:24:46.100
So, he's gonna be a lot more focused.

481
00:24:46.100 --> 00:24:48.202
When Daniel gives me that money and
says, here's your task.

482
00:24:48.202 --> 00:24:50.720
>> [LAUGH]
>> You don't get paid until you finish it.

483
00:24:50.720 --> 00:24:53.560
>> The phone shuts off,
the lights go out, the doors close, and

484
00:24:53.560 --> 00:24:55.610
you focus in on getting that job done.

485
00:24:55.610 --> 00:24:58.850
>> Absolutely, this is just like you
think about in a movie where I've got my

486
00:24:58.850 --> 00:25:00.450
15 screens around me.

487
00:25:00.450 --> 00:25:04.880
And I've got everything cut off from
the outside, I am focused on my task.

488
00:25:04.880 --> 00:25:07.580
I've got my sandwich and
my cup of water, and

489
00:25:07.580 --> 00:25:12.250
I don't leave the chair for
hours and hours at the time.

490
00:25:12.250 --> 00:25:14.890
So much more devoted which

491
00:25:14.890 --> 00:25:17.960
typically means they're gonna be
a little more successful as well, right?

492
00:25:19.720 --> 00:25:23.900
Malicious ones can be paid
by a rival organization.

493
00:25:23.900 --> 00:25:27.350
You might have somebody approach
a professional hacker and say,

494
00:25:27.350 --> 00:25:30.700
look this is our competition,
I want you to take them down.

495
00:25:30.700 --> 00:25:35.300
Or I want you to do something that's gonna
cause them problems thereby, eliminating

496
00:25:35.300 --> 00:25:41.580
or crippling my competition by giving
me an advantage in the business world.

497
00:25:41.580 --> 00:25:44.260
So, it could be paid by
a rival organization,

498
00:25:44.260 --> 00:25:46.430
you could be paid by
a disgruntled employee.

499
00:25:46.430 --> 00:25:51.530
We talked about an insider as being
somebody that is most likely a disgruntled

500
00:25:51.530 --> 00:25:56.180
employee, that's angry cuz they got
passed over for a promotion, or

501
00:25:56.180 --> 00:26:01.020
somebody took their favorite red stapler,
whatever the case may be.

502
00:26:01.020 --> 00:26:03.910
But what if they don't have the skill set,
right?

503
00:26:03.910 --> 00:26:06.850
I'm mad, I'm mad as heck because
Daniel got that promotion, and

504
00:26:06.850 --> 00:26:09.958
I've been here longer, and
I work better, and I do a better job.

505
00:26:09.958 --> 00:26:11.680
I should have got that promotion so,
I'm mad and

506
00:26:11.680 --> 00:26:14.040
I'm gonna make this organization pay.

507
00:26:14.040 --> 00:26:17.100
Problem is,
I don't have any skill set to do that.

508
00:26:17.100 --> 00:26:18.055
What's an alternative?

509
00:26:18.055 --> 00:26:21.350
Hey, go find somebody that does
have the skill set, right?

510
00:26:21.350 --> 00:26:25.490
I will give you x amount of
dollars if you can do this for me.

511
00:26:25.490 --> 00:26:29.640
So, you see professional hackers
being hired by rival organizations,

512
00:26:29.640 --> 00:26:32.843
disgruntled employees that
don't have the skill set.

513
00:26:32.843 --> 00:26:36.099
Or wanna just kinda offload
the work to somebody else, and

514
00:26:36.099 --> 00:26:39.360
the risk of getting caught hopefully,
to somebody else.

515
00:26:39.360 --> 00:26:44.770
Pay them to do it and I can maybe
reap some of the rewards, all right?

516
00:26:44.770 --> 00:26:47.740
Another type is going
to be a cyber criminal.

517
00:26:48.890 --> 00:26:53.030
And this one kinda crosses the lines
of several of the categories.

518
00:26:53.030 --> 00:26:59.470
But let's define a cyber criminal
as somebody that also gets paid

519
00:26:59.470 --> 00:27:05.600
like a professional hacker, but is usually
stealing the money from the target, right?

520
00:27:05.600 --> 00:27:08.150
Think about a normal criminal,
what does a normal criminal do?

521
00:27:08.150 --> 00:27:14.590
Goes to the gas station,
pulls out his jammy and wants money.

522
00:27:14.590 --> 00:27:16.270
Give me all the money in
the cash register, right?

523
00:27:16.270 --> 00:27:18.480
I'm trying to steal that money.

524
00:27:18.480 --> 00:27:20.420
The same thing with a cyber criminal,

525
00:27:20.420 --> 00:27:25.190
it's just a criminal that their
environment where they're performing their

526
00:27:25.190 --> 00:27:30.720
attack is in cyberspace rather than in the
physical world, but it's the same thing.

527
00:27:30.720 --> 00:27:38.151
Maybe I am trying to move money
from one account to another.

528
00:27:38.151 --> 00:27:42.573
Or I'm trying to do identity theft, which
I can then apply for a credit card and

529
00:27:42.573 --> 00:27:45.870
I can go on a shopping spree
on somebody else's dime.

530
00:27:45.870 --> 00:27:46.720
>> Ransomware.

531
00:27:46.720 --> 00:27:48.464
>> Yeah, ransomware, exactly.

532
00:27:48.464 --> 00:27:49.048
>> Big business right now.

533
00:27:49.048 --> 00:27:53.908
>> It's huge and lots of cases of
that where I break into a system,

534
00:27:53.908 --> 00:27:58.309
encrypt their system and say,
hey give me 500 bucks or

535
00:27:58.309 --> 00:28:02.110
a Bitcoin in order to get your data back,
right?

536
00:28:02.110 --> 00:28:05.210
So, I'm getting paid but
I didn't get hired by somebody,

537
00:28:05.210 --> 00:28:09.145
that's the difference between
professional and a cyber criminal.

538
00:28:09.145 --> 00:28:13.340
But again,
you could really call a professional,

539
00:28:13.340 --> 00:28:15.760
a type of cyber criminal, right?

540
00:28:15.760 --> 00:28:17.734
So that's where,
there's a little bit of gray in there.

541
00:28:17.734 --> 00:28:22.368
>> Mike, would like a pen tester, they're
being paid to break into systems, but

542
00:28:22.368 --> 00:28:24.590
they're doing it for good purposes.

543
00:28:24.590 --> 00:28:26.610
Would they also be a professional hacker?

544
00:28:26.610 --> 00:28:27.920
>> They would be a professional hacker.

545
00:28:27.920 --> 00:28:29.998
That's a very good point and
something we should mention, right?

546
00:28:29.998 --> 00:28:34.006
As a penetration tester for an
organization, you might work in-house for

547
00:28:34.006 --> 00:28:38.570
an organization or you might have your
own business where this is what you do.

548
00:28:38.570 --> 00:28:42.170
You're getting paid so,
you are a professional hacker but

549
00:28:42.170 --> 00:28:42.850
you're not malicious.

550
00:28:42.850 --> 00:28:46.540
Remember we say, professional hackers,
not all of them are malicious and

551
00:28:46.540 --> 00:28:50.970
most of these categories can have, where
what we call white hats and black hats.

552
00:28:50.970 --> 00:28:53.350
And we'll come back to some
of that terminology but

553
00:28:53.350 --> 00:28:56.770
a real quick analogy think of cowboys,
right?

554
00:28:56.770 --> 00:29:00.947
White hats, good guys, black hats, bad
guys, same thing within these categories.

555
00:29:00.947 --> 00:29:03.432
There's gonna be good and
bad probably of each.

556
00:29:03.432 --> 00:29:07.984
All right, we got a few more to go Daniel,
but we are getting short on time,

557
00:29:07.984 --> 00:29:09.158
aren't we there?

558
00:29:09.158 --> 00:29:11.225
>> Yes, a little bit but, you know what,

559
00:29:11.225 --> 00:29:13.731
that's the great thing
about here at ITProTV,

560
00:29:13.731 --> 00:29:18.100
we just make a part two when we need to
go more into more detail and more depth.

561
00:29:18.100 --> 00:29:20.590
So that's what we'll do Mike,
if that's okay with you that is?

562
00:29:20.590 --> 00:29:21.540
>> That works for me.

563
00:29:21.540 --> 00:29:24.100
>> All right, well, looks like we've
come to the end of this episode,

564
00:29:24.100 --> 00:29:25.880
we do thank you guys for watching.

565
00:29:25.880 --> 00:29:28.790
Definitely, check out the parts that
we've got coming up learning more about

566
00:29:28.790 --> 00:29:32.790
the different Threat Profiles by threat
actors and attacks that might happen.

567
00:29:32.790 --> 00:29:34.530
Looking forward to see you guys there.

568
00:29:34.530 --> 00:29:37.652
Until then, we're signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

569
00:29:37.652 --> 00:29:38.494
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

570
00:29:38.494 --> 00:29:39.598
>> And we'll see you next time.

571
00:29:39.598 --> 00:29:47.626
[MUSIC]

572
00:29:47.626 --> 00:29:49.475
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this	episode, Daniel	and Mike continue their explanation about different Threat Actors, specifically defining Hacktivists, State Sponsored Hackers, and Cyberterrorists. Then they discuss and define Threat Motives and Threat Intent which includes, the desire for money/power/recognition, revenge, and blackmail.
episodes.title: Threat Profiles Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.220 --> 00:00:01.170
Welcome to IT Pro TV.

2
00:00:01.170 --> 00:00:06.716
I'm your host.
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.716 --> 00:00:11.720
[MUSIC]
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

4
00:00:11.720 --> 00:00:15.881
>> Greetings everyone and welcome back
to another great episode of IT Pro TV.

5
00:00:15.881 --> 00:00:17.570
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie.

6
00:00:17.570 --> 00:00:20.570
And in today's episode,
we are continuing on with our series

7
00:00:20.570 --> 00:00:24.830
From Logical Operations,
the Cyber Security First Responder series.

8
00:00:24.830 --> 00:00:26.850
And of course joining me
back in the studio for

9
00:00:26.850 --> 00:00:30.160
a part two,
to continue our talk on thread actors.

10
00:00:30.160 --> 00:00:32.274
Our good friend Mr Mike Rodrick,
Mike welcome back sir.

11
00:00:32.274 --> 00:00:33.490
>> Hi, glad to have you.

12
00:00:33.490 --> 00:00:37.030
>> Thanks very much, glad to be back, and
yeah we're just gonna continue on as you

13
00:00:37.030 --> 00:00:40.530
said, describing our different thread
actors and then we'll move on from there.

14
00:00:40.530 --> 00:00:44.810
so we left off in that previous episode,
talking about cyber criminals.

15
00:00:44.810 --> 00:00:47.980
And we defined a cyber criminal
as somebody that's getting

16
00:00:47.980 --> 00:00:49.780
paid to do their cyber crimes.

17
00:00:49.780 --> 00:00:50.440
>> Mike Roderick.

18
00:00:50.440 --> 00:00:50.940
>> Yes.
>> [LAUGH]

19
00:00:50.940 --> 00:00:52.667
>> [LAUGH] No, no, no.

20
00:00:52.667 --> 00:00:54.164
>> Okay, hold on, wait.

21
00:00:54.164 --> 00:00:55.206
I admit to nothing.

22
00:00:55.206 --> 00:00:56.242
>> No, Homeland Security,

23
00:00:56.242 --> 00:00:57.290
I swear it's not me.

24
00:00:57.290 --> 00:00:59.620
But somebody that's getting paid, but

25
00:00:59.620 --> 00:01:05.050
typically not getting paid by a third
party, but stealing the money.

26
00:01:05.050 --> 00:01:08.850
So I'm gonna get paid, but only because I
was able to compromise your account and

27
00:01:08.850 --> 00:01:11.280
transfer that money into my account.

28
00:01:11.280 --> 00:01:16.043
So, we're dealing with things like
monetary theft, identity theft,

29
00:01:16.043 --> 00:01:18.005
fraud, could be blackmail.

30
00:01:18.005 --> 00:01:20.810
That would be another way to get paid for
my activities.

31
00:01:20.810 --> 00:01:24.810
I could break in,
compromise Daniel's information,

32
00:01:24.810 --> 00:01:29.730
find something juicy and then turn
around and use that to make money.

33
00:01:29.730 --> 00:01:33.320
Say, look I'm gonna release this
information if you don't pay me.

34
00:01:33.320 --> 00:01:36.690
So, getting paid but
not in the same way, not just somebody

35
00:01:36.690 --> 00:01:40.665
handing you a check well, probably
don't pay hackers with checks a lot.

36
00:01:40.665 --> 00:01:41.854
[LAUGH]
>> That's gonna leave a little bit of

37
00:01:41.854 --> 00:01:42.452
a paper trail but.

38
00:01:42.452 --> 00:01:44.193
>> Will you take a third party
out of state payroll check?

39
00:01:44.193 --> 00:01:47.027
>> [LAUGH]
>> No, no, I don't.

40
00:01:47.027 --> 00:01:48.240
I got my Square.

41
00:01:48.240 --> 00:01:49.489
I can hook it up to my iPhone.

42
00:01:49.489 --> 00:01:52.071
Here, just swipe your card through there.

43
00:01:52.071 --> 00:01:54.400
>> [LAUGH]
>> But yeah, so cyber criminals,

44
00:01:54.400 --> 00:01:56.580
somebody gets paid, but
usually by stealing.

45
00:01:56.580 --> 00:01:58.440
That's how they're making their money.

46
00:01:58.440 --> 00:02:00.080
Also, the other thing
about cyber criminals,

47
00:02:00.080 --> 00:02:04.760
a lot of times there's a what
they call cyber crime rings,

48
00:02:04.760 --> 00:02:08.770
as the terminology that cyber security or
logical operators uses.

49
00:02:08.770 --> 00:02:12.730
But there are online cyber crime rings.

50
00:02:12.730 --> 00:02:16.630
Just like in the physical world,
there's crime rings.

51
00:02:16.630 --> 00:02:18.770
The bad guys hang out with bad guys.

52
00:02:18.770 --> 00:02:20.110
They talk to each other.

53
00:02:20.110 --> 00:02:22.340
They share techniques and
things like that.

54
00:02:22.340 --> 00:02:24.150
Same thing for cyber criminals.

55
00:02:24.150 --> 00:02:28.120
There are places in the dark web or
out there in the internet,

56
00:02:28.120 --> 00:02:30.060
that you might not venture to.

57
00:02:30.060 --> 00:02:31.658
>> And don't want to.

58
00:02:31.658 --> 00:02:32.183
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah.

59
00:02:32.183 --> 00:02:35.770
[LAUGH] >> If you like your computer and
your data you probably don't want to.

60
00:02:35.770 --> 00:02:36.784
>> And a clean mind.

61
00:02:36.784 --> 00:02:39.300
[LAUGH]
>> It's rough out there, you all.

62
00:02:39.300 --> 00:02:40.044
>> Cause you can't unsee it.

63
00:02:40.044 --> 00:02:40.959
>> No you can't.

64
00:02:40.959 --> 00:02:43.710
>> Once you've seen it,
you can't unsee it.

65
00:02:43.710 --> 00:02:46.780
Yeah, so
there are actually rings of people or

66
00:02:46.780 --> 00:02:51.010
communities of bad guys and
where they can share techniques,

67
00:02:51.010 --> 00:02:55.460
share tools, share information about
potential targets and things like that.

68
00:02:56.640 --> 00:02:59.890
So these cyber-criminals
can become parts of those.

69
00:02:59.890 --> 00:03:02.670
And that just helps them
accomplish their end goal.

70
00:03:04.000 --> 00:03:05.180
And another classification.

71
00:03:05.180 --> 00:03:06.610
So we've got cyber criminals.

72
00:03:06.610 --> 00:03:09.030
Another classification
would be a hacktivist.

73
00:03:09.030 --> 00:03:10.299
I remember when this term first came out.

74
00:03:10.299 --> 00:03:12.057
And I was like,
[SOUND] that's a funny term.

75
00:03:12.057 --> 00:03:14.820
It just kind of sounds fun to say.

76
00:03:14.820 --> 00:03:16.110
You're a hacktivist.

77
00:03:16.110 --> 00:03:18.350
And most of us can probably figure out.

78
00:03:18.350 --> 00:03:21.017
I forget the term for
putting two words together.

79
00:03:21.017 --> 00:03:22.331
>> Yeah.

80
00:03:22.331 --> 00:03:24.745
>> Daniel is actually my English guy.

81
00:03:24.745 --> 00:03:25.245
[INAUDIBLE]
>> Yeah, I usually would have something.

82
00:03:25.245 --> 00:03:26.158
>> [LAUGH]

83
00:03:26.158 --> 00:03:26.873
>> But I do.

84
00:03:26.873 --> 00:03:27.833
>> I can't think of this one off the top

85
00:03:27.833 --> 00:03:29.156
of my head.
>> But it is.

86
00:03:29.156 --> 00:03:32.297
It's a combination of two words of

87
00:03:32.297 --> 00:03:38.480
activist and a hacker, a hacktivist,
if I can say that correctly.

88
00:03:39.560 --> 00:03:42.140
And from the term, it's one of
those that kind of defines itself.

89
00:03:42.140 --> 00:03:47.100
A hacktivist, you can probably
already know what I'm going to say,

90
00:03:47.100 --> 00:03:52.440
motivated by social issues,
this is somebody that

91
00:03:52.440 --> 00:03:56.740
is hacking for
what they believe is a good reason.

92
00:03:56.740 --> 00:03:59.580
>> So form of protest,
things of that nature.

93
00:03:59.580 --> 00:04:00.340
>> Exactly, yeah.

94
00:04:00.340 --> 00:04:05.620
These are gonna be people that are
convinced that their behavior is actually

95
00:04:05.620 --> 00:04:07.520
ethical and not malicious.

96
00:04:07.520 --> 00:04:10.030
I'm doing this for a very good reason.

97
00:04:10.030 --> 00:04:12.703
I'm saving animals from
being tested it against or-

98
00:04:12.703 --> 00:04:13.920
>> I think of anonymous,

99
00:04:13.920 --> 00:04:17.251
they sent modems and things to country,
I think it was Egypt,

100
00:04:17.251 --> 00:04:19.700
during that time when
they were blacked out.

101
00:04:19.700 --> 00:04:23.320
They couldn't get internet access and they
were showing them how to build VPNs and

102
00:04:23.320 --> 00:04:26.130
use the old phone systems to get
access to the rest of the world.

103
00:04:26.130 --> 00:04:29.590
Instructions, the whole nine yards air
dropping that stuff over there, so

104
00:04:29.590 --> 00:04:32.240
the people could basically because
their government had shut them down.

105
00:04:32.240 --> 00:04:34.384
>> So hacktivism, yeah.

106
00:04:34.384 --> 00:04:36.280
>> So trying to bypass some of
that censorship, but exactly.

107
00:04:36.280 --> 00:04:38.910
And they don't see themselves
as doing anything wrong.

108
00:04:38.910 --> 00:04:41.175
They're helping these people.

109
00:04:41.175 --> 00:04:44.465
But now if you're the Egyptian government-

00:17:24.967 --> 00:17:29.446
moving funds, I might be stealing
information from an organization.

340
00:17:29.446 --> 00:17:32.585
And then selling that information
to a rival organization or

341
00:17:32.585 --> 00:17:35.488
to somebody that could benefit
from that information.

342
00:17:35.488 --> 00:17:40.936
So indirectly, my desire is money,
but I'm not stealing money.

343
00:17:40.936 --> 00:17:44.692
I'm stealing something that I know
is of value to somebody else, and

344
00:17:44.692 --> 00:17:47.102
I can turn around and
sell it and make money.

345
00:17:47.102 --> 00:17:52.494
So probably, like I said, almost,
most attacks come back to the desire for

346
00:17:52.494 --> 00:17:55.629
money, whether it's direct or indirect.

347
00:17:55.629 --> 00:18:00.189
We can also have the desire for

348
00:18:00.189 --> 00:18:03.951
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's a powerful,

349
00:18:03.951 --> 00:18:08.994
pardon the pun, a powerful motivation for
a lot of attackers.

350
00:18:08.994 --> 00:18:15.558
That cyber terrorist wants to be able
instill that fear, cause that damage.

351
00:18:15.558 --> 00:18:20.438
They get a sense of power knowing that
they brought down an entire organization,

352
00:18:20.438 --> 00:18:24.097
or they brought a financial
institution to their knees, and

353
00:18:24.097 --> 00:18:27.560
they had to pay them money to
decrypt their information.

354
00:18:27.560 --> 00:18:31.694
That's a sense of power
that I have over them.

355
00:18:31.694 --> 00:18:35.571
They're this big organization,
yet they're bowing to my demands.

356
00:18:35.571 --> 00:18:38.584
[COUGH] Insiders,

357
00:18:38.584 --> 00:18:43.475
again, a sense of power, you treat
me like a little peon and yet I just

358
00:18:43.475 --> 00:18:46.615
sold all your customer information to-
>> Now who's the peon?

359
00:18:46.615 --> 00:18:47.205
>> Exactly.

360
00:18:47.205 --> 00:18:48.955
>> I'm gonna get back at you.

361
00:18:48.955 --> 00:18:53.004
>> Yeah, so that's that sense
of power that we might get.

362
00:18:53.004 --> 00:18:56.680
People that are after
power are often reckless.

363
00:18:56.680 --> 00:19:01.360
And because they're not thinking clearly,
or

364
00:19:01.360 --> 00:19:07.970
their motivation is power so they-
>> Ego has clouded their judgment, per se.

365
00:19:07.970 --> 00:19:10.731
>> Yeah, their better judgement
might be compromised and so

366
00:19:10.731 --> 00:19:14.730
they're willing to take risks that maybe
they shouldn't that's going to lead to,

367
00:19:14.730 --> 00:19:17.179
hopefully, their capture,
or their discovery.

368
00:19:17.179 --> 00:19:20.896
So one of the nice things about people
that are motivated by power is they can

369
00:19:20.896 --> 00:19:21.670
get reckless.

370
00:19:21.670 --> 00:19:27.300
They can set off alarms,
maybe,hopefully, we can detect them.

371
00:19:27.300 --> 00:19:32.350
Reputation and recognition,
this is another big motivator for

372
00:19:32.350 --> 00:19:33.640
the threat actors.

373
00:19:33.640 --> 00:19:36.740
I want to be recognized
as a skilled hacker.

374
00:19:36.740 --> 00:19:38.520
>> Again, ego coming into play, right?

375
00:19:38.520 --> 00:19:42.129
That seems to be, so that money and
ego, the two big heavy hitters so far.

376
00:19:42.129 --> 00:19:44.620
[LAUGH]
>> They really are, in most of these.

377
00:19:44.620 --> 00:19:50.700
As a recreational hacker, I want to
move into the world of professional.

378
00:19:50.700 --> 00:19:52.310
My skill set's been refined.

379
00:19:52.310 --> 00:19:53.890
I have fun doing this.

380
00:19:53.890 --> 00:19:57.090
I've gotten really good at it
because I treat it like a hobby.

381
00:19:57.090 --> 00:19:58.670
Now I think, you know what?

382
00:19:58.670 --> 00:20:00.720
I might be able to make
a little money doing this.

383
00:20:00.720 --> 00:20:03.080
Why don't I just try to offer my services?

384
00:20:03.080 --> 00:20:06.690
I got a friend that got a D and
he'd really like a B on that paper.

385
00:20:07.770 --> 00:20:08.649
>> What's the harm, right?

386
00:20:08.649 --> 00:20:10.537
>> Yeah,
give me a couple of hundred bucks and

00:20:10.537 --> 00:20:12.380
I can probably change your grade for you.

388
00:20:12.380 --> 00:20:16.490
And we're starting to move from

389
00:20:16.490 --> 00:20:18.650
But I get that recognition, right?

390
00:20:18.650 --> 00:20:21.970
I do a good job for one person,
maybe I start building a customer base,

391
00:20:21.970 --> 00:20:22.715
a clientele.

392
00:20:22.715 --> 00:20:26.200
So really true among recreationals.

393
00:20:26.200 --> 00:20:28.700
The other thing about
the recreational hacker,

394
00:20:28.700 --> 00:20:31.050
they don't want to be a script kiddie,
right?

395
00:20:31.050 --> 00:20:34.130
They want people to know, hey,
look, I'm not a script kiddie.

396
00:20:34.130 --> 00:20:36.780
I'm not just clicking buttons,
I know what the heck I'm doing.

397
00:20:36.780 --> 00:20:40.086
I wrote that script myself, right,
that wasn't just something I found.

398
00:20:40.086 --> 00:20:43.785
So recreational attackers, or actors,

399
00:20:43.785 --> 00:20:48.550
are looking for
that recognition of their skill set.

400
00:20:48.550 --> 00:20:50.500
They want to be known, again,

401
00:20:50.500 --> 00:20:54.690
they're moving up from the world
of being a script kiddie.

402
00:20:54.690 --> 00:20:59.950
They also might act careless because
again they want to make sure people know,

403
00:20:59.950 --> 00:21:03.140
well, that's a bad thing for
hacker normally.

404
00:21:03.140 --> 00:21:05.830
I know in their minds they're thinking,
I want everybody to know,

405
00:21:05.830 --> 00:21:09.040
but you don't want everybody to
know if you're a hacker, right?

406
00:21:09.040 --> 00:21:14.240
Old thing I learned years ago
is if you're a good hacker,

407
00:21:14.240 --> 00:21:15.670
everybody knows who you are.

408
00:21:15.670 --> 00:21:19.460
If you're a great hacker,
nobody knows who you are, right?

409
00:21:19.460 --> 00:21:20.310
That's the thing.

410
00:21:20.310 --> 00:21:24.267
That guy that you would never suspect,
or gal, don't get me wrong,

411
00:21:24.267 --> 00:21:27.691
that you would never suspect,
that's the dangerous one.

412
00:21:27.691 --> 00:21:31.229
The one that brags it about it all
the time, that talks about his skills,

413
00:21:31.229 --> 00:21:35.405
that shows people things that he's done,
that's the one that's gonna get caught,

414
00:21:35.405 --> 00:21:38.653
sooner than later, because he's
gonna tell the wrong person, or

415
00:21:38.653 --> 00:21:40.226
that information is out there.

416
00:21:40.226 --> 00:21:45.603
You don't think the police,
the enforcement side of things,

417
00:21:45.603 --> 00:21:49.872
has people in those rings
of the cyber criminals.

418
00:21:49.872 --> 00:21:53.010
That's their goal,
is to infiltrate those rings.

419
00:21:53.010 --> 00:21:55.520
And so when you post, hey I did this,
and blah, blah, blah, look at here,

00:21:55.520 --> 00:21:58.870
this is this web page that I defaced,
well, that information gets out,

421
00:21:58.870 --> 00:22:02.800
and before you know it, you've got the
black van parked in front of your house.

422
00:22:04.360 --> 00:22:08.130
So that careless attitude
when you're looking for

423
00:22:08.130 --> 00:22:12.180
reputation or recognition,
that's what, as a good guy,

424
00:22:12.180 --> 00:22:17.180
I can hopefully take advantage of,
is their desire for reputation.

425
00:22:17.180 --> 00:22:19.714
But, as a bad guy, as a threat actor,

426
00:22:19.714 --> 00:22:24.166
maybe I'll start charging more

427
00:22:24.166 --> 00:22:28.409
Because hey, if you want something done,
Daniel's the guy to talk to, but

00:22:28.409 --> 00:22:31.741
he's gonna cost you a little
more than that script kiddie.

00:22:31.741 --> 00:22:35.510
So now his pricing has gone up, right?

430
00:22:35.510 --> 00:22:39.500
And then other motives,
just the fun of it, right?

431
00:22:39.500 --> 00:22:43.070
Just the exploration, just to see if

432
00:22:43.070 --> 00:22:45.080
Why did you climb that mountain?

433
00:22:45.080 --> 00:22:45.962
>> Why not?
>> Because it was there, right?

434
00:22:45.962 --> 00:22:46.732
>> Yeah.

435
00:22:46.732 --> 00:22:52.440
>> Same thing with the thriller seekers,
the explorers, if I can get that word out.

436
00:22:55.210 --> 00:23:00.067
Again, this is like you're recreational

437
00:23:00.067 --> 00:23:03.738
They're maybe not trying
to do anything bad but

438
00:23:03.738 --> 00:23:07.510
they're just trying to
practice their skills.

439
00:23:07.510 --> 00:23:08.196
They're trying to refine.

440
00:23:08.196 --> 00:23:12.707
They wanna move from script
kiddie to recreational.

441
00:23:12.707 --> 00:23:15.602
They want to move from
recreational to professional.

442
00:23:15.602 --> 00:23:20.162
They want to go from professional

443
00:23:20.162 --> 00:23:22.399
So, they're practicing their skills.

444
00:23:22.399 --> 00:23:25.810
They're trying out new tools
that they've just read about,

445
00:23:25.810 --> 00:23:28.316
techniques that they've found somewhere.

446
00:23:28.316 --> 00:23:32.857
Those are the kind of motivations
we have for fun thrill exploration.

447
00:23:32.857 --> 00:23:35.556
And again, gray areas, right?

448
00:23:35.556 --> 00:23:39.709
Not everything is gonna fit neatly into

00:23:39.709 --> 00:23:44.198
Might be doing it for

450
00:23:44.198 --> 00:23:47.966
There might be more than

451
00:23:47.966 --> 00:23:51.294
I don't believe in testing on animals,

00:23:51.294 --> 00:23:55.193

00:23:55.193 --> 00:23:55.831
>> Yeah.
[LAUGH]

00:23:55.831 --> 00:23:57.881
>> So my primary motivation might be

00:23:57.881 --> 00:23:59.344
a political thing, but

00:23:59.344 --> 00:24:03.515
I'm also motivated by that dollar

I can keep my power on so that I can
Power all my tools that I use to attack.

00:24:07.927 --> 00:24:10.936
So there is gonna be some

459
00:24:10.936 --> 00:24:16.895
Keep in mind these are categories that we
can use for conversation, for reports.

460
00:24:16.895 --> 00:24:19.015
When we're talking to
other cyber professionals,

461
00:24:19.015 --> 00:24:21.762
cyber security professionals,
when we're generating reports,

462
00:24:21.762 --> 00:24:23.780
when we're doing information online.

463
00:24:23.780 --> 00:24:27.654
That's where these classifications really
come into play, as well as the exam.

464
00:24:27.654 --> 00:24:28.355
Don't forget the exam.

465
00:24:28.355 --> 00:24:29.895
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] They might ask you

466
00:24:29.895 --> 00:24:30.595
a question or two.

467
00:24:30.595 --> 00:24:31.987
But Mike's right.

468
00:24:31.987 --> 00:24:35.533
When it comes to the context of
the conversation, it helps to have

469
00:24:35.533 --> 00:24:39.672
at least some type of definition for
the different types that are out there.

470
00:24:39.672 --> 00:24:43.098
So again, a good reason for

471
00:24:43.098 --> 00:24:47.360
>> Exactly, all right, next thing I
wanna talk about is the intent, right?

472
00:24:47.360 --> 00:24:52.259
We've already talked about the actors,
the motivation.

00:24:52.259 --> 00:24:56.840
Then we wanna talk about the intent,
which is really the ultimate goal.

474
00:24:56.840 --> 00:25:03.810
And this kind of blurs, in my mind,
intent and motive are very similar, right?

475
00:25:03.810 --> 00:25:09.520
But the intent is the ultimate goal,
not so much what's motivating you.

476
00:25:09.520 --> 00:25:15.210
You might be motivated by money but
the intent was to bring that website down

477
00:25:16.400 --> 00:25:21.020
or to prevent people from being
able to buy those fur coats.

478
00:25:21.020 --> 00:25:22.780
That was my intent.

479
00:25:22.780 --> 00:25:25.240
My motivation was my love for animals.

480
00:25:25.240 --> 00:25:27.648
So do you see the difference
there between motive, intent?

481
00:25:27.648 --> 00:25:31.805
Sometimes they can be a little
difficult to distinguish between.

482
00:25:31.805 --> 00:25:35.450
But the ultimate goal of
the malicious behavior is the intent.

483
00:25:36.650 --> 00:25:39.490
And again,
as a cybersecurity professional,

484
00:25:39.490 --> 00:25:44.105
as a first responder understanding
the intent can help me protect my system.

485
00:25:44.105 --> 00:25:47.300
It helps me understand what
they're trying to do, so

486
00:25:47.300 --> 00:25:50.218
I know where is it that I
need to focus my efforts?

487
00:25:50.218 --> 00:25:51.777
Where do we need to spend our money?

488
00:25:51.777 --> 00:25:56.904
What controls should we implement first or
focus on when it comes to

489
00:25:56.904 --> 00:26:02.230
security controls because I know
what their intent is, right?

490
00:26:02.230 --> 00:26:04.860
What is their different
classifications of intent?

491
00:26:04.860 --> 00:26:09.220
Well, theft is probably
the most common goal, again.

492
00:26:09.220 --> 00:26:13.880
Whether that's theft of money,
whether that's theft of information.

493
00:26:13.880 --> 00:26:17.350
Theft is typically one of the intents.

494
00:26:17.350 --> 00:26:20.736
Again, the motivation might be money,
but my intent is to steal your customer

495
00:26:20.736 --> 00:26:23.986
database so that I can turn around and
sell that to one of your competitors.

496
00:26:23.986 --> 00:26:27.501
So my intent was to steal your database.

497
00:26:27.501 --> 00:26:31.001
My motive was the money that
I'm gonna get from stealing and

498
00:26:31.001 --> 00:26:32.760
then selling your database.

499
00:26:34.640 --> 00:26:40.515
With theft, more inclined to
hit high profile information.

500
00:26:40.515 --> 00:26:43.851
I wanna get something that I
know I can turn around and use-

501
00:26:43.851 --> 00:26:45.323
>> [CROSSTALK] Something that's more

502
00:26:45.323 --> 00:26:45.834
valuable.

503
00:26:45.834 --> 00:26:48.766
The higher profile it is,
the more money you can make off it.

504
00:26:48.766 --> 00:26:53.222
>> Yeah, exactly, right, that database
from that hairsalon with names and

505
00:26:53.222 --> 00:26:54.572
phone numbers, meh.

506
00:26:54.572 --> 00:26:57.124
But if that database has names,
phone numbers, and

507
00:26:57.124 --> 00:26:59.570
credit cards, much more valuable, right?

508
00:27:01.290 --> 00:27:04.260
So, high profile information.

509
00:27:05.590 --> 00:27:08.250
Espionage is another intent.

510
00:27:08.250 --> 00:27:15.465
The ultimate goal was to perform
espionage, to steal secrets, right?

511
00:27:15.465 --> 00:27:21.920
And my motivation might be political but
my end goal is the espionage.

00:27:21.920 --> 00:27:23.770
Could be state sponsored.

00:27:23.770 --> 00:27:27.194
And it could be internal versus external.

00:27:27.194 --> 00:27:31.386
If it's state sponsored, as a nation,

515
00:27:31.386 --> 00:27:36.202
some skilled attackers together so I can
attack another nation to prevent them from

516
00:27:36.202 --> 00:27:38.295

00:27:38.295 --> 00:27:43.770
Or to cause them issues, downtime,

00:27:43.770 --> 00:27:46.300
But it could be internal as well.

00:27:46.300 --> 00:27:51.230
It might be the state-sponsored going

520
00:27:52.900 --> 00:27:56.755
Like a country that doesn't want
their people to be able to access

521
00:27:56.755 --> 00:27:59.218
the web without some kind of censorship.

00:27:59.218 --> 00:28:04.309
So that would be an example of
state-sponsored espionage, but

00:28:04.309 --> 00:28:10.077
not against external but
against internal organizations, all right?

524
00:28:10.077 --> 00:28:14.551
It could be industrial espionage, and
this probably I don't know if it's more

525
00:28:14.551 --> 00:28:18.175
of less common than say state
sponsored against other nations.

526
00:28:18.175 --> 00:28:23.026
But as an industry,
I want to figure out what the heck

00:28:23.026 --> 00:28:28.210
that other competitor,
another industry in the same or

00:28:28.210 --> 00:28:30.595
some other-
>> [CROSSTALK] I make cogs and wheels.

00:28:30.595 --> 00:28:34.490
You make cogs and wheels and
Mike's kicking my butt in the market.

530
00:28:34.490 --> 00:28:35.920
Well, what's he doing that's so great?

531
00:28:35.920 --> 00:28:39.394
How come his cogs are selling better
than mine, they're last longer.

532
00:28:39.394 --> 00:28:43.629
I wanna find out what's going on so
that I can more compete with him,

533
00:28:43.629 --> 00:28:45.502
if not do better than he does.

534
00:28:45.502 --> 00:28:46.271
>> Yeah, absolutely.

535
00:28:46.271 --> 00:28:49.600
We both make the same thing,
we got same pricing point.

536
00:28:49.600 --> 00:28:51.728
Yet their profit margins
are much higher than mine.

537
00:28:51.728 --> 00:28:52.733
What are we doing wrong?

538
00:28:52.733 --> 00:28:54.970
Let me find that secret
that they're using.

539
00:28:54.970 --> 00:28:58.811
So that'd be an example of
industrial type espionage.

540
00:28:58.811 --> 00:29:05.709
And that's another intent is to steal
this other industry's information.

541
00:29:05.709 --> 00:29:09.541
Revenge is another big, big intent, right?

542
00:29:09.541 --> 00:29:13.710
In the end,

00:29:13.710 --> 00:29:18.638
Now revenge is typically something

00:29:18.638 --> 00:29:20.890

00:29:20.890 --> 00:29:25.200
It's almost like a,
I don't wanna say a side intent.

00:29:25.200 --> 00:29:27.220
But it's a bonus intent.

547
00:29:27.220 --> 00:29:33.210
Or revenge was my initial intent but

00:29:33.210 --> 00:29:38.350
And out of it, I get revenge on the
organization because I was hired away or

00:29:38.350 --> 00:29:41.730
I'll say this industry fired me,

00:29:41.730 --> 00:29:44.630
I went to another organization
in the same industry and

00:29:44.630 --> 00:29:48.190
I'm gonna help them perform espionage,

00:29:48.190 --> 00:29:52.620
So the intent might be espionage from

00:29:52.620 --> 00:29:55.010

554
00:29:55.010 --> 00:29:57.819
That's what I'm getting out of it, is I'm
gonna help this new organization take

00:29:57.819 --> 00:29:59.702

556
00:29:59.702 --> 00:30:05.310
>> And what's funny is it's probably one

557
00:30:05.310 --> 00:30:09.749
Even though there's not a whole lot to it,

558
00:30:09.749 --> 00:30:14.950

559
00:30:14.950 --> 00:30:18.600
>> Absolutely, and sometimes it's
if you've got a group of hackers,

560
00:30:18.600 --> 00:30:20.820
like let's say state sponsored, and

561
00:30:20.820 --> 00:30:26.370
they've gathered up a team that they wanna
use for this attack that they're planning.

562
00:30:26.370 --> 00:30:29.950
Their intent might be, as a government,

563
00:30:29.950 --> 00:30:34.464
their intent might be
against another government.

00:30:34.464 --> 00:30:38.271
But the individuals within that group,

00:30:38.271 --> 00:30:41.386
that person really has a problem

566
00:30:41.386 --> 00:30:42.666
with this other company.

567
00:30:42.666 --> 00:30:45.709
So I'm gonna take Daniel's revenge and

568
00:30:45.709 --> 00:30:50.430
use that help him to motivate
my intent as a nation, right?

569
00:30:50.430 --> 00:30:53.967
So, again,
you see some crossover there where it

570
00:30:53.967 --> 00:30:57.937
might be different intents
within the attack, right?

571
00:30:57.937 --> 00:31:01.739
I'm not willing to do it for your reasons,
but because I hate that country and

572
00:31:01.739 --> 00:31:02.801
what they've done.

573
00:31:02.801 --> 00:31:04.090
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.

574
00:31:04.090 --> 00:31:07.901
>> Well, okay, I'm gonna go ahead and
join forces with you and

575
00:31:07.901 --> 00:31:10.835
throw my skill set in to get my revenge,
okay?

576
00:31:10.835 --> 00:31:12.323
Defamation of character is another one.

577
00:31:12.323 --> 00:31:13.387
>> That's a fun one.
[LAUGH]

578
00:31:13.387 --> 00:31:16.663
>> Yes, this is one that's, again,

579
00:31:16.663 --> 00:31:19.510
kind of falls back to revenge.

580
00:31:20.680 --> 00:31:22.408
I want to make Daniel look like a fool.

581
00:31:22.408 --> 00:31:25.816
I want to make him look
bad in the public eye.

582
00:31:25.816 --> 00:31:31.998
I'm doing it for revenge, but my intent
is to deform his or deface his character.

583
00:31:31.998 --> 00:31:34.240
>> So again, going back to our cogs.

584
00:31:34.240 --> 00:31:36.700
We're both in the same business.

585
00:31:36.700 --> 00:31:39.023
If I've stolen Mike's secrets,
I've done espionage, awesome.

586
00:31:39.023 --> 00:31:41.038
Well, Mike can come right back and
go, well,

587
00:31:41.038 --> 00:31:42.957
Daniel clubs baby fur
seals on the weekend.

588
00:31:42.957 --> 00:31:46.080
>> [LAUGH]
>> Maybe I don't do that.

589
00:31:46.080 --> 00:31:48.080
Probably I don't.

590
00:31:48.080 --> 00:31:50.340
Hence the defamation of character.

591
00:31:50.340 --> 00:31:53.741
He's just putting it out there that I
do things that most people will find

592
00:31:53.741 --> 00:31:56.263
reprehensible, so
that you just won't buy from me.

593
00:31:56.263 --> 00:31:58.048
And increase Mike's profit margins.

594
00:31:58.048 --> 00:31:59.768
>> Yes, absolutely.

595
00:31:59.768 --> 00:32:03.008
And it's a great point too
about whether it's true,

596
00:32:03.008 --> 00:32:08.052
because when it comes to defamation of
character Doesn't really matter, right?

597
00:32:08.052 --> 00:32:10.944
Because now I'm putting the owners
on them to try to prove it wrong,

598
00:32:10.944 --> 00:32:11.770
if it's not true.

599
00:32:12.870 --> 00:32:17.860
Did I compromise Daniel's emails and
see him purchase that ticket to get on

600
00:32:17.860 --> 00:32:20.420
that cruise ship to go up there
where those baby seals there and

601
00:32:20.420 --> 00:32:23.380
start clubbing them and
push that information out?

602
00:32:23.380 --> 00:32:26.510
Or did I just make it
up out of the thin air?

603
00:32:26.510 --> 00:32:27.850
Does it matter?

604
00:32:27.850 --> 00:32:30.410
All right?
You know in the political arena we see

605
00:32:30.410 --> 00:32:34.330
this all the time, especially here in
the states I'm sure everywhere else.

606
00:32:34.330 --> 00:32:37.910
You know this political
person is doing a campaign,

607
00:32:37.910 --> 00:32:41.840
a commercial or what have you and
they're saying how this other person

608
00:32:41.840 --> 00:32:44.250
voted against this nine time out of ten,
blah, blah, blah.

609
00:32:44.250 --> 00:32:47.040
Is it true, is it not.

610
00:32:47.040 --> 00:32:48.160
Does it matter?

611
00:32:48.160 --> 00:32:50.180
Because a lot of people
won't go any further and

612
00:32:50.180 --> 00:32:52.860
do their own research to
verify what you just said.

613
00:32:52.860 --> 00:32:56.640
>> They planted the seed and now it's
gonna bloom and blossom all itself.

614
00:32:56.640 --> 00:33:01.150
>> With today's social media, you see
we've talked about this very thing.

615
00:33:01.150 --> 00:33:01.730
>> Many times.

616
00:33:01.730 --> 00:33:06.700
>> Several times, how people will take
information that they found, somewhere,

617
00:33:06.700 --> 00:33:11.330
and just re-post it as fact and
no checking, no nothing, like my gosh,

618
00:33:11.330 --> 00:33:12.620
can you believe what this person is doing.

619
00:33:12.620 --> 00:33:14.910
Where did you get that information?

620
00:33:14.910 --> 00:33:15.720
Over here.

621
00:33:15.720 --> 00:33:17.600
Well, they took one word here,
one word here, and

622
00:33:17.600 --> 00:33:21.510
one word here, from somebody's
long statement, and made it look.

623
00:33:21.510 --> 00:33:25.200
So, it's when it comes to defamation
of character, whether it's true or

624
00:33:25.200 --> 00:33:29.240
not, it can still pretty
a far reaching effect.

625
00:33:31.040 --> 00:33:35.130
So spreading information can also
be a form of sabotage, right.

626
00:33:35.130 --> 00:33:42.565
If I can Daniel, does the word,
I don't wanna deform you.

627
00:33:42.565 --> 00:33:44.110
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] If I wanted to apply

628
00:33:44.110 --> 00:33:45.830
defamation of character to you-
>> Slander.

629
00:33:45.830 --> 00:33:46.970
>> Slander, I like that word.

630
00:33:46.970 --> 00:33:48.410
Okay, we'll use slander.

631
00:33:48.410 --> 00:33:54.520
If I Slander your company's CEO.

632
00:33:54.520 --> 00:33:58.450
That could be a form a sabotage
against your organization.

633
00:33:58.450 --> 00:34:03.670
Or do some revelation of methods
that you might be using,

634
00:34:03.670 --> 00:34:07.520
might or might not be using,
that slanders against your organization.

635
00:34:07.520 --> 00:34:10.950
I'm never buying that
product again because

636
00:34:10.950 --> 00:34:13.900
they test on little rabbits all right.

637
00:34:13.900 --> 00:34:16.940
That could be defamation of
character of the organization.

638
00:34:16.940 --> 00:34:21.330
It doesn't have to be an individual that
they're performing the defamation or

639
00:34:21.330 --> 00:34:22.260
the slander against.

640
00:34:22.260 --> 00:34:24.348
>> Kentucky Fried Chicken kills
millions of chickens a year.

641
00:34:24.348 --> 00:34:26.181
[LAUGH]
>> Right?

642
00:34:26.181 --> 00:34:27.150
>> And indeed they do.

643
00:34:27.150 --> 00:34:27.770
>> It's true.

644
00:34:27.770 --> 00:34:32.350
>> Because they serve chicken but the way
you put makes it sound really, really bad.

645
00:34:32.350 --> 00:34:33.080
>> Right.
>> All right.

646
00:34:34.580 --> 00:34:37.020
We got more to go Daniel but
I know you give me that evil eye there.

647
00:34:37.020 --> 00:34:38.320
Tell me we're out of time.

648
00:34:38.320 --> 00:34:39.890
>> What you gonna do, right?

649
00:34:39.890 --> 00:34:43.320
The clock should ticks on and
there's nothing we can do to stop it.

650
00:34:43.320 --> 00:34:45.590
Other than to create a part three
because that's what we have to do.

651
00:34:45.590 --> 00:34:47.600
There's plenty of more information to go.

652
00:34:47.600 --> 00:34:49.930
Mike's got a lot of good stuff for
you guys that you need to learn,

653
00:34:49.930 --> 00:34:53.120
especially before the exam itself
that would probably be helpful.

654
00:34:53.120 --> 00:34:55.820
So we will definitely
be doing a part three.

655
00:34:55.820 --> 00:34:58.440
As for this episode though,
it looks like we have come to the end.

656
00:34:58.440 --> 00:34:59.510
Hopefully you've enjoyed it.

657
00:34:59.510 --> 00:35:00.810
So we're gonna go ahead and sign off.

658
00:35:00.810 --> 00:35:03.390
For ITProTV I've been
your host Daniel Lowrie.

659
00:35:03.390 --> 00:35:04.050
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

660
00:35:04.050 --> 00:35:06.543
>> And we'll see you next time.

661
00:35:06.543 --> 00:35:12.589
[MUSIC]

662
00:35:12.589 --> 00:35:17.709
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike finish exploring the different Threat Motives as well as discussing Attack Vectors and Technique Criteria. The Attack Vectors discussed includes Vulnerabilites, Exploits, and Techniques used while the Technique Criteria involves direct vs. indirect, stealth/non-stealth, and client-side/server-side.
episodes.title: Threat Profiles Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.344
Welcome to ITPRO.TV.

2
00:00:01.344 --> 00:00:06.596
I'm your host [CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:06.596 --> 00:00:08.341
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.341 --> 00:00:12.030
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:12.030 --> 00:00:12.560
>> All right,

6
00:00:12.560 --> 00:00:16.610
greetings everyone and welcome to
another great episode of IT Pro TV.

7
00:00:16.610 --> 00:00:19.670
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and
we are back with another

8
00:00:19.670 --> 00:00:24.690
in our series on the logical operations
of cybersecurity first responders.

9
00:00:24.690 --> 00:00:26.030
And of course joining us back,

10
00:00:26.030 --> 00:00:30.300
we're coming at you with part
three on threat intents.

11
00:00:30.300 --> 00:00:32.250
That is our good friend Mr. Mike Rodrick.

12
00:00:32.250 --> 00:00:33.180
Mike, welcome back.

13
00:00:33.180 --> 00:00:34.240
>> Thanks for having me back.

14
00:00:34.240 --> 00:00:36.500
And yeah, we've got more to go,
right, with intent.

15
00:00:36.500 --> 00:00:38.150
There's so many different intents.

16
00:00:38.150 --> 00:00:41.140
And in the end, remember,
we're talking about threat profiles.

17
00:00:41.140 --> 00:00:44.550
Which we're gonna kinda tie
in at the very end here.

18
00:00:44.550 --> 00:00:45.390
So let's continue on.

19
00:00:45.390 --> 00:00:47.040
We were talking about different intents.

20
00:00:47.040 --> 00:00:49.320
What is their ultimate goal.

21
00:00:49.320 --> 00:00:51.780
We've talked about the actors,
who they are,

22
00:00:51.780 --> 00:00:55.980
trying to classify them script kiddie,
professional, cyber terrorist.

23
00:00:55.980 --> 00:01:00.120
We talked about their motivation,
what is their motivating factor.

24
00:01:00.120 --> 00:01:03.860
Is it money, is it fame, and
fortune and that kind of thing.

25
00:01:03.860 --> 00:01:08.500
And their intent is that ultimate goal
of what they would like the outcome,

26
00:01:08.500 --> 00:01:10.760
the end result to be.

27
00:01:10.760 --> 00:01:13.180
And I showed you how intent and

28
00:01:13.180 --> 00:01:16.690
motive are very similar,
sometimes hard to distinguish between.

29
00:01:18.080 --> 00:01:20.690
But the intent is that the ultimate goal

30
00:01:22.730 --> 00:01:27.520
where my motivation might be revenge.

31
00:01:27.520 --> 00:01:32.380
But the goal of the attack is defacing
your company in the public view, so

32
00:01:32.380 --> 00:01:34.850
that we can differentiate like that.

33
00:01:34.850 --> 00:01:37.720
So we left off talking about
deformation of character,

34
00:01:38.770 --> 00:01:41.360
the next thing I want
talk about is blackmail.

35
00:01:41.360 --> 00:01:45.806
Another one of our major
intents is the blackmail.

36
00:01:45.806 --> 00:01:51.290
>> Kind of a subcategory of profit or
money motivation.

37
00:01:51.290 --> 00:01:53.910
>> Yes, or a subcategory of revenge even.

38
00:01:53.910 --> 00:01:57.170
So they all start, again,
blurring together there.

39
00:01:57.170 --> 00:02:00.830
But understanding generally
that blackmail is typically,

40
00:02:03.030 --> 00:02:06.650
you're gonna get information that
somebody does not want exposed or

41
00:02:07.760 --> 00:02:11.360
that an organization that that
information is proprietary.

42
00:02:11.360 --> 00:02:13.090
And I don't want it exposed.

43
00:02:13.090 --> 00:02:14.600
I get a hold of that information.

44
00:02:14.600 --> 00:02:19.820
I'm now gonna hold it over your head and
try to use that as leverage to get

45
00:02:19.820 --> 00:02:24.810
money or whatever the case
may be from an organization.

46
00:02:24.810 --> 00:02:26.020
So it can be for revenge.

47
00:02:26.020 --> 00:02:29.610
It could be for monetary gain.

48
00:02:29.610 --> 00:02:34.692
Again, I get that email of Daniel's
confirmation of ticket for the seabess.

49
00:02:34.692 --> 00:02:35.540
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

50
00:02:35.540 --> 00:02:36.040
>> I can't even say it.

51
00:02:36.040 --> 00:02:37.322
>> Couldn't get it out,

52
00:02:37.322 --> 00:02:37.865
can you.

53
00:02:37.865 --> 00:02:38.645
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah.

54
00:02:38.645 --> 00:02:39.870
>> Can't even say it.

55
00:02:39.870 --> 00:02:43.200
But trying to get information about,

56
00:02:43.200 --> 00:02:46.610
maybe I catch Daniel
in a compromising act.

57
00:02:46.610 --> 00:02:48.370
I've got a photographic evidence.

58
00:02:48.370 --> 00:02:50.550
This is now something that
I could hold over him.

59
00:02:50.550 --> 00:02:55.860
Say, I will release this if you
don't give me that promotion or

60
00:02:55.860 --> 00:03:02.890
shut down your website and
stop doing this practice or give me money.

61
00:03:02.890 --> 00:03:08.370
So you see I'm pulling in multiple
motives but that same intent.

62
00:03:08.370 --> 00:03:12.000
So kind of draw a little
bit of gray there.

63
00:03:12.000 --> 00:03:15.365
But typically comes from
a breach in communication media,

64
00:03:15.365 --> 00:03:20.650
whether that's email,
phone calls, paper mail.

65
00:03:20.650 --> 00:03:21.850
I get that information.

66
00:03:21.850 --> 00:03:25.200
It's information that shouldn't
have been disclosed to me.

67
00:03:25.200 --> 00:03:29.919
But through my efforts I've been able to
compromise Daniel's web mail account.

68
00:03:29.919 --> 00:03:31.431
I can now get his emails.

69
00:03:31.431 --> 00:03:35.270
I can get, he should have put
that in an email he knew better.

70
00:03:35.270 --> 00:03:38.360
But now I've got that email and
I can use it to blackmail him.

71
00:03:38.360 --> 00:03:39.470
Hey pay me this.

72
00:03:39.470 --> 00:03:43.630
Step down from the organization,
otherwise I will release this information.

73
00:03:43.630 --> 00:03:47.900
It might be better for you to go ahead and
step down rather than deal with

74
00:03:47.900 --> 00:03:51.050
the repercussions of the information
that I'm getting ready to release.

75
00:03:51.050 --> 00:03:54.150
So can use blackmail for several purposes.

76
00:03:55.320 --> 00:04:00.340
Another one would be, when we're
talking about intent, activism, or

77
00:04:00.340 --> 00:04:04.730
political, again this can be the end
goal as well as the motivator.

78
00:04:04.730 --> 00:04:07.110
We saw this in both categories.

79
00:04:07.110 --> 00:04:10.280
We saw activism as a threat
actor classification.

80
00:04:10.280 --> 00:04:13.100
See how this term kind of goes
across the borders there.

81
00:04:13.100 --> 00:04:16.090
Raise awareness of the cause
that they are fighting for.

82
00:04:16.090 --> 00:04:21.060
Now that maybe my intent,
is I'm doing this

83
00:04:21.060 --> 00:04:26.140
because my motive was the fact that
I don't like cruelty to animals.

84
00:04:26.140 --> 00:04:29.690
So my motive is to protect those
little rabbits that you're testing on.

85
00:04:29.690 --> 00:04:36.190
My overall intent might be to stop them
from performing those types of actions.

86
00:04:36.190 --> 00:04:40.180
So it could be for
a reason, for hacktivism.

87
00:04:40.180 --> 00:04:41.590
It could be political.

88
00:04:41.590 --> 00:04:46.750
I want revenge against this country,
this nation.

89
00:04:46.750 --> 00:04:50.260
But my overall intent
is to get the word out,

90
00:04:50.260 --> 00:04:52.330
that this country is
performing these actions.

91
00:04:52.330 --> 00:04:56.000
Now, the rest of the world knows about it
and maybe I can get more done against it.

92
00:04:56.000 --> 00:04:59.810
Or to prevent it or to stop it,
or whatever the case may be.

93
00:04:59.810 --> 00:05:02.860
So raise awareness of
the cause you're fighting for.

94
00:05:02.860 --> 00:05:08.330
A lot of time the idea is to
cause a denial of service.

95
00:05:08.330 --> 00:05:12.430
Where I can prevent people from accessing
your site and ordering your product.

96
00:05:12.430 --> 00:05:16.460
Or accessing your site and you being able
to disseminate this bad information.

97
00:05:16.460 --> 00:05:19.870
You know I can stop you from that.

98
00:05:19.870 --> 00:05:25.380
Doxing is a term that kind of falls
within this as a subcategory.

99
00:05:26.680 --> 00:05:30.951
Would be practice of publishing
personally identifiable.

100
00:05:30.951 --> 00:05:32.324
If I can say this.

101
00:05:32.324 --> 00:05:33.087
Slow down.

102
00:05:33.087 --> 00:05:38.350
Personally identifiable information
about individuals online.

103
00:05:38.350 --> 00:05:43.160
So, maybe I have
compromised some personally

104
00:05:43.160 --> 00:05:47.600
identifiable information, my goal where my

105
00:05:47.600 --> 00:05:52.810
motive was to access this personal
information that I know this company has.

106
00:05:52.810 --> 00:05:57.020
My overall intent was then to take the
information that I got and publish it and

107
00:05:57.020 --> 00:05:57.770
make it available.

108
00:05:59.080 --> 00:06:00.170
That would be doxing,

109
00:06:00.170 --> 00:06:04.480
publishing personally identifiable
information about individuals online.

110
00:06:06.080 --> 00:06:08.400
So lots of different intents.

111
00:06:08.400 --> 00:06:10.790
We've talked about actors,
motives, and intents.

112
00:06:12.180 --> 00:06:14.780
Let's talk about attack vectors next.

113
00:06:14.780 --> 00:06:20.800
And really an attack vector is simply
the method that the attack takes.

114
00:06:20.800 --> 00:06:23.360
What was the means of comprising.

115
00:06:23.360 --> 00:06:28.960
How did you get into the system to access
that personally identifiable information

116
00:06:28.960 --> 00:06:35.140
or to access that secret formula
that you're going to steal.

117
00:06:35.140 --> 00:06:36.740
How did you get in.

118
00:06:36.740 --> 00:06:38.290
What was the avenue of attack.

119
00:06:38.290 --> 00:06:42.100
And that's really what an attack
vector is, is the avenue of attack.

120
00:06:42.100 --> 00:06:45.980
Method that an attack takes is
the actual definition they wanna use.

121
00:06:47.500 --> 00:06:50.760
Typically, an attack
vector is a vulnerability.

122
00:06:50.760 --> 00:06:55.060
It's a hole within the system,
or within your network,

123
00:06:55.060 --> 00:06:58.710
that somebody is gonna try to leverage,
or take advantage of.

124
00:06:58.710 --> 00:07:02.890
>> Now Mike, there would necessarily have
to be some sort of vulnerability for

125
00:07:02.890 --> 00:07:04.435
an attack to even tech list, correct.

126
00:07:04.435 --> 00:07:05.185
>> Exactly.

127
00:07:05.185 --> 00:07:07.805
And this is what worries
a security professional,

128
00:07:07.805 --> 00:07:11.655
what we're always trying to minimize,
is what we call our attack surface.

129
00:07:11.655 --> 00:07:16.465
We're trying to reduce the number of
attack vectors that we are exposed to or

130
00:07:16.465 --> 00:07:20.365
we have exposed,
thereby minimizing or reducing

131
00:07:20.365 --> 00:07:24.990
the likelihood of somebody attacking or
being successful in their attack.

132
00:07:24.990 --> 00:07:28.100
So, attack vector, again,
method that an attack takes.

133
00:07:28.100 --> 00:07:32.055
We're talking about vulnerabilities, as I
said, holes within your system or network.

134
00:07:32.055 --> 00:07:36.310
Vulnerability can be caused
by different things.

135
00:07:36.310 --> 00:07:40.840
It could be a vulnerability in, let's say,
software that you've implemented.

136
00:07:42.030 --> 00:07:45.342
Unbeknownst to you,
this software has a vulnerability.

137
00:07:45.342 --> 00:07:49.737
And if somebody does a certain set
of steps or combination of steps,

138
00:07:49.737 --> 00:07:51.904
they can take advantage of that.

139

So we build these different
