episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike begin their discussion on the Tools and Techniques used by the Threat Actors to gather information about target networks and/or devices. They start their conversation by explaining the crucial information gathering methods used when Footprinting a target. This includes DNS info gathering, Dumpster Diving, Social Media searching, and even Google searching.

50
00:02:50.320 --> 00:02:55.110
back to the beginning so that they can,
maybe successfully carry out an attack.

51
00:02:55.110 --> 00:03:01.390
And it's the same thing that
cyber criminals, anybody

52
00:03:01.390 --> 00:03:05.510
that's doing this attack is gonna do,
no one's gonna blindly start the attack.

53
00:03:05.510 --> 00:03:08.551
If they're gonna be successful
they have to do some

54
00:03:08.551 --> 00:03:11.973
reconnaissance and-
>> If they wanna successfully do it again

55
00:03:11.973 --> 00:03:13.856
[LAUGH] without being behind bars.

56
00:03:13.856 --> 00:03:14.999
[LAUGH]
>> Exactly.

57
00:03:14.999 --> 00:03:15.910
>> Probably a good idea.

58
00:03:15.910 --> 00:03:19.850
>> And as security professionals, that's
the phase that we would love to catch them

59
00:03:19.850 --> 00:03:22.060
in, before they actually
launch the attacks, right?

60
00:03:22.060 --> 00:03:26.590
While they're doing that
reconnaissance and/or controlling

61
00:03:26.590 --> 00:03:27.950
what information is available,

62
00:03:27.950 --> 00:03:33.420
that they're able to discover through
footprinting, scanning, enumeration.

63
00:03:33.420 --> 00:03:37.722
Because if they can't, if they can't get
the information they need to successfully

64
00:03:37.722 --> 00:03:41.679
launch an attack, odds are they're
gonna move onto the next target, right?

65
00:03:41.679 --> 00:03:45.462
And so, if we understand what they're
doing, techniques they're using,

66
00:03:45.462 --> 00:03:48.606
what information they're getting,
where it's coming from,

67
00:03:48.606 --> 00:03:52.940
how I can better secure that information,
I can protect my network, that's the idea.

68
00:03:52.940 --> 00:03:55.820
All right, so,
let's start off with footprinting, right?

69
00:03:55.820 --> 00:03:59.610
Footprinting is really gathering

70
00:03:59.610 --> 00:04:03.220
information about your target,
or about the target.

71
00:04:03.220 --> 00:04:08.190
So, we're talking about, you can
kinda draw the line here, we can have

72
00:04:08.190 --> 00:04:12.600
what's called open source footprinting and
closed source footprinting.

73
00:04:12.600 --> 00:04:14.850
Open source, information gathering,

74
00:04:14.850 --> 00:04:18.260
if you will,
is information that's publicly available,

75
00:04:18.260 --> 00:04:23.310
whereas closed source would be information
that's not publicly available, all right?

76
00:04:23.310 --> 00:04:26.494
And you'd be surprised, this is something
that every organization should go through.

77
00:04:26.494 --> 00:04:29.352
They should perform these kinds of
exercises where they do their own

78
00:04:29.352 --> 00:04:30.060
footprinting.

79
00:04:30.060 --> 00:04:34.620
They do their own reconnaissance on what
information is publicly available about

80
00:04:34.620 --> 00:04:41.130
organization because a lot of companies
don't realize what's out there, right?

81
00:04:41.130 --> 00:04:42.232
It is better now,

82
00:04:42.232 --> 00:04:46.937
we're much more security conscious than
we were ten years ago for example.

83
00:04:46.937 --> 00:04:52.030
So, it's gotten much better,
it's not quite the Wild West that it was.

84
00:04:52.030 --> 00:04:54.840
But still, I think a lot of organizations
would be surprised how much

85
00:04:54.840 --> 00:04:59.470
information is available to anybody that
chooses to go out and look for it, right?

86
00:04:59.470 --> 00:05:02.949
So, when we're talking about footprinting
and publicly available information,

87
00:05:02.949 --> 00:05:04.590
what are we talking about?

88
00:05:04.590 --> 00:05:06.850
Well, IP addresses, right,

89
00:05:06.850 --> 00:05:11.530
DNS server addresses, IP ranges,
these are things that I can go to.

90
00:05:11.530 --> 00:05:13.970
We could do a Whois Lookup
at a WHOIS database.

91
00:05:13.970 --> 00:05:19.890
This is a database maintained by the
registrars when we register domain names.

92
00:05:19.890 --> 00:05:23.284
I wanna start a company, xyz.com, right?

93
00:05:23.284 --> 00:05:24.770
We're gonna have a web presence.

94
00:05:24.770 --> 00:05:27.000
I'm gonna need some public IP addresses.

95
00:05:27.000 --> 00:05:30.410
I'm gonna go to a registrar and
I'm going to register that name,

96
00:05:30.410 --> 00:05:32.800
make sure nobody else
has that name in use.

97
00:05:32.800 --> 00:05:37.160
And I'm going to have to tell them
whose gonna be hosting my DNS.

98
00:05:37.160 --> 00:05:40.340
So, they can update the public DNS
servers with that information so,

99
00:05:40.340 --> 00:05:41.980
people can get to my web page.

100
00:05:43.210 --> 00:05:46.210
They're gonna assign me
a block of addresses and

101
00:05:46.210 --> 00:05:50.180
when you go through that registration you
have to provide information, who you are,

102
00:05:50.180 --> 00:05:54.470
the company's name, addresses,
point of contacts, things like this.

103
00:05:54.470 --> 00:05:58.706
Well, all that information is available
publicly if we're not careful, and

104
00:05:58.706 --> 00:06:00.259
some of it has to be, right?

105
00:06:00.259 --> 00:06:04.547
I mean, they have to be able to find my
DNS servers in order to get to my website

106
00:06:04.547 --> 00:06:07.250
to buy my product so
I can stay in business.

107
00:06:07.250 --> 00:06:09.375
So that's not something I can try to hide.

108
00:06:09.375 --> 00:06:10.111
>> Or would want to.

109
00:06:10.111 --> 00:06:10.948
>> Or would want to.

110
00:06:10.948 --> 00:06:14.461
>> Right and it is kinda hard to stay
in business, like you were saying,

111
00:06:14.461 --> 00:06:18.582
if no one can find my website which is,
I'm a web-driven profit business then,

112
00:06:18.582 --> 00:06:21.140
I'm kinda defeating my own purpose there.

113
00:06:21.140 --> 00:06:23.150
So, it's a good thing that
people can find my website.

114
00:06:23.150 --> 00:06:26.180
>> Absolutely, so,
how do we keep that information safe?

115
00:06:26.180 --> 00:06:30.560
Well, we can definitely limit how
much information they can get.

116
00:06:30.560 --> 00:06:34.190
Some of it, as I said, has to be available
so they can go to registrars and

117
00:06:34.190 --> 00:06:35.615
they can do searches.

118
00:06:35.615 --> 00:06:38.890
Cuz they have to be able to find out
if that domain name is in use, right,

119
00:06:38.890 --> 00:06:42.900
because I wanna register xyz.com,
somebody already has that.

120
00:06:42.900 --> 00:06:46.411
Well, like in those database, they've
made them a little more difficult and

121
00:06:46.411 --> 00:06:49.139

122
00:06:49.139 --> 00:06:52.364
It used to be, where, man,
you would go to one of these registrars,

123
00:06:52.364 --> 00:06:55.090
type in the name, it was already in use,
you click on it and

124
00:06:55.090 --> 00:06:57.597
it will show you all
the registration information for

125
00:06:57.597 --> 00:07:01.670
the current holder of that domain name,
or that portion of the namespace.

126
00:07:01.670 --> 00:07:06.276
And we're talking about,
who registered it, physical addresses,

127
00:07:06.276 --> 00:07:10.345
points of contact, phone numbers,
all of that's in there.

128
00:07:10.345 --> 00:07:12.422
Now, we can do private registrations.

129
00:07:12.422 --> 00:07:15.376
And not that this is new, but
it's becoming more common,

130
00:07:15.376 --> 00:07:18.250
people are realizing
the importance of doing this.

131
00:07:18.250 --> 00:07:20.710
Or we can make a lot of

132
00:07:20.710 --> 00:07:24.730
If they're searching the WHOIS database,
they need to know if that domain name is

00:07:24.730 --> 00:07:27.740

Hey, it's in use, sorry,
come up with another name, I got it first,

00:07:30.811 --> 00:07:32.055
blah, blah, blah, blah.

00:07:32.055 --> 00:07:33.983
You can usually get on a waiting list or

00:07:33.983 --> 00:07:37.400

138
00:07:37.400 --> 00:07:40.610
But they don't need all that other

139
00:07:40.610 --> 00:07:41.910

140
00:07:41.910 --> 00:07:46.196
So, understanding that, going back and

141
00:07:46.196 --> 00:07:51.172
making sure that if you've chosen the
private options, limiting the information,

142
00:07:51.172 --> 00:07:52.988

143

Point of contact for the company
doesn't need to be Daniel Lowrie,

144
00:07:56.595 --> 00:07:57.617
it can be IT admin.

00:07:58.825 --> 00:08:01.800

Daniel might be the one that gets that But

it doesn't have to say that information

00:08:06.350 --> 00:08:08.050
So protecting that information.

149
00:08:08.050 --> 00:08:11.520
Phone numbers, contact information

00:08:11.520 --> 00:08:14.840
It used to be, and

00:08:19.740 --> 00:08:24.566

You click on it, and it shows you

00:08:33.750 --> 00:08:36.190
And this is not information

00:08:39.820 --> 00:08:42.760
What harm could come from that?

Why do I care if they have a list

And who is the managers and

The CEOs name is listed or

the manager of the IT department

00:09:41.230 --> 00:09:42.620
So I can say hey, this is Joe in IT.

Look, Bob wants us, and they know,

That's the guy that's in

Right, so just being able to throw those

00:09:54.760 --> 00:09:57.630
So we wanna make sure we're thinking

00:09:59.710 --> 00:10:03.830

00:15:17.800 --> 00:15:22.330

You don't realize,

This is the kind of thing that

It was just a general mindset, I think

Because now it's out on the Internet and

As a company, an organization, you need

511
00:26:04.977 --> 00:26:09.117
just an example of how people don't think
about what they're putting in social

512
00:26:09.117 --> 00:26:11.796
media and it turns around and
it ends up biting you.

513
00:26:11.796 --> 00:26:13.140
So you've gotta be careful with that.

514
00:26:13.140 --> 00:26:16.170
Search engines,
another great source of information.

515
00:26:16.170 --> 00:26:18.040
Really, it's one of the bigger sources,

516
00:26:18.040 --> 00:26:21.710
probably, because that's all they do,
right?

517
00:26:21.710 --> 00:26:23.980
>> You'd be amazed what you could
do with a Google search bar.

518
00:26:23.980 --> 00:26:25.420
It's insane.

519
00:26:25.420 --> 00:26:30.260
>> And we can go so far beyond just
putting in words into that search bar.

520
00:26:30.260 --> 00:26:34.110
When you talk about Google hacking,
right, we're not hacking Google.

521
00:26:34.110 --> 00:26:35.510
That's not the goal here.

522
00:26:35.510 --> 00:26:41.040
We're using Google as a method
to facilitate my hacking, right?

523
00:26:41.040 --> 00:26:42.180
That's what Google hacking means.

524
00:26:42.180 --> 00:26:44.945
It doesn't mean we're
hacking Google servers.

525
00:26:44.945 --> 00:26:50.530
Using the fact that they've spidered and
indexed the majority of the web out there.

526
00:26:50.530 --> 00:26:55.110
And people don't realize, they think,
all right I've got this website, but

527
00:26:55.110 --> 00:26:56.270
if I don't put a link.

528
00:26:56.270 --> 00:27:00.710
I can put a webpage, an HTML document
on my web server and as long as I don't

529
00:27:00.710 --> 00:27:05.350
link to it directly, you'd have to know
the name to type it in to get to it.

530
00:27:05.350 --> 00:27:07.940
So it's gonna be secure,
nobody's gonna be able to find it

531
00:27:07.940 --> 00:27:11.320
cuz I'm the only one that knows
it's there, there's no links to it.

532
00:27:11.320 --> 00:27:12.736
Well sounds good in theory, right?

533
00:27:12.736 --> 00:27:15.795
>> [LAUGH]
>> Nobody can click a link and

534
00:27:15.795 --> 00:27:16.870
get to that page.

535
00:27:16.870 --> 00:27:18.060
But guess what?

536
00:27:18.060 --> 00:27:19.060
Those Google spiders have.

537
00:27:19.060 --> 00:27:21.575
>> That's right, the all-seeing
eye known as Google has found you.

538
00:27:21.575 --> 00:27:23.339
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah [LAUGH] that's indexed,

539
00:27:23.339 --> 00:27:24.400
it's out there.

540
00:27:24.400 --> 00:27:27.400
I mean, you can Google search for
password files, and

541
00:27:27.400 --> 00:27:29.855
you'd be shocked at how
many you would find.

542
00:27:29.855 --> 00:27:33.060
Because people think, I'll put it on
my web server, nobody can get to it.

543
00:27:33.060 --> 00:27:35.270
That way I can get to it
from anywhere I'm at.

544
00:27:35.270 --> 00:27:37.920
And they think it's safe,
and it's definitely not.

545
00:27:37.920 --> 00:27:40.790
Now I understand that there's a lot of
techniques that are getting developed and

546
00:27:40.790 --> 00:27:44.860
have been developed for hiding some
of that stuff from these spiders or

547
00:27:44.860 --> 00:27:47.350
these crawlers that these
search engines use.

548
00:27:47.350 --> 00:27:52.950
But did you start out that way or
has it already been indexed somewhere?

549
00:27:52.950 --> 00:27:56.150
It's one of those things,
it's really tough.

550
00:27:56.150 --> 00:27:57.460
So that's Google hacking.

551
00:27:57.460 --> 00:28:01.520
But just search engines in general are
gonna to be able to pull back information,

552
00:28:01.520 --> 00:28:02.980
and a good idea to use more than one.

553
00:28:02.980 --> 00:28:05.710
In fact there are some search
engines that do just that,

554
00:28:05.710 --> 00:28:09.270
like I think Dogpile was
one of my dad's oldies

555
00:28:09.270 --> 00:28:12.530
that he used to use cuz it combined
the results of several search engines.

556
00:28:12.530 --> 00:28:17.735
It wasn't really a search engine itself,
it was a way to combine multiple searches.

557
00:28:17.735 --> 00:28:21.450
There's different engines, have different
pages crawled, you get different results,

558
00:28:21.450 --> 00:28:24.380
so usually people will try more than one.

559
00:28:24.380 --> 00:28:27.960
The other one that people don't
think about is metadata, right?

560
00:28:27.960 --> 00:28:30.790
Metadata is data about data.

561
00:28:30.790 --> 00:28:32.960
Information about information.

562
00:28:32.960 --> 00:28:36.280
And office documents, for
example, have metadata.

563
00:28:36.280 --> 00:28:37.810
The author, when it was created,

564
00:28:37.810 --> 00:28:41.850
last modified,
what version of the application was used.

565
00:28:41.850 --> 00:28:46.030
Photos have geotagging
information in there.

566
00:28:46.030 --> 00:28:50.755
And people are posting these up
to websites and social media.

567
00:28:50.755 --> 00:28:54.478
And people with the right tools
can pull that metadata down.

568
00:28:55.670 --> 00:28:59.970
You've got files available,
documents available on your website.

569
00:28:59.970 --> 00:29:04.740
Maybe help documents or reference manuals
for product resale or what have you.

570
00:29:04.740 --> 00:29:06.140
And you think, well that's great.

571
00:29:06.140 --> 00:29:09.540
I put all these products out there so
people can find the owners manual for

572
00:29:09.540 --> 00:29:11.690
that lawnmower they bought ten years ago.

573
00:29:11.690 --> 00:29:16.240
That's great, but it's also a source of
information that we might not think about.

574
00:29:16.240 --> 00:29:17.420
Who was the author?

575
00:29:17.420 --> 00:29:22.170
Where it was created, possibly information
about the computer that was used, right?

576
00:29:22.170 --> 00:29:25.760
The name of the computer,
the operating system, the patch level.

577
00:29:25.760 --> 00:29:28.470
Depends on what metadata is
stored in those documents.

578
00:29:28.470 --> 00:29:32.520
So this can be scrubbed out of documents
before they're posted up there.

579
00:29:32.520 --> 00:29:37.827
But it is something that we do have to
think about as far as a way that the bad

580
00:29:37.827 --> 00:29:43.420
guys can gather information on our
networks and on our organization.

581
00:29:43.420 --> 00:29:47.990
So in the end, footprinting is
just gathering information.

582
00:29:47.990 --> 00:29:50.430
It's the first phase in an attack.

583
00:29:50.430 --> 00:29:54.150
It's really where a good
majority of the attack's spent.

584
00:29:54.150 --> 00:29:56.900
Reconnaissance, in general,
as we go through these next two steps,

585
00:29:56.900 --> 00:29:59.540
is where the majority of
the time is spent on an attack.

586
00:29:59.540 --> 00:30:02.000
Cuz the more information that
the bad guys can gather,

587
00:30:02.000 --> 00:30:05.780
the more successful their
attacks will most likely be.

588
00:30:06.790 --> 00:30:09.965
>> All right Mike, you definitely scared
the bejesus out of just about everybody.

589
00:30:09.965 --> 00:30:11.810
>> [LAUGH]
>> At this point in time because

590
00:30:11.810 --> 00:30:15.980
we're starting to realize man, I put this
on my Twitter, I put that on my Facebook.

591
00:30:15.980 --> 00:30:17.560
I might wanna go clean some stuff up,
right?

592
00:30:17.560 --> 00:30:20.125
So if you are doing that,
this is a good wake up call for

593
00:30:20.125 --> 00:30:23.317
you to understand that when you
put something out on social media,

594
00:30:23.317 --> 00:30:26.566
you're basically taking out a full
page ad in the local newspaper or

595
00:30:26.566 --> 00:30:30.113
the world newspaper, that is, and
saying, here's some information.

596
00:30:30.113 --> 00:30:31.642
So be very, very careful.

597
00:30:31.642 --> 00:30:34.430
We wanna make sure that anything
that has to do with your business.

598
00:30:34.430 --> 00:30:36.440
Hey, personal sites are personal sites.

599
00:30:36.440 --> 00:30:38.180
Put anything you feel like on there, but

600
00:30:38.180 --> 00:30:41.960
be aware that if you put anything about a
business, an organization, if you work for

601
00:30:41.960 --> 00:30:45.270
a government, things of that nature you
might be really giving up the ghost.

602
00:30:45.270 --> 00:30:46.864
So be very very careful on that.

603
00:30:46.864 --> 00:30:51.213
And there's a lot of cool ways in
which we can gather information and

604
00:30:51.213 --> 00:30:54.380
do that footprinting phase of our process.

605
00:30:54.380 --> 00:30:56.580
Mike, I know you got a ton
more information to go.

606
00:30:56.580 --> 00:30:59.950
We're just scratching
the surface on this section.

607
00:30:59.950 --> 00:31:01.760
So looks like we're gonna
have to do a part two.

608
00:31:01.760 --> 00:31:02.970
I hope you're down with that.

609
00:31:02.970 --> 00:31:03.970
>> I am down with that.

610
00:31:03.970 --> 00:31:04.980
>> All right, awesome.

611
00:31:04.980 --> 00:31:07.030
Hopefully you guys are down
with that as well.

612
00:31:07.030 --> 00:31:10.840
But it is time for us to sign off for
this episode, so we'll do that.

613
00:31:10.840 --> 00:31:13.810
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

614
00:31:13.810 --> 00:31:14.550
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

615
00:31:14.550 --> 00:31:16.673
>> And we'll see you next time.

616
00:31:16.673 --> 00:31:22.628
[MUSIC]

617
00:31:22.628 --> 00:31:24.670
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike continue their discussion on the Tools and Techniques used by the Threat Actors to gather information about target networks and/or devices. Here they explore Port Scanning, Vulnerability Scanning, and Network Scanning using tools like Nmap. Also covered is system/user Enumeration.
episodes.title: Tools and Techniques Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.250 --> 00:00:01.201
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.201 --> 00:00:02.383
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.383 --> 00:00:07.006
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:07.006 --> 00:00:08.206
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.206 --> 00:00:12.131
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:12.131 --> 00:00:13.354
>> All right, greetings everyone.

7
00:00:13.354 --> 00:00:16.330
Welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

8
00:00:16.330 --> 00:00:17.848
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie.

9
00:00:17.848 --> 00:00:21.594
And in today's episode we're continuing
on with our First Responder series from

10
00:00:21.594 --> 00:00:22.144
CyberSec.

11
00:00:22.144 --> 00:00:24.240
Or the Logical Operations, should I say.

12
00:00:24.240 --> 00:00:27.400
Logical Operations,
CyberSec, First Responder.

13
00:00:27.400 --> 00:00:29.630
That put it in the correct order for you.

14
00:00:29.630 --> 00:00:34.020
And of course, to put us all in correct
order with information we need to know for

15
00:00:34.020 --> 00:00:38.060
that very series, is our good friend,
Mr Mike Roger joining us today.

16
00:00:38.060 --> 00:00:38.740
Welcome back, Mike.

17
00:00:38.740 --> 00:00:39.380
How's it going?

18
00:00:39.380 --> 00:00:40.370
>> It's going great, Daniel.

19
00:00:40.370 --> 00:00:41.932
Thanks for having me back.

20
00:00:41.932 --> 00:00:45.990
All right, so we left off in that
previous episode talking about

21
00:00:45.990 --> 00:00:47.780
different attack tools and techniques.

22
00:00:47.780 --> 00:00:51.180
And we kind of went through that
first phase of our reconnaissance.

23
00:00:51.180 --> 00:00:55.330
The footprinting phase,
where we're really gathering information.

24
00:00:55.330 --> 00:01:00.110
It's all about finding information,
open source, as well as closed sourced.

25
00:01:00.110 --> 00:01:04.040
Stuff that has to be or
is publicly available, close sourced,

26
00:01:04.040 --> 00:01:07.640
stuff that is not meant
to be publicly available.

27
00:01:07.640 --> 00:01:09.530
Maybe we figure out how
to get that information.

28
00:01:09.530 --> 00:01:12.000
We social engineer it out of people.

29
00:01:12.000 --> 00:01:14.240
We do get that information.

30
00:01:14.240 --> 00:01:17.020
All right,
next I wanna talk about scanning.

31
00:01:17.020 --> 00:01:20.610
Once we've gone through
our footprinting phase,

32
00:01:20.610 --> 00:01:25.140
our next phase is going to
be scanning our targets.

33
00:01:25.140 --> 00:01:27.120
And we're trying to, again,

34
00:01:27.120 --> 00:01:30.370
gather information about the targets
that are being attacked.

35
00:01:30.370 --> 00:01:33.110
I should say, this is what the bad
actors are going to be doing.

36
00:01:33.110 --> 00:01:36.450
We're here to learn how to stop that,
not become them.

37
00:01:36.450 --> 00:01:41.030
But remember, we want to be able
to put your mind in their place.

38
00:01:41.030 --> 00:01:43.900
If you can think like they can,
if you can understand the tools and

39
00:01:43.900 --> 00:01:48.070
techniques that they're using, you're
better off in defending against them.

40
00:01:48.070 --> 00:01:53.460
All right, so scanning, it's really just a
more active way of gathering information.

41
00:01:53.460 --> 00:01:55.270
Footprinting is a very passive thing.

42
00:01:55.270 --> 00:01:57.740
I'm really not,
I'm not breaking any systems,

43
00:01:57.740 --> 00:01:59.730
I'm typically not breaking any laws.

44
00:01:59.730 --> 00:02:01.960
We're usually not crossing any lines,

45
00:02:01.960 --> 00:02:04.480
we're just gathering publicly
available information.

46
00:02:04.480 --> 00:02:07.560
Again sometimes not publicly but
dumpster diving.

47
00:02:07.560 --> 00:02:13.280
I guess dumpster diving, technically,
could be illegal in some areas.

48
00:02:13.280 --> 00:02:14.850
>> Depends on where the dumpster is.

49
00:02:14.850 --> 00:02:16.360
I think in the United States,

50
00:02:16.360 --> 00:02:20.580
anyway, garbage that hits a curb
is considered public domain.

51
00:02:20.580 --> 00:02:21.810
And you can have access to it.

52
00:02:21.810 --> 00:02:26.420
So if there's a dumpster outside of the
building that's not within their confines,

53
00:02:26.420 --> 00:02:27.730
then it's free rein.

54
00:02:27.730 --> 00:02:31.320
Which is typically where they are now
putting dumpsters behind gates,

55
00:02:31.320 --> 00:02:33.600
locked doors within their property.

56
00:02:33.600 --> 00:02:35.370
So that you have to actually
trespass to get to it.

57
00:02:35.370 --> 00:02:37.770
>> Yeah, exactly, so
you end up breaking the law.

58
00:02:37.770 --> 00:02:39.470
And hopefully that slows people down.

59
00:02:39.470 --> 00:02:43.790
But when we get to scanning, a little bit
more effective, or I'm sorry, more active.

60
00:02:43.790 --> 00:02:45.980
We're really starting to
touch the systems now.

61
00:02:45.980 --> 00:02:48.650
Now with the footprinting, we typically
don't touch the systems at all.

62
00:02:48.650 --> 00:02:54.710
We got the IP range from Whois database
lookups, not from touching their systems.

63
00:02:54.710 --> 00:02:58.430
We've got employee contact
information from social media,

64
00:02:58.430 --> 00:03:00.180
not from touching their systems.

65
00:03:00.180 --> 00:03:03.240
With scanning, we do start
touching the systems themselves.

66
00:03:03.240 --> 00:03:08.420
We can do port scanning, where we're
scanning target machines looking for

67
00:03:08.420 --> 00:03:09.420
ports.

68
00:03:09.420 --> 00:03:13.170
Remember a port,
when we're talking about a socket, right,

69
00:03:13.170 --> 00:03:17.095
that two computers make when they're
communicating with each other.

70
00:03:17.095 --> 00:03:20.170
There's three bits of information
that going to creating that socket.

71
00:03:20.170 --> 00:03:24.129
You've got your protocol that's
being used, your IP address, and

72
00:03:24.129 --> 00:03:25.709
your port number, right?

73
00:03:25.709 --> 00:03:30.658
So TCP 12.1.2.3:80 for example.

74
00:03:30.658 --> 00:03:33.621
That means I'm gonna be
using TCP is my protocol,

75
00:03:33.621 --> 00:03:37.510
the IP address of that web server,
and I wanna hit it on port 80.

76
00:03:37.510 --> 00:03:41.696
Cuz that's the port that it's configured
to listen on to serve up web pages,

77
00:03:41.696 --> 00:03:44.290
if they're using HTTP.

78
00:03:44.290 --> 00:03:48.925
So a computer system has, basically,

79
00:03:48.925 --> 00:03:52.159
65,536 ports on it.

80
00:03:52.159 --> 00:03:56.846
And you can really think of each one of
those ports as being a doorway into that

81
00:03:56.846 --> 00:03:58.940
device or into that machine.

82
00:03:58.940 --> 00:04:02.960
Because it can establish
a socket to the same IP address.

83
00:04:02.960 --> 00:04:06.770
But each one of those ports individually
is how our computers multi task,

84
00:04:06.770 --> 00:04:10.470
keep web traffic separate,
what application is receiving this data.

85
00:04:10.470 --> 00:04:14.060
That port number lets it know what service
it was going to, things like that.

86
00:04:15.570 --> 00:04:20.630
But by scanning a port or scanning ports,
I should say, when a bad guy or

87
00:04:20.630 --> 00:04:25.770
a threat actor starts scanning your
systems, they're looking for open ports.

88
00:04:25.770 --> 00:04:28.640
Because a port can be either open or
closed.

89
00:04:28.640 --> 00:04:31.280
If it's closed, that means the, let's say,

90
00:04:31.280 --> 00:04:35.280
that server is not gonna respond to
requests that come across that port.

91
00:04:35.280 --> 00:04:36.860
It's just gonna ignore them.

92
00:04:36.860 --> 00:04:39.970
If the port is open,
that means it's listening on that port and

93
00:04:39.970 --> 00:04:42.600
is allowed to establish
connections on that port.

94
00:04:42.600 --> 00:04:46.310
And so the threat actors are scanning
your systems, looking for

95
00:04:46.310 --> 00:04:47.770
those ports that are open.

96
00:04:47.770 --> 00:04:51.040
But the ports that the servers
are listening in, and I say server,

97
00:04:51.040 --> 00:04:53.770
could be a client machine or
any type of device.

98
00:04:55.510 --> 00:04:59.050
That those ports are open, and I'm gonna
be able to potentially make a connection

99
00:04:59.050 --> 00:05:02.200
there, and
try to work my way into the system.

100
00:05:02.200 --> 00:05:03.230
So that's port scanning.

101
00:05:03.230 --> 00:05:07.170
Scanning those ports, and I'll show
you some tools we can use for that.

102
00:05:08.330 --> 00:05:09.775
Things like Nmap, for example.

103
00:05:09.775 --> 00:05:12.300
Nmap is probably the most common one.

104
00:05:12.300 --> 00:05:14.740
It's available for
both Windows as well as Linux.

105
00:05:14.740 --> 00:05:17.770
It actually is a Linux tool that's
been ported over to Windows.

106
00:05:19.455 --> 00:05:20.958
But it's a very easy one to use.

107
00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:24.150
It's a very powerful one,
it has a lot of capabilities.

108
00:05:24.150 --> 00:05:25.790
But it'll do basic port scanning.

109
00:05:25.790 --> 00:05:29.970
And there's dozens of tools
that will do port scanning.

110
00:05:29.970 --> 00:05:33.930
So we can scan certain targets
to see what ports are open.

111
00:05:33.930 --> 00:05:35.370
And what information does that give me,

112
00:05:35.370 --> 00:05:37.990
other than that's a possible
attack vector, right?

113
00:05:37.990 --> 00:05:40.320
If that port is open,
that's an attack vector.

114
00:05:40.320 --> 00:05:43.920
I can now try to make
a connection on that port.

115
00:05:43.920 --> 00:05:47.679
This is why we close ports if they're not
necessary, or they're not being used.

116
00:05:47.679 --> 00:05:51.430
This is why we run firewalls at both
the network level and the host level.

117
00:05:52.730 --> 00:05:55.730
Other information that I can
get from just port scanning is,

118
00:05:55.730 --> 00:05:57.270
I see what ports are open.

119
00:05:57.270 --> 00:06:00.440
Well, Daniel, if I tell you that
a server is running port 80,

120
00:06:00.440 --> 00:06:02.190
what does that tell you about that server?

121
00:06:02.190 --> 00:06:05.050
>> It immediately let's me know that
it's most likely a web server that we're

122
00:06:05.050 --> 00:06:05.800
dealing with.

123
00:06:05.800 --> 00:06:06.310
>> Yeah, exactly.

124
00:06:06.310 --> 00:06:08.390
It's probably running
some type of web service.

125
00:06:08.390 --> 00:06:11.200
Apache, IIS, something like that.

126
00:06:11.200 --> 00:06:13.650
So not only am I seeing
what ports are open,

127
00:06:13.650 --> 00:06:18.710
I'm starting to see what services
are running on those servers, right?

128
00:06:18.710 --> 00:06:23.880
And through those open ports,
we can do more detailed scanning.

129
00:06:23.880 --> 00:06:25.910
We can start to do banner grabbing.

130
00:06:25.910 --> 00:06:28.020
We can make Telnet connections.

131
00:06:28.020 --> 00:06:31.840
And we can get more information
about the service that's

132
00:06:31.840 --> 00:06:33.580
opening that port in the first place.

133
00:06:33.580 --> 00:06:36.840
And then some of those services
themselves can be enumerated.

134
00:06:36.840 --> 00:06:39.110
Which we're gonna talk about
here in just a minute.

135
00:06:40.310 --> 00:06:42.360
So port scanning, very common method for

136
00:06:42.360 --> 00:06:45.370
the bad guys to start their
mapping of your network.

137
00:06:46.570 --> 00:06:49.710
Just networking scanning in general
really is typically the first step,

138
00:06:49.710 --> 00:06:52.100
because I don't know what hosts
you have on that network.

139
00:06:52.100 --> 00:06:57.614
Maybe I've determined that you
leased a Class C address from IANA.

140
00:06:57.614 --> 00:07:01.050
So I know what your address
range most likely is.

141
00:07:01.050 --> 00:07:05.200
But do you have all 254
hosts on that network?

142
00:07:05.200 --> 00:07:09.690
Or which IP addresses are in use,
which ones are dead, are not being used.

143
00:07:09.690 --> 00:07:12.630
So I can do a network scan looking for
live hosts,

144
00:07:12.630 --> 00:07:16.150
trying to see what IP
addresses are responding.

145
00:07:16.150 --> 00:07:19.403
We can also discover other devices that
might be out there on that network.

146
00:07:19.403 --> 00:07:25.960
Looking for routers, firewalls,
and computers, right.

147
00:07:25.960 --> 00:07:28.430
Vulnerability scanning is another one.

148
00:07:28.430 --> 00:07:30.300
This is something that,
as IT professionals,

149
00:07:30.300 --> 00:07:32.780
we should be doing on our own systems.

150
00:07:32.780 --> 00:07:36.320
The bad guys are definitely doing it
on your systems, if they can get in.

151
00:07:36.320 --> 00:07:40.650
Because a vulnerability scanner,
just think about that for a second.

152
00:07:40.650 --> 00:07:42.930
Vulnerability scanner.

153
00:07:42.930 --> 00:07:46.040
Something that's scanning for
vulnerabilities.

154
00:07:46.040 --> 00:07:47.240
What's a vulnerability?

155
00:07:47.240 --> 00:07:48.930
A weakness in a system.

156
00:07:48.930 --> 00:07:50.534
What do I do with a vulnerability?

157
00:07:50.534 --> 00:07:53.558
I find an exploit that can
leverage that vulnerability,

158
00:07:53.558 --> 00:07:55.387
and give me access to your system.

159
00:07:55.387 --> 00:08:00.651
So by doing a vulnerability scan,
as a bad guy, That's telling me how,

160
00:08:00.651 --> 00:08:04.780
it's helping me find ways
to get into your system.

161
00:08:04.780 --> 00:08:08.940
I can see that you're vulnerable
to directory traversal.

162
00:08:08.940 --> 00:08:13.430
So now I know what exploit I wanna
get to attack that vulnerability.

163
00:08:13.430 --> 00:08:15.980
And again, there are scanners that just

164
00:08:15.980 --> 00:08:20.406
do that like Microsoft Baseline
Security Analyzer for one example.

165
00:08:20.406 --> 00:08:22.901
There's several.

166
00:08:22.901 --> 00:08:26.210
They make lots of different vulnerability
scanners and these are, again,

167
00:08:26.210 --> 00:08:30.040
things that I should run as a network
admin to see what I'm vulnerable against

168
00:08:30.040 --> 00:08:34.020
so that I can do risk assessments, so
that I can try to patch or prevent or

169
00:08:34.020 --> 00:08:36.140
mitigate or reduce some of that risk.

170
00:08:36.140 --> 00:08:39.270
But it's also what the bad guys are doing
when they're trying to attack your

171
00:08:39.270 --> 00:08:40.690
systems.

172
00:08:40.690 --> 00:08:42.230
We also have web app scanning.

173
00:08:42.230 --> 00:08:43.310
Web applications,

174
00:08:43.310 --> 00:08:48.080
extremely popular, everything is
a web app nowadays it seems like.

175
00:08:49.500 --> 00:08:50.540
Our time clock here.

176
00:08:50.540 --> 00:08:52.570
Hey there's an app for that.

177
00:08:52.570 --> 00:08:54.630
So vulnerabilities in those apps.

178
00:08:54.630 --> 00:08:57.030
Cuz a lot of these apps that
you're running, you didn't write.

179
00:08:57.030 --> 00:08:59.630
You didn't create,
you bought from somebody.

180
00:08:59.630 --> 00:09:02.580
So you're trusting that
their code is secure and

181
00:09:02.580 --> 00:09:08.300
that there's no vulnerabilities in that
web apps a lot of times are written by,

182
00:09:08.300 --> 00:09:12.140
you know, I go to my dev team,
I say hey I need this web app.

183
00:09:12.140 --> 00:09:13.650
We need this to do this.

184
00:09:13.650 --> 00:09:19.320
And we put pressures on the developers
to get it done yesterday, right?

185
00:09:19.320 --> 00:09:20.260
Nevermind security.

186
00:09:20.260 --> 00:09:20.950
Just get it done.

187
00:09:20.950 --> 00:09:21.809
I've got to get it out there.

188
00:09:22.960 --> 00:09:23.730
Now we've been hacked.

189
00:09:23.730 --> 00:09:25.220
Why didn't put security in this?

190
00:09:25.220 --> 00:09:27.040
Why didn't you think about security?

191
00:09:27.040 --> 00:09:28.810
Who in the heck would

192
00:09:28.810 --> 00:09:30.830
Well, you said to get it out yesterday.

193
00:09:30.830 --> 00:09:32.535
I did what I had to do.

194
00:09:32.535 --> 00:09:35.128
>> I can get it done quick or I can get
it done right but you can't have both.

195
00:09:35.128 --> 00:09:36.486
[LAUGH]
>> Exactly.

196
00:09:36.486 --> 00:09:40.345
So web app scanners,
they're scanning for web applications,

197
00:09:40.345 --> 00:09:45.140
applications that are maybe not directly
exposed, but support your web page.

198
00:09:45.140 --> 00:09:47.710
Authentication modules and

199
00:09:47.710 --> 00:09:52.020
things like that that they then
might be running scripting engines.

200
00:09:52.020 --> 00:09:55.670
Look, I can see in their source code,
it's calling PHP scripts.

201
00:09:55.670 --> 00:09:58.820
It tells me a lot about your environment,
what you're using.

202
00:09:58.820 --> 00:10:01.290
So scanning for those web applications.

203
00:10:01.290 --> 00:10:03.610
So a lot of different scanning techniques.

00:10:03.610 --> 00:10:06.160
We'll go over a couple of

205
00:10:07.250 --> 00:10:12.120
And then our third one that's kinda
part of this is going to be enumeration.

206
00:10:12.120 --> 00:10:16.380
Enumeration is a big fancy word for

207
00:10:16.380 --> 00:10:21.700
Or creating a list and we can list

00:10:21.700 --> 00:10:23.140
User enumeration, right?

00:10:23.140 --> 00:10:27.010
Trying to enumerate what user

00:10:27.010 --> 00:10:29.760
There's two things I need to

00:10:29.760 --> 00:10:32.290
A username and a password, right?

00:10:32.290 --> 00:10:35.970
If I can list out all the usernames,

00:10:35.970 --> 00:10:38.070
Granted, they're typically
not that hard to figure out,

214
00:10:38.070 --> 00:10:41.960
but if the information's available,
that's one less thing.

215
00:10:41.960 --> 00:10:44.395
>> I'll take 50% of the job being done for
me any day of the week.

216
00:10:44.395 --> 00:10:46.010
[LAUGH]
>> Absolutely,

217
00:10:46.010 --> 00:10:48.180
one less thing that I've
got to struggle with.

218
00:10:48.180 --> 00:10:49.830
So user enumeration,

219
00:10:49.830 --> 00:10:53.230
try to enumerate what applications
are being run on your systems.

220
00:10:53.230 --> 00:10:58.370
If I can go into a network and I can see
that people are running Open Office or

00:10:58.370 --> 00:11:00.710
running Photoshop or

00:11:05.850 --> 00:11:08.360
I see these applications

00:11:08.360 --> 00:11:09.930
I know that they've got vulnerabilities.

00:11:09.930 --> 00:11:12.860
And if those applications aren't

00:11:12.860 --> 00:11:15.310

00:11:15.310 --> 00:11:18.990
A lot of times we're bad

00:11:18.990 --> 00:11:21.060

00:11:21.060 --> 00:11:24.670
Heck, a lot of places we don't control

00:11:24.670 --> 00:11:26.170

00:11:26.170 --> 00:11:31.940
I remember working with one organization,

00:11:37.240 --> 00:11:42.650

00:11:46.300 --> 00:11:47.540
Didn't bother asking.

00:11:47.540 --> 00:11:49.040

00:11:49.040 --> 00:11:52.750

00:12:02.540 --> 00:12:06.370

00:12:06.370 --> 00:12:10.440
And he opened up the entire

00:12:10.440 --> 00:12:11.890
Now nothing ever came of it and

245
00:12:11.890 --> 00:12:15.850
We caught it and we got rid of it, but
that's the kind of thing that can happen.

246
00:12:15.850 --> 00:12:19.210
And that's why they're doing

00:12:19.210 --> 00:12:22.080
Because they can find that
that one person downloaded and

00:12:26.590 --> 00:12:30.250
So doing an application enumeration,

There are tons of tools, like in

You find all these names@microsoft.com or

What good is that going to do me?

So being able to discover

part three for all of us, right?

584
00:30:32.990 --> 00:30:34.740
This is really a good stopping spot.

585
00:30:34.740 --> 00:30:37.536
We understand what's gonna happen on it,
what with the scan.

586
00:30:37.536 --> 00:30:41.110
Now Mike can just jump right
into demonstrating those.

587
00:30:41.110 --> 00:30:43.510
So I look forward to that and
hopefully you do as well.

588
00:30:43.510 --> 00:30:46.440
And you'll join us back for
that part three but Mike's right,

589
00:30:46.440 --> 00:30:48.350
we're totally out of time for
this episode.

590
00:30:48.350 --> 00:30:50.580
So it looks like it's time for
us to sign off.

591
00:30:50.580 --> 00:30:53.210
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

592
00:30:53.210 --> 00:30:54.000
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

593
00:30:54.000 --> 00:30:55.143
>> And we'll see you next time.

594
00:30:56.145 --> 00:31:02.108
[MUSIC]

595
00:31:02.108 --> 00:31:05.319
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike continue their discussion on the Tools and Techniques used by the Threat Actors to gather information about target networks and/or devices. Here they pick up by demonstrating the use of the Nmap network scanning utility. They will show you how to look for live hosts, scan those hosts for running services, as well as version and Operating
episodes.title: Tools and Techniques Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:03.617
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.617 --> 00:00:08.091
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.091 --> 00:00:08.632
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.632 --> 00:00:11.894
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

5
00:00:11.894 --> 00:00:13.575
>> All right, greetings everyone.

6
00:00:13.575 --> 00:00:16.544
And welcome to another
great episode of ITPro.TV.

7
00:00:16.544 --> 00:00:21.205
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie, and in
today's episode we are back with more of

8
00:00:21.205 --> 00:00:24.756
our logical operations
CyberSec First Responder series and

9
00:00:24.756 --> 00:00:27.137
one of our lovely parts going into this.

10
00:00:27.137 --> 00:00:29.846
We are into a part three,
but very cool stuff today.

11
00:00:29.846 --> 00:00:32.216
We are talking about scanning and
enumeration,

12
00:00:32.216 --> 00:00:34.010
all sorts of very cool things.

13
00:00:34.010 --> 00:00:35.320
Mike is joining us today.

14
00:00:35.320 --> 00:00:36.824
Mike, we're so glad to have you back man.

15
00:00:36.824 --> 00:00:37.644
How's it going today?

16
00:00:37.644 --> 00:00:40.585
>> It's going great, and I'm excited
cuz now we're going to actually demo

17
00:00:40.585 --> 00:00:43.585
some of the stuff that we have been
talking about, so some cool stuff here.

18
00:00:43.585 --> 00:00:48.692
We are gonna be doing a little bit of
work with Nmap as well as Wireshark.

19
00:00:48.692 --> 00:00:52.212
So on our previous episode,
we were talking about scanning,

20
00:00:52.212 --> 00:00:55.271
we were talking about foot printing and
numeration.

21
00:00:55.271 --> 00:00:59.114
We said scanning is where we start
touching the systems where were gonna

22
00:00:59.114 --> 00:01:02.397
start gathering information
about what systems they have?

23
00:01:02.397 --> 00:01:04.174
Where the live hosts are?

24
00:01:04.174 --> 00:01:07.686
Cuz hopefully in the foot printing phase,
we've got a IP address ranges,

25
00:01:07.686 --> 00:01:09.538
we've got an idea of where things are.

26
00:01:09.538 --> 00:01:13.366
Now, we just need to find out what's
actually there, cuz we know you

27
00:01:13.366 --> 00:01:17.466
get a class c or a class b address from
IANA, you're not using all of them.

28
00:01:17.466 --> 00:01:19.630
So I need to figure out
where those live hosts are.

29
00:01:19.630 --> 00:01:22.963
Nmap is one of those
premiere tools doing that.

30
00:01:22.963 --> 00:01:26.788
It's quick, light weight,
easy to get installed,

31
00:01:26.788 --> 00:01:30.192
if it's not already and
we can use that to scan.

32
00:01:30.192 --> 00:01:32.891
So let's do that,
let's take a look at my screen here.

33
00:01:32.891 --> 00:01:38.710
Again, I've got my Kali Linux box fired
up, and I've got my terminal open.

34
00:01:38.710 --> 00:01:42.394
And if we just type in nmap,
we get all of our instructions.

35
00:01:42.394 --> 00:01:46.720
Well a brief review of
the possible switches.

36
00:01:46.720 --> 00:01:48.241
>> Man, Nmap for more information.

37
00:01:48.241 --> 00:01:48.993
>> There you go.

38
00:01:48.993 --> 00:01:50.192
>> [LAUGH]
>> Just right on time.

39
00:01:50.192 --> 00:01:54.786
We could do man, short for manual, nmap,

40
00:01:54.786 --> 00:01:59.519
and we'll get a large file of information.

41
00:01:59.519 --> 00:02:05.069
Yes, some very detailed Information
on uses, options, switches,

42
00:02:05.069 --> 00:02:10.145
all of that good stuff, and
we press Q to get out of that man page,

43
00:02:10.145 --> 00:02:13.170
or you can always go out to nmap.org.

44
00:02:13.170 --> 00:02:15.822
They got great documentation out there.

45
00:02:15.822 --> 00:02:19.244
There's lots of websites you can find
with little cheat sheets and people,

46
00:02:19.244 --> 00:02:20.859
you can combine switches, right?

47
00:02:20.859 --> 00:02:22.730
All these different commands.

48
00:02:22.730 --> 00:02:27.170
We can start combining them together
like OS detection, versioning,

49
00:02:27.170 --> 00:02:30.135
what ports we're hitting,
things like that.

50
00:02:30.135 --> 00:02:30.875
>> Timing options.

51
00:02:30.875 --> 00:02:35.112
>> Timing options, and so you could
string a bunch of these options together.

52
00:02:35.112 --> 00:02:37.010
And there's a lot of sites out there,

53
00:02:37.010 --> 00:02:39.730
I see people that have
done that quite some time.

54
00:02:39.730 --> 00:02:43.362
This is the set of scan options that I
use, that gives me the best results.

55
00:02:43.362 --> 00:02:46.780
So you'll develop your own, but
you can try other people's as well.

56
00:02:46.780 --> 00:02:49.076
So let's take a look,
I keep talking and keep talking.

57
00:02:49.076 --> 00:02:51.491
>> [LAUGH]
>> Let's actually do something here.

58
00:02:51.491 --> 00:02:54.982
So if I wanna do like just
a simple ping scan, all right?

59
00:02:54.982 --> 00:03:02.208
That's Nmap, and we know it's a -s and
then n, little s, little n.

60
00:03:02.208 --> 00:03:06.560
So little s, scan type, little n for
basically no port scans.

61
00:03:06.560 --> 00:03:10.338
So we're just gonna limit this to ping,
ignore port scans and

62
00:03:10.338 --> 00:03:12.940
I'm gonna type in my address range.

63
00:03:12.940 --> 00:03:15.101
We'll do, that is not right.

64
00:03:15.101 --> 00:03:17.196
Let's try that again with a num
lock key on, 10.0.100.0/24.

65
00:03:17.196 --> 00:03:21.667
All right, I'm gonna

66
00:03:21.667 --> 00:03:26.612
limit this a little bit.

67
00:03:26.612 --> 00:03:29.293
I don't need to scan the entire
ITPro.TV network, and

68
00:03:29.293 --> 00:03:31.412
we don't want the results
to take too long.

69
00:03:31.412 --> 00:03:34.656
And so there we go, here's my results.

70
00:03:34.656 --> 00:03:37.461
And I can see it looks like
I got three live hosts here.

71
00:03:37.461 --> 00:03:41.239
I've got 10.0.100.101,

72
00:03:41.239 --> 00:03:46.134
100.200, and then 100.99, right?

73
00:03:46.134 --> 00:03:52.018
And it did that,
265 IP addresses in 3.51 seconds, right?

74
00:03:52.018 --> 00:03:55.110
And I determined that I
only have three live hosts.

75
00:03:55.110 --> 00:03:56.241
And that's what I'm saying,

76
00:03:56.241 --> 00:03:58.341
the first think you wanna do
is discover your live hosts.

77
00:03:58.341 --> 00:04:00.950
Because if I'm gonna turn around and
start doing deeper scans.

78
00:04:00.950 --> 00:04:05.454
I don't wanna hit the other 253
addresses that there's no hosts on.

79
00:04:05.454 --> 00:04:06.970
That's just a waste of time.

80
00:04:06.970 --> 00:04:11.050
It's gonna generate noise and
increase the possibility or the likelihood

81
00:04:11.050 --> 00:04:15.530
that I'm going to be detected or I'm gonna
set off intrusion detection systems.

82
00:04:16.700 --> 00:04:22.160
So that gives us our live host, so
little s, little, n is a good one to know.

83
00:04:22.160 --> 00:04:26.898
Another one that they call out
specifically is a TCP connect scan.

84
00:04:26.898 --> 00:04:29.940
And we'll just kind of cheat here and
change my options.

85
00:04:31.310 --> 00:04:33.797
That's gonna be little s, capital T.

86
00:04:33.797 --> 00:04:39.923
Little s, capital T for
a TCP connect scan, all right.

87
00:04:39.923 --> 00:04:45.568
And actually, I should have used my,
that might take just a little while.

88
00:04:45.568 --> 00:04:48.516
Let's not do that,
I'm gonna do Ctrl+C to end that.

89
00:04:48.516 --> 00:04:52.943
And let's just do that against one machine
rather than the entire network range.

90
00:04:52.943 --> 00:04:59.222
Now that I know my live hosts,
we'll try 101 first, all right?

91
00:04:59.222 --> 00:05:02.492
Now TCP and there's my results, and
we'll talk about these in a second.

92
00:05:02.492 --> 00:05:04.801
Let me explain to you what's
going on here, right.

93
00:05:04.801 --> 00:05:07.470
We're gonna talk about a TCP connection,

94
00:05:07.470 --> 00:05:11.406
when two nodes connect using
transmission control protocol.

95
00:05:11.406 --> 00:05:16.222
It is a connection oriented service, that
means there is a connection established

96
00:05:16.222 --> 00:05:19.475
and there is guaranteed
delivery meaning I can verify.

97
00:05:19.475 --> 00:05:23.510
The other ends gonna verify for
me that they received the packet and

98
00:05:23.510 --> 00:05:25.540
the packet was intact.

99
00:05:25.540 --> 00:05:30.250
Kind of like doing certified mail,
where the other end has to sign for

100
00:05:30.250 --> 00:05:33.500
it saying that they got it, so
they can't say that they didn't get it.

101
00:05:34.610 --> 00:05:36.810
With TCP, to establish that connection,

102
00:05:36.810 --> 00:05:39.110
we go through what's called
a three way handshake.

103
00:05:39.110 --> 00:05:43.764
There's the TCP three way handshake,
and the originator of the conversation,

104
00:05:43.764 --> 00:05:46.924
let's say, I'm a node and
Daniel's a node, right?

105
00:05:46.924 --> 00:05:48.968
If I want to connect to Daniel,

106
00:05:48.968 --> 00:05:53.309
what I'm gonna do is send an initial
packet known as a SIN packet.

107
00:05:53.309 --> 00:05:57.139
That means I'm gonna send a TCP IPP
packet over to Daniel's address.

108
00:05:57.139 --> 00:06:01.277
And in that packet there are flags
that we can raise, basically,

109
00:06:01.277 --> 00:06:03.243
bits that we can turn on or off.

110
00:06:03.243 --> 00:06:08.400
And I'm gonna turn on the syn flag,
syn is short for synchronization.

111
00:06:08.400 --> 00:06:11.180
So what I'm doing is I'm saying,
hey, Daniel, I wanna talk to you.

112
00:06:11.180 --> 00:06:13.570
Let's synchronize so
that we're on the same page.

113
00:06:13.570 --> 00:06:16.667
Talking about timing is what
we're really synchronizing.

114
00:06:16.667 --> 00:06:21.500
And sequence numbers is what
we're gonna start synchronizing.

115
00:06:21.500 --> 00:06:22.430
So Daniel,

116
00:06:22.430 --> 00:06:26.600
if he's the node that I'm trying to talk
to, is gonna receive that sent request.

117
00:06:26.600 --> 00:06:30.630
He'll say, look Mike wants to talk to me,
he's requesting synchronization.

118
00:06:30.630 --> 00:06:34.980
So Daniel is gonna send a packet back,
that is gonna have two flags raised.

119
00:06:34.980 --> 00:06:39.693
It's gonna have the acknowledgement flag
raised to acknowledge my synchronization

120
00:06:39.693 --> 00:06:43.237
request, and it's gonna
synchronization request of his own.

121
00:06:43.237 --> 00:06:46.821
We call it the SYN-ACK packet, because
he's sending back a packet that has

122
00:06:46.821 --> 00:06:50.000
the SYN flag raised, and
the acknowledgement flag raised.

123
00:06:50.000 --> 00:06:52.420
So he's acknowledging
the initial SYN request, and

124
00:06:52.420 --> 00:06:55.680
he's requesting
a synchronization of his own.

125
00:06:55.680 --> 00:06:59.850
And when I get that SYN-ACK packet,
I say, look Daniel, does want to talk.

126
00:06:59.850 --> 00:07:04.050
He acknowledged my synchronization request
and he sent me a synchronization request.

127
00:07:04.050 --> 00:07:07.683
And now I'm gonna send back a final
packet, an acknowledgement.

128
00:07:07.683 --> 00:07:11.450
That's going to acknowledge
his synchronization request.

129
00:07:11.450 --> 00:07:15.860
Once that third packet goes back,
now we have established a connection and

130
00:07:15.860 --> 00:07:18.430
we can start sending data back and forth.

131
00:07:18.430 --> 00:07:19.855
That's the TCP three way handshake.

132
00:07:19.855 --> 00:07:24.002
SYN, SYN-ACK, ACK, right?

133
00:07:24.002 --> 00:07:25.857
SYN, SYN-ACK, and ACK.

134
00:07:25.857 --> 00:07:29.021
And when we use this scan,
the reason I go off on that.

135
00:07:29.021 --> 00:07:34.056
When we do a -s big T, capital T,
that's what we're doing, is a TCP connect.

136
00:07:34.056 --> 00:07:37.452
And what it's trying to do,
because I didn't limit port numbers.

137
00:07:37.452 --> 00:07:39.425
It's actually going through each port and

138
00:07:39.425 --> 00:07:42.013
it's trying to establish
a connection on those ports.

139
00:07:42.013 --> 00:07:45.352
And if it gets back a SYN-ACK and
then I do an ACK,

140
00:07:45.352 --> 00:07:50.254
I've got that handshake set up then
that port shows up as open, right?

141
00:07:50.254 --> 00:07:53.984
So that's my TCP connect scan.

142
00:07:53.984 --> 00:07:56.648
It's a good scan to do
when you're looking for

143
00:07:56.648 --> 00:07:59.392
open ports although it is a noisy scan,
right?

144
00:07:59.392 --> 00:08:02.264
It's got a lot of packets going back and
forth, it's establishing that,

145
00:08:02.264 --> 00:08:03.047
there's a record.

146
00:08:03.047 --> 00:08:07.176
Most likely on the other end of who sent
me the initial SYN packet, all right?

147
00:08:07.176 --> 00:08:09.770
So it's not a very stealthy scan.

148
00:08:09.770 --> 00:08:15.250
This is not something you're gonna do
when you're trying to avoid detection.

149
00:08:15.250 --> 00:08:18.010
But let's take a look at my results here.

150
00:08:18.010 --> 00:08:20.663
>> It looks like you found yourself
a Windows machine there, Mike.

151
00:08:20.663 --> 00:08:22.360
>> Yeah, it really does, doesn't it?

152
00:08:22.360 --> 00:08:26.230
And evidently,
my zoom is not working too well on.

153
00:08:26.230 --> 00:08:30.260
But anyway, we can see,
it says that the host is up, right?

154
00:08:30.260 --> 00:08:33.410
So it'll send an initial ping,
and then my ports,

155
00:08:33.410 --> 00:08:37.310
I can see these are the ports
that this system has open, right?

156
00:08:37.310 --> 00:08:42.070
I can see port 135, MSRPC,
Remote procedure call.

157
00:08:42.070 --> 00:08:44.120
I got to my NetBios port 139.

158
00:08:44.120 --> 00:08:48.510
And I got 445, Microsoft DS.

159
00:08:48.510 --> 00:08:50.994
And I've got 3389.

160
00:08:50.994 --> 00:08:52.340
Mswbt dash server.

161
00:08:52.340 --> 00:08:55.560
We know that's probably remote
desktop on this machine.

162
00:08:56.870 --> 00:09:02.030
And yeah, a good indication that this very
well could be a Windows machine, right?

163
00:09:02.030 --> 00:09:07.940
The MAC address is showing as Microsoft,
and that's because of the identifier

164
00:09:07.940 --> 00:09:11.820
out here that's been assigned to different
vendors to create their network adapters.

165
00:09:11.820 --> 00:09:14.730
In my case,
it's actually running on a HyperV server.

166
00:09:14.730 --> 00:09:17.260
So those MAC addresses are generated, and

167
00:09:17.260 --> 00:09:20.500
the pool of addresses has
been assigned to Microsoft.

168
00:09:20.500 --> 00:09:23.841
So anything running on my
Hyper-V Server or what have you,

169
00:09:23.841 --> 00:09:27.197
is actually gonna show up his Windows
as far as the MAC address goes.

170
00:09:27.197 --> 00:09:31.420
It's really all it's telling you is that
that MAC address is assigned to Microsoft.

171
00:09:31.420 --> 00:09:32.940
Or that's the vendor.

172
00:09:32.940 --> 00:09:36.100
I forget the OUID or OID that's out there.

173
00:09:36.100 --> 00:09:39.504
That's the first six digits in
the MAC address, all right?

174
00:09:39.504 --> 00:09:41.708
But the important thing
here is the scan itself.

175
00:09:41.708 --> 00:09:46.542
-sT gives you your TCP scan, all right?

176
00:09:46.542 --> 00:09:50.520
What if I want to run,
I want to do some OS detection.

177
00:09:50.520 --> 00:09:52.330
Now that I've scanned that machine,

178
00:09:52.330 --> 00:09:55.920
I see the ports that are open,
I wanna do a little OS detection.

179
00:09:55.920 --> 00:10:01.214
For that, we're gonna do nmap -O,
all right,

180
00:10:01.214 --> 00:10:06.140
and my address 10.0.100.101.

181
00:10:06.140 --> 00:10:10.470
And we'll let it run.

182
00:10:10.470 --> 00:10:13.040
So capital O for
operating system detection.

183
00:10:13.040 --> 00:10:14.010
And there's my results.

184
00:10:14.010 --> 00:10:15.300
Again, I see the port scans.

185
00:10:15.300 --> 00:10:17.240
It does another port scan on there.

186
00:10:17.240 --> 00:10:20.930
And then, right below that, look at that.

187
00:10:20.930 --> 00:10:22.310
Microsoft Windows 10.

188
00:10:22.310 --> 00:10:23.590
All right.

189
00:10:23.590 --> 00:10:26.180
It even tells me some
build information there.

190
00:10:26.180 --> 00:10:27.920
Distance one hop away.

191
00:10:27.920 --> 00:10:29.480
So that's what that capital O.

192
00:10:29.480 --> 00:10:30.380
Let's try the other one.

193
00:10:30.380 --> 00:10:31.156
Let's try 200.

194
00:10:35.523 --> 00:10:37.107
With that same capital O and
see what happens.

195
00:10:39.139 --> 00:10:42.350
All right, again,
why do we wanna know the operating system?

196
00:10:42.350 --> 00:10:45.200
Because that tells me what
vulnerabilities they might have.

197
00:10:45.200 --> 00:10:46.330
All right?

198
00:10:46.330 --> 00:10:50.090
I know that Windows 10 is bullet-proof and
has no vulnerabilities.

199
00:10:50.090 --> 00:10:51.160
So now I know I'm done.

200
00:10:51.160 --> 00:10:55.860
>> [LAUGH] Well, plus you're gonna
kind of waste your time trying to

201
00:10:55.860 --> 00:10:58.360
do some attack that works
only on Windows machines.

202
00:10:58.360 --> 00:11:00.530
If they're running a Linux machine and
then vice versa, right?

203
00:11:00.530 --> 00:11:04.440
It doesn't make sense to, that's
script kiddie level stuff, right guys?

204
00:11:04.440 --> 00:11:07.842
That, I have a script that does something,
there's a live machine,

205
00:11:07.842 --> 00:11:11.488
chuck it and the kitchen sink at it,
and so, hopefully I come a [INAUDIBLE].

206
00:11:11.488 --> 00:11:13.038
If not, well, I'll go to the next thing.

207
00:11:13.038 --> 00:11:14.937
I'm just looking for whatever can happen,

208
00:11:14.937 --> 00:11:17.020
where here I wanna start
being more targeted.

209
00:11:17.020 --> 00:11:18.410
I wanna be that professional level.

210
00:11:18.410 --> 00:11:22.870
I wanna say, okay, this is a Microsoft
operating system of some ilk.

211
00:11:22.870 --> 00:11:24.260
It's Windows 10, great.

212
00:11:24.260 --> 00:11:26.800
I've got my Windows 10
exploits right here,

213
00:11:26.800 --> 00:11:28.580
maybe one of those will work on this.

00:23:19.360 --> 00:23:21.910
Let me get it started, and
then we'll talk about it.

441
00:23:21.910 --> 00:23:25.189
Download it from Wireshark,
go ahead and Google Wireshark.

442
00:23:26.490 --> 00:23:31.120
Used to be called ethereal, so
if you're familiar with ethereal,

443
00:23:33.680 --> 00:23:35.970
sorry, I can't talk and
click at the same time.

444
00:23:35.970 --> 00:23:39.330
Let me remember where I put that,
there we go.

445
00:23:41.886 --> 00:23:48.640
Somewhere in here,
I have Wireshark, there we go.

446
00:23:48.640 --> 00:23:53.960
And we'll go ahead and get this guy fired
up, and then I'll go back to talking.

447
00:23:53.960 --> 00:23:57.431
I'll click Next on the wizard,
and I agree to the EULA.

448
00:23:57.431 --> 00:24:00.717
I'll leave everything checked there,

449
00:24:00.717 --> 00:24:05.268
nothing to change here,
we're just keep on trucking.

450
00:24:05.268 --> 00:24:05.954
And we'll click next.

451
00:24:05.954 --> 00:24:08.480
This I wanna show you, all right?

452
00:24:09.790 --> 00:24:14.190
As you're installing Wireshark,
it prompts me to install WinPcap.

453
00:24:14.190 --> 00:24:19.440
WinPcap is a library that allows
Windows to work with raw packet data.

454
00:24:19.440 --> 00:24:21.285
Microsoft left that out intentionally.

455
00:24:21.285 --> 00:24:24.796
They didn't think end users really need,
or have a desire to work with,

456
00:24:24.796 --> 00:24:26.190
end packets, raw packets.

457
00:24:27.270 --> 00:24:30.300
This is going to give us that
capability back in Windows, so

458
00:24:30.300 --> 00:24:33.730
definitely install it if you
don't have it installed already.

459
00:24:33.730 --> 00:24:37.650
Let it install WinPcap,
whatever the latest version is.

460
00:24:37.650 --> 00:24:39.950
It's also got a beta now for USBPcap.

461
00:24:39.950 --> 00:24:44.250
More and more stuff going across
USB ports, especially with USBC or

462
00:24:44.250 --> 00:24:44.794
Thunderbolt.

463
00:24:44.794 --> 00:24:49.320
I'm gonna need to start
monitoring that for data, for

464
00:24:49.320 --> 00:24:53.260
infiltration and things like that
as Wireshark is ahead of the game.

465
00:24:54.910 --> 00:24:58.950
Anyway, there's other packet
capture utilities you can use.

466
00:24:58.950 --> 00:25:03.881
Tcpdump is one I can use from
the command line, a very popular one.

467
00:25:03.881 --> 00:25:06.160
What's another one?
Network Monitor, which is now what,

468
00:25:06.160 --> 00:25:08.370
Message Analyzer, I think from Microsoft?

469
00:25:08.370 --> 00:25:11.833
They changed the name up on that one.

470
00:25:11.833 --> 00:25:14.101
It's not included, I don't think,
with the operating system, but

471
00:25:14.101 --> 00:25:15.312
you can download it from Microsoft.

472
00:25:15.312 --> 00:25:18.906
Let me go ahead and
let it install WinPcap.

473
00:25:18.906 --> 00:25:24.324
And notice that I let WinPcap
launch automatically at start-up?

474
00:25:24.324 --> 00:25:27.677
That way when I fire up Wireshark, I don't
have to worry about whether WinPcap is

475
00:25:27.677 --> 00:25:30.770
available or not, and
this will continue the installation.

476
00:25:30.770 --> 00:25:34.078
So what it allows me to do is
capture packets off of the network.

477
00:25:34.078 --> 00:25:37.970
Something we gotta keep in mind,
again, the disclaimer.

478
00:25:37.970 --> 00:25:41.660
Do not run this in your Enterprise
environment unless you have permissions

479
00:25:41.660 --> 00:25:44.550
to do so,
because this does capture raw packets and

480
00:25:44.550 --> 00:25:46.370
you will see data in those packets.

481
00:25:46.370 --> 00:25:48.830
If it's not encrypted,
you can read emails,

482
00:25:48.830 --> 00:25:51.240
you can read documents that
are being transferred.

483
00:25:51.240 --> 00:25:53.570
You can see passwords if
they're not encrypted.

484
00:25:53.570 --> 00:25:56.990
So in other words, you can access
information that you shouldn't have access

485
00:25:56.990 --> 00:25:59.210
to, that your pay grade
doesn't give you access too.

486
00:25:59.210 --> 00:26:03.360
Just because the CEO is emailing a
manager, you're sitting in the middle and

487
00:26:03.360 --> 00:26:07.420
you capture the information, and
you can see that payroll sheet, all right?

488
00:26:07.420 --> 00:26:09.130
And you can get in a lot of trouble for
that.

489
00:26:09.130 --> 00:26:13.479
So do not install this at work
unless you have permission to do so,

490
00:26:13.479 --> 00:26:15.308
do it on your home network.

491
00:26:15.308 --> 00:26:18.520
Another thing to keep in mind with
packet capture utilities like this,

492
00:26:18.520 --> 00:26:21.210
the majority of networks
nowadays are switched ethernet.

493
00:26:21.210 --> 00:26:25.774
So what that means is you have
a point-to-point connection between your

494
00:26:25.774 --> 00:26:27.109
node and the switch.

495
00:26:27.109 --> 00:26:30.538
The only traffic that's coming out
that wire and down to your node,

496
00:26:30.538 --> 00:26:34.280
is traffic that's destined for
your node or broadcast traffic, right?

497
00:26:34.280 --> 00:26:35.528
So that's all you're gonna see.

498
00:26:35.528 --> 00:26:36.750
You run packet capture,

499
00:26:36.750 --> 00:26:40.340
you're not gonna see anything else
unless you happen to be behind a hub.

500
00:26:41.390 --> 00:26:42.477
Or you've got a,

501
00:26:42.477 --> 00:26:47.117
a lot of times what we do is we do what's
called port mirroring on the switch,

502
00:26:47.117 --> 00:26:51.779
where all traffic gets put out the
appropriate port, plus the port mirror.

503
00:26:51.779 --> 00:26:54.819
And that's where I can monitor
all the traffic from and

504
00:26:54.819 --> 00:26:57.671
see what the other people
on the network are doing.

505
00:26:57.671 --> 00:27:02.510
All right, I'll click Next on my wizard
here, and I'll go ahead and click Finish.

506
00:27:02.510 --> 00:27:07.181
And we now have Wireshark installed,
but we are out of time.

507
00:27:07.181 --> 00:27:09.790
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, I got another cliffhanger for you.

508
00:27:09.790 --> 00:27:12.191
We'll just leave it right
there ,and we'll come back and

509
00:27:12.191 --> 00:27:14.750
we'll take a look at how to run
Wireshark and how we can use it.

510
00:27:14.750 --> 00:27:16.470
>> Mike,
you are the king of the cliffhanger, man.

511
00:27:16.470 --> 00:27:20.413
Really leave us wanting, salivating over,
I wanna see Wireshark run.

512
00:27:20.413 --> 00:27:24.075
I wanna see data get captured from
across the network, maybe a password,

513
00:27:24.075 --> 00:27:24.969
something cool.

514
00:27:24.969 --> 00:27:27.926
But yeah, if you want to see that,
you'll definitely have to come back for,

515
00:27:27.926 --> 00:27:29.300
what are we on, part four now?

516
00:27:29.300 --> 00:27:29.900
>> I believe so.

517
00:27:29.900 --> 00:27:31.020
>> The mini-series continues.

518
00:27:31.020 --> 00:27:32.860
>> [LAUGH]
>> Hopefully we will see you there.

519
00:27:32.860 --> 00:27:35.980
As for this episode,
it does look like we are out of time.

520
00:27:35.980 --> 00:27:37.260
So we're gonna go ahead and sign off for

521
00:27:37.260 --> 00:27:39.350
ITProTV, I've been your
host Daniel Lowrie.

522
00:27:39.350 --> 00:27:40.190
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

523
00:27:40.190 --> 00:27:41.782
>> And we'll see you next time.

524
00:27:41.782 --> 00:27:48.739
[MUSIC]

525
00:27:48.739 --> 00:27:52.002
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike continue their look at the techniques and tools used by CyberSec First Responders. Here they demonstrate and explain the use of Protocol analyzers, aka Packet Sniffers, specifically they will demo one of the most popular sniffers called Wireshark.
episodes.title: Tools and Techniques Part 4
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.108 --> 00:00:02.721
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.721 --> 00:00:08.353
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.353 --> 00:00:12.183
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.183 --> 00:00:14.073
>> All right, greetings everyone, and

5
00:00:14.073 --> 00:00:16.385
welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:16.385 --> 00:00:19.822
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, and in
today's episode we are continuing on with

7
00:00:19.822 --> 00:00:23.362
more in our CyberSec First Responders
series, and joining us again, of course,

8
00:00:23.362 --> 00:00:24.336
our good friend, Mr.

9
00:00:24.336 --> 00:00:27.244
Mike Rodrick, Michael, welcome back,
how are you doing today?

10
00:00:27.244 --> 00:00:30.721
>> I'm doing fantastic, thanks for
having me back once again.

11
00:00:30.721 --> 00:00:35.354
And yeah, in this episode, we're going to
continue on with tools and techniques, and

12
00:00:35.354 --> 00:00:38.355
what I wanna do here is take
a look at a protocol analyzer,

13
00:00:38.355 --> 00:00:41.761
or a packet capture utility,
I mean, they go by several names.

14
00:00:41.761 --> 00:00:46.641
There really are different functions when
you talk about a protocol analyzer versus

15
00:00:46.641 --> 00:00:50.774
a packet capture utility, or
a network sniffer, a network capturer.

16
00:00:50.774 --> 00:00:55.031
But Wireshark, the one I'm gonna demo for
you, does a lot of that,

17
00:00:55.031 --> 00:00:59.813
it allows me to work with the raw packets,
it is a packet capture utility, or

18
00:00:59.813 --> 00:01:04.852
a network monitor utility, or a network
sniffer, whatever you wanna call it.

19
00:01:04.852 --> 00:01:08.903
You can also do some protocol analysis
with it, because it's gonna show me

20
00:01:08.903 --> 00:01:12.843
the raw packets and I can see what
protocols are being used on my network.

21
00:01:12.843 --> 00:01:16.538
Maybe I spot something that maybe
shouldn't be there, or like,

22
00:01:16.538 --> 00:01:20.163
I know here for example,
when I was running this the other day and

23
00:01:20.163 --> 00:01:24.259
I found a stranger protocol,
one I hadn't seen a lot of, PTPV2, which

24
00:01:24.259 --> 00:01:29.053
is precision time protocol, turns out to
be version two, and it was just flooding.

25
00:01:29.053 --> 00:01:31.983
There was all kinds of traffic
on my network, come to find out,

26
00:01:31.983 --> 00:01:35.799
it's our phones, or our Cisco phones,
I forget who makes our phones, Polycom,

27
00:01:35.799 --> 00:01:37.875
I think, is who makes them.

28
00:01:37.875 --> 00:01:41.841
They were using that to synchronize their
times and things like that, so, yeah,

29
00:01:41.841 --> 00:01:45.289
it's interesting what you can see
when you start capturing packets and

30
00:01:45.289 --> 00:01:48.278
looking out there on the network and
seeing what's going on,

31
00:01:48.278 --> 00:01:51.464
it's a very important part of our
skill set as first responders.

32
00:01:51.464 --> 00:01:54.795
Being in and understanding security,
we have to monitor our network,

33
00:01:54.795 --> 00:01:57.404
we need to know what should and
shouldn't be there, and

34
00:01:57.404 --> 00:02:00.955
the only way to do that is to monitor it,
to look and see what's going on, and

35
00:02:00.955 --> 00:02:04.253
that way when something is out of place,
you're gonna recognize it.

36
00:02:04.253 --> 00:02:08.945
And getting familiar with the tools before
you need them is always a good thing, so

37
00:02:08.945 --> 00:02:10.856
let's take a look at Wireshark.

38
00:02:10.856 --> 00:02:15.662
If we take a look at my screen here, I've
got my Windows 10 device opened up, and

39
00:02:15.662 --> 00:02:20.193
I'm gonna go ahead and fire up Wireshark
and the first thing I want to do is open

40
00:02:20.193 --> 00:02:24.680
up a saved capture, as soon as Wireshark
decides to play along with me here.

41
00:02:24.680 --> 00:02:27.383
And what that means is,
when you do a packet capture,

42
00:02:27.383 --> 00:02:31.649
you're gonna see the information real time
on your screen with a utility like this,

43
00:02:31.649 --> 00:02:35.218
but I can save that information,
and I should save that information.

44
00:02:35.218 --> 00:02:38.325
That way, we can go back at
our leisure and analyze and

45
00:02:38.325 --> 00:02:43.091
go through the packets as we see fit, or
somebody calls me up, I could say, yeah,

46
00:02:43.091 --> 00:02:47.954
I've got a packet capture from that day,
let's go take a look at what was going on.

47
00:02:47.954 --> 00:02:52.205
So I'm gonna open it up,
simply File, Open, and

48
00:02:52.205 --> 00:02:56.865
I'll browse, and
there is my reconisance.pcap, or

49
00:02:56.865 --> 00:03:02.056
it's a .pcapng is the file,
and that's pretty standard.

50
00:03:02.056 --> 00:03:06.186
One of the cool things about Wireshark,
and most of our packet captures,

51
00:03:06.186 --> 00:03:10.114
is I can use like TCPDump to create
the capture, because it's quick,

52
00:03:10.114 --> 00:03:14.107
it's command line, I can script it,
I can have a little batch file that

53
00:03:14.107 --> 00:03:18.900
I run to fire this thing off and capture
1,000 packets and then stop the capture so

54
00:03:18.900 --> 00:03:21.928
I can start automating that and
run it periodically.

55
00:03:21.928 --> 00:03:27.197
But analyzing with TCPDump is not fun
because it's in that command prompt.

56
00:03:27.197 --> 00:03:31.498
I can open that file up with Wireshark and
now I can do my filters with a graphical

57
00:03:31.498 --> 00:03:35.931
user interface, so much powerful when it
comes to being able to filter traffic,

58
00:03:35.931 --> 00:03:40.328
look at conversations, for example,
follow streams, those kind of things.

59
00:03:40.328 --> 00:03:41.091
So lets-
>> Yeah,

60
00:03:41.091 --> 00:03:44.763
it's definitely more easily looked at
quickly, and say, I see what that is,

61
00:03:44.763 --> 00:03:47.857
I see what that is, looking at TCPDump
output can just look like a bunch

62
00:03:47.857 --> 00:03:50.493
of white text on a black background,
to be honest with you.

63
00:03:50.493 --> 00:03:52.867
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] It really does all start to

64
00:03:52.867 --> 00:03:57.399
blur together, here, I've got color
coding, and highlighting, and it,

65
00:03:57.399 --> 00:04:02.138
I almost want to say deciphers, but it
converts my hex for me, things like that,

66
00:04:02.138 --> 00:04:04.189
makes it a lot easier to work with.

67
00:04:04.189 --> 00:04:08.139
So I'll go ahead and open this guy up and
I'll click open, and it should open

68
00:04:08.139 --> 00:04:12.588
up that capture, and so here's an example
capture that logic operations created for

69
00:04:12.588 --> 00:04:15.613
us, and I can see open there's
three panes in Wireshark,

70
00:04:15.613 --> 00:04:19.174
there's a lot of pain in Wireshark now,
kidding, that was a joke.

71
00:04:19.174 --> 00:04:22.364
>> [LAUGH]
>> There's three different panes,

72
00:04:22.364 --> 00:04:25.143
I've got my top pane,
which is where I see the actual packets.

73
00:04:25.143 --> 00:04:29.363
So, up here, each one of these is
a packet that my sniffer has captured and

74
00:04:29.363 --> 00:04:32.154
you can see I can highlight them,
click on them,

75
00:04:32.154 --> 00:04:36.240
and if you are watching these panes below,
this middle pane is an actual

76
00:04:36.240 --> 00:04:40.087
breakdown of the packet,
where I can go in and say, you know what?

77
00:04:40.087 --> 00:04:44.172
I want to look at this packet, and
I can see that it's a TCP packet.

78
00:04:44.172 --> 00:04:48.993
Let's see what information is in
that TCP header, and there it is.

79
00:04:48.993 --> 00:04:52.821
I can see source port, destination port,
now look at that destination port,

80
00:04:52.821 --> 00:04:54.220
what were they doing there?

81
00:04:54.220 --> 00:04:55.767
443, what's that for, do we remember?

82
00:04:55.767 --> 00:04:56.791
>> That's SSL.

83
00:04:56.791 --> 00:04:59.915
>> Yeah, so
somebody was making a secure connection or

84
00:04:59.915 --> 00:05:04.183
they were attempting to make a secure
connection to the other end here.

85
00:05:04.183 --> 00:05:06.668
What else?
So, I could look at the flags in here.

86
00:05:06.668 --> 00:05:11.041
We talked about the TCP3 way
handshake where there's a SIN and

87
00:05:11.041 --> 00:05:14.273
then a SIN ac sent back
as a response to the SIN.

88
00:05:14.273 --> 00:05:17.301
And then, a final acknowledgement, so

89
00:05:17.301 --> 00:05:22.028
SIN, SIN ac, ac, the three way,
or the TCP3 way handshake.

90
00:05:22.028 --> 00:05:25.969
So, here, I can see that the flag,
the syn flag, is actually raised, so

91
00:05:25.969 --> 00:05:28.396
it's turned on,
you can see that one there.

92
00:05:28.396 --> 00:05:31.052
There's all the other flags.

93
00:05:31.052 --> 00:05:34.348
>> Urge, push, and all the other good
ones, there's a lot of good stuff.

94
00:05:34.348 --> 00:05:35.267
If you mess around,

95
00:05:35.267 --> 00:05:38.359
this really comes in handy when
you're messing with nmap, right?

96
00:05:38.359 --> 00:05:42.964
And if you're playing around with nmap,
and you're looking at the output through

97
00:05:42.964 --> 00:05:46.448
Wireshark as the attack or scan,
should I say, is happening,

98
00:05:46.448 --> 00:05:50.812
you'll get a lot of cool information in
that Xmas tree scan that is available.

99
00:05:50.812 --> 00:05:53.655
Or using maybe a custom flag scan,
you can look in here and

100
00:05:53.655 --> 00:05:56.617
make sure that that scan is
actually is what is happening and

101
00:05:56.617 --> 00:06:00.129
look at the results from the machine
that you're actually scanning.

102
00:06:00.129 --> 00:06:04.289
It's very cool stuff to get in here and
see it at that base level.

103
00:06:04.289 --> 00:06:09.119
>> Absolutely, Daniel, I can't stress
enough, if you want to get into security,

104
00:06:09.119 --> 00:06:14.089
really just even networking in general,
but especially security, you need to work

105
00:06:14.089 --> 00:06:18.305
with a packet capture utility,
figure out which one you like the best.

106
00:06:18.305 --> 00:06:21.901
Wireshark is my preferred,
it's free, easily available,

107
00:06:21.901 --> 00:06:26.599
wherever I'm at I can always download it
again, because you want to get familiar

108
00:06:26.599 --> 00:06:30.886
with your particular programs,
interface, filtering capabilities,

109
00:06:30.886 --> 00:06:35.265
where everything is, but yes,
get out there and capture some trade data.

110
00:06:35.265 --> 00:06:40.000
Again, do this on your home network where
you're not going to get in trouble or

111
00:06:40.000 --> 00:06:44.018
have permission from your enterprise,
or have a test lab set up and

112
00:06:44.018 --> 00:06:48.971
some virtual machines that you can use to
capture data because all those things you

113
00:06:48.971 --> 00:06:51.521
talk about in theory, you get to see now.

114
00:06:51.521 --> 00:06:55.853
Most of you have been through server
classes or even network plus, where we

115
00:06:55.853 --> 00:07:01.036
talk about DHCP and the DORA process,
Discover, Offer, Request, Acknowledgement.

116
00:07:01.036 --> 00:07:04.847
If you run one of these and then do
a release renew on a client on you network

117
00:07:04.847 --> 00:07:09.225
or whatever, you're gonna actually capture
those packets, and you will see DHCP

118
00:07:09.225 --> 00:07:13.757
offer, here's the IP address that it's
offering the client, here's my request.

119
00:07:13.757 --> 00:07:17.940
>> Mike, this was one of the most
asked questions back when I was

120
00:07:17.940 --> 00:07:22.207
doing instructural ed training,
is okay I see what it does but

121
00:07:22.207 --> 00:07:24.439
when or why would I ever do this?

122
00:07:24.439 --> 00:07:27.585
Well it comes down to the fact,
is something not working?

123
00:07:27.585 --> 00:07:30.476
And okay, DHCP is a prime example, right?

124
00:07:30.476 --> 00:07:35.345
It's doing that DORA process, if I'm not
getting DHCP addresses to my network,

125
00:07:35.345 --> 00:07:36.769
why is that happening?

126
00:07:36.769 --> 00:07:40.218
My server's up, I can ping it,
my computers are up, I can't ping them

127
00:07:40.218 --> 00:07:44.204
because they don't have addresses yet,

00:17:26.700 --> 00:17:27.220

338
00:17:40.120 --> 00:17:42.570
Keep in mind display filters
doesn't remove packets.

00:17:42.570 --> 00:17:44.940
Display filter just filters
what you're seeing.

340
00:17:44.940 --> 00:17:48.330
So you can always apply a filter and
then remove the filter and

00:17:48.330 --> 00:17:49.770

00:17:49.770 --> 00:17:51.730
You can do a Capture Filter,

00:17:51.730 --> 00:17:54.710
which means you can set the filter

00:17:54.710 --> 00:17:58.173

00:17:58.173 --> 00:18:02.680

00:18:02.680 --> 00:18:05.230
Normally, though,
if we're just doing baselines or

347
00:18:05.230 --> 00:18:07.930
