we don't do a capture filter.

348
00:18:07.930 --> 00:18:09.740
Cuz I wanna capture everything and

349
00:18:09.740 --> 00:18:13.190
then I can use display filters
to make it easier to look at.

350
00:18:13.190 --> 00:18:16.300
Also keep in mind, and I think we
mentioned this the other day, Daniel,

351
00:18:16.300 --> 00:18:21.150
we talk about switched ethernet,
which is what most networks are nowadays.

352
00:18:21.150 --> 00:18:25.010
So when you run packet captures, you're
only gonna see, if you're connected to

353
00:18:25.010 --> 00:18:28.770

that that switch allows out that port,

354
00:18:28.770 --> 00:18:33.780
which is only things that are destined for
you or broadcast traffic, all right?

355
00:18:33.780 --> 00:18:36.000
So if you wanna see the rest
of the traffic on the network,

356
00:18:36.000 --> 00:18:39.300
if I wanna sniff Daniel's traffic and
see what he's doing on the Internet,

357
00:18:39.300 --> 00:18:43.570
what websites he's visiting, for
example, I'd have to get between him and

358
00:18:43.570 --> 00:18:46.950

on the other side of the switch.

359
00:18:46.950 --> 00:18:49.380
Good place to do monitoring is a proxy,
right,

371
00:19:19.030 --> 00:19:21.400

00:19:21.400 --> 00:19:25.260

are susceptible to flooding,

00:19:25.260 --> 00:19:28.540

00:19:28.540 --> 00:19:32.820

00:19:32.820 --> 00:19:37.260

that, I can maybe make it give up and

00:19:37.260 --> 00:19:40.050

just spit everything out every port.

00:19:40.050 --> 00:19:44.043

nowadays and just say nope, I'm not doing

378
00:19:44.043 --> 00:19:47.935

up and push everything out that port.

00:19:47.935 --> 00:19:48.933

00:19:48.933 --> 00:19:50.333

I'm gonna say continue without saving.

591
00:30:57.091 --> 00:30:58.380
It starts a new capture.

592
00:30:58.380 --> 00:31:03.130
I'm going to drag this file to my
desktop and say, yes, I trust it.

593
00:31:03.130 --> 00:31:06.218
And then I'm gonna stop my capture.

594
00:31:06.218 --> 00:31:12.145
Now we're gonna filter this down to, let's
say, SMB, should be what we are looking.

595
00:31:12.145 --> 00:31:15.730
I just served 20 to 12 so
let's do SNB two.

596
00:31:15.730 --> 00:31:16.528
Here we go.

597
00:31:16.528 --> 00:31:21.260
Here is my conversation from
10.0.100.101 to the server.

598
00:31:21.260 --> 00:31:22.720
If I right click and

599
00:31:22.720 --> 00:31:28.000
follow stream, here are the packets
that are going back and forth.

600
00:31:28.000 --> 00:31:29.680
Great information.

601
00:31:29.680 --> 00:31:31.748
Looks good.

602
00:31:31.748 --> 00:31:32.736
Aren't you excited?

603
00:31:32.736 --> 00:31:33.253
But look right here.

604
00:31:33.253 --> 00:31:35.715
>> Look at that.

605
00:31:35.715 --> 00:31:39.293
>> Account number 123456789.

606
00:31:39.293 --> 00:31:42.340
So, we were able to see that data,
in fact, let's do one more.

607
00:31:42.340 --> 00:31:44.520
Not another capture but
I'm gonna close that.

608
00:31:44.520 --> 00:31:47.460
Where else you can see that,
if I find that particular packet,

609
00:31:47.460 --> 00:31:50.870
which is right here, then on the bottom
pane where I said it decodes it for

610
00:31:50.870 --> 00:31:53.980
you That was definitely not the packet.

611
00:31:53.980 --> 00:31:55.611
So, let's just flip through,
there it is, right there.

612
00:31:55.611 --> 00:31:57.950
My read response, account 123456789.

613
00:31:57.950 --> 00:32:01.040
So, that's what I'm saying,
with tools like this,

614
00:32:01.040 --> 00:32:02.500
one you can get yourself in trouble.

615
00:32:02.500 --> 00:32:06.090
But this is really what allows you to take
a deep look at the traffic that's going on

616
00:32:06.090 --> 00:32:06.990
in your network.

617
00:32:06.990 --> 00:32:10.596
So, you can analyze attacks or potential
attacks, find out what's going on.

618
00:32:10.596 --> 00:32:15.260
So play around with Wire Shark or whatever
packet capture utility of your choice.

619
00:32:15.260 --> 00:32:18.130
Get familiar with it, it's something
that you really need in your toolbox.

620
00:32:18.130 --> 00:32:19.470
>> And very cool stuff Mike.

621
00:32:19.470 --> 00:32:23.769
We really appreciate you stopping by and
explaining packet capturing,

622
00:32:23.769 --> 00:32:28.498
packet sniffing software to us because it
is a very handy thing to know how to do.

623
00:32:28.498 --> 00:32:31.540
It's nice to be able to use it for
trouble shooting purposes.

624
00:32:31.540 --> 00:32:35.190
It's nice to be able to trust but verify

625
00:32:35.190 --> 00:32:39.440
that the machines on your system are only
passing traffic that they should be.

626
00:32:39.440 --> 00:32:42.670
Maybe you've got malware on one and
your suspicious of it.

627
00:32:42.670 --> 00:32:44.360
Throw up the packet capture.

628
00:32:44.360 --> 00:32:47.550
Put your filter in place to see what
conversations are happening between

629
00:32:47.550 --> 00:32:50.770
that machine specifically and
where ever else that you like and

630
00:32:50.770 --> 00:32:52.800
then check that out and
see what's going on in there.

631
00:32:52.800 --> 00:32:55.820
Maybe find someone internally
is sniffing your network.

632
00:32:55.820 --> 00:32:58.340
We talked about this, inside threats.

633
00:32:58.340 --> 00:33:00.670
Don't forget about that,
you want to see that happening.

634
00:33:00.670 --> 00:33:01.930
Hey, where's that scan coming from?

635
00:33:01.930 --> 00:33:04.525
It's coming from Bob's
computer on the third floor.

636
00:33:04.525 --> 00:33:06.790
He shouldn't be doing that,
he's in accounting.

637
00:33:06.790 --> 00:33:07.960
Why is he scanning the network?

638
00:33:07.960 --> 00:33:12.075
So, very interesting stuff, and then of
course being able to save that stuff for

639
00:33:12.075 --> 00:33:15.053
later for further exploration
is also very handy as well.

640
00:33:15.053 --> 00:33:17.420
So, hopefully you got
a lot out of this episode.

641
00:33:17.420 --> 00:33:19.060
Very good information.

642
00:33:19.060 --> 00:33:21.600
That being said, though,
we are out of time for this one so

643
00:33:21.600 --> 00:33:23.010
we're gonna have to close it down.

644
00:33:23.010 --> 00:33:24.141
Thanks for joining us everyone.

645
00:33:24.141 --> 00:33:27.070
Signing off for ITPro TV I've
been your host, Daniel Lowery.

646
00:33:27.070 --> 00:33:27.870
>> And I'm Mike Roderick.

647
00:33:27.870 --> 00:33:29.257
>> And we'll see you next time.

648
00:33:31.032 --> 00:33:36.984
[MUSIC]

649
00:33:36.984 --> 00:33:40.211
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike continue their look at the techniques and tools used by CyberSec First Responders. This time around they will be demonstrating and explaining how to scan your environment for vulnerabilities using the Nessus vunerability scanner.
episodes.title: Tools and Techniques Part 5

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike discuss password attacks commonly used by both Security Admin and Threat Actor. They begin with password sniffing, which exploys the use of a protocol analyzer/packet sniffer to capture passwords from network packets. Then they explore password cracking through Brute Force, Dictionary, Guessing, and Rainbow Tables.
episodes.title: Password Attacks
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:02.628
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.628 --> 00:00:08.396
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.396 --> 00:00:12.520
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.520 --> 00:00:14.000
>> All right, greetings everyone.

5
00:00:14.000 --> 00:00:16.999
Welcome to another exciting
episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:16.999 --> 00:00:18.761
I am your host Daniel Lowrie,

7
00:00:18.761 --> 00:00:22.650
and in today's episode we are kicking
off more on our CFR series.

8
00:00:22.650 --> 00:00:25.630
That's right,
the old CyberSec First Responder.

9
00:00:25.630 --> 00:00:28.610
And joining me back in the studio is one
of the craziest people I've ever met in

10
00:00:28.610 --> 00:00:29.630
my entire life.

11
00:00:29.630 --> 00:00:31.360
Our good friend, Mr Mike Rodrick.

12
00:00:31.360 --> 00:00:32.130
Mike, welcome back.

13
00:00:32.130 --> 00:00:33.240
How's it going today?

14
00:00:33.240 --> 00:00:34.285
>> I don't know, I'm crazy.

15
00:00:34.285 --> 00:00:36.208
[LAUGH]
>> That's loco.

16
00:00:36.208 --> 00:00:38.364
[CROSSTALK] [LAUGH]
>> Thanks for having me back.

17
00:00:38.364 --> 00:00:39.048
Glad to be here.

18
00:00:39.048 --> 00:00:44.330
And yeah, continuing on with our
good old CFR-210 Logical Operations.

19
00:00:44.330 --> 00:00:47.050
So today we're gonna take a look at,
kind of the next phase,

20
00:00:47.050 --> 00:00:49.750
if you've been following these
episodes along in order.

21
00:00:49.750 --> 00:00:52.830
Going through the, basically,
an attack methodology, if you will.

22
00:00:53.900 --> 00:00:55.990
Because as a first responder,

23
00:00:55.990 --> 00:01:00.500
or anybody in security, we need to
understand exactly what they're doing.

24
00:01:00.500 --> 00:01:02.740
How they're going about
attacking our systems.

25
00:01:02.740 --> 00:01:04.330
So we can better defend against it, right?

26
00:01:04.330 --> 00:01:08.240
So we've talked about kind of the
reconnaissance, doing that footprinting.

27
00:01:08.240 --> 00:01:12.980
Gathering all the information
we can about our target.

28
00:01:12.980 --> 00:01:15.550
We've looked at doing some scanning.

29
00:01:15.550 --> 00:01:19.000
Trying to see what's out there,
what hosts are up,

30
00:01:19.000 --> 00:01:22.520
what ports they have open,
what services they're offering.

31
00:01:22.520 --> 00:01:27.400
So we can get an idea of what it is, or
how they're going to attack the system.

32
00:01:27.400 --> 00:01:30.210
Or how the bad guys would be attacking
our system if we're looking at it from

33
00:01:30.210 --> 00:01:31.660
a security standpoint.

34
00:01:31.660 --> 00:01:34.430
And then we took at doing
vulnerability scans, right.

35
00:01:34.430 --> 00:01:38.379
Which is really once we found our live
host, we see what services are running.

36
00:01:39.610 --> 00:01:41.700
We can use that information and

37
00:01:41.700 --> 00:01:47.070
search through some vulnerability
databases, like Offensive Security.

38
00:01:47.070 --> 00:01:48.500
Or I'm trying to think of
what some of the other

39
00:01:48.500 --> 00:01:49.790
vulnerability databases are out there.

40
00:01:49.790 --> 00:01:53.260
But there's the Common Vulnerabilities and
Exploit database,

41
00:01:53.260 --> 00:01:55.860
the CVE, that we can search through.

42
00:01:55.860 --> 00:01:59.093
Once I know you're running,
say Apache version x, right.

43
00:01:59.093 --> 00:02:03.607
I can now go through and see what
vulnerabilities that particular version

44
00:02:03.607 --> 00:02:07.280
might be susceptible to,
if it's not patched.

45
00:02:07.280 --> 00:02:10.180
Really the next phase
that we wanna get into,

46
00:02:10.180 --> 00:02:13.060
as we start into our gaining access phase,
right?

47
00:02:13.060 --> 00:02:16.520
Once we've done our reconnaissance,
we've done our scanning.

48
00:02:16.520 --> 00:02:18.890
Then they start the gaining access phase.

49
00:02:18.890 --> 00:02:21.820
And for that, typically,
we need a password, right?

50
00:02:21.820 --> 00:02:25.520
I mean it really depends on
the vulnerability that you're gonna use.

51
00:02:25.520 --> 00:02:26.860
It's just another method of attack.

52
00:02:26.860 --> 00:02:29.520
Some vulnerabilities you exploit,
you might not need.

53
00:02:29.520 --> 00:02:32.830
And that's one of the reasons we use them,
because we're gonna kind of bypass

54
00:02:32.830 --> 00:02:36.978
the authentication by doing maybe a buffer
overflow, or some other form of attack.

55
00:02:36.978 --> 00:02:40.580
But having usernames and passwords
is a big part of the attack process.

56
00:02:42.210 --> 00:02:43.890
So the question is how
do they obtain that?

57
00:02:43.890 --> 00:02:48.510
How do the bad guys get our usernames and
our passwords to our systems?

58
00:02:48.510 --> 00:02:51.530
And different methods that we can use,
right.

59
00:02:51.530 --> 00:02:55.460
Usernames are pretty easy,
typically, to come up with.

60
00:02:55.460 --> 00:02:58.130
Especially if you're an insider
because you already know the format.

61
00:02:58.130 --> 00:03:01.480
Like first initial, last name or
first name, middle initial,

62
00:03:01.480 --> 00:03:03.310
last initial, whatever the case may be.

63
00:03:03.310 --> 00:03:07.000
Typically not too hard to figure
out some of the usernames.

64
00:03:07.000 --> 00:03:10.610
There's always the built in accounts,
that are administrator,

65
00:03:10.610 --> 00:03:13.193
that's one that I really
love to get access to.

66
00:03:13.193 --> 00:03:15.870
So the username part of
it we've got to discover.

67
00:03:15.870 --> 00:03:19.700
And we can do that through
some of our scanning.

68
00:03:19.700 --> 00:03:23.670
We can do our enumeration where
we start listing out users.

69
00:03:23.670 --> 00:03:28.010
Email addresses, remember we've looked
at that like using the harvester.

70
00:03:28.010 --> 00:03:33.030
Their email address is mike@itprotv
most likely their user name is Mike.

71
00:03:33.030 --> 00:03:34.380
So we can get information that way.

72
00:03:34.380 --> 00:03:38.270
Then when it comes to getting
the passwords, how do we get those?

73
00:03:38.270 --> 00:03:39.595
How are the bad guys
getting our passwords?

74
00:03:39.595 --> 00:03:45.350
And one method that they would use
would be password sniffing, right?

75
00:03:45.350 --> 00:03:47.378
We've already seen sniffers,

76
00:03:47.378 --> 00:03:52.040
we've talked about packa caps
utilities like Wireshark, for example.

77
00:03:52.040 --> 00:03:54.448
Well if you're sending your
password across the network,

78
00:03:54.448 --> 00:03:57.010
it's just like any other packet
that's traveling out there.

79
00:03:57.010 --> 00:03:58.100
If there's a password in there,

80
00:03:58.100 --> 00:04:01.760
I capture that packet, I can then attempt
to get the password out of there.

81
00:04:01.760 --> 00:04:05.910
If it's a plain text protocol it's
going to show up right in Wireshark.

82
00:04:05.910 --> 00:04:08.920
I'm just going to be able to
read it right out of there.

83
00:04:08.920 --> 00:04:13.252
Which is why we try to avoid
using any type of authentication

84
00:04:13.252 --> 00:04:16.468
that transmits credentials in plain text.

85
00:04:16.468 --> 00:04:18.143
It's just not a good idea.

86
00:04:18.143 --> 00:04:20.580
Like Dan, you got any examples there?

87
00:04:20.580 --> 00:04:23.120
What's something you've,
>> Yeah, plain text, passwords,

88
00:04:23.120 --> 00:04:24.960
they get passed through FTP, right.

89
00:04:24.960 --> 00:04:27.050
So if you're logging into an FTP account.

90
00:04:27.050 --> 00:04:28.500
Telnet is another great one.

91
00:04:28.500 --> 00:04:32.740
These are typically the ones that you
will see as plain text passwords.

92
00:04:32.740 --> 00:04:35.720
But if there's any kind of web
authentication that doesn't encrypt

93
00:04:35.720 --> 00:04:39.290
the traffic that's going through it
could be inside those packets as well.

94
00:04:39.290 --> 00:04:40.320
You always wanna use,

95
00:04:40.320 --> 00:04:44.740
any time authentication is being passed,
you typically always want to.

96
00:04:44.740 --> 00:04:47.270
I'll go out on a climb and
say, not typically,

97
00:04:47.270 --> 00:04:51.160
you definitely always want to
use some form of encryption.

98
00:04:51.160 --> 00:04:52.610
Some form of encoding so

99
00:04:52.610 --> 00:04:56.530
that It can't just be looked at
through something like Wireshark.

100
00:04:56.530 --> 00:04:59.790
>> Yeah, I mean you're just making it
way too easy for the bad guys, right.

101
00:04:59.790 --> 00:05:01.040
So we're going to avoid that.

102
00:05:01.040 --> 00:05:03.360
And as Daniel said, great examples there.

103
00:05:03.360 --> 00:05:07.375
FTP, if you're not doing secure FTP
that's going to send it in plain text.

104
00:05:07.375 --> 00:05:10.300
Telnet, that's why we try
to avoid that nowadays.

105
00:05:10.300 --> 00:05:11.360
Cuz it's plain text.

106
00:05:11.360 --> 00:05:14.980
And if I'm a user on the network and
Daniel's an administrator and

107
00:05:14.980 --> 00:05:18.970
he's Telnetting into some
server to remotely manage it.

108
00:05:18.970 --> 00:05:21.360
If I'm running Wireshark,
I can capture those credentials and

109
00:05:21.360 --> 00:05:23.520
now I can authenticate as Daniel.

110
00:05:23.520 --> 00:05:25.040
So never a good idea to use plain text.

111
00:05:25.040 --> 00:05:27.510
We wanna make sure that
we're using something.

112
00:05:27.510 --> 00:05:28.631
What about your developers?

113
00:05:28.631 --> 00:05:32.280
You develop a web app for
internal use or external use.

114
00:05:32.280 --> 00:05:36.800
They might simply put an HTML form out
there and let you type in username and

115
00:05:36.800 --> 00:05:39.490
password and submit it back to
the server for authentication.

116
00:05:39.490 --> 00:05:44.970
And a little database and to use any
type of encryption in that transmission.

117
00:05:44.970 --> 00:05:48.610
So sniffing definitely a big part
of it and any of your sniffers.

118
00:05:48.610 --> 00:05:52.094
It doesn't have to be anything in
particular because we're just grabbing

119
00:05:52.094 --> 00:05:53.042
those raw packets.

120
00:05:53.042 --> 00:05:57.979
So Wireshark, there are some that look
specifically for authentication packets,

121
00:05:57.979 --> 00:05:59.480
which can be handy.

122
00:05:59.480 --> 00:06:04.220
You know, you can fire up,
I'm trying to think of a good example.

123
00:06:07.275 --> 00:06:08.415
Now, of course, I'm drawing a blank.

124
00:06:08.415 --> 00:06:12.165
But there are some sniffers
where you can configure them so

125
00:06:12.165 --> 00:06:14.375
that they're just looking for
authentication packets.

126
00:06:14.375 --> 00:06:17.655
They'll ignore HTTP packets and
those kinds of things.

127
00:06:17.655 --> 00:06:19.195
We don't care about those at this point.

128
00:06:19.195 --> 00:06:20.745
I'm just looking for authentication.

129
00:06:20.745 --> 00:06:23.465
Makes it easier, that way you don't
have to filter your results and find it.

130
00:06:23.465 --> 00:06:26.840
It just says I'm only gonna
look at authentication.

131
00:06:26.840 --> 00:06:28.040
So sniffing is one.

132
00:06:28.040 --> 00:06:31.460
Keep in mind, if I'm gonna sniff,
I've got to be in the network somehow.

133
00:06:31.460 --> 00:06:33.980
So maybe I already
compromised a machine and

134
00:06:33.980 --> 00:06:35.720
now I'm trying to escalate my credentials.

135
00:06:35.720 --> 00:06:40.970
Because I was able to social engineer
a password out of a user and

136
00:06:40.970 --> 00:06:43.510
I can authenticate as them but
they're just a standard user.

137
00:06:43.510 --> 00:06:45.440
They don't have any administrative access.

138
00:06:45.440 --> 00:06:46.850
But now I can get into the network.

139
00:06:46.850 --> 00:06:49.110
I can authenticate as them and
potentially,

140
00:06:49.110 --> 00:06:52.830
if I'm compromised the machine in there,
run a sniffer from the inside and

141
00:06:52.830 --> 00:06:53.820
try to capture that traffic.

142
00:06:53.820 --> 00:06:55.450
That's the big thing about sniffing.

143
00:06:55.450 --> 00:06:56.020
Keep that in mind.

144
00:06:56.020 --> 00:06:57.090
We've talked about it.

145
00:06:57.090 --> 00:06:58.860
We talked about packet capture.

146
00:06:58.860 --> 00:07:00.661
You gotta be able to see
that traffic to capture it.

147
00:07:00.661 --> 00:07:03.338
And if you're on a switched
ethernet that can be a challenge or

148
00:07:03.338 --> 00:07:05.870
something that we've got to deal with.

149
00:07:05.870 --> 00:07:07.520
All right, but what else?

150
00:07:07.520 --> 00:07:11.367
If they can't capture the traffic, because
that's typically an internal thing.

151
00:07:11.367 --> 00:07:14.260
And unless we're doing some
kind of web front end.

152
00:07:14.260 --> 00:07:16.810
Where we've got no
authentication on the traffic

153
00:07:16.810 --> 00:07:19.690
from the outside that's authenticating,
then they could do that.

154
00:07:19.690 --> 00:07:23.630
But as far as inside goes sniffing is one.

155
00:07:23.630 --> 00:07:26.635
The other one would just be
password cracking, right?

156
00:07:26.635 --> 00:07:28.955
I'm trying to break the password.

157
00:07:28.955 --> 00:07:33.332
Trying to, well, yeah,
there are no other way to say it.

158
00:07:33.332 --> 00:07:34.406
>> Yeah.
>> I have to break the password, right.

159
00:07:34.406 --> 00:07:35.430
>> Kinda comes down.

160
00:07:35.430 --> 00:07:36.988
>> Yeah, so how do we do that?

161
00:07:36.988 --> 00:07:38.465
What can we do?

162
00:07:38.465 --> 00:07:39.895
How can I break their password?

163
00:07:39.895 --> 00:07:41.985
Well, the easiest one.

164
00:07:41.985 --> 00:07:45.295
When I say easy,
I don't mean easy as in easy to succeed,

165
00:07:45.295 --> 00:07:48.670
but easy to perform is password guessing.

166
00:07:48.670 --> 00:07:49.358
Easy enough.

167
00:07:49.358 --> 00:07:52.175
I just go to the authentication
dialogue box, and

168
00:07:52.175 --> 00:07:55.135
I know his user name is dlowrie so
I put that in there.

169
00:07:55.135 --> 00:07:57.400
And then I start typing in passwords and
hit Enter.

170
00:07:57.400 --> 00:08:00.158
And if it works, great,
if it doesn't Guess something else,

171
00:08:00.158 --> 00:08:02.199
that's what password

00:20:06.380 --> 00:20:06.950
A 0 or a 1.

401
00:20:06.950 --> 00:20:09.670
Well, if I have a three
character password and

it's in binary, how many possible
passwords can I come up with?

403
00:20:13.060 --> 00:20:15.690
Two to the third, 2 times 2 is 4.

00:20:15.690 --> 00:20:19.735
Times 2 is 8, so there's eight possible
passwords I could come up with.

405
00:20:19.735 --> 00:20:20.605
Zero, zero, zero.

406
00:20:20.605 --> 00:20:22.385
Zero, zero, one.

407
00:20:22.385 --> 00:20:23.965
Zero, one, zero, one, zero.

408
00:20:23.965 --> 00:20:25.555
I could go through all of them,
you guys get the idea.

00:20:25.555 --> 00:20:29.655
So there's eight possible passwords
with a three character binary password.

410
00:20:29.655 --> 00:20:33.855
Add one character, let's say we'll
do a four character binary password.

00:20:33.855 --> 00:20:36.830
So does the number of possibilities
go from eight to nine?

412
00:20:36.830 --> 00:20:41.140
Now, two to the fourth, 2 times 2 is 4,
times 2 is 8, times 2 is 16.

413
00:20:41.140 --> 00:20:46.250
So by adding one character I double
the number of possibilities for

414
00:20:46.250 --> 00:20:47.980
that password, right?

415
00:20:47.980 --> 00:20:49.050
And that's what we're trying to do,

416
00:20:49.050 --> 00:20:52.820
is increase the overall
number of possibilities.

417
00:20:52.820 --> 00:20:55.350
When we look at our passwords we're
using letters and numbers and

418
00:20:55.350 --> 00:20:56.610
special characters.

419
00:20:56.610 --> 00:21:01.050
If I'm only using letters is 26 lower
case less than English language.

420
00:21:01.050 --> 00:21:03.946
So if they had a three password,

421
00:21:03.946 --> 00:21:08.679
three character password,
it would be a what 26?

422
00:21:08.679 --> 00:21:12.310
No, it would be 26 to the third,
all right.

423
00:21:12.310 --> 00:21:13.380
If you, I dont

00:21:13.380 --> 00:21:14.760
know what that number is by heart
>> [LAUGH]

425
00:21:14.760 --> 00:21:16.410
>> But if you, yes, it's big.

00:21:16.410 --> 00:21:19.870
But if you add one character
now it is 26 to the fourth.

00:21:19.870 --> 00:21:23.980
So you've multiplied the results
of the last one by 26 basically.

428
00:21:23.980 --> 00:21:27.340
So you are increasing it
exponentially each character you add.

429
00:21:27.340 --> 00:21:30.785
So going from a seven character
password to an eight character

430
00:21:30.785 --> 00:21:34.510
password increases the number
of possibilities exponentially.

431
00:21:35.670 --> 00:21:38.870
Then if you add complexity into it

432
00:21:38.870 --> 00:21:42.420
you're increasing the number of
possibilities per character.

433
00:21:42.420 --> 00:21:43.550
That's really what we're doing.

434
00:21:43.550 --> 00:21:46.840
The length is the number
of possibilities overall.

435
00:21:46.840 --> 00:21:50.260
The character sets the number
of possibilities per character.

436
00:21:50.260 --> 00:21:53.550
I was saying if it's just lowercase,
26 to the third.

437
00:21:53.550 --> 00:21:56.930
But if you're using uppercase and
lowercase, now we're up to 52.

438
00:21:56.930 --> 00:22:01.670
You add in numbers and special characters,
there's 10 numbers, zero through nine.

439
00:22:01.670 --> 00:22:04.710
And there's 32 special characters, so
now we're up to somewhere around 96.

440
00:22:04.710 --> 00:22:09.820
So now it's 96 to the third
instead of 26 to the third.

441
00:22:09.820 --> 00:22:10.450
Right?

442
00:22:10.450 --> 00:22:12.590
Big, big difference in
the number of possibilities.

443
00:22:12.590 --> 00:22:17.140
So yes, long, long is good but
you've gotta make it complex also

444
00:22:17.140 --> 00:22:20.070
to increase the number of
possibilities per character.

00:22:20.070 --> 00:22:23.060
>> But Mike, I have such a hard time

Pass phrases are really good
because they're gonna be long,

00:22:32.210 --> 00:22:35.460

00:22:35.460 --> 00:22:40.700
I have heard methods of like,

00:22:40.700 --> 00:22:42.620
do the first and

00:22:42.620 --> 00:22:46.300
Or the first letter of every word,

453
00:22:47.505 --> 00:22:49.615
But many different methods
you could use to generate.

00:22:49.615 --> 00:22:51.745
And you can use password generators too,

455
00:22:51.745 --> 00:22:55.565
which come up with random strings

456
00:22:55.565 --> 00:22:58.045
Anyway, this is not a class about
making strong passwords, so

457
00:22:58.045 --> 00:22:59.065
we'll get back to the point.

458
00:22:59.065 --> 00:23:00.585
How do we crack these passwords?

459
00:23:01.625 --> 00:23:05.275
We talked about password guessing,
we talked about brute forcing,

460
00:23:05.275 --> 00:23:07.215
we talked about dictionary attacks.

461
00:23:07.215 --> 00:23:11.320
The last one I wanna talk about

462
00:23:11.320 --> 00:23:12.380
All right.

463
00:23:12.380 --> 00:23:16.230
When we store passwords most of
the password databases they're gonna

464
00:23:16.230 --> 00:23:19.410
store them in an encrypted format
they're not juts talking your password,

465
00:23:19.410 --> 00:23:21.980
and storing it in that database.

466
00:23:21.980 --> 00:23:24.490
They're running it through what's
called a hashing algorithm.

467
00:23:24.490 --> 00:23:29.950
Generating a hash value, which is
an encrypted version of your password.

468
00:23:29.950 --> 00:23:33.150
And the cool thing about hash values or
hashing algorithms.

469
00:23:33.150 --> 00:23:37.410
The output there, that hash value,
is unreversible, right?

470
00:23:37.410 --> 00:23:40.540
Hashes, hashing algorithms,
are one-way encryption.

471
00:23:40.540 --> 00:23:43.820
In other words, once I've encrypted
that password using the hash value,

472
00:23:43.820 --> 00:23:45.785
if somebody steals that hash value.

473
00:23:45.785 --> 00:23:48.975
They're not gonna be able to
reverse engineer the encryption and

474
00:23:48.975 --> 00:23:50.779
get the original password back out.

475
00:23:50.779 --> 00:23:57.357
That's just the way hashes work because
they have a fixed length output.

476
00:23:57.357 --> 00:24:02.947
It's not gonna be reversible I shouldn't
say it's not possible, but it's very,

477
00:24:02.947 --> 00:24:08.871
very, very unlikely that you could reverse
that, and that's what makes Azure so good.

478
00:24:08.871 --> 00:24:14.026
But, what I can do, because of the fact
that it's a fixed length output, right,

479
00:24:14.026 --> 00:24:18.807
in other words, I can take, if I've
got hashing algorithm, and I take four

480
00:24:18.807 --> 00:24:23.963
characters, let's say the word blue, and
I put it into this hashing algorithm,

481
00:24:23.963 --> 00:24:28.671
that hashing algorithm, it might
output a 256 bit string, but if I take

482
00:24:28.671 --> 00:24:33.505
a whole sentence and put it through there,
the output is still 256 bits.

483
00:24:33.505 --> 00:24:36.527
That's the algorithm itself defines that,

484
00:24:36.527 --> 00:24:41.618
which means there's not a one-on-one
relationship between the input and

485
00:24:41.618 --> 00:24:46.251
the output, in other words,
there's going to be some collisions.

486
00:24:46.251 --> 00:24:50.751
That means more than one input could end
up generating the same output in this

487
00:24:50.751 --> 00:24:54.549
hashing algorithm, and
that's where rainbow tables come in,

488
00:24:54.549 --> 00:24:59.541
because what I need to authenticate it's
you is not your password, I need something

489
00:24:59.541 --> 00:25:04.534
that's gonna generate the same hash value
as your password did when it was encrypted

490
00:25:04.534 --> 00:25:08.863
because in the account database,
it's the hash value that's stored.

491
00:25:08.863 --> 00:25:11.824
So, if whatever I put in
the authentication box,

492
00:25:11.824 --> 00:25:16.408
gets run through the hashing algorithm and
generates a matching hash value,

493
00:25:16.408 --> 00:25:20.428
it's gonna assume that I must have
inputed the right information,

494
00:25:20.428 --> 00:25:24.966
because the right output came out,
and so it's gonna let me authenticate.

495
00:25:24.966 --> 00:25:26.987
I don't need to know your password,

496
00:25:26.987 --> 00:25:30.322
I need to know something that
generates the same hash value.

497
00:25:30.322 --> 00:25:33.715
So what rainbow tables are,
is where somebody has sat and

498
00:25:33.715 --> 00:25:36.827
just started running
everything they can think of,

499
00:25:36.827 --> 00:25:40.518

and generating the output.

500
00:25:40.518 --> 00:25:44.796
So now what I can do, is I can,
here's Daniel's hash for his password,

501
00:25:44.796 --> 00:25:49.638
maybe I captured it as it was traveling

00:25:49.638 --> 00:25:53.737
they encrypted it, it's not plain text,
but I got that hash value.

503
00:25:53.737 --> 00:25:57.433
Now I can go to the rainbow table,

504
00:25:57.433 --> 00:26:01.459
I can find a match for that hash value,

505
00:26:01.459 --> 00:26:05.096
it's going to tell me what they
used to generate that hash value.

506
00:26:05.096 --> 00:26:08.725
Now I can turn around and use that
to authenticate as you, all right?

507
00:26:08.725 --> 00:26:15.329
That's the way rainbow tables work,
they are losing their effectiveness as

we go with more Better hashing algorithms,

00:26:21.422 --> 00:26:25.335
Because as we get into,
I don't know, SHA-512, or

a higher hashing algorithms-

>> I don't know the output,
I just read about it the other day and

they said there are no

515
00:26:35.488 --> 00:26:36.460
>> Yet.
>> [LAUGH]

>> Because what happens is,

if the output string is long enough,

then I cannot generate a table big

00:26:48.219 --> 00:26:52.618
to get all the possible hash values,

520
00:26:52.618 --> 00:26:57.371
So with some of our older hashing
algorithms, like MD5, it was a small

521
00:26:57.371 --> 00:27:02.600
enough, I don't wanna say key space, but
it was small enough to where we could

00:27:02.600 --> 00:27:08.171
generate enough hash values to be able to

00:27:08.171 --> 00:27:11.880
So as those get better,
rainbow tables will be less efficient, but

00:27:11.880 --> 00:27:16.371
then what happens is computers become
more powerful, we can make bigger tables,

525
00:27:16.371 --> 00:27:19.364
we can store more,
we can search through it faster, so

00:27:19.364 --> 00:27:23.360
then maybe it does become a little
more useful at some point, all right?

527
00:27:23.360 --> 00:27:26.815
So a lot of different techniques
they can use to crack the password,

528

I'm gonna show you an example, when we

actually we'll do a dictionary attack,

But we've got sniffing the password,

Hopefully, you'll look forward to that as

For ITProTV,

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike demonstrate the use of Ncrack, a popular password cracking utility, to perform a dictionary attack against an SSH server.
episodes.title: Password Attacks Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explore the world of Exploit Frameworks. They begin by discussing the different Frameworks that you may encounter as a First Responder, including Metasploit, Core Impact, and CANVAS. Then then perform a demonstration of compromising a vulnerable system using Metasploit.
episodes.title: Gaining Access

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explore the common web attacks that are used by Threat Actors against web servers and clients. They begin by explaining Cross-Site Scripting(XSS) and Cross-Site Request Forgery attacks. Then they discuss the components of a SQL Injection attack. Finally, they finish by exploring Directory Traversal and Local/Remote File Inclusion (LFI/RFI) attacks.

our sequel injection for

480
00:26:07.290 --> 00:26:08.950
when we come back with another episode.

481
00:26:08.950 --> 00:26:10.420
>> Awesome.
Well, I look forward to seeing that.

482
00:26:10.420 --> 00:26:13.149
It's going to be really cool to
see how these things are done.

483
00:26:14.260 --> 00:26:16.260
When you see it,
it's actually gonna blow your mind,

484
00:26:16.260 --> 00:26:17.790
because it's not really that difficult.

485
00:26:17.790 --> 00:26:19.450
You just have to know a little
bit about a little bit.

486
00:26:19.450 --> 00:26:23.390
And then you should be able to throw
these commands at these web servers and

487
00:26:23.390 --> 00:26:25.951
they will return interesting results.

488
00:26:25.951 --> 00:26:26.900
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

489
00:26:26.900 --> 00:26:28.670
I'm really looking forward
to that part two, Mike.

490
00:26:28.670 --> 00:26:29.880
Hopefully you are as well.

491
00:26:29.880 --> 00:26:32.290
But like Mike was saying,
we are out of time for this episode.

492
00:26:32.290 --> 00:26:35.670
So we are going to have to call it a day,
thanks for watching.

493
00:26:35.670 --> 00:26:38.820
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lawrie.

494
00:26:38.820 --> 00:26:39.502
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

495
00:26:39.502 --> 00:26:41.012
>> And we'll see you next time.

496
00:26:41.012 --> 00:26:47.700
[MUSIC]

497
00:26:47.700 --> 00:26:50.513
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike continue exploring the common web attacks that are used by Threat Actors against web servers and clients. Here they walk you through a demonstration of a typical SQL Injection attack against a web server.
episodes.title: Web Attacks Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explain the concept of Malware. Here they carefully define what Malware is as well as explore the many different types of Malware that you may encounter. Finally, they discuss the methods of avoidance and remediation using Anti-Virus systems.
episodes.title: Malware
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.960 --> 00:00:07.346
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:07.346 --> 00:00:08.666
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.666 --> 00:00:12.615
You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.615 --> 00:00:13.865
>> All right, greetings everyone and

5
00:00:13.865 --> 00:00:16.935
welcome to another exciting
episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:16.935 --> 00:00:18.245
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, and

7
00:00:18.245 --> 00:00:22.115
in today's episode we are moving
on with more on our CFR Series.

8
00:00:22.115 --> 00:00:23.655
And joining us back in the studio for

9
00:00:23.655 --> 00:00:26.655
another great topic I'm sure,
our good friend Mr Mike Roderick.

10
00:00:26.655 --> 00:00:28.595
Mike, welcome back and how is it today?

11
00:00:28.595 --> 00:00:32.120
>> It's going great, pressure's on and
it's gonna be a great topic gosh darn.

12
00:00:32.120 --> 00:00:33.861
>> [LAUGH]
>> Like to set the bar high.

13
00:00:33.861 --> 00:00:36.478
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, thanks for having me back
and we're continuing on, as you said,

14
00:00:36.478 --> 00:00:37.799
with Logical Operation CFR-210.

15
00:00:37.799 --> 00:00:40.913
In this one we're gonna be
taking a look at malware, right?

16
00:00:40.913 --> 00:00:42.792
>> Dum, dum, dum!

17
00:00:42.792 --> 00:00:45.490
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, exactly.

18
00:00:45.490 --> 00:00:48.050
Eerie music going in the background.

19
00:00:48.050 --> 00:00:54.420
Malware is kind of a general term,
if you will, for something we don't want.

20
00:00:54.420 --> 00:00:56.100
When we talk about malware,

21
00:00:56.100 --> 00:00:59.380
malicious software is really
where this word came from.

22
00:00:59.380 --> 00:01:02.130
I forget the term when you
combine two words like that, but

23
00:01:02.130 --> 00:01:04.860
malicious software shortened to malware.

24
00:01:04.860 --> 00:01:09.630
It's kind of an all-encompassing umbrella
term for a lot of different categories.

25
00:01:09.630 --> 00:01:11.930
Things that we should be familiar with.

26
00:01:11.930 --> 00:01:14.140
So we're gonna go through a few
of those different categories,

27
00:01:14.140 --> 00:01:17.930
make sure we understand what they are,
what the differences are because

28
00:01:17.930 --> 00:01:21.020
we have to be able to one,
talk about it intelligently.

29
00:01:21.020 --> 00:01:24.360
Daniel I'm sure you've had this
several times, I know I have.

30
00:01:24.360 --> 00:01:25.333
People come to you and

31
00:01:25.333 --> 00:01:28.260
say, my gosh I've got a virus
can you help me fix my computer?

32
00:01:29.450 --> 00:01:30.580
They don't have a virus.

33
00:01:30.580 --> 00:01:32.758
What they've got is adware, right?

34
00:01:32.758 --> 00:01:36.070
That may be slowing their system down or
there's an update pending and

35
00:01:36.070 --> 00:01:37.283
they just need to reboot the system.

36
00:01:37.283 --> 00:01:39.100
>> [LAUGH]
>> Or something like that.

37
00:01:39.100 --> 00:01:40.761
>> That's nine times
out of ten right there.

38
00:01:40.761 --> 00:01:43.738
>> Yeah, but everybody calls
everything a virus because for

39
00:01:43.738 --> 00:01:46.480
the untrained person that works,
it's fine.

40
00:01:46.480 --> 00:01:49.440
But for us, if we're gonna talk
intelligently, if we're gonna do research,

41
00:01:49.440 --> 00:01:51.854
if we're going to protect and
understand this,

42
00:01:51.854 --> 00:01:54.360
we need to understand
the different categories.

43
00:01:54.360 --> 00:01:56.420
And not everything is nice and tidy,

44
00:01:56.420 --> 00:02:00.980
there are some things that'll overlap
a little bit, but let's go through them.

45
00:02:00.980 --> 00:02:03.390
We talk about a virus, first of all.

46
00:02:03.390 --> 00:02:09.690
A virus is malware or code that is
going to attach itself to a file.

47
00:02:09.690 --> 00:02:11.983
And when you receive an infected file,

48
00:02:11.983 --> 00:02:16.460
a file that has a virus attached to it,
you open that file up.

49
00:02:16.460 --> 00:02:19.320
Well that file is opened up, and
we know the way that computers work.

50
00:02:19.320 --> 00:02:22.940
That means that it's loaded up into RAM,
Random Access Memory, so

51
00:02:22.940 --> 00:02:25.540
that the application can work with it and
present it.

52
00:02:25.540 --> 00:02:26.570
Well, guess what?

53
00:02:26.570 --> 00:02:29.060
The virus that was attached to the file

54
00:02:29.060 --> 00:02:32.340
is also now a resident in
your Random Access Memory.

55
00:02:32.340 --> 00:02:34.577
And what it's going to do is look for

56
00:02:34.577 --> 00:02:38.914
anything else that you have open
currently and try to attach to that.

57
00:02:38.914 --> 00:02:42.452
And then, If it can or can't that's great,
but if you save that file and

58
00:02:42.452 --> 00:02:46.003
you send it to somebody else, they
open it up it loads into their memory.

59
00:02:46.003 --> 00:02:50.304
Anything they have open can then become
infected, they save and close their files,

60
00:02:50.304 --> 00:02:54.220
they send an attachment to somebody,
and so on and so forth, right?

61
00:02:54.220 --> 00:02:58.630
So viruses,
the key to the definition there on viruses

62
00:02:58.630 --> 00:03:00.800
is that it really needs
our help to spread.

63
00:03:00.800 --> 00:03:04.235
It can replicate from one file to
the other if we open it up and

64
00:03:04.235 --> 00:03:05.692
let it reside in memory.

65
00:03:05.692 --> 00:03:09.610
And we open other things up that aren't
infected, they can become infected.

66
00:03:09.610 --> 00:03:14.620
So it can replicate itself within
our system, the infected system.

67
00:03:14.620 --> 00:03:17.000
But to get from one system to another,

68
00:03:17.000 --> 00:03:18.980
that is going to require
human interaction.

69
00:03:18.980 --> 00:03:21.460
I'm gonna have to send
an infected file to somebody.

70
00:03:21.460 --> 00:03:24.705
They're gonna open it up,
infect their system, all their files,

71
00:03:24.705 --> 00:03:26.360
then they could send it.

72
00:03:26.360 --> 00:03:29.521
It's the old, and she told two friends and
so on and so on, right?

73
00:03:29.521 --> 00:03:30.240
>> That's correct.

74
00:03:30.240 --> 00:03:32.333
>> It starts growing or
spreading exponentially.

75
00:03:32.333 --> 00:03:35.859
But again, the key there is that viruses
need our help to spread because the two

76
00:03:35.859 --> 00:03:36.928
that people, I think,

77
00:03:36.928 --> 00:03:40.330
have the most trouble with
differentiating are viruses and worms.

78
00:03:40.330 --> 00:03:42.140
And let's jump to worm then.

79
00:03:42.140 --> 00:03:44.660
A worm is like a virus.

80
00:03:44.660 --> 00:03:46.860
It's code, malformed code or

81
00:03:46.860 --> 00:03:51.990
malicious code, but
it doesn't require our help, all right?

82
00:03:51.990 --> 00:03:56.010
A worm can replicate itself and
spread itself.

83
00:03:56.010 --> 00:03:59.340
Doesn't attach to files or to programs.

84
00:03:59.340 --> 00:04:01.840
It's basically stand alone,
almost like a file.

85
00:04:01.840 --> 00:04:04.160
Just like any other document
you might have on your system.

86
00:04:04.160 --> 00:04:05.720
>> So
it's much more intelligent than a virus.

87
00:04:05.720 --> 00:04:10.340
Where a virus requires us to basically
propagate it for it, the worm says,

88
00:04:10.340 --> 00:04:12.690
I don't need your help,
I can just do this all on my own.

89
00:04:12.690 --> 00:04:14.280
>> Yes, absolutely.

90
00:04:14.280 --> 00:04:17.000
Viruses typically do harm, right?

91
00:04:17.000 --> 00:04:20.340
Most of them are designed
to do something malicious,

92
00:04:20.340 --> 00:04:24.010
whether that is simply to
infect other files and spread.

93
00:04:24.010 --> 00:04:26.580
But usually it's going to cause
slowdowns on your system,

94
00:04:26.580 --> 00:04:30.910
it could attempt to remove
files from your system.

95
00:04:30.910 --> 00:04:32.430
Could harm your system in some way.

96
00:04:32.430 --> 00:04:36.330
Prevent the operating system from booting,
depending on what it is.

97
00:04:36.330 --> 00:04:41.260
Whereas worms a lot of times don't
really have any malicious payload

98
00:04:41.260 --> 00:04:44.910
other than the fact that they can
replicate like bunny rabbits, all right?

99
00:04:44.910 --> 00:04:49.770
What happens with worms because they're
self-replicating, they start replicating.

100
00:04:49.770 --> 00:04:53.230
You get one system infected on your
network and it starts replicating,

101
00:04:53.230 --> 00:04:56.400
looking for other systems that
are susceptible that it can infect.

102
00:04:56.400 --> 00:05:00.340
And it will get on to those guys, and
then begin the process again from there.

103
00:05:00.340 --> 00:05:05.530
Now you got three machines, four machines,
pretty soon your network is

104
00:05:05.530 --> 00:05:09.690
completely saturated with
replication traffic from this worm.

105
00:05:09.690 --> 00:05:14.050
It's generating so
much as it gets more and more systems.

106
00:05:14.050 --> 00:05:19.326
You can do an Internet search for SQL
Slammer and you'll find if you look for

107
00:05:19.326 --> 00:05:23.872
one of the moving heat maps you'll
see that it starts out small.

108
00:05:23.872 --> 00:05:28.329
And then starts growing faster and faster
and all of the sudden just goes bloop, and

109
00:05:28.329 --> 00:05:29.550
most of the map is red.

110
00:05:29.550 --> 00:05:31.138
>> [LAUGH]
>> Once it goes,

111
00:05:31.138 --> 00:05:33.990
again it's an exponential growth.

112
00:05:33.990 --> 00:05:38.600
And I know we got SQL Slammer at one
of the facilities I used to work at.

113
00:05:38.600 --> 00:05:41.440
Had a gentlemen that was doing some
instructing, had a SQL machine.

114
00:05:41.440 --> 00:05:46.350
This was way back when, and it was SQL
2000 running, but it was unpatched and

115
00:05:46.350 --> 00:05:48.970
gave it access to the Internet
not thinking about it.

116
00:05:48.970 --> 00:05:52.700
Did not take long,
got SQL Slammer on there.

117
00:05:52.700 --> 00:05:56.305
And within a few minutes,
I mean, it was not long.

118
00:05:56.305 --> 00:05:57.315
>> [CROSSTALK]
>> Our network was toast.

119
00:05:57.315 --> 00:05:58.148
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.

120
00:05:58.148 --> 00:06:00.528
>> And just trying to remove it is near,
I mean,

121
00:06:00.528 --> 00:06:04.910
you gotta start shutting everything down,
all right, to quiet the network.

122
00:06:04.910 --> 00:06:07.060
Cuz I can't remote into a system and
try to fix it, I mean,

123
00:06:07.060 --> 00:06:09.018
the network is just dead in the water.

124
00:06:09.018 --> 00:06:11.410
It was amazing.
>> There's been a few of those guys that

125
00:06:11.410 --> 00:06:13.760
have just really taken
the Internet by storm.

126
00:06:13.760 --> 00:06:17.180
I remember Code Red and
Nimda, things of that nature.

127
00:06:17.180 --> 00:06:18.440
They just spread like wildfire.

128
00:06:18.440 --> 00:06:20.040
And it's funny, if you go out and

129
00:06:20.040 --> 00:06:24.880
you do a Google search for how much
damages do those things actually cost?

130
00:06:24.880 --> 00:06:27.790
They are massive amounts of money,
it is crazy.

131
00:06:27.790 --> 00:06:30.650
Just through network disruption.

132
00:06:30.650 --> 00:06:31.600
>> Yeah, exactly.

133
00:06:31.600 --> 00:06:33.760
I mean no real malicious
payload to speak of.

134
00:06:33.760 --> 00:06:36.340
Not to say that they can't,
and they definitely can.

135
00:06:36.340 --> 00:06:38.110
But a lot of times,
that's really not the purpose of the worm.

136
00:06:38.110 --> 00:06:39.810
It's just to bring down the network,

137
00:06:39.810 --> 00:06:43.990
cause a denial of service on
as many people as they can.

138
00:06:43.990 --> 00:06:48.300
So viruses again, need our help to spread,
worms replicate on their own.

139
00:06:48.300 --> 00:06:52.310
Viruses are typically harder to get rid
of, because they're attached to files.

140
00:06:52.310 --> 00:06:56.960
And we oftentimes have difficulty
figuring out which files are infected.

141
00:06:56.960 --> 00:06:59.690
We can remove some files but
if we don't get all of them, and

142
00:06:59.690 --> 00:07:03.590
that one file gets opened up again,
the system's infected again.

143
00:07:03.590 --> 00:07:06.280
So they can be very tricky to eradicate.

144
00:07:06.280 --> 00:07:10.350
Whereas a worm, because it's
a standalone file, we can usually

145
00:07:10.350 --> 00:07:14.670
find it a little bit easier and get rid of
it, if we can get across the network or

146
00:07:14.670 --> 00:07:20.691
physically get to that machine to do
such an investigation, all right?

147
00:07:20.691 --> 00:07:23.360
Adware, software that
automatically displays or

148
00:07:23.360 --> 00:07:25.690
downloads unsolicited advertisements.

149
00:07:25.690 --> 00:07:31.000
This is another one that probably most
of us out there have maybe seen once or

150
00:07:31.000 --> 00:07:33.435
twice, maybe on your own machine, right?

151
00:07:33.435 --> 00:07:37.295
You get little ads that pop up,
little pop-ups.

152
00:07:37.295 --> 00:07:40.405
Most of our browsers are really
good at blocking those.

153
00:07:40.405 --> 00:07:44.315
Although now they do the pop-unders,
it's not quite the same.

154
00:07:44.315 --> 00:07:49.625
A lot of times adware is not malicious
other than the fact that it distracts you.

155
00:07:49.625 --> 00:07:50.235
>> It's annoying.

156
00:07:50.235 --> 00:07:50.955
>> And it's annoying.

157
00:07:52.000 --> 00:07:52.991
Yeah, it's annoying as heck.

158
00:07:52.991 --> 00:07:56.143
I mean, I have seen cases
where the adware was very bad,

159
00:07:56.143 --> 00:08:00.369
and even without opening up a browser,
just reboot the machine and log on,

160
00:08:00.369 --> 00:08:03.680
Ads start popping up and
basically covering the desktop.

161
00:08:03.680 --> 00:08:08.343
That was an extreme case, but a lots of
time again adware is just more annoying

162
00:08:08.343 --> 00:08:11.520
than it is harmful, but
it can slow the system down.

163
00:08:11.520 --> 00:08:14.060
It can take up resources,
which is not a good thing.

164
00:08:14.060 --> 00:08:18.950
And they're unsolicited, they can be
offensive depending on what the product is

165
00:08:18.950 --> 00:08:22.330
and if happens to be a product
that you find offensive.

166
00:08:22.330 --> 00:08:25.080
So, it's still not good.

167
00:08:25.080 --> 00:08:27.960
Spyware is another category
that we have to deal with.

168
00:08:27.960 --> 00:08:33.100
Spyware, the name pretty much tells you
everything you need to know about that.

169
00:08:33.100 --> 00:08:37.760
Software that's designed to track and
then report back.

170
00:08:37.760 --> 00:08:41.720
That could be keystroke loggers.

171
00:08:41.720 --> 00:08:44.560
It could track your web pages
that you're visiting and

172
00:08:44.560 --> 00:08:46.540
send that information off to somebody.

173
00:08:48.240 --> 00:08:52.720
It could b, taking screenshots
periodically of what you're doing.

174
00:08:52.720 --> 00:08:56.000
Every time you click your mouse, this
thing takes a screenshot in the background

175
00:08:56.000 --> 00:08:57.970
and starts FTPing it to a bad guy.

176
00:08:59.490 --> 00:09:01.530
So spyware can definitely be bad.

177
00:09:01.530 --> 00:09:05.280
A lot of times it's not
harmful to the machine.

178
00:09:05.280 --> 00:09:09.550
But it can be harmful to you or your
enterprise because you type in a password

179
00:09:09.550 --> 00:09:10.750
and now somebody has your password.

180
00:09:10.750 --> 00:09:14.320
You type in a bank account number and
information to log in and

181
00:09:14.320 --> 00:09:15.680
somebody can capture that information.

182
00:09:15.680 --> 00:09:18.630
So it can be very harmful, not so
much to the operating system or

183
00:09:18.630 --> 00:09:21.880
the computer, but to our data.

184
00:09:21.880 --> 00:09:25.870
And it's really up to
whoever creates the spyware

185
00:09:25.870 --> 00:09:26.969
what it is they're trying to collect.

186
00:09:28.060 --> 00:09:29.670
They might just want all
your personal pictures,

187
00:09:29.670 --> 00:09:31.760
you know, it just depends on
what they're trying to do.

188
00:09:31.760 --> 00:09:33.270
They can turn your camera on.

189
00:09:33.270 --> 00:09:36.140
You gotta be careful with these things.

190
00:09:36.140 --> 00:09:37.550
Trojan horses.

191
00:09:37.550 --> 00:09:42.040
A Trojan horse, most of us are probably

192
00:09:42.040 --> 00:09:46.720
familiar with the story of the Greeks and
the Trojans and how that works.

193
00:09:46.720 --> 00:09:50.360
And it's a very similar concept and
why they called it a Trojan horse.

194
00:09:50.360 --> 00:09:54.280
And the idea is, I need to get
a malicious payload onto a system.

195
00:09:54.280 --> 00:09:57.900
But I know they're not going to click
a link if it says, hey, malicious payload.

196
00:09:57.900 --> 00:09:59.280
Click here, right?

197
00:09:59.280 --> 00:10:00.390
Please infect your machine.

198
00:10:00.390 --> 00:10:01.520
You want all your files to be.

199
00:10:01.520 --> 00:10:02.235
>> You'd be surprised, Mike.

200
00:10:02.235 --> 00:10:03.126
[LAUGH] You'd be surprised.

201
00:10:03.126 --> 00:10:05.000
>> [LAUGH] Would you like to
delete all your files at once?

202
00:10:05.000 --> 00:10:05.700
Click here.

203
00:10:05.700 --> 00:10:08.620
So usually it's a little more difficult.

204
00:10:08.620 --> 00:10:10.410
So what we do is we wrap it up.

205
00:10:10.410 --> 00:10:11.090
Right?

206
00:10:11.090 --> 00:10:14.920
A Trojan horse is software that
pretends to be something you want.

207
00:10:14.920 --> 00:10:20.102
When in fact it has a malicious payload of
something that you absolutely do not want.

208
00:10:20.102 --> 00:10:20.836
Alright.

209
00:10:20.836 --> 00:10:25.650
We used to use a lot of those
e-greeting cards as wrappers.

210
00:10:25.650 --> 00:10:29.170

Most software like this will let you have.

It does a scan eventually and

It's focused on spyware.

What can we do to prevent from

00:33:06.910 --> 00:33:10.160
All very important tasks as

00:33:10.160 --> 00:33:12.450

Anybody that has a computer, turns it on,

These are concepts and

No, stay safe out there.

Don't click on links that you

[LAUGH] That being said, it looks like

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike jump into the fascinating world of Man-in-the-Middle attacks. They begin by defining what Man-in-the-Middle(MitM) attacks are and then further explore the different types of MitMs that you may encounter. This includes ARP Spoofing, DHCP Spoofing, Session Hijacking, and DNS Poisoning.

00:00:25.670 --> 00:00:28.810
And of course joining me in the studio
to lend his vast knowledge,

9
00:00:28.810 --> 00:00:31.190
to that very topic is our good friend Mr.
Mike Rodrick.

10
00:00:31.190 --> 00:00:32.120
Mike welcome back sir.

11
00:00:32.120 --> 00:00:34.245
>> Thank you very much,
thanks for having me back and

12
00:00:34.245 --> 00:00:36.025
yeah we're gonna as you say continue on.

13
00:00:36.025 --> 00:00:41.169
In this one we're gonna be looking at
what we call man-in-the-middle attack,

14
00:00:41.169 --> 00:00:42.950
or MitM, for short.

15
00:00:42.950 --> 00:00:45.010
You might see that abbreviation now and
again.

16
00:00:45.010 --> 00:00:47.560
Capital M, little i, little t, capital M.

17
00:00:47.560 --> 00:00:48.823
And go,
what the heck are they talking about?

18
00:00:48.823 --> 00:00:50.980
>> [LAUGH]
>> Did they mistype M&Ms?

19
00:00:50.980 --> 00:00:52.700
That is one of my favorite candies.

20
00:00:52.700 --> 00:00:55.088
No, no,
it's a type of doctors abbreviation for.

21
00:00:55.088 --> 00:00:56.291
So, man in the middle.

22
00:00:56.291 --> 00:01:02.120
And the name kind of really tells
you a little bit about the attack.

23
00:01:02.120 --> 00:01:03.900
Right, man in the middle.

24
00:01:03.900 --> 00:01:05.960
That's maybe not politically correct,

25
00:01:05.960 --> 00:01:10.480
we should say person in the middle,
cuz it can definitely be a woman as well.

26
00:01:10.480 --> 00:01:16.290
But, the idea is that bad actor is
gonna get in-between a conversation.

27
00:01:16.290 --> 00:01:17.430
Sit in the middle, right.

28
00:01:17.430 --> 00:01:22.980
Imagine an end user, and they are
connecting to their financial institution,

29
00:01:22.980 --> 00:01:26.470
to check on their bank accounts, or
pay bills, or whatever the case may be.

30
00:01:26.470 --> 00:01:29.610
And me as the bad actor,
what I would like to do,

31
00:01:29.610 --> 00:01:35.130
is try to get in-between them and
have that conversation go through me.

32
00:01:35.130 --> 00:01:40.090
All right, so they can still talk to the
bank, the bank can still talk to them, but

33
00:01:40.090 --> 00:01:42.080
I'm gonna sit in between
their conversation.

34
00:01:42.080 --> 00:01:46.050
And what that means that I can do
as a bad actor, I can just view,

35
00:01:46.050 --> 00:01:48.360
I can do what we call passive
man in the middle attacks,

36
00:01:48.360 --> 00:01:50.450
where I'm just viewing
the data as it goes by.

37
00:01:50.450 --> 00:01:52.520
>> Seems like a form of
wire tapping almost,

38
00:01:52.520 --> 00:01:55.690
where you're just kind of tapping in and
listening to the conversation.

39
00:01:55.690 --> 00:01:57.360
So it should get
the information that you want.

40
00:01:57.360 --> 00:01:58.040
>> Absolutely right.

41
00:01:58.040 --> 00:01:59.470
That's really exactly what you're doing.

42
00:01:59.470 --> 00:02:00.950
You get to see it all go by.

43
00:02:00.950 --> 00:02:02.320
That would be passive.

44
00:02:02.320 --> 00:02:08.100
If you want to do an active man in
the middle, we can even modify that data.

45
00:02:08.100 --> 00:02:12.680
There are applications we can get,
that will allow me to kind of

46
00:02:12.680 --> 00:02:17.220
pause the conversation or pre-made some
packets, and try to slip them in there.

47
00:02:17.220 --> 00:02:20.562
Or modify packets again as they go by.

48
00:02:20.562 --> 00:02:25.710
In between my manager and the boss, I get
that email that says, hey we need to fire

49
00:02:25.710 --> 00:02:30.734
Mike, and I modify it a little bit, and
I say, hey we need to give Mike a raise.

50
00:02:30.734 --> 00:02:33.374
>> [LAUGH]
>> And pass it on, right.

51
00:02:33.374 --> 00:02:36.760
>> Why is Mike still here,
[LAUGH] What's he doing?

52
00:02:36.760 --> 00:02:38.295
>> Came back for my red stapler.

53
00:02:38.295 --> 00:02:39.300
>> Yeah, that's right.

54
00:02:39.300 --> 00:02:41.630
So that's the idea behind
man in the middle.

55
00:02:41.630 --> 00:02:46.750
And man in the middle attacks
can be tricky to pull off.

56
00:02:46.750 --> 00:02:50.270
But, there are a lot of tools out there,
that take the heavy lifting,

57
00:02:50.270 --> 00:02:52.490
as Daniel likes to say
out of the equation.

58
00:02:52.490 --> 00:02:54.380
And then it becomes really simple.

59
00:02:54.380 --> 00:02:56.320
Most of those cost a little bit of money.

60
00:02:57.590 --> 00:03:02.300
But, there's other ways to go about doing,
a man in the middle.

61
00:03:02.300 --> 00:03:04.560
And so,
some terms we need to be familiar with.

62
00:03:04.560 --> 00:03:07.110
And we'll talk a little bit about
a couple of the methods here.

63
00:03:07.110 --> 00:03:09.880
And then we'll do a little
demonstration on one way,

64
00:03:09.880 --> 00:03:13.960
that we might be able to perform
a man in the middle attack.

65
00:03:13.960 --> 00:03:17.390
Spoofing, impersonation,
and hijacking, all right.

66
00:03:17.390 --> 00:03:18.550
Terms we need to be familiar with.

67
00:03:18.550 --> 00:03:21.730
We need to understand
the difference between those terms.

68
00:03:21.730 --> 00:03:24.370
Because, sometimes spoofing and
impersonation, people will come and

69
00:03:24.370 --> 00:03:25.550
try to use them interchangeably.

70
00:03:25.550 --> 00:03:27.640
We're talking about
security computer systems.

71
00:03:27.640 --> 00:03:29.618
They definitely have different meanings.

72
00:03:29.618 --> 00:03:34.420
Spoofing is gonna be typically
a software based attack,

73
00:03:34.420 --> 00:03:36.700
where I try to take over the identity.

74
00:03:36.700 --> 00:03:41.250
Of a user, of a service,
of a computer, of something like that.

75
00:03:41.250 --> 00:03:42.240
I'm gonna pretend,

76
00:03:42.240 --> 00:03:46.470
I want the network to think I'm the DNS
server that everybody's supposed to use.

77
00:03:46.470 --> 00:03:47.930
I'm not, I'm the bad guy.

78
00:03:47.930 --> 00:03:50.480
But I'm gonna spoof, I'm gonna pretend
to the network and say, hey, I'm Mr.

79
00:03:50.480 --> 00:03:52.820
DNS server, come talk to me, right.

80
00:03:52.820 --> 00:03:55.420
That'd be the idea behind spoofing.

81
00:03:55.420 --> 00:03:58.490
Or you can forge IP address to spoof, and

82
00:03:58.490 --> 00:04:01.840
make it look like you are a node
that belongs on the network.

83
00:04:01.840 --> 00:04:05.110
Even though you're coming from the outside
interface on that router, you've got

84
00:04:05.110 --> 00:04:09.560
an address that looks like all the other
machines on the local area network.

85
00:04:09.560 --> 00:04:11.330
Maybe the router doesn't pay attention,

86
00:04:11.330 --> 00:04:13.678
the rules aren't set up correctly,
allows it to come through.

87
00:04:13.678 --> 00:04:20.470
Impersonation is human-based attack,
I guess you could say.

88
00:04:20.470 --> 00:04:23.640
That's when I'm gonna pretend
to be somebody I'm not.

89
00:04:23.640 --> 00:04:28.690
This is me putting on the jumpsuit,
the work suit, the overalls.

90
00:04:28.690 --> 00:04:29.590
And coming in and

91
00:04:29.590 --> 00:04:33.070
saying, hey I'm here to work on your
air conditioning in the server closet.

92
00:04:33.070 --> 00:04:35.010
Right, can you show me the way,
open the door?

93
00:04:35.010 --> 00:04:36.790
That would be impersonation.

94
00:04:36.790 --> 00:04:42.190
A lot of times, impersonation is
done remotely, like phone calls.

95
00:04:42.190 --> 00:04:44.310
You call up,
you say you're from the help desk, and

96
00:04:44.310 --> 00:04:47.130
you try to get somebody
to give you information.

97
00:04:47.130 --> 00:04:49.600
You're impersonating
a help desk personnel.

98
00:04:49.600 --> 00:04:51.920
So, it's a social engineering type attack,
but

99
00:04:51.920 --> 00:04:55.530
you're using impersonation
to try to accomplish that.

100
00:04:55.530 --> 00:04:58.665
And in large companies where
you don't know everybody,

101
00:04:58.665 --> 00:05:03.251
it's relatively easy to do, especially if
you can drop a couple of names in there.

102
00:05:03.251 --> 00:05:08.223
People are, when they can't
verify your identity easily,

103
00:05:08.223 --> 00:05:12.807
they're usually more likely
to give you information.

104
00:05:12.807 --> 00:05:16.900
Right, I know it sounds weird but
I don't know.

105
00:05:16.900 --> 00:05:19.600
It sounds like the guy from the help desk.

106
00:05:19.600 --> 00:05:22.300
I think Joe is one of
the guys on the help desk.

107
00:05:22.300 --> 00:05:25.740
I don't want to embarrass myself,
and say who are you?

108
00:05:25.740 --> 00:05:26.980
Yeah, yeah here's my user name.

109
00:05:26.980 --> 00:05:29.080
Here's my password, kind of thing.

110
00:05:29.080 --> 00:05:30.371
>> Prey on our insecurities, right?

111
00:05:30.371 --> 00:05:31.610
>> Yeah, absolutely.

112
00:05:31.610 --> 00:05:36.450
And then people's desire to be liked,
to be helpful, to get praise.

113
00:05:36.450 --> 00:05:40.750
It's a really cool psychological
journey going into the world of social

114
00:05:40.750 --> 00:05:42.528
engineering, if you're
into that kinda thing.

115
00:05:43.720 --> 00:05:45.440
All right, so that's impersonation.

116
00:05:45.440 --> 00:05:50.650
And then session hijacking, is when I
try to take over an existing session.

117
00:05:50.650 --> 00:05:52.980
A lot of times man-in-the-middle attacks,

118
00:05:52.980 --> 00:05:55.680
are precursors to session
hijacking attacks.

119
00:05:55.680 --> 00:05:58.950
Where I can maybe get in
between the conversation, and

120
00:05:58.950 --> 00:06:02.880
then knock the other end off and
continue to talk to server,

121
00:06:02.880 --> 00:06:06.550
it thinking that I was the person
that I knocked offline, right?

122
00:06:06.550 --> 00:06:09.570
So, taking over a session, sometimes
that's the easier route to go for

123
00:06:09.570 --> 00:06:10.690
the bad guys.

124
00:06:10.690 --> 00:06:15.260
And rather than try to break into your
account, get your information so that I

125
00:06:15.260 --> 00:06:19.010
can authenticate as you, how about I just
wait until you authenticate, push you out

126
00:06:19.010 --> 00:06:23.650
of the way, step in your place, and you've
already done the authentication, right.

127
00:06:23.650 --> 00:06:27.140
So, now I can kinda take over
that conversation, all right.

128
00:06:27.140 --> 00:06:29.610
So, those are the terms we need
to be familiar with, spoofing,

129
00:06:29.610 --> 00:06:32.100
impersonation, session hijacking.

130
00:06:32.100 --> 00:06:33.723
Now, let's talk about some of
these different spoofing methods.

131
00:06:33.723 --> 00:06:36.531
There's different protocols
that we can do this with, or

132
00:06:36.531 --> 00:06:38.920
different ways we can go about spoofing.

133
00:06:38.920 --> 00:06:42.790
A common one that we see is ARP spoofing.

134
00:06:42.790 --> 00:06:46.980
ARP, if you remember back to your Network+
days, your Address Resolution Protocol.

135
00:06:46.980 --> 00:06:49.350
And if we think about
the way networks work,

136
00:06:49.350 --> 00:06:55.220
the way data is transmitted using
TCP/IP on an ethernet based network,

137
00:06:55.220 --> 00:07:00.150
we know that the packets get routed
via the network address, right.

138
00:07:00.150 --> 00:07:02.140
So, it's looking at the network address,
and

139
00:07:02.140 --> 00:07:06.660
it's looking at the routers figuring
out what the best route to go is.

140
00:07:06.660 --> 00:07:08.880
They finally get into
the local area network.

141
00:07:08.880 --> 00:07:12.470
That network, whatever that network
ID is it gets to the network.

142
00:07:12.470 --> 00:07:14.970
Once the router gets it to that network,

143
00:07:14.970 --> 00:07:21.070
the last leg of the journey is
actually done using the MAC address.

144
00:07:21.070 --> 00:07:23.580
So IP, the IP portion of TCPIP,

145
00:07:23.580 --> 00:07:27.930
the IP protocol, internet protocol
is gonna call upon ARP and say,

146
00:07:27.930 --> 00:07:33.470
hey look what is the MAC address for
10.1.2.3?

147
00:07:33.470 --> 00:07:39.380
And ARP is a broadcast-based,
the node that has that, which should

148
00:07:39.380 --> 00:07:42.630
be able to hear it, because remember
broadcast, limited to that subnet, but

149
00:07:42.630 --> 00:07:46.380
we've already made it to the destination
network, so that node should hear this.

150
00:07:46.380 --> 00:07:49.010
And that node should respond and
say hey, that's me.

151
00:07:49.010 --> 00:07:51.122
My MAC address, that's me, 10.1.2.3.

152
00:07:51.122 --> 00:07:57.327
Here's my MAC address, and then the packet
can make the final leg of the journey.

153
00:07:57.327 --> 00:08:01.910
The ARP information is cached by
the nodes, they keep a little ARP table.

154
00:08:01.910 --> 00:08:04.800
And the ARP is not a real secure protocol.

155
00:08:04.800 --> 00:08:06.760
It wasn't designed to be secure.

156
00:08:06.760 --> 00:08:10.370
And unfortunately what nodes do
is they hear these ARP requests,

157
00:08:10.370 --> 00:08:13.320
because they're broadcasts,
they hear the replies, and

158
00:08:13.320 --> 00:08:17.000
they all start caching this information,
or they can.

159
00:08:17.000 --> 00:08:19.490
But they'll cache,
when they get a response, they cache that.

160
00:08:19.490 --> 00:08:22.810
And if they get another response,
they'll cache that and

161
00:08:22.810 --> 00:08:24.190
they'll overwrite the original cache.

162
00:08:24.190 --> 00:08:27.840
Like if, well in our case,
we're gonna try to do some spoofing.

163
00:08:27.840 --> 00:08:32.450
We might change that IP address to the
same MAC address and when that node hears

164
00:08:32.450 --> 00:08:35.060
it, and goes to cache it, he's like wait,
I already have that MAC address.

165
00:08:35.060 --> 00:08:36.800
I'll just override it you know.

166
00:08:36.800 --> 00:08:39.280
If it was the same IP address and
MAC address.

167
00:08:39.280 --> 00:08:40.990
Or well, I'll show you.

168
00:08:40.990 --> 00:08:43.300
We'll take a look at it and
I'll give you a better view.

169
00:08:43.300 --> 00:08:46.730
It's hard to kind of describe that,
but that's what ARP spoofing is about,

170
00:08:46.730 --> 00:08:53.610
trying to convince the network that my MAC
address is what goes with that IP address.

171
00:08:53.610 --> 00:08:58.080
The packet might have been destined for
the IP address of the server, right.

172
00:08:58.080 --> 00:09:00.690
But what I'm gonna do is
let the network know that,

173
00:09:00.690 --> 00:09:04.150
hey, that Mac address goes to
my IP address, not the servers.

174
00:09:04.150 --> 00:09:05.640
Then the packet will get delivered to me.

175
00:09:05.640 --> 00:09:08.470
Because, I'm going to respond and
say, that's my IP address.

176
00:09:08.470 --> 00:09:10.520
Here's my Mac address,
and let it come over.

177
00:09:10.520 --> 00:09:11.850
All right.

178
00:09:11.850 --> 00:09:12.610
So, ARP spoofing.

179
00:09:13.650 --> 00:09:17.310
Then, as far as what we can do
with ARP Spoofing or protecting or

180
00:09:17.310 --> 00:09:18.620
litigating their risks?

181
00:09:18.620 --> 00:09:20.840
It's not a lot that we can do.

182
00:09:20.840 --> 00:09:25.130
You can make the ARP table static.

183
00:09:25.130 --> 00:09:28.660
You can tell it to where it's not
allowed to overwrite and cache that.

184
00:09:28.660 --> 00:09:32.830
>> Give it that whole dynamic ARP
updating thing that they have built in.

185
00:09:32.830 --> 00:09:35.060
>> Yeah, which eliminates that thread.

186
00:09:35.060 --> 00:09:39.610
But it also is a bare to
manage because as you add new

187
00:09:39.610 --> 00:09:43.940
nodes you got to make sure those
are entered into that arc table.

188
00:09:43.940 --> 00:09:47.370
And if anything changes,
that's got to be updated.

189
00:09:47.370 --> 00:09:50.620
So it's It's really difficult
to do that a lot of times.

190
00:09:50.620 --> 00:09:54.210
If they are going to do this, they'll do
it on just specific nodes that people

191
00:09:54.210 --> 00:09:59.560
might be trying to attack by file servers,
by DNS servers.

192
00:09:59.560 --> 00:10:02.110
I'll just do it on those,
not on every one on the network.

193
00:10:03.360 --> 00:10:06.700
Even then, it can be a little
bit of a bear to manage.

194
00:10:06.700 --> 00:10:11.700
You can create subnets because
ARP is a broadcast protocol then

195
00:10:12.740 --> 00:10:14.430
they won't go beyond the subnet.

196
00:10:14.430 --> 00:10:17.660
So I can't spoof anything
on a different subnet.

197
00:10:17.660 --> 00:10:19.170
It's only gonna work on the subnet I'm on.

198
00:10:19.170 --> 00:10:22.990
It doesn't help the subnet I'm on but
it does help the rest of my network.

199
00:10:22.990 --> 00:10:25.970
Instead of one big network we
create several subnets and

200
00:10:25.970 --> 00:10:27.550
it mitigates that risk a little bit.

201
00:10:27.550 --> 00:10:30.350
>> You just did a little clever
administration there with your

202
00:10:30.350 --> 00:10:31.470
network and you can.

203
00:10:31.470 --> 00:10:34.420
Like you said,
mitigate that down to not being such

204
00:10:34.420 --> 00:10:36.260
an atom bomb inside of your network.

205
00:10:36.260 --> 00:10:39.130
>> Exactly, because I really need
to do spoofing on both ends.

206
00:10:39.130 --> 00:10:41.260
I need to convince the client
that I'm the server.

207
00:10:41.260 --> 00:10:43.510
I need to convince the server
that I'm the client.

208
00:10:43.510 --> 00:10:44.850
If those guys are on different subnets,

209
00:10:44.850 --> 00:10:47.120
how can I spoof both of
them at the same time?

210
00:10:47.120 --> 00:10:50.060
That's going to be challenging there.

211
00:10:50.060 --> 00:10:53.820
You can also set up your IDS,
your intrusion detection systems,

212
00:10:53.820 --> 00:10:59.870
to maybe start monitoring for
multiple ARP change requests,

213
00:10:59.870 --> 00:11:03.480
updates to caches to look for
abnormal activity there.

214
00:11:03.480 --> 00:11:07.970
All right another one we need to worry
about is good old DNS poisoning.

215
00:11:07.970 --> 00:11:09.280
And with DNS poisoning.

216
00:11:10.330 --> 00:11:14.370
There's DNS poisoning and DNS hijacking,

217
00:11:14.370 --> 00:11:17.080
I wanna make sure we understand
the difference between the two.

218
00:11:17.080 --> 00:11:20.590
With DNS poisoning,
we're actually attacking the DNS server.

219
00:11:20.590 --> 00:11:24.370
Or we're using the DNS server
to facilitate our attack,

220
00:11:24.370 --> 00:11:26.100
is probably a better way to say it.

221
00:11:26.100 --> 00:11:28.910
What I'm gonna do, and
if you're not familiar with the way

222
00:11:28.910 --> 00:11:32.210
DNS works you should probably
go do a little research on that.

223
00:11:32.210 --> 00:11:35.550
But the short version is,
when you send a query,

224
00:11:35.550 --> 00:11:37.210
a question to your local DNS server.

225
00:11:37.210 --> 00:11:40.970
And if it's not authoritative for that
namespace, it's not your organization,

226
00:11:40.970 --> 00:11:43.090
you're trying to connect to Google,
or Microsoft,

227
00:11:43.090 --> 00:11:44.820
or Ebay, or something like that.

228
00:11:44.820 --> 00:11:48.680
Your DNS server who is not authoritative
has to go find the IP address for

229
00:11:48.680 --> 00:11:50.310
the destination you're looking for.

230
00:11:50.310 --> 00:11:53.060
And he does that by talking
to a series of hosts or

231
00:11:53.060 --> 00:11:55.070
DNS servers out there on the internet.

232
00:11:55.070 --> 00:12:00.530
And what we can try to do is send

233
00:12:00.530 --> 00:12:06.160
a query to our DNS server for some fake
domain, all right, just some made up name.

234
00:12:06.160 --> 00:12:07.750
Well, it's not gonna be authoritative for
it.
