And they should be in order.

461
00:24:07.400 --> 00:24:10.350
We've got synchronization,
acknowledgement requests.

462
00:24:10.350 --> 00:24:12.500
We've got our sequence number for
the packets.

463
00:24:12.500 --> 00:24:14.220
And there's an order they go.

464
00:24:14.220 --> 00:24:20.310
Now way back in the day, those
sequence numbers were one, two, three.

465
00:24:20.310 --> 00:24:21.430
What comes after three?

466
00:24:22.440 --> 00:24:23.500
Four, five-
>> 17.

467
00:24:23.500 --> 00:24:25.430
>> Yes, 17, [LAUGH] all right.

468
00:24:25.430 --> 00:24:27.650
So it was easy to predict, so

469
00:24:27.650 --> 00:24:30.120
what I could do is I could try
to step in the conversation.

470
00:24:30.120 --> 00:24:32.950
And I can knock this guy offline,
and step in his place and

471
00:24:32.950 --> 00:24:34.370
take over that conversation.

472
00:24:34.370 --> 00:24:36.080
But I better have my
sequence number right.

473
00:24:36.080 --> 00:24:38.880
Otherwise, when my packet gets to
the other end of the conversation,

474
00:24:38.880 --> 00:24:42.140
it's gonna say, wait a second,
we were on one, two, three, four.

475
00:24:42.140 --> 00:24:46.660
I was expecting five and you sent 20,
something's not right here, all right?

476
00:24:46.660 --> 00:24:49.466
So, we need to be able to predict that
sequence number and way back when,

477
00:24:49.466 --> 00:24:52.053
it was a lot easier because we
used incremental sequence numbers.

478
00:24:52.053 --> 00:24:56.880
It might have been ten, 20, 30, 5,
10, 15, 1, 2, 3, what have you.

479
00:24:56.880 --> 00:24:58.960
Nowadays we're much smarter than that.

480
00:24:58.960 --> 00:25:02.180
And there's actual algorithms that'll
generate those sequence numbers.

481
00:25:02.180 --> 00:25:04.240
They're not just one, two, three anymore.

482
00:25:04.240 --> 00:25:06.100
But that doesn't mean
there can't be a pattern.

483
00:25:06.100 --> 00:25:10.620
You look at a famous
attack by Kevin Mitnick,

484
00:25:10.620 --> 00:25:13.590
the one that he got in all the trouble for
and went to jail for.

485
00:25:13.590 --> 00:25:19.140
One of the first hackers to really be
prosecuted, make a big deal of it.

486
00:25:19.140 --> 00:25:22.260
The attack that he did
compromised a machine.

487
00:25:22.260 --> 00:25:27.910
I'm going to forget the guy's name now,
Shimomura, I can't remember the name.

488
00:25:27.910 --> 00:25:29.050
>> Yeah the guy that caught him.

489
00:25:29.050 --> 00:25:31.920
>> Yes, the one that actually got-
>> The Japanese fellow, yes.

490
00:25:31.920 --> 00:25:35.210
I know, it's, I can see his face.

491
00:25:35.210 --> 00:25:37.960
He used to wear glasses, got a big long
pony tail, I can't think of his name.

492
00:25:37.960 --> 00:25:39.560
>> I can't think of his
name to save my life.

493
00:25:39.560 --> 00:25:44.730
But anyway, the attack was actually
accomplished by doing that,

494
00:25:44.730 --> 00:25:48.670
by being able to predict
the sequence numbers.

495
00:25:48.670 --> 00:25:54.558
At that time it was 128,000 and
the next it would be what 240, 256, 2000.

496
00:25:54.558 --> 00:26:00.430
256,000, they were still incremental,
there was a pattern to them.

497
00:26:00.430 --> 00:26:04.010
And he was able to deduce that pattern and
then forge packets and

498
00:26:04.010 --> 00:26:05.288
jump into a conversation.

499
00:26:05.288 --> 00:26:12.140
So session hijacking, again,
taking over an existing conversation.

500
00:26:12.140 --> 00:26:14.730
We could use cross-site scripting, right?

501
00:26:14.730 --> 00:26:17.840
Steal somebody's cookie and
try to bump them out.

502
00:26:17.840 --> 00:26:20.690
It's Tsutomu Shimomura.

503
00:26:20.690 --> 00:26:21.880
Shimomura.

504
00:26:21.880 --> 00:26:23.610
Shimomura, there you go.

505
00:26:23.610 --> 00:26:24.370
>> That's the guy.

506
00:26:24.370 --> 00:26:29.060
>> Hopefully we said that correctly or
pronounced that close.

507
00:26:29.060 --> 00:26:31.500
Different tools that we can use for
hijacking and

508
00:26:31.500 --> 00:26:34.650
spoofing, Hping and
Nmap believe it or not.

509
00:26:34.650 --> 00:26:36.280
Nmap, Caine and Abel.

510
00:26:36.280 --> 00:26:40.900
Ettercap, which is one we're gonna
use in our demo here in a minute.

511
00:26:40.900 --> 00:26:45.660
Those are for spoofing, Hping,
I can create packets with it.

512
00:26:45.660 --> 00:26:48.610
Nmap, a lot of those programs will
allow you to spoof your IP address.

513
00:26:48.610 --> 00:26:52.090
You can run a scan, but there's
a switch I can use with it to say hey,

514
00:26:52.090 --> 00:26:56.300
when you send this port scan packets out,
don't put my address as the source.

515
00:26:56.300 --> 00:27:00.900
Put this address as the source so
we can hide ourselves.

516
00:27:00.900 --> 00:27:03.172
>> Don't implicate,
implicate the guy next to me.

517
00:27:03.172 --> 00:27:04.340
[LAUGH]
>> And all the sudden

518
00:27:04.340 --> 00:27:07.810
you're in your cubicle and the guy next to
you, SWAT team comes in, takes him down.

519
00:27:07.810 --> 00:27:10.920
And you're like,
he must have done something bad.

520
00:27:10.920 --> 00:27:14.592
[LAUGH] Session hijacking, cookie catcher,

521
00:27:14.592 --> 00:27:18.460
DroidSheep [LAUGH], Cookie Monsters,
I love the names they have to come up.

522
00:27:18.460 --> 00:27:18.970
>> Yeah, very clever.

523
00:27:18.970 --> 00:27:22.870
>> There's so many tools they have
to get creative with them, and

524
00:27:22.870 --> 00:27:24.790
they do, they really do.

525
00:27:24.790 --> 00:27:27.600
All right Daniel, I do wanna do
a demonstration, but I'm looking at

526
00:27:27.600 --> 00:27:30.660
the clock and I think you're getting
ready to tell me but we are out of time.

527
00:27:30.660 --> 00:27:32.960
>> Well, Mike, you know, it's funny,
is that I was looking at the clock,

528
00:27:32.960 --> 00:27:34.510
we actually are out of time.

529
00:27:34.510 --> 00:27:36.750
So, welcome to reality,
it's a fun fun thing.

530
00:27:36.750 --> 00:27:41.050
That being said, we will have to
close the show, but like Mike said,

531
00:27:41.050 --> 00:27:42.440
he's definitely got a demonstration.

532
00:27:42.440 --> 00:27:46.530
We don't want to just talk about what this
man in the middle stuff looks like, right,

533
00:27:46.530 --> 00:27:48.600
we want to show you what it looks like.

534
00:27:48.600 --> 00:27:51.630
So you take this theory we've
done here in part one and

535
00:27:51.630 --> 00:27:54.940
we're gonna apply it in part two,
see it practically work itself out.

536
00:27:54.940 --> 00:27:56.720
So definitely join us for that one.

537
00:27:56.720 --> 00:27:59.030
But Mike you are correct,
we are out of time for this episode.

538
00:27:59.030 --> 00:28:02.020
So looks like it's time for
us to sign off from ITProTV.

539
00:28:02.020 --> 00:28:03.870
I've been your host Daniel Lowery.

540
00:28:03.870 --> 00:28:04.720
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

541
00:28:04.720 --> 00:28:05.633
>> We'll see you next time.

542
00:28:05.633 --> 00:28:13.016
[MUSIC]

543
00:28:13.016 --> 00:28:15.989
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike demonstrate the process of performing a Man-in-the-Middle attack. Here they take you step-by-step through the use of Ettercap to initiate an ARP Cache Poisoning technique which will facilitate the MitM attack.
episodes.title: Man in the Middle Attacks Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Mike, discuss wireless centric attacks as well as concepts surrounding denial-of-services attack or DoS. They will look at various topics such as wireless cracking, wireless client attacks, infrastructure attacks as well as various types of DoS-based attacks
episodes.title: Wireless and DoS Attacks
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:02.383
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host Don.

2
00:00:02.383 --> 00:00:07.141
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:07.141 --> 00:00:08.367
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.367 --> 00:00:10.594
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:10.594 --> 00:00:13.320
>> Hello, and welcome back to ITProTV,

6
00:00:13.320 --> 00:00:17.295
I'm your show host Wes Bryan, and
in today's episode we're coming back at

7
00:00:17.295 --> 00:00:21.435
you with more of the logical
operation CyberSec First Responder.

8
00:00:21.435 --> 00:00:24.175
And joining us back in the studios is
none other than Mr. Mike Roderick.

9
00:00:24.175 --> 00:00:25.215
Mike how you doing, sir?

10
00:00:25.215 --> 00:00:26.455
>> I am doing great Wes.

11
00:00:26.455 --> 00:00:28.970
Excited to be continuing on
with our logical operations,

12
00:00:28.970 --> 00:00:31.080
CyberSec First Responder, and

13
00:00:31.080 --> 00:00:35.860
in this episode we're gonna be taking
a look at Wireless and DoS attacks.

14
00:00:35.860 --> 00:00:38.970
What kind of things we face
with our wireless networks.

15
00:00:38.970 --> 00:00:41.570
We'll talk a little bit about
Denial of Service, as well.

16
00:00:41.570 --> 00:00:43.480
Both wired and wireless really.

17
00:00:43.480 --> 00:00:45.060
So let's start with wireless.

18
00:00:45.060 --> 00:00:47.270
When it comes to wireless attacks.

19
00:00:47.270 --> 00:00:53.730
One of the things we're gonna call on
in the objectives is wireless cracking,

20
00:00:53.730 --> 00:00:57.820
which is where we're really
trying to break the password for

21
00:00:57.820 --> 00:01:00.210
connecting to those wireless networks.

22
00:01:00.210 --> 00:01:05.540
Being able to then connect to those
wireless networks and gain access

23
00:01:05.540 --> 00:01:08.390
to the corporate network or whatever
that wireless network is attached to.

24
00:01:08.390 --> 00:01:10.230
Lots of different tools you can use for
this.

25
00:01:10.230 --> 00:01:14.390
We Same techniques that we use for
working with, say, password dumps,

26
00:01:14.390 --> 00:01:18.870
where you've got dictionary-based attacks,
you have brute force attacks.

27
00:01:18.870 --> 00:01:21.860
You can do the same thing
with the wireless networks,

28
00:01:21.860 --> 00:01:23.360
lots of different tools out there,

29
00:01:23.360 --> 00:01:27.580
free and commercial, that will facilitate
cracking these wireless networks.

30
00:01:27.580 --> 00:01:31.380
Like, Aircrack is probably one of
the most popular ones out there.

31
00:01:31.380 --> 00:01:35.195
It'll help you crack those WEP and
WPAs, as a matter of fact.

32
00:01:35.195 --> 00:01:38.660
AirSnort was one that's been around for
a while.

33
00:01:38.660 --> 00:01:40.360
I believe they pulled support for
that, but

34
00:01:40.360 --> 00:01:43.040
I think you can still get it out there.

35
00:01:43.040 --> 00:01:47.170
Cain and
Abel was another big password cracker.

36
00:01:47.170 --> 00:01:51.280
I can't remember if it was in this show or
the other shows, but Cain and

37
00:01:51.280 --> 00:01:54.290
Abel has been around for
a long time, Password Cracker,

38
00:01:54.290 --> 00:01:58.770
works with wireless packet or
passwords as well.

39
00:01:58.770 --> 00:02:00.820
What was another one I wanted to mention?

40
00:02:00.820 --> 00:02:06.020
WEP Attack, and older one that you can
use, Cloud Cracker, there's a lot of

41
00:02:06.020 --> 00:02:10.790
different tools out there that will help
me try break into those wireless networks.

42
00:02:12.670 --> 00:02:17.720
So, WPA2 is a protocol
that is relatively secure.

43
00:02:17.720 --> 00:02:21.400
We've got good encryption algorithms
in there and the problem with that is

44
00:02:21.400 --> 00:02:26.090
people will go ahead and turn on WPA,
which is the Wi-Fi protected setup.

45
00:02:26.090 --> 00:02:29.770
And the WPA has like an eight
pin password associated with it.

46
00:02:29.770 --> 00:02:31.700
Which is not too terribly hard to break.

47
00:02:31.700 --> 00:02:34.680
There's not that many
possibilities associated with that.

48
00:02:34.680 --> 00:02:39.360
So, you can take something that's
very strong, implement WPA and

49
00:02:39.360 --> 00:02:42.270
really kill all of your
security associated with it.

50
00:02:42.270 --> 00:02:47.500
So when we talk about wireless attacks,
password cracking is the big thing.

51
00:02:47.500 --> 00:02:50.580
Trying to get the keys to
break the encryption so

52
00:02:50.580 --> 00:02:53.770
that we can read encrypted traffic
on those wireless networks.

53
00:02:53.770 --> 00:02:57.975
It becomes more difficult to secure
wireless networks because it's unbound

54
00:02:57.975 --> 00:03:01.088
media, because it's just
floating out there in space.

55
00:03:01.088 --> 00:03:04.609
It's not contained within a wire where
I can control where that wire goes and

56
00:03:04.609 --> 00:03:08.129
the only place you can patch into it is
where I've got a port unless you want to

57
00:03:08.129 --> 00:03:10.990
crawl up into the attic and
cut a cable and splice it.

58
00:03:10.990 --> 00:03:13.270
Now with wireless,
you just have to be in range.

59
00:03:13.270 --> 00:03:17.610
And we can get some really good antennas,
and I don't have to be nearly as

60
00:03:17.610 --> 00:03:21.850
close as you think I do,
to get access to your wireless network.

61
00:03:21.850 --> 00:03:25.430
Other types of attacks you might see
in wireless that are pretty common

62
00:03:25.430 --> 00:03:29.540
are man-in-the-middle attacks or
session hijacking type attacks.

63
00:03:29.540 --> 00:03:34.460
Again, it's a little bit easier
to get in between the client and

64
00:03:34.460 --> 00:03:39.840
the access point for a wireless network,
compared to say a wired network.

65
00:03:39.840 --> 00:03:41.770
Infrastructure attacks as well,

66
00:03:41.770 --> 00:03:45.820
you know just doing a Denial of
Service on the access point.

67
00:03:45.820 --> 00:03:47.350
Flooding it with requests,

68
00:03:47.350 --> 00:03:51.770
making it so busy that legitimate users
can't connect to that access point.

69
00:03:51.770 --> 00:03:56.480
Setting up an evil twin, a Rogue Access
Point that people will try to connect to.

70
00:03:56.480 --> 00:03:57.760
It looks like your access point.

71
00:03:57.760 --> 00:03:58.870
It's got the same name.

72
00:03:58.870 --> 00:04:00.240
It just doesn't go anywhere.

73
00:04:00.240 --> 00:04:02.480
Or it goes to some servers that
look like your servers and

74
00:04:02.480 --> 00:04:04.940
I'm just collecting information, right.

75
00:04:04.940 --> 00:04:09.640
So you got rogue access points,
like I said, Denial of Service.

76
00:04:09.640 --> 00:04:11.590
Remember, I'll go ahead and
define Denial of Service, but

77
00:04:11.590 --> 00:04:14.960
we'll come back to it in a minute but
Denial of Service is making something so

78
00:04:14.960 --> 00:04:18.280
busy that it can't perform its normal job.

79
00:04:18.280 --> 00:04:21.360
So if its a wireless access point,
well its job is

80
00:04:21.360 --> 00:04:25.540
to accept wireless traffic bound for
it and put it on the wired network.

81
00:04:25.540 --> 00:04:28.840
It can flood, it can only handle so
much traffic at a time.

82
00:04:28.840 --> 00:04:30.500
Most of us have dealt with that ourselves.

83
00:04:30.500 --> 00:04:34.620
You get too many people on your access
point, and everything slows down,

84
00:04:34.620 --> 00:04:38.410
well I can just whip up a bunch of fake
clients, generate a lot of fake traffic,

85
00:04:38.410 --> 00:04:42.440
and I can make that access point so busy,
that it can't do what it's supposed to do.

86
00:04:42.440 --> 00:04:44.910
>> Mike how about pulling
the power on the access point?

87
00:04:44.910 --> 00:04:47.320
Would that be another form
of Denial of Service attack?

88
00:04:47.320 --> 00:04:50.930
>> Yeah, absolutely, you have physical
security trumps everything else.

89
00:04:50.930 --> 00:04:53.600
And if I can get to your
wireless access point

90
00:04:53.600 --> 00:04:56.270
I can just simply pull the plug on it.

91
00:04:56.270 --> 00:05:00.490
You see these access points put in
places that are reachable, right?

92
00:05:00.490 --> 00:05:01.790
I can just reach up there and touch it.

93
00:05:01.790 --> 00:05:05.550
I mean Wes,
you can go a little higher than I can but

94
00:05:05.550 --> 00:05:08.540
that's not gonna be a good idea if I
can just yank the cable out of it.

95
00:05:08.540 --> 00:05:11.200
It has to be tied back
to your network somehow.

96
00:05:11.200 --> 00:05:13.860
Pull the plug on it definitely
gonna deny the service there.

97
00:05:13.860 --> 00:05:15.700
Also we have to worry about signal bleed.

98
00:05:15.700 --> 00:05:19.390
And then we have to do surveys,
determine where our signal is going.

99
00:05:19.390 --> 00:05:21.730
We always try to make sure
that we've got good coverage,

100
00:05:21.730 --> 00:05:26.070
we don't want any dead spots in our
building so we can make sure that people

101
00:05:26.070 --> 00:05:30.860
can walk and seamlessly travel
from one access point to the next.

102
00:05:30.860 --> 00:05:34.500
But a lot of times we'll get a little too
carried away with that, and we don't pay

103
00:05:34.500 --> 00:05:38.350
attention to how close that access point
has gotten to the edge of the building.

104
00:05:38.350 --> 00:05:41.280
And so, not only we're getting good
coverage in that quarter office,

105
00:05:41.280 --> 00:05:44.350
we got good coverage in
the parking lot outside there.

106
00:05:44.350 --> 00:05:46.910
And that's where nobody is monitoring,
nobody is paying attention.

107
00:05:46.910 --> 00:05:51.050
So somebody could potentially be sitting
out all day long working on your wireless

108
00:05:51.050 --> 00:05:55.520
network, trying to break into it, or
capturing traffic or stealing information.

109
00:05:55.520 --> 00:05:58.350
And it's a little bit more,
you just don't notice it right?

110
00:05:58.350 --> 00:06:01.080
Because you're not thinking about
your wireless signal reaching out to

111
00:06:01.080 --> 00:06:05.230
the parking garage or
into that business next to you right?

112
00:06:05.230 --> 00:06:09.240
Or that empty space next to you that
somebody could potentially sit up in and

113
00:06:09.240 --> 00:06:11.040
try to get access to your network.

114
00:06:11.040 --> 00:06:14.510
>> Mike, you mentioned Denial of Service
when it comes to a wireless attack.

115
00:06:14.510 --> 00:06:17.270
Can you tell us a little bit more about
Denial of Service like maybe some of

116
00:06:17.270 --> 00:06:20.590
the attributes what we
could expect to maybe see.

117
00:06:20.590 --> 00:06:24.279
And even if we don't see it some of the
methodology behind performing one of these

118
00:06:24.279 --> 00:06:25.210
Denial of Service.

119
00:06:25.210 --> 00:06:27.118
>> Yeah, absolutely and
I wanna make sure we understand too,

120
00:06:27.118 --> 00:06:28.540
I'm not talking about just wireless here.

121
00:06:28.540 --> 00:06:33.050
When I'm talking about Denial of Service,
it's regardless of whether it's wired or

122
00:06:33.050 --> 00:06:34.260
wireless, right.

123
00:06:34.260 --> 00:06:37.470
There's Denial of Service attacks I
can do against wireless networks,

124
00:06:37.470 --> 00:06:40.480
there's Denial of Service attacks
I can do against wired networks.

125
00:06:40.480 --> 00:06:43.960
But the basic premise of a Denial
of Service, think about it, right?

126
00:06:43.960 --> 00:06:47.360
We've got machines on our network
they're providing services.

127
00:06:47.360 --> 00:06:50.650
Whether that's an access point,
providing wireless connectivity or

128
00:06:50.650 --> 00:06:53.790
that it's a DNS server
providing name resolution.

129
00:06:53.790 --> 00:06:58.070
Whether that's a DHEP server
providing TCPIP configuration.

130
00:06:58.070 --> 00:07:02.860
We've got machines that are delivering or
providing services.

131
00:07:02.860 --> 00:07:07.440
Denial of service means I'm gonna make
it where it can't do that anymore.

132
00:07:07.440 --> 00:07:09.250
Right?
Your DNS server is so

133
00:07:09.250 --> 00:07:12.430
busy with incoming requests
that people are waiting.

134
00:07:12.430 --> 00:07:15.320
My browser's just spinning and
spinning and spinning cuz it's waiting for

135
00:07:15.320 --> 00:07:16.300
the DNS server to respond.

136
00:07:16.300 --> 00:07:20.600
Hey, what is the IP address of this name,
this user's trying to connect to?

137
00:07:20.600 --> 00:07:23.840
And us not getting an answer
because it's too busy, or

Well bit twist will let you take
a trace file, and replay it.

367
00:20:05.400 --> 00:20:09.830
It's like you can take it and click play,
and it'll resend all that traffic that it

368
00:20:09.830 --> 00:20:14.650
captured which is really pretty cool in
and of itself because you can go out and

369
00:20:14.650 --> 00:20:17.010
you can get traces of attacks,

370
00:20:17.010 --> 00:20:21.240
you could just make systems really busy
by replaying large traces over and over.

371
00:20:21.240 --> 00:20:26.820
But this'll also let you tweak the packets
and replay them across the network.

372
00:20:26.820 --> 00:20:28.290
So it's kind of a cool tool.

373
00:20:28.290 --> 00:20:34.090
Packet sender is another one TCP, UDP,
and SSL are its big strengths there.

374
00:20:34.090 --> 00:20:39.620
Let's me create those packets and
try to forge them Pacagen,

375
00:20:39.620 --> 00:20:43.217
Scapy, I think both of those
are Linux based tools.

376
00:20:43.217 --> 00:20:48.680
Bit twist if I remember right is
pretty much anything, Windows, Linux,

377
00:20:48.680 --> 00:20:52.200
Mac and I believe that one is free to,
it's an open source.

378
00:20:52.200 --> 00:20:53.800
It's a fun one to play with.

379
00:20:53.800 --> 00:21:00.310
I say it is a fun one to play with if you
want to learn about packets and you wanna

380
00:21:00.310 --> 00:21:05.030
really get in and learn TCPIP and whatever
other protocols you want to deal with.

381
00:21:05.030 --> 00:21:08.400
Utilities like this are great work
because we can analyze that traffic.

382
00:21:08.400 --> 00:21:12.960
But again, it could be twisted around and
used for malicious purposes.

383
00:21:14.850 --> 00:21:19.700
This is how I can cause denial services
text because I can use a tool like

384
00:21:19.700 --> 00:21:25.070
a packet generator tool, and
I can generate false HTTP get requests.

385
00:21:25.070 --> 00:21:29.280
I can just, no return address or
an invalid return address or

386
00:21:29.280 --> 00:21:32.240
I never respond to the synac
that comes back and

387
00:21:32.240 --> 00:21:36.420
I just create open connections, do all
kinds of bad things with these packet

388
00:21:36.420 --> 00:21:40.140
crafting utilities that'll lead
to a denial of service attack.

389
00:21:40.140 --> 00:21:43.330
>> Man, I could see some of these
utilities here causing a bad

390
00:21:43.330 --> 00:21:44.100
day at the office.

391
00:21:44.100 --> 00:21:47.310
Between things like your packet crafters,
a little social engineering.

392
00:21:47.310 --> 00:21:50.910
I find out maybe you're doing things like
MAC filtering on your wireless network.

393
00:21:50.910 --> 00:21:53.870
Well, all I gotta do is set the network
adapter in promiscuous mode, and

394
00:21:53.870 --> 00:21:56.640
I can find the MAC addresses of the
devices that are already associated with

395
00:21:56.640 --> 00:21:59.820
the wireless network, get the packet
crafter here that Mike's talking about,

396
00:21:59.820 --> 00:22:00.880
and spoof the MAC address.

397
00:22:00.880 --> 00:22:04.120
And now all of a sudden, I make it sound
easy, it's not as easy as it sounds.

398
00:22:04.120 --> 00:22:07.140
I'm on the network so
a lot of scary stuff,

399
00:22:07.140 --> 00:22:11.390
definitely stuff that you have to protect
against and definitely for the exam.

400
00:22:11.390 --> 00:22:13.980
Now Mike it does look like we're
coming to the end of another episode.

401
00:22:13.980 --> 00:22:15.680
But when it comes to
things like wireless and

402
00:22:15.680 --> 00:22:19.080
denial of service attacks, any additional
words that you might like to let

403
00:22:19.080 --> 00:22:20.890
the viewers know when
it comes to the exam?

404
00:22:20.890 --> 00:22:23.070
>> You know, as far as this exam,
I don't think so.

405
00:22:23.070 --> 00:22:26.360
The main thing is understanding that when
we're talking about wireless attacks,

406
00:22:26.360 --> 00:22:30.070
a lot of the same attacks that we
deal with on a wired network is just,

407
00:22:30.070 --> 00:22:32.330
sometimes, a little bit easier for
the bad guys.

408
00:22:32.330 --> 00:22:33.975
Because it's unbound media.

409
00:22:33.975 --> 00:22:37.005
We got to make sure we're paying
attention to where we're allowing that

410
00:22:37.005 --> 00:22:38.855
signal to travel to.

411
00:22:38.855 --> 00:22:40.625
Are we covering the parking lot?

412
00:22:40.625 --> 00:22:43.553
Are we covering the office
next door to us?

413
00:22:43.553 --> 00:22:47.585
Understanding what a denial of service
attack is, in it's many different forms.

414
00:22:47.585 --> 00:22:50.505
I think like you mentioned it doesn't
have to be an electronic attack.

415
00:22:50.505 --> 00:22:53.955
If I can just unplug your router
that would be a denial of service.

416
00:22:55.290 --> 00:23:01.570
And then a distributed service when
we recruit zombies, create a botnet,

417
00:23:01.570 --> 00:23:06.570
and we use more than one attacker to try
to do a denial of service on a target.

418
00:23:06.570 --> 00:23:08.710
>> Well, I tell you what,
that's a lot of great information.

419
00:23:08.710 --> 00:23:12.250
Mike, as always, we do appreciate
the thorough explanations.

420
00:23:12.250 --> 00:23:16.040
I do think that it's time for us to wrap
up, but before we do, I'm gonna go ahead

421
00:23:16.040 --> 00:23:19.900
and put my tin hat on, go home and
turn my wireless access point off.

422
00:23:19.900 --> 00:23:20.900
Just kidding guys.

423
00:23:20.900 --> 00:23:21.830
Thanks for watching here.

424
00:23:21.830 --> 00:23:24.620
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Wes Ryan.

425
00:23:24.620 --> 00:23:25.460
>> And I'm Mike Roderick.

426
00:23:25.460 --> 00:23:27.130
>> And we'll see you next time.

427
00:23:27.130 --> 00:23:33.716
[MUSIC]

428
00:23:33.716 --> 00:23:35.900
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Mike talk about various data sources in cyber security. They discuss security intelligence, cyber security management, what to monitor, data collection and general guidelines
episodes.title: Data Sources
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.290 --> 00:00:03.426
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.426 --> 00:00:08.262
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.262 --> 00:00:11.011
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.060 --> 00:00:15.120
Hello, thanks for
joining us here in the ITProTV studios.

5
00:00:15.120 --> 00:00:18.500
I'm your host Wes Bryan, and in today's
episode we are continuing through our

6
00:00:18.500 --> 00:00:22.470
series in logical operations,
CyberSec First Responder.

7
00:00:22.470 --> 00:00:25.060
And joining us in the studios for
this endeavor is none other than Mr.

8
00:00:25.060 --> 00:00:25.680
Mike Roderick.

9
00:00:25.680 --> 00:00:27.030
Mike, how are you doing sir?

10
00:00:27.030 --> 00:00:28.760
>> Doing great Wes,
thanks for having me back.

11
00:00:28.760 --> 00:00:31.030
Excited to be here as always.

12
00:00:31.030 --> 00:00:33.850
So, yeah in this episode
we are continuing on.

13
00:00:33.850 --> 00:00:37.970
The objective we want to go over today
is going to be, explain the purpose and

14
00:00:37.970 --> 00:00:40.760
characteristics of various data sources.

15
00:00:40.760 --> 00:00:43.230
Right?
So when we talk about collecting all this

16
00:00:43.230 --> 00:00:47.080
information, bringing it all together, you
need to understand what information we're

17
00:00:47.080 --> 00:00:52.408
getting from these different sources and
where to go to look for this information.

18
00:00:52.408 --> 00:00:55.100
So, we're gonna start off with
a couple of definitions, and

19
00:00:55.100 --> 00:00:58.260
we'll kind of walk through some of
the different locations that we end

20
00:00:58.260 --> 00:01:00.890
up looking for or pulling this data from.

21
00:01:00.890 --> 00:01:04.818
And the first term, they use the term
security intelligence, right?

22
00:01:04.818 --> 00:01:09.650
And security intelligence
has been around for a while,

23
00:01:09.650 --> 00:01:12.840
before we ever had
the term cyber security.

24
00:01:12.840 --> 00:01:15.970
And I'm gonna read you a logical
operations definition so

25
00:01:15.970 --> 00:01:18.630
we understand what they
consider security intelligence,

26
00:01:18.630 --> 00:01:20.630
because it can vary
from different sources.

27
00:01:20.630 --> 00:01:26.230
The process through which data generated
in the ongoing use of information systems

28
00:01:26.230 --> 00:01:31.982
is collected, processed, integrated,
evaluated, analyzed and interpreted.

29
00:01:31.982 --> 00:01:33.750
Whew, right?

30
00:01:33.750 --> 00:01:35.040
There's a lot to it.

31
00:01:35.040 --> 00:01:37.440
So, when we're talking about
security intelligence,

32
00:01:37.440 --> 00:01:40.110
we're not talking about one little thing.

33
00:01:40.110 --> 00:01:41.980
It's really it's an overall process.

34
00:01:41.980 --> 00:01:46.030
We're talking about taking the information
that we're getting from all

35
00:01:46.030 --> 00:01:51.230
various systems on our network, devices,
endpoints, interconnectivity devices,

36
00:01:51.230 --> 00:01:55.820
services, wherever we're collecting
that data from collecting it up,

37
00:01:55.820 --> 00:01:59.730
figuring out how we can process
that information, evaluating it,

38
00:01:59.730 --> 00:02:02.830
analyzing it, and
then making sense out of those results and

39
00:02:02.830 --> 00:02:04.940
interpreting the results
of that information.

40
00:02:04.940 --> 00:02:07.540
>> Now Mike when it comes to certain
security intelligence, what are some of

41
00:02:07.540 --> 00:02:11.170
the benefits we can expect to see
when we're using something like that?

42
00:02:11.170 --> 00:02:15.350
>> Well, if you're going to and
pulling all of those information and

43
00:02:15.350 --> 00:02:18.460
doing you're analysis on it,
faster detection and

44
00:02:18.460 --> 00:02:22.750
remediation of threats, right because I'm
seeing I'm actually paying attention on

45
00:02:22.750 --> 00:02:25.830
what's going on the network
>> Hopefully somewhere

46
00:02:25.830 --> 00:02:28.435
we're going to see an alert.

47
00:02:28.435 --> 00:02:31.010
Think about it this way
you've got your network, and

48
00:02:31.010 --> 00:02:35.650
when you think about the scenarios,
somebody comes out and

49
00:02:35.650 --> 00:02:39.900
says, system's been compromised, data has
been exfiltrated, we've had a breach.

50
00:02:39.900 --> 00:02:42.700
All right well, that's after the fact.

51
00:02:42.700 --> 00:02:48.490
But if we were continuously monitoring all
of our different sources of information

52
00:02:48.490 --> 00:02:53.070
we might have seen the initial attack,
the breach of the firewall or

53
00:02:53.070 --> 00:02:55.740
the way they initially got into
the network before they ever made it to

54
00:02:55.740 --> 00:02:58.840
the system that had the important
information that was compromised.

55
00:02:58.840 --> 00:03:01.000
So by doing security intelligence,

56
00:03:01.000 --> 00:03:05.790
we can hopefully get faster
detection remediation of threats.

57
00:03:05.790 --> 00:03:11.030
And also helps us comply with
our regulatory bodies right,

58
00:03:11.030 --> 00:03:15.060
because we can audit, we can show what
we're doing, we can prove that we're

59
00:03:15.060 --> 00:03:19.210
performing these particular regulations,
whatever might be specified.

60
00:03:20.880 --> 00:03:22.480
So, we reduce data leakage,

61
00:03:22.480 --> 00:03:26.190
we reduce fraud again because
of early detection, right?

62
00:03:26.190 --> 00:03:27.710
We're monitoring everything.

63
00:03:27.710 --> 00:03:30.850
We're bringing all that data in and
we're making sense out of it.

64
00:03:30.850 --> 00:03:32.970
What else.

65
00:03:32.970 --> 00:03:37.240
Ability to detect potential weaknesses
before the exploit occurs, that's again,

66
00:03:37.240 --> 00:03:41.300
what I was saying, is we might be able to
pick that up, pick the signs of the attack

67
00:03:41.300 --> 00:03:46.279
up well before it actually turns
into a full on data breach.

68
00:03:46.279 --> 00:03:48.110
All right.

69
00:03:48.110 --> 00:03:50.670
Now the problem with this it sounds easy.

70
00:03:50.670 --> 00:03:53.860
Frank, we'll just pull all of
the information in, and analyze it,

71
00:03:53.860 --> 00:03:55.380
and we'll be safe from attacks.

72
00:03:55.380 --> 00:03:56.330
Right?

73
00:03:56.330 --> 00:03:57.940
>> One of the things
that I think about Mike,

74
00:03:57.940 --> 00:04:00.910
is that is seems like your information's
coming from multiple sources here, and

75
00:04:00.910 --> 00:04:03.210
it looks like that could be
a little bit of a daunting task.

76
00:04:03.210 --> 00:04:05.539
>> Absolutely, and you've got to decide
what information is actually relevant?

77
00:04:07.650 --> 00:04:08.960
>> What do I need to pay attention to,

78
00:04:08.960 --> 00:04:12.900
because we're gonna have tons
of information coming in, and

79
00:04:12.900 --> 00:04:15.920
I've got to decide what kind
of information is relevant.

80
00:04:15.920 --> 00:04:18.110
How do I pull out the important pieces?

81
00:04:18.110 --> 00:04:20.920
Making that information useful.

82
00:04:20.920 --> 00:04:25.070
A lot of these log files come in
a format that's barely human readable?

83
00:04:25.070 --> 00:04:27.410
It's just very difficult to sit there and

84
00:04:27.410 --> 00:04:30.480
just read the log file
in its normal output so

85
00:04:30.480 --> 00:04:35.280
making that information to the point where
I can actually do something with it.

86
00:04:35.280 --> 00:04:38.580
I need to be able to query and
show all of events that occurred

87
00:04:38.580 --> 00:04:43.168
in a certain date range or all certain
event type, or of a certain user,

88
00:04:43.168 --> 00:04:47.871
right, being able to make that
information mean something to me.

89
00:04:47.871 --> 00:04:52.700
And it takes a lot of time, right, to set
up all this up, to configure software,

90
00:04:52.700 --> 00:04:55.470
to be able to pull the data
from different sources,

91
00:04:55.470 --> 00:05:00.450
to get the right tools to be able
to analyze that information.

92
00:05:00.450 --> 00:05:03.920
And then, training people to be
able to work that software and

93
00:05:03.920 --> 00:05:07.900
to analyze that information and
keeping that information safe.

94
00:05:07.900 --> 00:05:10.000
That's something that
sometimes we forget about.

95
00:05:10.000 --> 00:05:14.680
We're putting all this stuff in a place to
keep our network and our data safe, right?

96
00:05:14.680 --> 00:05:18.410
So we've got all those logs coming in,
we've got maybe seam systems,

97
00:05:18.410 --> 00:05:22.425
or CSM systems,
cyber security management systems

98
00:05:22.425 --> 00:05:26.175
that are pulling all this information
in from all these different sources.

99
00:05:26.175 --> 00:05:30.185
That information is confidential,
right, it needs to be protected.

100
00:05:30.185 --> 00:05:34.367
So we've gotta secure the security data,
if that makes sense, and

101
00:05:34.367 --> 00:05:36.269
we've gotta think about that as well.

102
00:05:36.269 --> 00:05:38.967
All right?

103
00:05:38.967 --> 00:05:42.437
So when we talk about security
intelligence collection or

104
00:05:42.437 --> 00:05:46.668
pulling this information together,
it kinda has a life cycle to it, right?

105
00:05:46.668 --> 00:05:49.168
We've got our planning and our direction

106
00:05:49.168 --> 00:05:54.338
phase when we're deciding what information
we need to gather, from what sources.

107
00:05:54.338 --> 00:05:57.188
Then we're gonna go through
a collection phase where we do

108
00:05:57.188 --> 00:05:58.778
pull that information in.

109
00:05:58.778 --> 00:06:00.348
That information's gotta be processed.

110
00:06:00.348 --> 00:06:04.348
It's gotta be made to where
we can actually use it,

111
00:06:04.348 --> 00:06:08.360
whether that's putting it in a database so
that I can query it, or some other systems

112
00:06:08.360 --> 00:06:12.750
or processing all of that raw data and
then doing your analysis, right?

113
00:06:12.750 --> 00:06:17.370
Going through and making sense of it,
pulling out the important information,

114
00:06:17.370 --> 00:06:21.960
looking for signs of attack or data
exfiltration or whatever we're looking

115
00:06:21.960 --> 00:06:26.020
for, and then dissemination of that
information out to the appropriate people.

116
00:06:26.020 --> 00:06:29.280
That's another big part of this process,
right?

117
00:06:29.280 --> 00:06:33.390
If If I'm that security person that's
pulling all this information in and

118
00:06:33.390 --> 00:06:36.880
analyzing these files,
I need to make sure that when I

119
00:06:36.880 --> 00:06:41.690
find information that's pertinent to other
department heads or whomever it may be,

120
00:06:41.690 --> 00:06:45.850
that this information gets put back
out to them in a meaningful manner.

121
00:06:46.880 --> 00:06:48.274
So dissemination and

122
00:06:48.274 --> 00:06:52.820
integration of the information back
into the system that we can use.

123
00:06:52.820 --> 00:06:55.420
And it starts all over,
it doesn't just stop there, right?

124
00:06:55.420 --> 00:06:57.100
It's cyclical in nature.

125
00:06:57.100 --> 00:07:01.840
We're gonna be constantly going
through this collection, process,

126
00:07:01.840 --> 00:07:05.610
analysis, dissemination, collection,
process, analysis, dissemination.

127
00:07:05.610 --> 00:07:12.720
We just go around and around and
it's a never ending cycle, right?

128
00:07:12.720 --> 00:07:17.360
Now another term that we wanted
to define here is actually,

129
00:07:17.360 --> 00:07:22.500
before we do that,
we talk about our collection plan again.

130
00:07:22.500 --> 00:07:26.758
We wanna think about what information we
need really, that's going to be one of

131
00:07:26.758 --> 00:07:31.349
the challenges that we face is trying to
determine what information is appropriate.

132
00:07:32.960 --> 00:07:34.010
Where can I get the information, right?

133
00:07:35.060 --> 00:07:37.660
Do my routers have good
logging capabilities?

134
00:07:37.660 --> 00:07:38.610
Can I get information from them?

135
00:07:38.610 --> 00:07:40.220
What about my switches?

136
00:07:40.220 --> 00:07:44.205
Do they provide any type of logging or
information?

137
00:07:44.205 --> 00:07:48.433
Nodes on my network,
my Windows systems, my Linux systems,

138
00:07:48.433 --> 00:07:52.271
my services, DNS logs,
DHCP logs, things like that.

139
00:07:52.271 --> 00:07:54.466
Where am I gonna get
this information from?

140
00:07:54.466 --> 00:07:57.253
And really, we wanna make
sure that we bring everybody.

141
00:07:57.253 --> 00:07:59.910
In, when we're deciding where
the information come from,

142
00:07:59.910 --> 00:08:01.838
we should get al the departments involved,

143
00:08:01.838 --> 00:08:05.640
because they might have a source of
information that I didn't think of, right?

144
00:08:05.640 --> 00:08:08.190
That hey, did you know these logs,
this information here?

145
00:08:08.190 --> 00:08:11.380
No, that would be a great information
to throw in with the rest of them.

146
00:08:11.380 --> 00:08:14.250
The more information I can get,
the better in the end.

147
00:08:14.250 --> 00:08:18.720
I mean it does make it a challenge to get
it down, all the important information.

148
00:08:18.720 --> 00:08:21.080
But, I'd rather have a little too much and

149
00:08:21.080 --> 00:08:24.160
have to filter it down, than not have
that information in the first place.

150
00:08:24.160 --> 00:08:25.400
I'm getting everybody involved,

151
00:08:25.400 --> 00:08:31.380
making sure that we find all the different
data sources that we have available.

152
00:08:31.380 --> 00:08:35.210
Now a term that actually that
I wasnt familiar with- 'CSM'.

153
00:08:35.210 --> 00:08:38.100
This has some other meanings to it.

154
00:08:38.100 --> 00:08:41.190
But its relatively new
in the security front.

155
00:08:41.190 --> 00:08:43.000
Cyber security management.

156
00:08:43.000 --> 00:08:46.130
And you go out there and look, and
you're not gonna find a whole lot on this.

157
00:08:46.130 --> 00:08:51.030
But cyber security management is really
kind of what we're talking about here.

158
00:08:51.030 --> 00:08:55.040
Getting all of this information
that's vital, organizing it,

159
00:08:55.040 --> 00:09:00.290
making it into something that I can
use Is really what CSM is all about.

160
00:09:00.290 --> 00:09:01.010
What I think what we're

161
00:09:02.460 --> 00:09:07.710
seeing is there is going to be software
that is going to be doing this soon.

162
00:09:07.710 --> 00:09:11.300
If I take a look, let me pull something
up real quick and I'll show you guys.

failed attempt, failed attempt,

395
00:21:29.319 --> 00:21:32.704
failed attempt, failed attempt,
failed attempt, and then nothing.

396
00:21:32.704 --> 00:21:36.790
And they go, okay, well,
they gave up or did they?

397
00:21:36.790 --> 00:21:40.780
If I'm not monitoring successful logins,
the very next login might've been success.

398
00:21:40.780 --> 00:21:44.662
That's why the failed stopped was because
the person guessed the right password, and

399
00:21:44.662 --> 00:21:46.965
got into the resource they
were trying to get into.

400
00:21:46.965 --> 00:21:49.834
If I wasn't monitoring,
if I wasn't logging that information,

401
00:21:49.834 --> 00:21:51.895
I wouldn't have any record of that.

402
00:21:51.895 --> 00:21:56.288
So what you might think is, I don't wanna
monitor successful logins because I

403
00:21:56.288 --> 00:22:00.015
have hundreds of employees and
they successfully log in all the time.

404
00:22:00.015 --> 00:22:03.280
The problem is,
you might need that information.

405
00:22:03.280 --> 00:22:06.851
So, it's a tough job to
try to filter this, or

406
00:22:06.851 --> 00:22:11.530
to try to determine what it is
that I need to capture and save.

407
00:22:11.530 --> 00:22:16.433
And that's why I say these systems that
help accumulate these information and

408
00:22:16.433 --> 00:22:19.340
allow me to filter it
down are very important.

409
00:22:19.340 --> 00:22:22.520
Because we find that we need to
monitor quite a bit of stuff.

410
00:22:22.520 --> 00:22:24.220
We need to log almost all of it.

411
00:22:24.220 --> 00:22:26.900
And then, we just have to filter
it down into something useful.

412
00:22:26.900 --> 00:22:31.790
So striking that balance between too
much data and not enough useful data.

413
00:22:31.790 --> 00:22:35.889
We also need to make sure that we
don't violate any laws or regulations,

414
00:22:35.889 --> 00:22:39.868
that we are logging everything that
the regulations say I have to log.

415
00:22:39.868 --> 00:22:44.528
We look at HIPAA and Sarbanes-Oxley,
and regulations like this.

416
00:22:44.528 --> 00:22:49.176
And they're gonna have specific
guidelines that say, there needs to be

417
00:22:49.176 --> 00:22:54.330
a record of anybody that accesses
personally identifiable information.

418
00:22:54.330 --> 00:22:57.260
Any changes that are made to that
information needs to be logged.

419
00:22:57.260 --> 00:22:59.596
Last modified, last viewed,
things like that.

420
00:22:59.596 --> 00:23:02.291
There's gonna be regulations
that say what you've got to do.

421
00:23:02.291 --> 00:23:03.315
And if you're not,

422
00:23:03.315 --> 00:23:07.180
you're gonna open yourself up to
tremendous amounts of liability.

423
00:23:07.180 --> 00:23:12.290
So understanding what the laws and the
regulations say that I've got to log and

424
00:23:12.290 --> 00:23:16.770
that I've got to maintain, or retain,
I guess is a better word for that.

425
00:23:16.770 --> 00:23:20.890
So when it comes to data collection,
there's definitely a planning phase

426
00:23:20.890 --> 00:23:25.790
in this, trying to decide what it is that
I need capture, what it is I need to log.

427
00:23:26.815 --> 00:23:30.340
Cuz it is such a tough balance there,
trying to get enough information to make

428
00:23:30.340 --> 00:23:35.070
it useful, yet not too much information
where it's just overwhelming and

429
00:23:35.070 --> 00:23:36.680
I can't find what I'm looking for.

430
00:23:36.680 --> 00:23:37.567
>> You know, Mike,

431
00:23:37.567 --> 00:23:41.353
you were talking to us about going to
a conference where there were CIOs, and

432
00:23:41.353 --> 00:23:44.798
CSOs were sharing information in
the security intelligence world.

433
00:23:44.798 --> 00:23:47.710
As far as our information that we get to,

434
00:23:47.710 --> 00:23:52.687
are there other sources as well or
have we pretty much covered those?

435
00:23:52.687 --> 00:23:55.065
>> No, we could list a few out there and

436
00:23:55.065 --> 00:23:59.440
there might be some things that
you might not have thought about.

437
00:23:59.440 --> 00:24:02.062
We talk about OS administration logs.

438
00:24:02.062 --> 00:24:02.942
All right?

439
00:24:02.942 --> 00:24:07.891
Probably thought of those perimeter logs,
VPN logs, network audits, file and

440
00:24:07.891 --> 00:24:12.332
directory audits, malware detection,
sys logs, application logs,

441
00:24:12.332 --> 00:24:14.310
physical security logs.

442
00:24:14.310 --> 00:24:16.330
Right?
There's one that you might forget about.

443
00:24:16.330 --> 00:24:21.850
Because we're so focused on our networks,
that we forget about the front desk and

444
00:24:21.850 --> 00:24:23.346
the fact that that
security guard out there,

445
00:24:23.346 --> 00:24:28.570
has a sign-in sheet of tracking
when these visitors came in.

446
00:24:28.570 --> 00:24:32.480
I might have a record of somebody logging
in but I don't know who this person is,

447
00:24:32.480 --> 00:24:36.716
and in that visitor log I would
have seen something maybe.

448
00:24:36.716 --> 00:24:39.640
I know we might probably don't make them
accounts but again, just trying to throw

449
00:24:39.640 --> 00:24:43.860
out some examples there of things
that you might not think about.

450
00:24:43.860 --> 00:24:45.930
Web scans, thread intelligence.

451
00:24:45.930 --> 00:24:48.070
When we're doing our vulnerability scans.

452
00:24:48.070 --> 00:24:49.650
Change management records.

453
00:24:49.650 --> 00:24:51.055
These are important to keep around.

454
00:24:51.055 --> 00:24:55.250
Understanding change management, when
you're making a change to a configuration.

455
00:24:55.250 --> 00:24:57.640
That's my record of what
the value used to be.

456
00:24:57.640 --> 00:24:58.820
We might find that we tested it.

457
00:24:58.820 --> 00:24:59.610
We thought we were good.

458
00:24:59.610 --> 00:25:00.880
We made the change.

459
00:25:00.880 --> 00:25:02.865
And that broke something
else that we didn't notice.

460
00:25:02.865 --> 00:25:05.870
Now we need to try to roll back,
having that information,

461
00:25:05.870 --> 00:25:09.300
those change management records,
I know what the old value used to be.

462
00:25:09.300 --> 00:25:12.910
So a lot of sources for
security intelligence.

463
00:25:12.910 --> 00:25:17.790
As far as guidelines on
what we need to collect.

464
00:25:17.790 --> 00:25:21.760
Again, it's gonna differ
between organizations,

465
00:25:21.760 --> 00:25:24.595
what information we have available even,
to collect.

466
00:25:24.595 --> 00:25:28.900
But looking at identifying and
prioritizing our risks,

467
00:25:28.900 --> 00:25:33.585
identifying potential data sources and
then trying to narrow that focus.

468
00:25:34.705 --> 00:25:38.595
Now we also need to think about
what fields we need to log.

469
00:25:38.595 --> 00:25:43.415
A lot of these systems,
when I look at routers or switches or

470
00:25:43.415 --> 00:25:46.125
whatever the case maybe,
we can enable logging.

471
00:25:46.125 --> 00:25:49.185
And then we can enable
some level of verbosity,

472
00:25:49.185 --> 00:25:53.862
we might be able to customize or pick and
choose what fields we wanna log.

473
00:25:53.862 --> 00:25:54.917
Right?

474
00:25:54.917 --> 00:25:58.540
And there are definitely some things
that we wanna make sure that we get.

475
00:25:58.540 --> 00:26:01.940
Like for an event I need to know when
that event started and when it ended.

476
00:26:01.940 --> 00:26:04.625
Right?
This is gonna be critical to correlating

477
00:26:04.625 --> 00:26:06.600
logs from other systems.

478
00:26:06.600 --> 00:26:11.200
Because if I know when that event started
and ended, now I can go collect the logs

479
00:26:11.200 --> 00:26:15.030
from my firewall, from my routers,
from my switches,

480
00:26:15.030 --> 00:26:18.260
from the hosts that were affected,
and I can pull that same time frame.

481
00:26:18.260 --> 00:26:20.300
And I can start analyzing
that information, and

482
00:26:20.300 --> 00:26:24.030
look for signs of that attack
all through my network.

483
00:26:24.030 --> 00:26:27.150
I need to know who was
involved in the event.

484
00:26:27.150 --> 00:26:33.640
What work station, or what server, if any
employees were involved, what happened?

485
00:26:33.640 --> 00:26:38.490
Information specific to the details
of that event need to be logged.

486
00:26:38.490 --> 00:26:39.270
Where it happened?

487
00:26:39.270 --> 00:26:39.980
What system?

488
00:26:39.980 --> 00:26:44.320
Again, what system got compromised or
what system was used to perform the scan?

489
00:26:44.320 --> 00:26:48.340
And it looks like they bounced
a scan off of one of my servers,

490
00:26:48.340 --> 00:26:49.840
to scan the rest of my internal network.

491
00:26:50.960 --> 00:26:52.730
And where it originated.

492
00:26:52.730 --> 00:26:53.890
Did it originate in house?

493
00:26:53.890 --> 00:26:54.730
Was it external?

494
00:26:54.730 --> 00:26:56.550
Did it come through our firewall?

495
00:26:56.550 --> 00:27:00.610
All gonna be important information
that we wanna make sure we capture.

496
00:27:00.610 --> 00:27:05.550
>> Mike it seems like the unsung hero, you
said in the beginning of the episode about

497
00:27:05.550 --> 00:27:09.870
things like detection and remediation
Looks like we need to move those apart,

498
00:27:09.870 --> 00:27:11.710
and put identification right
in the middle as well.

499
00:27:11.710 --> 00:27:14.820
Seems like identification is
a big part of this, likewise.

500
00:27:14.820 --> 00:27:15.920
>> Absolutely.

501
00:27:15.920 --> 00:27:20.810
And things that we wanna think about for,
when we say we're logging again,

502
00:27:20.810 --> 00:27:23.450
we're trying to make sure we're getting
all the pertinent information but

503
00:27:23.450 --> 00:27:24.590
not too much information.

504
00:27:24.590 --> 00:27:28.130
So we can keep that information useful.

505
00:27:28.130 --> 00:27:31.570
And really, what we wanna do is,
we wanna look at our systems.

506
00:27:31.570 --> 00:27:32.980
Not every system's the same.

507
00:27:32.980 --> 00:27:36.900
We don't need to do the same
logging on Wes's laptop,

508
00:27:36.900 --> 00:27:41.230
as I do on my DNS server, or
my domain controller, right?

509
00:27:41.230 --> 00:27:42.050
Or my firewall.

510
00:27:42.050 --> 00:27:44.690
They're all gonna have
different levels of logging.

511
00:27:44.690 --> 00:27:48.080
And so what we do is,
we look at the impacts of the systems.

512
00:27:48.080 --> 00:27:50.770
What would happen if that
system was compromised?

513
00:27:50.770 --> 00:27:53.260
What kind of information is
being stored on that system?

514
00:27:53.260 --> 00:27:54.700
How sensitive is that?

515
00:27:54.700 --> 00:27:57.200
Again, this goes back to doing
our risk analysis, right?

516
00:27:57.200 --> 00:28:01.252
And understanding the impact,
making our little matrix.

517
00:28:01.252 --> 00:28:05.420
And so once we got that impact matrix or
the risk matrix,

518
00:28:05.420 --> 00:28:11.780
where I know the likelihood of occurrence
and the impact of an occurrence,

519
00:28:11.780 --> 00:28:16.230
I can divide my systems up into low,
moderate and high impact systems.

520
00:28:16.230 --> 00:28:20.560
And on low impact systems, we might be
keeping the logs for a week or two.

521
00:28:20.560 --> 00:28:22.160
All right.
And then I'm just recycling them.

522
00:28:22.160 --> 00:28:24.840
I don't need to waste
that space storing them.

523
00:28:24.840 --> 00:28:25.940
Maybe we don't need log,

524
00:28:25.940 --> 00:28:31.250
we transfer the logs every 24
hours over to our seam system.

525
00:28:31.250 --> 00:28:34.960
Maybe we look at them once a week or
something like that.

526
00:28:34.960 --> 00:28:38.630
Again, this is not set in stone,
don't write these numbers down and go,

527
00:28:38.630 --> 00:28:41.330
this is exactly what
Mike said we need to do.

528
00:28:41.330 --> 00:28:44.370
>> But it does seem like, you were
mentioning with risk assessment there,

529
00:28:44.370 --> 00:28:48.520
that we would have to do some kind of node
criticality and be able to classify those.

530
00:28:48.520 --> 00:28:53.540
Because quantity of logs might be greatly
different between my YouTube searching and

531
00:28:53.540 --> 00:28:55.730
a send-off server that's
maybe running Apache.

532
00:28:55.730 --> 00:28:56.358
>> Yeah, exactly.

533
00:28:56.358 --> 00:29:04.840
I might transfer logs from my low
impact system every 24 hours.

534
00:29:04.840 --> 00:29:08.930
My high impact systems, it might be every
five minutes that I transfer those logs.

535
00:29:08.930 --> 00:29:10.480
Remember it's a high impact system.

536
00:29:10.480 --> 00:29:16.592
That means we've determined that
the risk impact is high on those.

537
00:29:16.592 --> 00:29:19.535
So I better make sure
I've got those records,

538
00:29:19.535 --> 00:29:23.292
what if there is a breach,
what's the bad guy gonna try to do?

539
00:29:23.292 --> 00:29:25.400
Are they gonna try to
wipe those log files.

540
00:29:25.400 --> 00:29:27.080
And so
every five minutes I'm shipping it off.

541
00:29:27.080 --> 00:29:28.110
That way if there is a breach,

542
00:29:28.110 --> 00:29:32.430
I'm losing five minutes of
log files at the most, right.

543
00:29:32.430 --> 00:29:34.850
How often do I analyze those logs?

544
00:29:34.850 --> 00:29:37.018
On those low-impact systems,
maybe it's once a week.

545
00:29:37.018 --> 00:29:41.370
On those high-impact systems, it might
be every hour that I go through and

546
00:29:41.370 --> 00:29:42.240
analyze those logs.

547
00:29:42.240 --> 00:29:45.740
And when I say analyze the logs,
it could be human, right?

548
00:29:45.740 --> 00:29:49.776
It could be me or
somebody analyzing them with human eyes.

549
00:29:49.776 --> 00:29:54.120
Or it could be an automated system
that's looking for keywords or

550
00:29:54.120 --> 00:29:57.758
certain IP ranges, or
certain patterns in the log files.

551
00:29:57.758 --> 00:30:01.170
And so it doesn't necessarily
have to be me every hour,

552
00:30:01.170 --> 00:30:02.365
thumbing through the log files.

553
00:30:02.365 --> 00:30:05.410
This is why we have Seam
systems,this is why we have those

554
00:30:05.410 --> 00:30:10.176
cyber security management systems,
to help us with this amount of data right.

555
00:30:10.176 --> 00:30:14.250
This is where big data analytics
is coming in to cyber security.

556
00:30:14.250 --> 00:30:16.622
Because we're realizing
the information is there,

557
00:30:16.622 --> 00:30:19.120
we've gotta make sure that
we're paying attention.

558
00:30:19.120 --> 00:30:22.920
We know where to get it, what
information we need, how to analyze it,

559
00:30:22.920 --> 00:30:24.610
how to make sense out of all of it.

560
00:30:24.610 --> 00:30:26.840
>> Mike, a lot of great
information on data sources.

561
00:30:26.840 --> 00:30:27.990
It's so much information,

562
00:30:27.990 --> 00:30:30.870
it doesn't look like we can fit
it all into 30 minutes though.

563
00:30:30.870 --> 00:30:33.680
Looking at this list that it does
look like we're gonna have to go into

564
00:30:33.680 --> 00:30:35.040
a part two.

565
00:30:35.040 --> 00:30:37.420
Cuz judging by that clock,
we don't have anymore time.

566
00:30:37.420 --> 00:30:40.575
Mike, before we wrap this one up, do you
have any additional information you might

567
00:30:40.575 --> 00:30:42.740
wanna throw to our viewers
about things like logging?

568
00:30:42.740 --> 00:30:45.720
>> I have a ton, but I think we'll
just save it for the next episode.

569
00:30:45.720 --> 00:30:47.390
>> All right,
well that's a great place to stop.

570
00:30:47.390 --> 00:30:50.270
Mike as always, thank you for
being here at the ITProTV studios.

571
00:30:50.270 --> 00:30:52.150
And thank you to you, the viewer watching.

572
00:30:52.150 --> 00:30:54.710
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

573
00:30:54.710 --> 00:30:55.760
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

574
00:30:55.760 --> 00:31:04.170
>> We'll see you next time.
[MUSIC]

575
00:31:04.170 --> 00:31:06.556
>> Thank you for watching
>> ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike continue their discussion on various data sources in cyber security. They look at information processing, external data sources, publicly available information, collection and report automation and data retention.
episodes.title: Data Sources Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.240
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.240 --> 00:00:01.968
I'm your host [CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:01.968 --> 00:00:06.183
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:06.183 --> 00:00:11.694
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.694 --> 00:00:14.545
>> Hello and
welcome to the ITProTV studios.

6
00:00:14.545 --> 00:00:17.465
I'm your host Wes Bryan, and in today's
episode, we're continuing through

7
00:00:17.465 --> 00:00:21.535
our series in logical operations,
cyber site first responder.

8
00:00:21.535 --> 00:00:25.192
And joining us back for a part two in
data sources, is none other than Mr.

9
00:00:25.192 --> 00:00:25.845
Mike Rodrick.

10
00:00:25.845 --> 00:00:27.870
Mike, how you doing sir?
>> Doing great Wes, thanks for

11
00:00:27.870 --> 00:00:29.955
having me back, excited to be here.

12
00:00:29.955 --> 00:00:32.215
So yeah, we left off kind of in
the middle of a thought there,

13
00:00:32.215 --> 00:00:34.415
ran out of time in that previous episode.

14
00:00:34.415 --> 00:00:37.830
We've been talking about data sources,
pulling information in.

15
00:00:37.830 --> 00:00:40.132
So we're just gonna,
kind of jump right back into it.

16
00:00:40.132 --> 00:00:42.290
At the end of the last episode,

17
00:00:42.290 --> 00:00:48.300
we were talking about configuring logging
on systems based on their impact, right?

18
00:00:48.300 --> 00:00:51.530
Our low impact systems,
we might not monitor as often.

19
00:00:51.530 --> 00:00:56.468
We ship the logs over once a week and
we analyze those logs once a week.

20
00:00:56.468 --> 00:01:00.780
But we ship them over, maybe 24 hours and
we monitor them once a week.

21
00:01:00.780 --> 00:01:04.310
With my high-impact systems, I might be
shipping those over every five minutes and

22
00:01:04.310 --> 00:01:06.940
analyzing those logs every six hours,
right?

23
00:01:06.940 --> 00:01:08.840
Depending on the impact of the system.

24
00:01:08.840 --> 00:01:12.150
Also things we need to
think about are going to be

25
00:01:12.150 --> 00:01:14.840
which events should actually prompt for
an alert, all right?

26
00:01:14.840 --> 00:01:18.980
Because our systems scan, our intrusion
detection, our intrusion prevention

27
00:01:18.980 --> 00:01:24.340
systems, these can be set to
send an alert, notify somebody.

28
00:01:24.340 --> 00:01:27.640
Which is a good thing, but
then again, it's kinda like,

29
00:01:27.640 --> 00:01:29.570
what information am I gathering.

30
00:01:29.570 --> 00:01:31.630
What events should trigger alerts?

31
00:01:31.630 --> 00:01:35.860
Not everything should trigger an alert,
because I'll end up with too many alerts,

32
00:01:35.860 --> 00:01:37.790
and I won't pay attention to them.

33
00:01:37.790 --> 00:01:41.100
Because they're happening every five
minutes anyway, I just ignore them.

34
00:01:41.100 --> 00:01:42.910
So I've got to make sure I'm careful and

35
00:01:42.910 --> 00:01:45.140
we're not doing the boy who cried wolf,
right?

36
00:01:45.140 --> 00:01:47.840
I wanna make sure our
alerts are meaningful.

37
00:01:49.600 --> 00:01:54.500
So events that should trigger an alert,
faults affecting system operations, but

38
00:01:54.500 --> 00:01:57.510
not general status messages.

39
00:01:57.510 --> 00:02:00.373
I need to know if DNS failed to start, but

40
00:02:00.373 --> 00:02:04.092
I don't need to know the DNS
started successfully.

41
00:02:04.092 --> 00:02:07.010
You're gonna see those
events in the log files.

42
00:02:07.010 --> 00:02:09.660
So, and I want to capture both of them,
don't get me wrong.

43
00:02:09.660 --> 00:02:12.214
But when DNS successfully
starts I don't need an alert.

44
00:02:12.214 --> 00:02:15.810
I don't need an email coming to me or
a pop-up message or anything like that.

45
00:02:15.810 --> 00:02:21.060
But if DNS fails to start,
maybe I need an alert on that one.

46
00:02:21.060 --> 00:02:24.440
If changes result in security or

47
00:02:24.440 --> 00:02:27.480

00:02:27.480 --> 00:02:30.750

00:03:43.548 --> 00:03:47.560

>> Mike, you've been mentioning

And that's where,

I can develop a system

You pull all these raw log files in and

I can look it depending

I can, very customizable, so I can get

00:11:47.020 --> 00:11:49.370

00:11:49.370 --> 00:11:51.810

00:11:51.810 --> 00:11:55.010
And I'm gonna have it there in

00:11:55.010 --> 00:11:56.570
And I can use the SIEM systems for

00:11:56.570 --> 00:12:01.390

Because it's so much information and

Mike, earlier, you mentioned in

Is that something that's gonna

There's still certain things

Like when we talk about

00:13:16.530 --> 00:13:18.180
Vulnerability scanners are great.

00:13:18.180 --> 00:13:20.548

00:13:38.150 --> 00:13:43.130
But that being said, some of the things

The human can say, yeah, that might be

This is where that human analyst

00:14:55.690 --> 00:14:57.611
You mentioned things like HIPAA and

00:14:57.611 --> 00:15:00.260
[INAUDIBLE] I think I

I've never say that one right.

>> Absolutely, understand the term

So we need to follow that,

You wanna if not bring somebody in.

I mean this is opening yourselves

If they come in and do, let's say, HIPAA

It can be upwards of $5,000

fines that you're gonna get levied, this

And so, we've gotta make sure we

00:16:44.170 --> 00:16:47.120
how long we have to keep the information,
when and

00:16:47.120 --> 00:16:48.960
how to dispose of that information.

308
00:16:50.070 --> 00:16:53.650
Once the retention period's over,
do I just take that banker's box and

00:16:53.650 --> 00:16:54.620
throw it in the garbage?

00:16:54.620 --> 00:16:56.300
Or does it have to go in the shredder?

00:16:56.300 --> 00:17:00.900
Do those hard drives have to get DoD

And everything is good.

00:17:03.170 --> 00:17:07.220
The data retention in itself

00:17:07.220 --> 00:17:09.970
Doesn't mean keep an electronic copy, or

Like I said,
in banker's boxes that you have to keep.

Talk to your lawyers, you know?

318

Make sure there's an organization.

This is where you need

One of the big things I always

Taking care of this ahead of time is

And protecting your network cuz that's

organization, protecting my data,
making sure that we're in business and

making money
>> It sounds like you're saying as well,

ignorance is not an excuse,

and audit the auditors here
>> Yes absolutely,

you can't say I didn't know, right,

If you are in the healthcare industry,

You can talk to other industries.

Go talk to the security guys for

another organization that's

Or in the same field as you.

Hey, how do you deal with this?

Let's talk about it.

And we're not gonna give up company

All right, let's talk a little bit now,

as we talked about data retention,

So now we're gonna start taking a look

And the first thing they mentioned is

00:19:19.957 --> 00:19:21.573
All right, so

That looks good.

Don't worry, I'm not giving away

But we can see things like domain name,

00:19:40.869 --> 00:19:44.983
multicast, looks like no IPv6 cvf.

There's some information

There's the IP address and

00:19:54.226 --> 00:19:58.710
And so this is a couple things that we
should think about when we're looking at

00:19:58.710 --> 00:19:59.470
this information.

00:19:59.470 --> 00:20:05.580
One, good for me to have as a security

We also wanna think about,

this is a relatively simple config file,

there can be a lot of sensitive

Like let's take a look at

It's not gonna be all that important on

So routing tables can

Cam tables are content addressable memory.

00:21:27.140 --> 00:21:28.470
And this is what switches use, right?

We've talked about switches in other

We know that a switch has what we

a CAM table, and that's where it maps

394
00:21:44.930 --> 00:21:45.520
Right?

395
00:21:45.520 --> 00:21:49.235
And so that when a switch is supposed to

00:21:51.080 --> 00:21:52.990
How does he know what

That cam table.

NAT tables, same thing.

A lot of information, a lot of NAT,

We've gotta make sure we

I do a little IP config, forward slash,

I can go back through here,

00:22:45.170 --> 00:22:46.720
I haven't been on the internet in a while.

Last pass is the last thing I saw.

But in here,

I should say recently resolved,
fully qualified domain names or

DNS names, mappings to IP addresses.

419
00:22:59.370 --> 00:23:03.880
And from this information I can

00:23:05.530 --> 00:23:08.570
Almost you can see their Internet

00:23:08.570 --> 00:23:10.220
So if I've got a compromised machine.

Or if there's anything left in it

Eventually those records

00:23:23.400 --> 00:23:26.320
So, pulling back that information.

426

What else?

ARP caches are another
one that we can look at.

428
00:23:29.760 --> 00:23:37.020
If I do an arp -a,
I can see all my IP to mac addresses.

429
00:23:37.020 --> 00:23:38.620
These are cached on my system.

430
00:23:40.630 --> 00:23:45.580
And looking at this information, I could

see two different IP addresses, point it

00:23:50.520 --> 00:23:53.759
an indication of a man in the middle

So pulling this information back,

434
00:23:57.480 --> 00:24:02.430
So, I guess in the end the point here is

a lot of different places not just your

00:24:07.795 --> 00:24:10.230
We've gotta make sure we understand

00:24:10.230 --> 00:24:13.650
all different places that we

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike continue their discussion on various data sources in cyber security. They look at firewall logs, IPS and IDS logs, web application firewall logs, carrier logs, network sniffers, operating system and vulnerability testing data

But there's a lot of places
to get information and

14
00:00:39.082 --> 00:00:44.450
that's really what this module or
this particular objective is all about.

15
00:00:44.450 --> 00:00:47.590
So, let's just pick up where we left
off and we were talking about some of

16
00:00:47.590 --> 00:00:52.370
the different locations as far as
network device data or state data like

17
00:00:52.370 --> 00:00:57.680
your routing tables on your routers,
your CAM tables on your switches.

18
00:00:57.680 --> 00:01:00.760
And we talked a little about
what I might find in there and

19
00:01:00.760 --> 00:01:04.010
why I need to protect that
information about our networks.

20
00:01:04.010 --> 00:01:06.950
Those routing tables, right,
if the outside world could

21
00:01:06.950 --> 00:01:11.950
somehow get your router to
share that routing information.

22
00:01:11.950 --> 00:01:15.790
They can find information about your

23
00:01:15.790 --> 00:01:21.360
gonna make it easier for the bad guys
to step through your network, right.

24
00:01:21.360 --> 00:01:22.240
Your CAM tables,

25
00:01:22.240 --> 00:01:26.270
where your switchers are keeping track of
what MAC addresses lie out what ports.

26
00:01:26.270 --> 00:01:28.740
If somebody's manipulating
that information,

27
00:01:28.740 --> 00:01:30.810
they might be try to sniff data.

28
00:01:30.810 --> 00:01:33.520
Remember, one of the things
about when we sniff traffic,

29
00:01:33.520 --> 00:01:37.010
we only see the traffic that's
destined for our network adapter and

30
00:01:37.010 --> 00:01:39.880
we go on to promiscuous mode now
we can see all the data even if

31
00:01:39.880 --> 00:01:43.880
it is not bound for us unless we're
on a switch Ethernet environment.

32
00:01:43.880 --> 00:01:46.540
And now all of a sudden the switch
is filtering the data before

33
00:01:46.540 --> 00:01:47.510
it ever gets to me.

34
00:01:47.510 --> 00:01:51.400
So how can I sniff Wes' traffic right
if I can't but if I can get in and

35
00:01:51.400 --> 00:01:56.350
I CAM table and convince that switch that
Wes' MAC address lies out my port then

36
00:01:56.350 --> 00:01:59.340
maybe I can get it to send his data out of
my port, I could capture that information.

37
00:01:59.340 --> 00:02:01.780
So playing around that CAM table.

38
00:02:01.780 --> 00:02:05.050
NAT tables again can give up
a lot of information about

39
00:02:05.050 --> 00:02:08.910
your internal networks and
DNS caches and ARP caches.

40
00:02:08.910 --> 00:02:14.030
Remember DNS is named IP address mappings,
this is where I can do spoofing,

41
00:02:14.030 --> 00:02:19.200
if I can convince your machine
that BankofAmerica.com

42
00:02:19.200 --> 00:02:23.380
is my IP address,
that can lead to attacks, right.

43
00:02:23.380 --> 00:02:26.840
The ARP cache, this is how we do man in
the middle attacks, is I convince one

44
00:02:26.840 --> 00:02:30.980
end of the conversation that the MAC
address he's trying to reach is me and

45
00:02:30.980 --> 00:02:34.480
I convince the other end of the
conversation that the MAC address they're
