00:25:31.990 --> 00:25:34.340
And again, it's a good practice
cuz we can look at these and

482
00:25:34.340 --> 00:25:36.980
go, can I see what this
is actually going to do?

483
00:25:36.980 --> 00:25:38.990
Because on the exam that's
what you're gonna get.

484
00:25:38.990 --> 00:25:40.560
You're not gonna be
creating the expression,

485
00:25:40.560 --> 00:25:43.510
they're gonna give you expressions and
you got to make sure you understand

486
00:25:43.510 --> 00:25:46.150
what that expression is
actually going to return.

487
00:25:47.370 --> 00:25:50.370
So, in this case they've got error4/i,

488
00:25:50.370 --> 00:25:55.140
the 4/i is making a case insensitive or
ignored case is what that's for.

489
00:25:55.140 --> 00:26:00.395
So, you can see it matches the word error,
even though there is capital E there.

490
00:26:00.395 --> 00:26:07.190
Mallius one two three, slash dot, or
backslash dot backslash W one comma four.

491
00:26:07.190 --> 00:26:10.110
Now what the heck is that looking for?

492
00:26:10.110 --> 00:26:15.669
Well, it's gonna match the name
one mallius one two three dot,

493
00:26:15.669 --> 00:26:20.270
and then my little W is

494
00:26:20.270 --> 00:26:25.630
saying word, one through four digits long,

495
00:26:25.630 --> 00:26:29.750
cuz my extension basically could be three
or four characters of what they're saying.

496
00:26:29.750 --> 00:26:35.880
So it would match mallius123.bat.,
alright.

497
00:26:35.880 --> 00:26:39.610
This one used to search for
email address, I know what that done.

498
00:26:39.610 --> 00:26:47.230
So, here they're saying remember the plus
is one or more instance all right.

499
00:26:47.230 --> 00:26:49.180
Yeah, plus is one.

500
00:26:49.180 --> 00:26:51.870
Sometimes they get those confused,
plus and asterisk.

501
00:26:51.870 --> 00:26:56.792
The plus of one origin is a dot and
then the @ symbol.

502
00:26:56.792 --> 00:26:58.140
>> But that's not negated though, so

503
00:26:58.140 --> 00:27:00.930
it must be a special character
>> What's that?

504
00:27:00.930 --> 00:27:04.150
>> Right, at the beginning of that,
that dot is not negated out.

505
00:27:04.150 --> 00:27:07.150
>> You know,
I honestly think this might be a typo

506
00:27:07.150 --> 00:27:11.250
because you wouldn't normally look for
a dot in front of the @ symbol.

507
00:27:11.250 --> 00:27:11.780
>> Agreed.

508
00:27:11.780 --> 00:27:13.164
>> What's that?
>> Agreed.

509
00:27:13.164 --> 00:27:16.485
>> Yeah, I think this might be
a little bit of a typo here, or

510
00:27:16.485 --> 00:27:19.060
it could be something that they're doing.

511
00:27:19.060 --> 00:27:22.060
In this case there is a dot, right?

512
00:27:22.060 --> 00:27:24.200
In the E, but
normally you're not looking for that.

513
00:27:24.200 --> 00:27:26.760
So my guess is this is a bit
of a mistake on the slide,

514
00:27:26.760 --> 00:27:29.430
we have to experiment around and
then we could test it out, but

515
00:27:29.430 --> 00:27:34.660
then there's an @ symbol and then
there's another data, and you know what?

516
00:27:34.660 --> 00:27:37.730
>> No, it is definitely,
it's the wild card, yeah.

517
00:27:37.730 --> 00:27:40.140
>> It's the wild card,
it's not the peer, silly me.

518
00:27:40.140 --> 00:27:41.989
I'm sitting and
going why are they putting that there?

519
00:27:43.530 --> 00:27:44.855
The fun of regular expressions.

520
00:27:44.855 --> 00:27:46.460
>> [LAUGH]
>> That is my wild card, so

521
00:27:46.460 --> 00:27:48.250
saying any number of characters.

522
00:27:48.250 --> 00:27:49.920
>> Right.
>> Is really what they are saying.

523
00:27:49.920 --> 00:27:52.730
And then the @ symbol and
then any number of characters,

524
00:27:52.730 --> 00:27:54.410
like the dot is the wild card.

525
00:27:54.410 --> 00:27:58.510
And it has to be at least one, cuz
a valid email address would have at least

526
00:27:58.510 --> 00:28:00.852
one character out in
front of that @ symbol.

527
00:28:00.852 --> 00:28:02.466
A @microsoft.com, right.

528
00:28:02.466 --> 00:28:07.845
There has to be some characters
after the @ symbol, right.

529
00:28:07.845 --> 00:28:12.538
The domain for the email address,then they
are saying should be a dot now they have

530
00:28:12.538 --> 00:28:16.210
escaped it,so this is actual dot
character not the wild card and

531
00:28:16.210 --> 00:28:18.740
then some characters,either A through Z.

532
00:28:19.840 --> 00:28:23.640
Two to four instances of A through Z, so

533
00:28:23.640 --> 00:28:29.529
the last could be dot com, dot TV,
>> Dot AU, whatever.

534
00:28:29.529 --> 00:28:33.700
>> Dot AU, I'm trying to think
of a four dot, dot party.

535
00:28:33.700 --> 00:28:35.323
That's five- that's
the new top of the band so

536
00:28:35.323 --> 00:28:36.552
you'd have to do two-
>> dot TV.

537
00:28:36.552 --> 00:28:39.090
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, dot TV for two.

538
00:28:39.090 --> 00:28:42.870
Yeah, what is a- what is a four?

539
00:28:43.970 --> 00:28:45.050
>> I don't know Vinnie.

540
00:28:45.050 --> 00:28:47.730
>> WWW3.
No that's the beginning.

541
00:28:47.730 --> 00:28:49.170
What am I thinking?

542
00:28:49.170 --> 00:28:51.140
>> Yeah.
>> I can't think of anything off top

543
00:28:51.140 --> 00:28:52.210
of my head.

544
00:28:52.210 --> 00:28:56.060
>> There are a bunch of new
ones that dot me, dot party,

545
00:28:56.060 --> 00:28:59.120
dot blah bla blah, I don't even know so.

546
00:28:59.120 --> 00:29:02.680
Down below that here's one looking for
the date and were not gonna.

547
00:29:02.680 --> 00:29:06.748
I know were about out of time so I think
we've seen enough examples of what we need

548
00:29:06.748 --> 00:29:09.660
to do, is be able to interpret these and
it can be tricky,

549
00:29:09.660 --> 00:29:12.080
you do have to spend a little time.

550
00:29:12.080 --> 00:29:16.180
Let me see if I can find the one, let's do
this one and then I'll find the one for

551
00:29:16.180 --> 00:29:17.440
the IP address as well,

552
00:29:17.440 --> 00:29:21.840
cause this one kinda shows a good example
of some groupings and some ors in here.

553
00:29:21.840 --> 00:29:26.390
So what it's saying is,
in this inner group, right?

554
00:29:26.390 --> 00:29:28.480
I've got a, we've got a month day year.

555
00:29:28.480 --> 00:29:31.900
And if you think of them about
the month format, right, two digits for

556
00:29:31.900 --> 00:29:36.870
the month well the first, it could be
the second month or the third month.

557
00:29:36.870 --> 00:29:38.240
How does that format look?

558
00:29:38.240 --> 00:29:41.210
Zero one if it's a two digit month format.

559
00:29:41.210 --> 00:29:43.570
So the first character is gonna be a zero.

560
00:29:43.570 --> 00:29:45.800
And then the second character
could be a one through nine.

561
00:29:45.800 --> 00:29:48.840
That would cover January, February,
March, April, May, June, July,

562
00:29:48.840 --> 00:29:49.700
August and September.

563
00:29:50.740 --> 00:29:56.440
Or there'll be a one out in front and
then a zero, which would be October.

564
00:29:56.440 --> 00:29:58.520
But then we got November and
December, 11 and 12.

565
00:29:58.520 --> 00:30:01.864
So one followed by either a zero,
one or two.

566
00:30:01.864 --> 00:30:06.180
There's no three,
because there is no month thirteen, right?

567
00:30:06.180 --> 00:30:07.370
So it's saying one of these.

568
00:30:07.370 --> 00:30:10.350
So you see how you're accounting for
all possibilities.

569
00:30:10.350 --> 00:30:15.800
But instead of trying to do it in one
complex expression, they're just saying,

570
00:30:15.800 --> 00:30:18.120
hey, let's look for all the months
that have zero in front of it,

571
00:30:18.120 --> 00:30:21.960
and then let's do an or, and look for all
the months that have a one in front of it.

572
00:30:21.960 --> 00:30:25.370
They kind of break it up into two parts,
and make it a lot easier to work with.

573
00:30:25.370 --> 00:30:29.057
>> Of course this example won't
work if someone uses 2/24.

574
00:30:29.057 --> 00:30:32.190
They have to do the 02 or
it's not going to work.

575
00:30:32.190 --> 00:30:34.130
>> Yes, and
that's where I come out here and

576
00:30:34.130 --> 00:30:37.600
have to put the question
mark right after that zero.

577
00:30:37.600 --> 00:30:38.710
So I'm saying there might or

578
00:30:38.710 --> 00:30:43.420
might not be a zero and then a one
through nine possibility, right?

579
00:30:43.420 --> 00:30:45.160
So we can start combining those things up.

580
00:30:45.160 --> 00:30:48.250
And then they escape the slash and
do the same thing for

581
00:30:48.250 --> 00:30:51.320
the dates, again accounting for
all possibilities.

582
00:30:51.320 --> 00:30:54.410
Zero one through 31 days in a month.

583
00:30:54.410 --> 00:30:58.430
So, zero one through nine, so that'd be
days zero through nine, and then one,

584
00:30:58.430 --> 00:31:01.530
and then some digit,
because it could be anything.

585
00:31:01.530 --> 00:31:06.690
Notice instead of doing a one to nine,
they just did a digit, right?

586
00:31:06.690 --> 00:31:08.650
Which they could have done here as well.

587
00:31:08.650 --> 00:31:10.630
So that would be, what, 10 through 19.

588
00:31:10.630 --> 00:31:15.537
And then a 2/d,
that'd be day 20 through 29.

589
00:31:15.537 --> 00:31:20.571
And then a three, and
it went back to the open closed bracket

590
00:31:20.571 --> 00:31:25.720
because it can't be a two,
there's no day 32 to day 34.

591
00:31:25.720 --> 00:31:28.620
So it's three open bracket zero one
closed bracket closed parenthesis.

592
00:31:28.620 --> 00:31:32.490
Close the entire parenthesis for
that whole set and then a slash and

593
00:31:32.490 --> 00:31:33.910
then dealing with a year.

594
00:31:33.910 --> 00:31:38.010
And then one more, let's take a look,
I think I've got an IP.

595
00:31:38.010 --> 00:31:42.520
Maybe I don't have an IP address range
in here, my computer's locked up.

596
00:31:43.690 --> 00:31:47.020
Oops, that was it, there it is.

597
00:31:47.020 --> 00:31:49.700
We've seen that, when there's a URL,

598
00:31:49.700 --> 00:31:55.221
that's a good one to look at.

599
00:31:55.221 --> 00:31:56.086
God, I can't get my computer to
play along with me, there we go.

600
00:31:56.086 --> 00:31:59.057
You can see they're doing
open parenthesis http or

601
00:31:59.057 --> 00:32:03.689
https colon Forward slash forward slash
and that looks really weird when look at

602
00:32:03.689 --> 00:32:07.367
it right.Back slash forward
slash back slash forward slash.

603
00:32:07.367 --> 00:32:13.762
They're escaping each one of those
forward slashes and then dot asterisk.

604
00:32:13.762 --> 00:32:16.396
>> Which is wildcard.

605
00:32:16.396 --> 00:32:21.650
>> Which is my wild card because
can be any number of characters.

606
00:32:21.650 --> 00:32:25.690
And then dot with the backslash,
so that's the period, right,

607
00:32:25.690 --> 00:32:29.640
the name .com or .edu or gov.

608
00:32:29.640 --> 00:32:32.150
So here they're accounting for
that domain, but

609
00:32:32.150 --> 00:32:36.415
then they're also accounting for
subdomains in there.

610
00:32:36.415 --> 00:32:40.955
You can see they've got another
forward slash, which is escape for

611
00:32:40.955 --> 00:32:45.895
the back slash, and then dot asterisk and
then optionally more than that, right?

612
00:32:45.895 --> 00:32:49.900
There's another back slash
optional dot asterisk, so

613
00:32:49.900 --> 00:32:53.745
again learning to interpret these is,
can I say fun?

614
00:32:53.745 --> 00:32:55.150
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.

615
00:32:55.150 --> 00:32:57.020
Yeah, that's what it is, fun.

616
00:32:57.020 --> 00:33:00.292
>> Yeah, all right,
when we start looking for

617
00:33:00.292 --> 00:33:04.104
IP addresses again it can
get just as complex here.

618
00:33:04.104 --> 00:33:07.383
You could see they are saying,
all right for Class C's,

619
00:33:07.383 --> 00:33:11.790
really the key here is to think
about what are all the possibility?

620
00:33:11.790 --> 00:33:14.610
How do I account for
all the possibilities?

621
00:33:14.610 --> 00:33:17.060
And what are they trying to do?

622
00:33:17.060 --> 00:33:22.350
Search for all Class C IP addresses,
so they're saying (19[2-9],

623
00:33:22.350 --> 00:33:27.310
so really what they should
say is all private range.

624
00:33:27.310 --> 00:33:28.759
No that's not right.

625
00:33:30.250 --> 00:33:31.190
Anyway, yeah.

626
00:33:31.190 --> 00:33:33.898
So one, nine and then two to nine.

627
00:33:33.898 --> 00:33:39.171
Here they've got their open parentheses

628
00:33:39.171 --> 00:33:45.150
then a digit, one through three digits,

629
00:33:45.150 --> 00:33:47.960
So a little shortcut syntax there.

630
00:33:47.960 --> 00:33:52.518
They're saying the digit can be anything,
there's gonna be at least or

631
00:33:52.518 --> 00:33:54.473
it could be one through three.

632
00:33:54.473 --> 00:33:56.454
No, what are they saying there?

633
00:33:56.454 --> 00:34:00.534
I take that back, what they're doing
here is they're saying at least one,

634
00:34:00.534 --> 00:34:02.332
up to three instances of a digit.

635
00:34:02.332 --> 00:34:07.150
And then they're saying this whole thing

636
00:34:07.150 --> 00:34:11.450
And then they're or and then they account
for anything that starts with a two and so

637
00:34:11.450 --> 00:34:12.960

638
00:34:12.960 --> 00:34:16.590
Playing around with these,

valid IP addresses, you can end

640
00:34:20.290 --> 00:34:23.355
But the best thing to do is just get

641
00:34:23.355 --> 00:34:27.516
>> Wow, I can't even say the word right.

642
00:34:27.516 --> 00:34:30.750
It's that offescating so

643
00:34:30.750 --> 00:34:34.540
mangling of the tongue of the mind
it just twists you into a pretzel.

644
00:34:34.540 --> 00:34:36.406
Regular expression,
not one of my favorite things to do.

645
00:34:36.406 --> 00:34:37.380
>> [LAUGH]
>> Probably not gonna

00:34:38.590 --> 00:34:42.040
>> Maybe it is, there are guys out

648
00:34:43.600 --> 00:34:47.480
As you could see, it's almost like a

649

reinterpreted by yet another language.

650
00:34:50.740 --> 00:34:52.830
It's a very twisty for

00:34:52.830 --> 00:34:56.420

me bonkers from time to time.

652
00:34:56.420 --> 00:34:58.040
I know it does the same thing for Mike.

00:34:58.040 --> 00:34:59.650
But it's something we got to know, right?

00:34:59.650 --> 00:35:02.530
So you need at least some

655
00:35:02.530 --> 00:35:03.920
Especially if you wanna pass this exam,

00:35:03.920 --> 00:35:06.700
they're gonna chuck something

00:35:06.700 --> 00:35:08.360
You need to have that level of knowledge,
so

00:35:08.360 --> 00:35:11.900

00:35:11.900 --> 00:35:15.381
And then as you start working in

661
00:35:18.102 --> 00:35:20.340
So you have to be able to

662
00:35:20.340 --> 00:35:24.319
Mike, thanks for you, you did walk us

663
00:35:24.319 --> 00:35:25.436

664
00:35:25.436 --> 00:35:27.980
How to use it from what
Mike has shown you,

665
00:35:27.980 --> 00:35:31.710
you should be able to get very
versed if you were so inclined.

666
00:35:31.710 --> 00:35:34.640
He gave you a lot of good
information on working with regex.

667
00:35:34.640 --> 00:35:37.094
We do appreciate that, and
we do appreciate you guys for watching,

668
00:35:37.094 --> 00:35:39.085

669
00:35:39.085 --> 00:35:42.380
Or just loving every last second of

670
00:35:42.380 --> 00:35:47.240
But it is has come that time yet again for

671
00:35:47.240 --> 00:35:50.410
Thanks for watching for ITPROTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowery.

00:35:50.410 --> 00:35:51.320

00:35:59.983 --> 00:36:01.790

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike show you some of the common tools used in the Windows OS to analyze security incidents. Here they will walk you through using tools like Regedit, Wireshark, netstat, nmap, SpaceSniffer, Tasklist, msconfig, and AD explorer.
episodes.title: Analyze Incidents with Windows

movie actors and stuff?

481
00:26:05.173 --> 00:26:06.063
>> [LAUGH]
>> They're just people.

482
00:26:06.063 --> 00:26:09.316

[CROSSTALK] Will you sign my book.

483
00:26:09.316 --> 00:26:13.180
>> [LAUGH] So
I guess we all got our heroes, right?

484
00:26:13.180 --> 00:26:16.880
[LAUGH] But you can see, this is
a pretty cool view of what's going.

485
00:26:16.880 --> 00:26:18.770
My system, let me zoom in here.

486
00:26:18.770 --> 00:26:20.380
Take a look.

487
00:26:20.380 --> 00:26:21.540
Process Explorer.

488
00:26:22.770 --> 00:26:23.940
Which one did I fire up first?

489
00:26:23.940 --> 00:26:25.550
I forgot.
Yeah, Process Explorer

490
00:26:25.550 --> 00:26:28.390
really good at examining
resource utilization.

491
00:26:28.390 --> 00:26:30.190
What is it that's using up all my memory?

492
00:26:30.190 --> 00:26:33.010
What is it that's using
up all my processor?

493
00:26:33.010 --> 00:26:36.660
I can see that information here and
notice it's dynamic.

494
00:26:36.660 --> 00:26:39.160
It's changing as we go.

495
00:26:39.160 --> 00:26:43.150
I can take a look at these
individual Items that can kill them,

496
00:26:43.150 --> 00:26:47.220
it can suspend them, it could even
send these out to virus total.

497
00:26:47.220 --> 00:26:53.140
The other one is going to
be processed monitor and

498
00:26:53.140 --> 00:26:57.010
where as process explorer's more about
examining the resource utilization.

499
00:26:57.010 --> 00:27:00.630
Process monitor is really
looking at process interaction.

500
00:27:00.630 --> 00:27:02.700
What is interacting with what.

501
00:27:02.700 --> 00:27:07.950
What calls are, well that's different.

502
00:27:07.950 --> 00:27:09.760
There we go.

503
00:27:09.760 --> 00:27:10.430
>> Work with us computer [LAUGH].

504
00:27:10.430 --> 00:27:13.626
>> Just like a typical user I didn't
even read the error I just closed it.

505
00:27:13.626 --> 00:27:14.253
[LAUGH].

506
00:27:14.253 --> 00:27:15.100
>> Just closed it.

507
00:27:15.100 --> 00:27:17.190
>> I'll regret that later off screen.

508
00:27:17.190 --> 00:27:21.950
But here I can see, what processors
are reaching out and touching and

509
00:27:21.950 --> 00:27:22.740
what are they touching?

510
00:27:22.740 --> 00:27:25.200
It's reaching out and
touching this DLL, right.

511
00:27:26.900 --> 00:27:28.980
Boy, that is even small for me to see.

512
00:27:28.980 --> 00:27:34.610
Wmiprvse is reaching out and
talking to Fastprox.dll.

513
00:27:34.610 --> 00:27:36.520
Is that something that
should be happening?

514
00:27:36.520 --> 00:27:38.670
Maybe I need to do some investigation,
right?

515
00:27:38.670 --> 00:27:41.010
So, you can see a lot of
good information here.

516
00:27:43.270 --> 00:27:44.650
What else?

517
00:27:44.650 --> 00:27:48.100
You can narrow this down, like you
can show it just network activity.

518
00:27:48.100 --> 00:27:49.910
Let me turn all these off here.

519
00:27:52.163 --> 00:27:56.720
Get rid of everything so
I can look at process and thread activity.

520
00:27:56.720 --> 00:27:58.670
I can look at network activity.

521
00:27:58.670 --> 00:28:01.050
What's reaching out and
talking to my network.

522
00:28:01.050 --> 00:28:02.930
I've got file system activity.

523
00:28:04.050 --> 00:28:06.490
And I've got registry activity.

524
00:28:06.490 --> 00:28:08.350
Or you can turn them all on.

525
00:28:08.350 --> 00:28:10.390
And there's even a little
profiling events but

526
00:28:10.390 --> 00:28:12.960
that's this thing going out and
looking at my system.

527
00:28:12.960 --> 00:28:15.150
So, another good tool for

528
00:28:15.150 --> 00:28:20.150
analyzing processes running on
a Windows based system, right?

529
00:28:20.150 --> 00:28:23.370
Services, we need to know what
services are running on this system.

530
00:28:23.370 --> 00:28:26.380
Again, I might have malware
running in the background.

531
00:28:26.380 --> 00:28:29.760
We've got our standard tools
that we can use in Windows.

532
00:28:29.760 --> 00:28:36.100
If I type in services.msc I can
launch up my services console.

533
00:28:36.100 --> 00:28:40.730
And here I can see what services I have
which ones are running and I can sort this

534
00:28:40.730 --> 00:28:46.610
by status, I can take a look at
the startup type for these services.

535
00:28:46.610 --> 00:28:50.890
Which ones are set automatic or
manual, or delayed start.

536
00:28:52.570 --> 00:28:55.310
But it's always good to have
more than one tool, cuz said,

537
00:28:55.310 --> 00:28:58.520
malware likes to hide from
some of known Windows tools.

538
00:28:58.520 --> 00:29:01.340
Services Console definitely
one we can look at.

539
00:29:01.340 --> 00:29:04.960
You can also look at msconfig,
that's an oldie but

540
00:29:04.960 --> 00:29:07.720
a goodie, been around for a while.

541
00:29:07.720 --> 00:29:10.160
And this will show you services as well.

542
00:29:10.160 --> 00:29:13.770
One of the nice things about
msconfig other than the fact that

543
00:29:13.770 --> 00:29:16.140
you can't resize the window
which drives me crazy.

544
00:29:16.140 --> 00:29:20.560
Is that I have a check mark
hide all Microsoft services and

545
00:29:20.560 --> 00:29:23.880
it makes it a little bit easier
to at least get to third party.

546
00:29:23.880 --> 00:29:25.940
Not saying that everything
from Microsoft is trustworthy.

547
00:29:25.940 --> 00:29:27.330
If I'm gonna make something and

548
00:29:27.330 --> 00:29:31.240
disguise it, I'll try to make it
look like a Microsoft file, maybe.

549
00:29:31.240 --> 00:29:33.510
But Startup is no longer in system config.

550
00:29:33.510 --> 00:29:35.420
That's done through Task Manager, but

551
00:29:35.420 --> 00:29:39.070
they do give you a link to
jump over to Task Manager.

552
00:29:39.070 --> 00:29:41.950
Here I can see things are set
to start automatically.

553
00:29:41.950 --> 00:29:43.500
Another good place to go.

554
00:29:43.500 --> 00:29:47.010
If we go back to the registry
under current control set,

555
00:29:47.010 --> 00:29:51.780
one I didn't show you h key
local machine software Microsoft

556
00:29:51.780 --> 00:29:56.960
windows current control set, there's going
to be a key called run once and run.

557
00:29:56.960 --> 00:30:00.190
And these are things that are set to run
automatically when the system boots up.

558
00:30:00.190 --> 00:30:02.350
Another great place they
like to stash malware.

559
00:30:02.350 --> 00:30:04.940
You get rid of it,
you reboot the system and it's back.

560
00:30:04.940 --> 00:30:05.610
How did it get back?

561
00:30:05.610 --> 00:30:08.970
Cuz they hid it in those
run keys in your registry.

562
00:30:08.970 --> 00:30:10.040
Or you might come in here and

563
00:30:10.040 --> 00:30:14.500
see that it's configured to start up
automatically when you start that system.

564
00:30:14.500 --> 00:30:20.770
All right, another thing we want to
talk about is volatile memory analysis.

565
00:30:20.770 --> 00:30:22.235
Great place to look for evidence.

566
00:30:22.235 --> 00:30:24.815
Remember, when we're looking at evidence.

567
00:30:24.815 --> 00:30:27.195
We have to think about
the order of volatility.

568
00:30:27.195 --> 00:30:30.645
We wanna grab things
that are gonna go away.

569
00:30:30.645 --> 00:30:35.515
RAM being one of those that we wanna try
to capture early on, cuz of power failure

570
00:30:35.515 --> 00:30:40.095
or if machine get shutdown we get
ready to take it back to lab, right?

571
00:30:40.095 --> 00:30:44.480
We lose anything that's in RAM, so
we wanna try to get that information out.

572
00:30:44.480 --> 00:30:48.080
We're not going to actually
do a RAM scrape here, but

573
00:30:48.080 --> 00:30:52.570
I do want to show you a tool that can
be used to analyze that after the fact.

574
00:30:52.570 --> 00:30:53.870
And that's called Volatility.

575
00:30:53.870 --> 00:30:56.700
There are, again,
several that you can use.

576
00:30:56.700 --> 00:31:01.467
One of the cool things I found with,
where did I put that guy?

577
00:31:01.467 --> 00:31:04.730
There we are.

578
00:31:07.280 --> 00:31:15.110
I thought I moved this guy somewhere a
little more friendly, but maybe I did not.

579
00:31:15.110 --> 00:31:22.370
So Volatility, and why this command prompt
has a very small size, let's do that.

580
00:31:22.370 --> 00:31:27.610
And- That might be a little too big,
but we'll make it work, right?

581
00:31:27.610 --> 00:31:31.030
With Volatility we're
gonna launch the tool.

582
00:31:31.030 --> 00:31:35.680
And then, what you do is you tell it
what filename you want to analyze,

583
00:31:36.980 --> 00:31:38.540
this would be your memory dump.

584
00:31:38.540 --> 00:31:41.490
Now I've gone out and found there's some
really cool sites out there that have

585
00:31:41.490 --> 00:31:47.170
sample memory dumps of infected machines,
that you can use to practice your skills.

586
00:31:47.170 --> 00:31:51.769
I've got one of those here and you tell
it what, where the memory dump is and

587
00:31:51.769 --> 00:31:54.695
you have to tell it what
profile your gonna use.

588
00:31:54.695 --> 00:31:57.669
And the one I'm gonna use this
is from an Windows XP machine.

589
00:31:57.669 --> 00:32:02.170
So, I'm gonna do profile equals win

590
00:32:07.730 --> 00:32:08.688
>> XPSP2X86,

591
00:32:08.688 --> 00:32:12.010
cuz it has to know what
operating system dumped this.

592
00:32:12.010 --> 00:32:14.628
What is this from?

593
00:32:14.628 --> 00:32:19.430
So it knows the way things are organized
and how to display it for us,

594
00:32:19.430 --> 00:32:24.249
and then I can do different switches
with it like let's do sockets.

595
00:32:26.846 --> 00:32:30.685
And what this is gonna do is, it's looking
at this memory dump and you've gotta

596
00:32:30.685 --> 00:32:34.318
think that the memory dump is like
a snapshot of RAM from a running machine.

597
00:32:34.318 --> 00:32:38.600
So at the time this snapshot was taken,
what sockets were open?

598
00:32:38.600 --> 00:32:41.560
And I can see the different sockets here.

599
00:32:41.560 --> 00:32:44.132
Very cool.
Now, let's do a question mark with this

600
00:32:44.132 --> 00:32:47.040
guy, so I can show you some
of the options with that.

601
00:32:51.294 --> 00:32:53.665
Maybe, just thinking about it.

602
00:32:53.665 --> 00:32:54.407
That's right.

603
00:32:54.407 --> 00:32:55.540
That's a dash h for these guys.

604
00:33:00.978 --> 00:33:01.651
So, let's let it load up.

605
00:33:01.651 --> 00:33:03.350
>> Wow, what options.

606
00:33:03.350 --> 00:33:06.623
>> Yeah, there's a lot of switches
that you can use with it.

607
00:33:06.623 --> 00:33:10.284
The ones I was using there,
you got to point it to your file name and

608
00:33:10.284 --> 00:33:14.081
your profile and you can do --info
to get all the other profiles and

609
00:33:14.081 --> 00:33:16.830
then these are the plugins
that you're firing.

610
00:33:16.830 --> 00:33:22.038
So maybe I wanna look at API hooks or
I wanna look at dll list.

611
00:33:22.038 --> 00:33:26.430
What dlls were loaded up
when this dump was taken?

612
00:33:26.430 --> 00:33:30.490
So I can do that same command again and
just sent that to,

613
00:33:30.490 --> 00:33:32.360
what was that, dll dump?

614
00:33:32.360 --> 00:33:35.602
If I remember, dlllist.

615
00:33:35.602 --> 00:33:40.923
So, dlllist and
it's gonna show me again what dlls were

616
00:33:40.923 --> 00:33:46.470
loaded up in memory at the time
that this dump was taken.

617
00:33:46.470 --> 00:33:49.492
So this is how I can go back and
start looking and seeing again,

618
00:33:49.492 --> 00:33:51.656
what was going on that
machine at that time.

619
00:33:51.656 --> 00:33:54.360
They also mention in this objective
some Active Directory tools.

620
00:33:54.360 --> 00:33:55.363
They didn't load any of those up.

621
00:33:55.363 --> 00:33:59.715
We've got our standard
Active Directory consoles that we

622
00:33:59.715 --> 00:34:04.510
get in our domain controllers or
in our management utilities for

623
00:34:04.510 --> 00:34:09.304
Windows domains, but
there's also other tools you can get like

624
00:34:09.304 --> 00:34:14.900
AD Explorer which lets you go in and
pull back information on objects.

625
00:34:14.900 --> 00:34:17.313
What do we wanna look for
in Active Directory?

626
00:34:17.313 --> 00:34:20.422
Well, really we wanna monitor,
one of the big things you monitor for

627
00:34:20.422 --> 00:34:23.860
in Active Directory are new accounts and
group membership changes.

628
00:34:23.860 --> 00:34:25.608
Those are the kind of
things I wanna look for,

629
00:34:25.608 --> 00:34:28.704
cuz the bad guys are gonna be making new
accounts that they can use as a back door.

630
00:34:28.704 --> 00:34:32.660
So monitoring those,
using tools like AD Explorer.

631
00:34:32.660 --> 00:34:36.418
So, lot of different tools we have at our
disposal when we are examining a Windows

632
00:34:36.418 --> 00:34:37.647
based operating system.

633
00:34:37.647 --> 00:34:38.647
>> That's right.

634
00:34:38.647 --> 00:34:43.850
Windows has no lack of available options,
either built-in or third party provided.

635
00:34:43.850 --> 00:34:46.886
So if you need to to do some
analysis on a Windows machine,

636
00:34:46.886 --> 00:34:49.179
there's plenty of options there for you.

637
00:34:49.179 --> 00:34:51.465
That being said, Mike,
I'm looking at the time.

638
00:34:51.465 --> 00:34:52.663
We've run well out of it.

639
00:34:52.663 --> 00:34:55.315
For this episode,
we do thank you for joining us and

640
00:34:55.315 --> 00:34:58.770
walking us through some of the options
that we do have available for

641
00:34:58.770 --> 00:35:01.510
us doing analysis inside
of a Windows machine.

642
00:35:01.510 --> 00:35:03.283
That being said, we do thank you guys for

643
00:35:03.283 --> 00:35:05.800
joining us as well, but
it is that time for us to sign off.

644
00:35:05.800 --> 00:35:08.260
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

645
00:35:08.260 --> 00:35:09.094
>> And I'm Mike Roderick.

646
00:35:09.094 --> 00:35:10.542
>> And we'll see you next time.

647
00:35:10.542 --> 00:35:17.585
[MUSIC]

648
00:35:17.585 --> 00:35:24.279
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike show you some of the common tools used in Linux operating systems to analyze security incidents. Here they will walk you through using tools like nmap, tcpdump, dd, htop, free, rwho, and lastlog.
episodes.title: Analyze Incidents with Linux
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

>> All right, greetings, everyone and

I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode,

00:00:22.460 --> 00:00:25.768

00:00:25.768 --> 00:00:26.807
No [LAUGH].

12
00:00:26.807 --> 00:00:27.997
>> [LAUGH]
>> You look a little more

00:00:27.997 --> 00:00:28.644
like Mike Rodrick.

14
00:00:28.644 --> 00:00:30.114
That's who it is Mick Rodrick is

15
00:00:30.114 --> 00:00:30.716
joining us-

16
00:00:30.716 --> 00:00:31.989
>> [LAUGH]
>> Mike welcome.

17
00:00:31.989 --> 00:00:32.895
>> And
we won't be drawing any views today.

18
00:00:32.895 --> 00:00:34.783
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Thanks for having me,

19
00:00:34.783 --> 00:00:36.041
excited to be here as always.

20
00:00:36.041 --> 00:00:36.668
And yeah,

21
00:00:36.668 --> 00:00:41.940
continuing on with our good old CyberSec
First Responder from Logical Operations.

22
00:00:41.940 --> 00:00:44.520
All right, in this one, we're just gonna
kinda continue our thought process.

23
00:00:44.520 --> 00:00:48.036
In the previous episode, we were looking
at different tools we could use to analyze

24
00:00:48.036 --> 00:00:49.454
incidents on a Windows machine.

25
00:00:49.454 --> 00:00:52.251
Now we wanna take a look
at a Linux machine,

26
00:00:52.251 --> 00:00:55.768
and you'll see there's
a lot of similarities here.

27
00:00:55.768 --> 00:01:00.607
The first thing we're going to talk about
is tools that we have to use to look at

28
00:01:00.607 --> 00:01:05.089
the network, and surprise,
surprise they're the same tools right?

29
00:01:05.089 --> 00:01:07.894
Nmap, we know Nmap as a port scanner,

30
00:01:07.894 --> 00:01:12.640
does a little more than that but
is hard it's a port scanner.

31
00:01:12.640 --> 00:01:17.200
And so we can use Nmap in Linux, just like
we can in Windows, to scan our machine,

32
00:01:17.200 --> 00:01:19.020
see what ports are open.

33
00:01:19.020 --> 00:01:20.170
Why is that important?

34
00:01:20.170 --> 00:01:21.825
Because we need to know what
our machines are listening on.

35
00:01:21.825 --> 00:01:25.694
We need to look for signs of
malware that has a listener going.

36
00:01:25.694 --> 00:01:29.712
Some kind of back door that
maybe somebody has installed or

37
00:01:29.712 --> 00:01:34.800
they're transferring files out of
some port that's not normally open.

38
00:01:34.800 --> 00:01:37.780
And we can find that
using a tool like Nmap.

39
00:01:37.780 --> 00:01:39.905
Netstat, we saw that in Windows,

40
00:01:39.905 --> 00:01:43.733
I don't need to fire that up
against same information there.

41
00:01:43.733 --> 00:01:46.220
Wireshark, another one, right?

42
00:01:46.220 --> 00:01:50.054
Packet capture utility that we can use to
capture the traffic that's going across on

43
00:01:50.054 --> 00:01:51.739
the network, see what's going on.

44
00:01:51.739 --> 00:01:55.860
See what protocols are being used,
to look inside the packet,

45
00:01:55.860 --> 00:01:59.771
see what data's moving around,
if they are in plain text.

46
00:01:59.771 --> 00:02:03.327
There is one though that I'll show you
here that we didn't look in Windows.

47
00:02:03.327 --> 00:02:07.144
It's another packet capture utility,
and it's called Tcpdump.

48
00:02:07.144 --> 00:02:12.991
And it's basically a text version, it's
very similar in functionality I guess,

49
00:02:12.991 --> 00:02:15.672
it's the same as Wireshark, right?

50
00:02:15.672 --> 00:02:18.800
It's designed to grab network traffic.

51
00:02:18.800 --> 00:02:22.950
It's a packet capture utility, so
you can see as soon as I type Tcpdump and

52
00:02:22.950 --> 00:02:24.020
hit Enter.

53
00:02:24.020 --> 00:02:28.730
I can see all the traffic that's going
on between this machine and the network.

54
00:02:28.730 --> 00:02:31.620
So I'll close that, so that was Tcpdump.

55
00:02:31.620 --> 00:02:37.320
A traceroute is the same thing as has
tracert in our Windows environment.

56
00:02:37.320 --> 00:02:39.681
It's gonna give me
information about the path,

57
00:02:39.681 --> 00:02:42.858
that my pockets are taking on
the way to their final destination.

58
00:02:42.858 --> 00:02:45.043
Arp which we didn't look at in Windows,
but

59
00:02:45.043 --> 00:02:47.475
they do call out here on
the Linux side of things.

60
00:02:47.475 --> 00:02:52.300
But could be used in Windows just
as easy and for the same purpose.

61
00:02:52.300 --> 00:02:55.120
Arp is may address resolution protocol.

62
00:02:55.120 --> 00:03:00.409
This will be used to translate, or
it's what the TPC IP stack uses

63
00:03:00.409 --> 00:03:06.387
to resolve IP addresses in Mac addresses
for that last leg of its journey.

64
00:03:06.387 --> 00:03:11.121
We can do like an arp,
I don't really see a lot in here, but

65
00:03:11.121 --> 00:03:15.579
it's going to show me as I'm
looking at the arp cache.

66
00:03:15.579 --> 00:03:20.930
I can see,
what's recently been resolved, right?

67
00:03:20.930 --> 00:03:22.100
What is my machine?

68
00:03:22.100 --> 00:03:24.372
How to take the IP address forward and
turn it into a MAC address.

69
00:03:24.372 --> 00:03:27.817
I would see those there, and we would
be looking for unusual activity or

70
00:03:27.817 --> 00:03:29.091
unusual entries in here.

71
00:03:29.091 --> 00:03:33.159
Especially like duplications where I see
two different IP addresses pointing to

72
00:03:33.159 --> 00:03:34.840
the same MAC address.

73
00:03:34.840 --> 00:03:37.423
Good idea, something is going wrong there,
something is going on.

74
00:03:37.423 --> 00:03:41.390
Very well could be the beginnings
of a man in the middle of attack or

75
00:03:41.390 --> 00:03:45.520
somebody slipping in between two
nodes in a conversation, right?

76
00:03:45.520 --> 00:03:49.324
Ifconfig is a tool,
I'll go ahead and run it here.

77
00:03:49.324 --> 00:03:50.520
I'm sure we've seen it before.

78
00:03:50.520 --> 00:03:53.530
It's like ipconfig in windows.

79
00:03:53.530 --> 00:03:56.650
This is how I can look at
my TCP IP configuration for

80
00:03:56.650 --> 00:04:00.000
my different network adapters, right?

81
00:04:00.000 --> 00:04:04.980
When it comes to the file system in Linux,
a few different tools we can use.

82
00:04:04.980 --> 00:04:09.460
Lsof shows me a list of the files
that have been accessed, and

83
00:04:09.460 --> 00:04:13.680
more than that processes that
are accessing resources.

84
00:04:13.680 --> 00:04:15.989
As you can see, it's a long list here.

85
00:04:17.030 --> 00:04:21.695
But lsof allows me to list
that information out, so

86
00:04:21.695 --> 00:04:27.238
it's kind of like a processor
explorer might be in Windows.

87
00:04:27.238 --> 00:04:28.020
What else?

88
00:04:28.020 --> 00:04:29.590
Iperf is one.

89
00:04:29.590 --> 00:04:31.390
I don't have that one set up.

90
00:04:31.390 --> 00:04:33.758
With iperf,
you take two different machines and

91
00:04:33.758 --> 00:04:35.731
you run basically a client and a server.

92
00:04:35.731 --> 00:04:40.402
You can transmit data back and forth and
you can look at the bandwidth utilization.

93
00:04:40.402 --> 00:04:44.380
DD, we've made fun of-
>> [LAUGH]

94
00:04:44.380 --> 00:04:45.117
>> Have made fun of,

95
00:04:45.117 --> 00:04:48.472
but we've teased about this one before,
about what DD stands for right Daniel?

96
00:04:48.472 --> 00:04:50.280
>> Disk data destroyer and disk destroyer.

97
00:04:50.280 --> 00:04:52.756
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, data destroyer,
disk destroyer exactly.

98
00:04:52.756 --> 00:04:59.482
But it's what we would use to
create a copy of really anythiny.

99
00:04:59.482 --> 00:05:00.821
But typically of a hard drive, right?

100
00:05:00.821 --> 00:05:05.458
If we wanna make that copy that
we're gonna use to do analyze,

101
00:05:05.458 --> 00:05:07.780
we can use DD to do that.

102
00:05:07.780 --> 00:05:11.900
There are other newer versions of DD that
we can use as well that are maybe a little

103
00:05:11.900 --> 00:05:13.324
more forensically sound.

104
00:05:13.324 --> 00:05:16.860
But DD's built into most systems,
I could do a man dd.

105
00:05:16.860 --> 00:05:21.588
And you can see there's quite a few
switches that I can use with it.

106
00:05:21.588 --> 00:05:26.800
But it'll make that bit by bit
copy that we're looking for.

107
00:05:26.800 --> 00:05:29.283
Cuz then we can run our
hashing algorithms,

108
00:05:29.283 --> 00:05:31.577
verify that they're exactly the same.

109
00:05:31.577 --> 00:05:33.630
And then I can work with that copy and

110
00:05:33.630 --> 00:05:37.337
not mess with the original drive
that's under investigation.

111
00:05:37.337 --> 00:05:41.270
All right, so that would be dd.

112
00:05:41.270 --> 00:05:45.590
When it comes to processes
that we're working with in

113
00:05:45.590 --> 00:05:48.858
Linux top is the one that we all think of.

114
00:05:48.858 --> 00:05:53.670
I run top and I can see some
information about the system itself.

115
00:05:53.670 --> 00:05:58.042
What my current CPU utilisation is,
processes that are going on,

116
00:05:58.042 --> 00:05:59.612
what the process ID is.

117
00:05:59.612 --> 00:06:01.775
Who the ower of that processor is,

118
00:06:01.775 --> 00:06:05.290
what resources it is consuming
as far as CPU and memory.

119
00:06:05.290 --> 00:06:06.583
And what command, and

120
00:06:06.583 --> 00:06:10.815
how long they've been running, and
you can see it's actually dynamic.

121
00:06:10.815 --> 00:06:16.255
It's not just a static representation,
I mean it's changing as we speak.

122
00:06:16.255 --> 00:06:18.784
So it's kinda that live view,

123
00:06:18.784 --> 00:06:24.150
much like we would see in
Task Manager in our Windows system.

124
00:06:24.150 --> 00:06:28.502
There's also another one, you can go out
and get called htop, which is little bit

125
00:06:28.502 --> 00:06:32.622
more information and it's also a little
prettier it's kind of color coded.

126
00:06:32.622 --> 00:06:34.644
>> We like the colors, right?

127
00:06:34.644 --> 00:06:35.852
I haven't played with it.

128
00:06:35.852 --> 00:06:39.745
Top is it works fine if you've
come from the days of your-

129
00:06:39.745 --> 00:06:40.344
>> Yeah.

130
00:06:40.344 --> 00:06:44.679
[LAUGH]
>> I've been using Linux since like 2000.

131
00:06:44.679 --> 00:06:47.097
No, no, no, 1998 was the-
>> There you go.

132
00:06:47.097 --> 00:06:49.695
>> First time I installed, so
I'm in before the millenium there.

133
00:06:49.695 --> 00:06:51.655
But you just kinda get
used to these things, but

134
00:06:51.655 --> 00:06:53.230
I do like things that are color coded.

135
00:06:53.230 --> 00:06:57.122
So I probably will eventually like, now
that I'm running Linux more as my daily

136
00:06:57.122 --> 00:06:59.752
driver that's something that
I would do is use htop.

137
00:06:59.752 --> 00:07:02.766
Cuz having things like that can
really make this analysis process.

138
00:07:02.766 --> 00:07:06.404
You would think that's silly,
it's just colors, it makes it easier.

139
00:07:06.404 --> 00:07:11.051
It makes you be able to more visually
have a better idea of what's

140
00:07:11.051 --> 00:07:12.955
going on at a faster pace.

141
00:07:12.955 --> 00:07:16.558
Where before everything is just white text
kinda jumbled together and you have to go,

142
00:07:16.558 --> 00:07:19.075
okay, I gotta look in this area,
I gotta look in that area.

143
00:07:19.075 --> 00:07:24.106
Htop does a better job of steering
you toward areas that you might wanna

144
00:07:24.106 --> 00:07:29.236
be seeing, because of the colors and
things and the way they format it.

145
00:07:29.236 --> 00:07:32.198
So I would say use htop over top,
but no top.

146
00:07:32.198 --> 00:07:37.155
Because it's gonna be ubiquitous
throughout the systems where htop isn't.

147
00:07:37.155 --> 00:07:39.634
I've got a Linux system in front
of me right now, htop, nothing.

148
00:07:39.634 --> 00:07:40.948
It's not there, I'd have to install it.

149
00:07:40.948 --> 00:07:42.736
>> Right.
>> Top worked fine, Mike.

150
00:07:42.736 --> 00:07:43.340
>> Exactly.

151
00:07:43.340 --> 00:07:44.734
It's always going to be there.

152
00:07:44.734 --> 00:07:46.301
If you wanna take a look at my screen,

153
00:07:46.301 --> 00:07:48.534
I went out to the gentleman's
site that wrote htop.

154
00:07:48.534 --> 00:07:51.729
And you can see it's got
some screen shots here, and

155
00:07:51.729 --> 00:07:56.228
as well it looks like somehow same
information that we are getting from top

156
00:07:56.228 --> 00:07:59.860
a little prettier,
like you said color coded.

157
00:07:59.860 --> 00:08:00.817
Nice little graphs up here and

158
00:08:00.817 --> 00:08:02.968
little additional information
that they're throwing up there.

159
00:08:02.968 --> 00:08:09.838
I think we can see one and we had one
that was actually moving around there.

160
00:08:09.838 --> 00:08:13.710
But anyway,
you can see nice color coding to it.

161
00:08:13.710 --> 00:08:15.980
As Daniel said, sometimes that
makes the information stick out,

162
00:08:15.980 --> 00:08:21.410
especially abnormal information might pop
out a little more with that color coding.

163
00:08:22.620 --> 00:08:25.140
All right, so
we'll get back over to my Linux machine.

164
00:08:25.140 --> 00:08:27.811
I killed top,
we'll get rid of that one there.

165
00:08:27.811 --> 00:08:30.601
Ps is another one that we can use.

166
00:08:30.601 --> 00:08:33.979
Take a look at the processes
that are running on my system.

167
00:08:33.979 --> 00:08:35.556
You can do a man, oops.

168
00:08:35.556 --> 00:08:36.275
>> MSN.

169
00:08:36.275 --> 00:08:37.796
[LAUGH]
>> MSN, we could do that too.

170
00:08:37.796 --> 00:08:39.774
>> We're gonna go check a news outlet and
see how this thing works.

171
00:08:39.774 --> 00:08:41.104
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, gotta see what's going on.

172
00:08:41.104 --> 00:08:45.307
We'll see how the prosecution is going or
the indictments are going against

173
00:08:45.307 --> 00:08:48.206
the people that did the Yahoo
breach a few years ago.

174
00:08:48.206 --> 00:08:53.347
But here, you can see the man page for
it, it's rather lengthy.

175
00:08:53.347 --> 00:08:56.207
A lot of different
switches that I can use,

176
00:08:56.207 --> 00:09:00.511
depending on how I want that
output to be formatted, all right?

177
00:09:00.511 --> 00:09:03.030
So get familiar with that and
play around with it.

178
00:09:03.030 --> 00:09:05.210
Check and
see what information I can get, but

179
00:09:05.210 --> 00:09:09.840
again it's showing me the process ID,
what terminal is owning that.

180
00:09:09.840 --> 00:09:12.272
How long it's been running or when it
was running, what command was run there.

181
00:09:12.272 --> 00:09:16.393
>> I typically find myself
using the PS/AX or AXU switch.

182
00:09:16.393 --> 00:09:17.249
>> Let's try it.

183
00:09:17.249 --> 00:09:22.970
>> Cuz sometimes PS, as you saw when Mike
ran it, didn't show you a whole lot.

184
00:09:22.970 --> 00:09:26.042
But I bet if you do ps -ax, yeah,
get a little bit more there.

185
00:09:26.042 --> 00:09:27.236
>> Get a little bit more information.

186
00:09:27.236 --> 00:09:30.450
>> And then you can find process IDs,
like Mike was talking about.

187
00:09:30.450 --> 00:09:34.856
Typically, I'll need to find a process ID
to kill a process that's gone rogue, and

188
00:09:34.856 --> 00:09:37.724
sometimes my browser locks up and
just won't go away.

189
00:09:37.724 --> 00:09:41.888
ps -ax, sweet, there's the process ID,
kill, sometimes kill -9,

190
00:09:41.888 --> 00:09:44.451
which will Definitely murder that process.

191
00:09:44.451 --> 00:09:46.404
Put two in the back of its head and
bury it in a shallow grave.

192
00:09:46.404 --> 00:09:47.821
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah.

193
00:09:47.821 --> 00:09:48.769
[LAUGH]
>> As it does do.

194
00:09:48.769 --> 00:09:49.817
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

195
00:09:49.817 --> 00:09:52.086
>> And it's similar information what we're

196
00:09:52.086 --> 00:09:55.877
seeing from top it's not a dynamic view,
it is a static view, though.

197
00:09:55.877 --> 00:10:00.562
All right, other things we wanna look
at in Linux, we wanna be able to take

198
00:10:00.562 --> 00:10:05.190
a look at, maybe we're noticing
a resource utilization abnormality.

199
00:10:05.190 --> 00:10:07.780
We've got no memory left on the system.

200
00:10:07.780 --> 00:10:11.520
Free is a command that I can look at
see what kind of memory I have left.

201
00:10:13.580 --> 00:10:16.401
How much of it's free, how much of it,

202
00:10:16.401 --> 00:10:21.117
if I can slow down a little bit,
is available, how much is in use?

203
00:10:21.117 --> 00:10:22.536
>> Throw a -h on there.

204
00:10:22.536 --> 00:10:25.169
It helps those numbers become
a little easier to look at.

205
00:10:25.169 --> 00:10:26.302
[LAUGH]
>> -h,

206
00:10:26.302 --> 00:10:30.601
I don't know it's gonna change that,
thta's a good little tip there.

207
00:10:30.601 --> 00:10:34.139
All right, what else do we wanna do?

208
00:10:34.139 --> 00:10:37.290
Session management is another
thing we wanna take a look at.

209
00:10:37.290 --> 00:10:39.140
What sessions are going on?

210
00:10:39.140 --> 00:10:42.576
We can use the who command to see
who we are currently logged on as.

211
00:10:42.576 --> 00:10:44.567
You can see I am logged on as root.

212
00:10:44.567 --> 00:10:49.052
We've got the w command that gives you
a little more information about that

213
00:10:49.052 --> 00:10:51.070
currently logged on user.

214
00:10:51.070 --> 00:10:55.067
I can see what terminal they're in,
when they logged in,

215
00:10:55.067 --> 00:10:57.361
what they're currently using.

216
00:10:57.361 --> 00:11:00.604
rwho, I love these names.

217
00:11:00.604 --> 00:11:03.327
>> [LAUGH]
>> Is one that if I had other Linux boxes

218
00:11:03.327 --> 00:11:06.847
on here it should show you on
my network if they reported in.

219
00:11:06.847 --> 00:11:10.194
It'll show you information about who's
logged on to the different systems

220
00:11:10.194 --> 00:11:10.934
on the network.

221
00:11:10.934 --> 00:11:13.706
Lastlog is a good one.

222
00:11:13.706 --> 00:11:15.471
Now mines gonna look odd and

223
00:11:15.471 --> 00:11:20.360
most people that run this go how come
it shows that I've never logged on?

224
00:11:20.360 --> 00:11:22.610
I know I've logged on
as root several times.

225
00:11:22.610 --> 00:11:25.276
I'm logged on as root right now,
and yet is says never logged on.

226
00:11:25.276 --> 00:11:29.665
The thing to understand about last log
is it's not your log on sessions with

227
00:11:29.665 --> 00:11:31.696
the desktop interface like this.

228
00:11:31.696 --> 00:11:37.760
It's usually remote sessions or SSH
sessions where you're logging into those.

229
00:11:37.760 --> 00:11:39.430
Those would be captured here,

230
00:11:39.430 --> 00:11:44.920
you wanna see whose logging on locally to
this machine, that's when we use last.

231
00:11:44.920 --> 00:11:49.220
And last will show you the people that
have logged on, when they logged on and

232
00:11:49.220 --> 00:11:53.590
you can see like I'm still logged on and
still running.

233
00:11:53.590 --> 00:11:57.425
Tells me in the past though,
when I've logged on, when I've logged off.

234
00:11:57.425 --> 00:12:00.826
All right, so again,
a lot of similar tools.

235
00:12:00.826 --> 00:12:04.290
I know we didn't really seem
to spend as much time here.

236
00:12:04.290 --> 00:12:07.370
But we've seen these tools,
any other lessons, right?

237
00:12:07.370 --> 00:12:08.690
And we've seen them on Windows,

238
00:12:08.690 --> 00:12:12.096
they're no different on Linux at least the
ones that are common on Wireshark, Nmap.

239
00:12:12.096 --> 00:12:15.091
Those are the same whichever
one you're running it on so.

240
00:12:15.091 --> 00:12:18.167
So the best thing to do again
really looking at these tools and

241
00:12:18.167 --> 00:12:21.436
really understand what information
they're gonna give back.

242
00:12:21.436 --> 00:12:23.472
Cuz that's what you're gonna
need to know for the exam.

243
00:12:23.472 --> 00:12:27.441
If you're trying to determine,
who logged onto that system last?

244
00:12:27.441 --> 00:12:29.133
What command would I use in Linux?

245
00:12:29.133 --> 00:12:31.441
Where can I find that
information in Windows?

246
00:12:31.441 --> 00:12:34.408
If I need to see what processes
are running currently,

247
00:12:34.408 --> 00:12:37.388
what tool am I gonna use if
I'm in a Linux environment?

248
00:12:37.388 --> 00:12:40.910
What tool am I gonna use if
I'm in a Windows environment?

249
00:12:40.910 --> 00:12:44.740
How can I look at my TCP/IP configuration
on the different environments?

250
00:12:44.740 --> 00:12:46.740
Those are the things we
need to understand, and

251
00:12:46.740 --> 00:12:48.793
hopefully we've helped
with that a little bit.

252
00:12:48.793 --> 00:12:51.523
>> All right, Mike,
I know it's a bit of a short episode,

253
00:12:51.523 --> 00:12:53.915
kind of an addendum really,
to the Windows one.

254
00:12:53.915 --> 00:12:57.359
But they kind of go hand in hand,
like we've said, a lot of these tools,

255
00:12:57.359 --> 00:13:00.529
they like to bounce around,
regardless of the operating system.

256
00:13:00.529 --> 00:13:04.342
So if we've shown it to you in Windows,
it works the same in Linux.

257
00:13:04.342 --> 00:13:09.032
So we tried to really focus in on just the
Linux tools in this episode specifically.

258
00:13:09.032 --> 00:13:12.610
That being said we're gonna call
it a day for this here episode.

259
00:13:12.610 --> 00:13:14.500
Mike thanks again for
joining us yet again.

260
00:13:14.500 --> 00:13:16.330
We thank you for watching.

261
00:13:16.330 --> 00:13:19.370
But signing off for ITPro.TV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

262
00:13:19.370 --> 00:13:20.371
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

263
00:13:20.371 --> 00:13:21.478
>> And we'll see you next time.

264
00:13:21.478 --> 00:13:29.398
[MUSIC]

265
00:13:29.398 --> 00:13:32.145
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike walk you through the common methods and tools used for malware analysis. They cover methods like sandboxing, employing virtualization to create a safe environment for testing. They also explore reverse engineering tools and other general tools including AntiVirus software and Malware Scanners.

>> It's going great, Daniel, thanks for

17
00:00:36.920 --> 00:00:38.960
All right, so in this episode,
we wanna take a look and

18
00:00:38.960 --> 00:00:43.770
kinda summarize the methods and

19
00:00:43.770 --> 00:00:47.690
And if you are part of that

00:00:47.690 --> 00:00:49.970
you have a machine that's
been compromised or

we will use to define the incident.

482
00:23:47.932 --> 00:23:53.796
TAXII is more about how we can,
I'm gonna say transport but share that.

483
00:23:53.796 --> 00:23:57.615
Share that information, rules to allow
the sharing of that information.

484
00:23:57.615 --> 00:24:01.235
So they kind of work together which
is why you hear STIX and TAXII.

485
00:24:01.235 --> 00:24:05.445
But MAEC is another one, that M-A-E-C,
the Malware Attribute Enumeration and

486
00:24:05.445 --> 00:24:07.465
Characterization that you can use.

487
00:24:07.465 --> 00:24:10.862
So there's not one that everybody uses,
there are a couple.

488
00:24:10.862 --> 00:24:15.035
But as long as we're sharing information
with other organizations in my same

489
00:24:15.035 --> 00:24:15.720
industry.

490
00:24:15.720 --> 00:24:18.400
If we're all using the same
one we're good to go right?

491
00:24:18.400 --> 00:24:20.570
So we pick one and we go with it.

492
00:24:20.570 --> 00:24:22.067
I know the US government for

493
00:24:22.067 --> 00:24:25.265
example I think seems to be
moving towards STIX and TAXII.

494
00:24:25.265 --> 00:24:30.100
As their languages of choice for
sharing cyber breach information.

495
00:24:30.100 --> 00:24:31.900
It's what we would use
if I've had a breach and

496
00:24:31.900 --> 00:24:35.630
I need to call upon the federal
government here in the states to help me.

497
00:24:35.630 --> 00:24:39.430
I'm gonna use STIX and TAXII to
share that cyber breach information

498
00:24:39.430 --> 00:24:43.540
with Homeland Security, or NSA, or
whomever I'm sharing that with.

499
00:24:43.540 --> 00:24:44.830
So these are just protocols.

500
00:24:44.830 --> 00:24:47.600
Again, rules of how we define things.

501
00:24:47.600 --> 00:24:52.440
Terms we can use, acronyms we can use,
to all have a common language.

502
00:24:52.440 --> 00:25:00.240
To allow the sharing and the cooperation
when we're doing a cyber investigation.

503
00:25:00.240 --> 00:25:03.586
So just some things,
you have some different methods and

504
00:25:03.586 --> 00:25:06.523
different tools that we
use in malware analysis.

505
00:25:06.523 --> 00:25:09.260
>> All right,
well that kind of rounds it out for you.

506
00:25:09.260 --> 00:25:12.174
Getting the idea of the lay
of the land when it comes to.

507
00:25:12.174 --> 00:25:14.317
Okay we're pretty sure we have
some sort of malware here.

508
00:25:14.317 --> 00:25:17.760
Let's take a look at that and
see what it's trying to do.

509
00:25:17.760 --> 00:25:21.600
And then of course ultimately put the
kibosh on that cuz we don't like malware,

510
00:25:21.600 --> 00:25:22.650
it's bad for us.

511
00:25:22.650 --> 00:25:23.970
But we do need to understand it so

512
00:25:23.970 --> 00:25:27.390
that we can better prepare ourselves for
the future of malware.

513
00:25:27.390 --> 00:25:31.230
Mike, thank so much for explaining
the common ways in which we do that.

514
00:25:31.230 --> 00:25:35.490
Looking at the tools and methodologies
that are implemented in that endeavor.

515
00:25:35.490 --> 00:25:37.210
That being said it's time for
us to sign off.

516
00:25:37.210 --> 00:25:39.040
We do thank you guys for watching.

517
00:25:39.040 --> 00:25:41.750
For ITProTV I've been
your host Daniel Lowrie.

518
00:25:41.750 --> 00:25:42.590
>> And I'm Mike Roderick.

519
00:25:42.590 --> 00:25:43.578
>> And we'll see you next time.

520
00:25:43.578 --> 00:25:51.088
[MUSIC]

521
00:25:51.088 --> 00:25:53.060
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike look at the indications of a potential comprise within systems or networks. They talk about unauthorized programs, malicious software, registry modification, excessive bandwidth utilization, open ports, failed logons and more.
episodes.title: Potential Compromise Indicators
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.117 --> 00:00:01.179
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.179 --> 00:00:02.036
I'm your host Don.

3
00:00:02.036 --> 00:00:06.109
>> [SOUND] You're

4
00:00:06.109 --> 00:00:11.880
watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.880 --> 00:00:13.940
>> Hello and welcome to ITProTV.

6
00:00:13.940 --> 00:00:17.190
I'm your show host Wes Bryan, and
in today's episode we're continuing

7
00:00:17.190 --> 00:00:20.820
through our series in logical
operations cyber sec first responder.

8
00:00:20.820 --> 00:00:23.870
And joining us back in the studios is
none other than Mister Mike Rodrick.

9
00:00:23.870 --> 00:00:24.980
Mike how you doing today sir?

10
00:00:24.980 --> 00:00:27.190
>> I'm doing great Wes thanks for
having me back.

11
00:00:27.190 --> 00:00:32.620
In this episode we're gonna be taking
a look at potential compromise indicators.

12
00:00:32.620 --> 00:00:37.813
What are some things that you might see,
notice, show up in logs what have you that

13
00:00:37.813 --> 00:00:43.031
could indicate that there has been some
kind of compromise or breach or incident.

14
00:00:43.031 --> 00:00:46.116
So we're gonna take a look
at those in this episode.

15
00:00:46.116 --> 00:00:47.740
So let's talk about a few of them.

16
00:00:47.740 --> 00:00:49.270
Yeah the first thing that they call out.

17
00:00:49.270 --> 00:00:51.300
It's just some things they
call out on the objectives.

18
00:00:51.300 --> 00:00:52.450
We wanna go over them.

19
00:00:52.450 --> 00:00:54.048
Make sure we're ready for this exam.

20
00:00:54.048 --> 00:00:56.968
Unauthorized programs in the Startup menu.

21
00:00:56.968 --> 00:01:01.351
We know this is a great place to put
malware, try to get it in your startup so

22
00:01:01.351 --> 00:01:04.675
that it launches every time
you start up the machine, or

23
00:01:04.675 --> 00:01:09.131
every time you login to that machine,
it runs an application or a service,

24
00:01:09.131 --> 00:01:11.780
opens up a backdoor that starts listening.

25
00:01:11.780 --> 00:01:14.852
So you reboot your machine you
think you got it cleaned up, and

26
00:01:14.852 --> 00:01:18.591
sure enough there it is again,
because it's hiding in your startup menu.

27
00:01:18.591 --> 00:01:21.398
So this is where you need to
know your operating system,

28
00:01:21.398 --> 00:01:25.474
understand where you can go to see what
is configured to startup automatically.

29
00:01:25.474 --> 00:01:30.769
Like in our Windows systems,
you've got our MS Info,

30
00:01:30.769 --> 00:01:34.590
sorry and where do they hide it now Wes?

31
00:01:34.590 --> 00:01:35.610
>> Task manager.

32
00:01:35.610 --> 00:01:37.430
>> Task manager's another place we can go.

33
00:01:37.430 --> 00:01:39.850
Yeah.
So that's somewhere I wanna look.

34
00:01:39.850 --> 00:01:44.123
Unauthorized programs, things that
shouldn't be there, which kinda goes

35
00:01:44.123 --> 00:01:47.749
back to one of our earlier topics,
knowing what should be there.

36
00:01:47.749 --> 00:01:50.262
I can't determine what shouldn't be
there if I don't know what's already

37
00:01:50.262 --> 00:01:51.014
supposed to be there.

38
00:01:51.014 --> 00:01:53.617
So having a good baseline for
all of my systems,

39
00:01:53.617 --> 00:01:57.196
understanding what that server's
running so that when I look and

40
00:01:57.196 --> 00:02:02.020
see what's starting up automatically I can
spot the things that shouldn't be there.

41
00:02:02.020 --> 00:02:04.780
>> And you mentioned baseline so if I have
something that I already know is like

42
00:02:04.780 --> 00:02:07.310
a trusted operating system
I can compare to that too.

43
00:02:07.310 --> 00:02:10.600
If I need some kind of real
time live inspection because

44
00:02:10.600 --> 00:02:12.960
let's face it I know that I've
opened a task manager before and

45
00:02:12.960 --> 00:02:17.900
gone to the processes tab and I see 15
SvcHost, I have no clue what they are but

46
00:02:17.900 --> 00:02:20.360
then I see one and
it doesn't have any information on it.

47
00:02:20.360 --> 00:02:21.980
But it's definitely got a file path,

48
00:02:21.980 --> 00:02:24.930
somethings start to look a little fishy
here and we need to inspect it right?

49
00:02:24.930 --> 00:02:27.650
>> Yeah and you can get tools that'll
give you more information too.

50
00:02:27.650 --> 00:02:32.930
Like PS Exec and some of those
Sysinternals tools on a Windows system,

51
00:02:32.930 --> 00:02:35.900
Top htop, there's several for Lennox.

52
00:02:35.900 --> 00:02:38.910
That can show me what's
using my resources or

53
00:02:38.910 --> 00:02:43.820
what is it that those
services are launching?

54
00:02:43.820 --> 00:02:47.370
What's associated with them, and

55
00:02:47.370 --> 00:02:53.230
to see what is launching that SvcHost that
I have seven of and now I've got eight of?

56
00:02:53.230 --> 00:02:53.790
I'm not sure.

57
00:02:53.790 --> 00:02:55.870
And we gotta figure that out.

58
00:02:55.870 --> 00:02:56.880
Malicious software.

59
00:02:56.880 --> 00:02:59.580
Obviously that would be
a sign of a compromise.

60
00:02:59.580 --> 00:03:01.210
If you come into your system and and

61
00:03:01.210 --> 00:03:06.450
you notice that there's a keystroke logger
application running in your system tray.

62
00:03:06.450 --> 00:03:08.060
That's not a good thing, right?

63
00:03:08.060 --> 00:03:15.740
If I've got something else,
even something as benign as a sniffer.

64
00:03:15.740 --> 00:03:17.990
Or something like that running.

65
00:03:17.990 --> 00:03:22.090
If you didn't install it it's not
authorized software it shouldn't be there,

66
00:03:22.090 --> 00:03:26.180
it violates company policy,
it's something that you didn't install.

67
00:03:26.180 --> 00:03:27.820
Then somebody else did.

68
00:03:27.820 --> 00:03:29.080
Who put this there, what are they doing.

69
00:03:29.080 --> 00:03:32.300
They're scanning your system or
your network from the inside.

70
00:03:32.300 --> 00:03:35.130
They're using your machine
as their launch point.

71
00:03:35.130 --> 00:03:39.330
So noticing malicious software,
the presence of attack tools.

72
00:03:39.330 --> 00:03:43.400
As a bad guy once I compromise
one machine inside,

73
00:03:43.400 --> 00:03:46.470
my next goal is to get
my tools over there.

74
00:03:46.470 --> 00:03:50.260
I'm gonna e-MCAT or something and
make some kind of Troj or

75
00:03:50.260 --> 00:03:53.410
tunnel over your machine,
some kind of connection.

76
00:03:53.410 --> 00:03:55.560
I'm gonna upload my tools over there so

77
00:03:55.560 --> 00:03:59.130
that I can start scanning from
the inside or launching more attacks

78
00:03:59.130 --> 00:04:02.020
from the other side of your firewall,
which is gonna be a lot easier.

79
00:04:02.020 --> 00:04:05.430
So noticing something like that,
or noticing

80
00:04:05.430 --> 00:04:09.320
that your hard drive's out of space and
all of a sudden you're a warez provider or

81
00:04:09.320 --> 00:04:13.160
you're hosting a bunch of movies for
somebody, not gonna be good right.

82
00:04:13.160 --> 00:04:18.072
It's definitely a sign of some
kind of attack or compromise.

83
00:04:18.072 --> 00:04:21.110
Another thing we can look for
registry entries right.

84
00:04:21.110 --> 00:04:22.410
We've talked about this,

85
00:04:22.410 --> 00:04:25.410
we know we can dive into
the registry in a Windows system.

86
00:04:25.410 --> 00:04:28.765
The registry is where all of my
settings are gonna be stored.

87
00:04:28.765 --> 00:04:32.909
We talk about like HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE,
HKEY_CURRENT_USER.

88
00:04:32.909 --> 00:04:36.194
And in there,
if we dive down into these and

89
00:04:36.194 --> 00:04:41.805
we start working our way down in,
we'll find keys like run And run once.

90
00:04:41.805 --> 00:04:48.600
HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Wind-
ows, I forget the entire path.

91
00:04:48.600 --> 00:04:52.862
You get down into their current control
set run or run once, this is places

92
00:04:52.862 --> 00:04:57.640
where I can put stuff that's gonna
execute when you start up the machine.

93
00:04:57.640 --> 00:05:01.850
Might not necessarily show up
in your start up items but

94
00:05:01.850 --> 00:05:05.560
it is going to start when you log in or
when you launch that machine.

95
00:05:05.560 --> 00:05:08.380
>> I've noticed applications, Mike,
that didn't have like a root kit,

96
00:05:08.380 --> 00:05:11.700
we know has administrative level access
but this one didn't happen to have it so

97
00:05:11.700 --> 00:05:14.430
one of the first things I
started to see was H key and

98
00:05:14.430 --> 00:05:17.190
that was a telltale sign it's a registry,
right?

99
00:05:17.190 --> 00:05:17.770
H key.
And

100
00:05:17.770 --> 00:05:19.580
it was a user account
control that was blocking it.

101
00:05:19.580 --> 00:05:22.180
It would do a series of blocks and
come to find out it was

102
00:05:22.180 --> 00:05:24.900
a malicious program that was
trying to access the registry but

103
00:05:24.900 --> 00:05:28.935
thank goodness in this case as example,
the user account control will say no,

104
00:05:28.935 --> 00:05:31.065
you don't have that
administrative level access.

105
00:05:31.065 --> 00:05:34.075
So that one was a little bit lucky,
I kind of got some warnings.

106
00:05:34.075 --> 00:05:36.765
But you know if you already have that
administrative level access it might be

107
00:05:36.765 --> 00:05:37.445
transparent to you.

108
00:05:37.445 --> 00:05:38.565
You might not see it, right.

109
00:05:38.565 --> 00:05:41.965
>> Absolutely, and
this is where things can hide,

110
00:05:41.965 --> 00:05:45.745
you think you got rid of all traces
of say a virus, some kind of malware,

111
00:05:45.745 --> 00:05:48.560
some kind of spyware
>> You reboot the system and

112
00:05:48.560 --> 00:05:49.800
there it is again, right?

113
00:05:49.800 --> 00:05:51.280
And it's because they've added it.

114
00:05:51.280 --> 00:05:55.890
There's a key somewhere, they've added
a registry key that's reinstalling or

115
00:05:55.890 --> 00:06:00.470
rerunning whatever malicious code it
is every time you fire up that machine.

116
00:06:02.120 --> 00:06:07.300
Excessive bandwidth usage If you
noticed the network's going really

117
00:06:07.300 --> 00:06:12.960
slow or you see that when you look
at something like Task Manager or

118
00:06:12.960 --> 00:06:15.810
some other network monitor
that you're using and

119
00:06:15.810 --> 00:06:18.910
all the bandwidth is being utilized yet,
you're not running anything.

120
00:06:18.910 --> 00:06:20.550
You don't even have a browser open.

121
00:06:20.550 --> 00:06:21.750
What's going on?

122
00:06:21.750 --> 00:06:24.420
Some malware could be on your system and
it's

123
00:06:24.420 --> 00:06:29.520
either attacking other machines on your
network, doing scans, exfiltrating data.

124
00:06:29.520 --> 00:06:34.775
So any unusual bandwidth utilization is
an indicator that could be compromised.

125
00:06:34.775 --> 00:06:37.825
>> It's kind of interesting, I just
happen to have an example for this one.

126
00:06:37.825 --> 00:06:42.357
I have a friend and
both of them are online gamers.

127
00:06:42.357 --> 00:06:48.727
And they asked me a couple weeks back they
said, we're using 36 gigs of data a day.

128
00:06:48.727 --> 00:06:52.177
And if you're gaming that doesn't,
maybe does not sound like a lot but

129
00:06:52.177 --> 00:06:54.125
all their machines were idle.

130
00:06:54.125 --> 00:06:56.835
And come to find out when he
connected to the gaming server and

131
00:06:56.835 --> 00:06:59.070
it downloads some additional content,

132
00:06:59.070 --> 00:07:01.970
it downloaded some additional content that
they didn't want stored on the machine.

133
00:07:01.970 --> 00:07:03.420
And it was calling outbound and

134
00:07:03.420 --> 00:07:07.770
they ended up finding it, that that was
where all that bandwidth was being used.

135
00:07:07.770 --> 00:07:08.390
>> Yeah, absolutely,

136
00:07:08.390 --> 00:07:12.260
that's a great example of how
this could be a good indicator.

137
00:07:12.260 --> 00:07:14.710
They had no idea that
they were compromised

138
00:07:14.710 --> 00:07:17.880
until they noticed the bandwidth
utilization issue.

139
00:07:17.880 --> 00:07:19.500
Something was sucking
up their bandwidth and

140
00:07:19.500 --> 00:07:21.090
they know it wasn't anything they were.

141
00:07:21.090 --> 00:07:23.010
I've got everything closed and
I am not doing anything yet

142
00:07:23.010 --> 00:07:25.350
I am still using gigs of data.

143
00:07:25.350 --> 00:07:27.390
So what is it that is doing this?

144
00:07:27.390 --> 00:07:28.640
This is an indicator.

145
00:07:28.640 --> 00:07:30.733
Again, it is not saying
there is a comprise.

146
00:07:30.733 --> 00:07:33.325
None of these are you
definitely been comprised.

147
00:07:33.325 --> 00:07:37.034
But these are things that
are going to get me to think and

148
00:07:37.034 --> 00:07:42.531
do a further investigation and decide
whether there has been an incident or not.

149
00:07:42.531 --> 00:07:47.813
They could be ex filtrating data
using tools that are sucking

150
00:07:47.813 --> 00:07:52.578
up bandwidth and
this is where knowing what is normal,

151
00:07:52.578 --> 00:07:56.941
again, what is expected
is gonna come into play.

152
00:07:56.941 --> 00:08:01.077
If I don't know how much
bandwidth I'm normally using.

153
00:08:01.077 --> 00:08:04.681
Then I'm not going to know when there's
an excessive amount of bandwidth being

154
00:08:04.681 --> 00:08:05.229
utilized.

155
00:08:05.229 --> 00:08:08.210
So in a corporate environment for
example we have baselines.

156
00:08:08.210 --> 00:08:11.650
We've monitored our traffic for
periods of time not just for

157
00:08:11.650 --> 00:08:15.220
five minute slice, all right,
cuz it could be if it's at lunch time and

158
00:08:15.220 --> 00:08:18.440
we're not getting a true representation
of utilization of my network.

159
00:08:18.440 --> 00:08:22.490
So we monitor it for periods of time
throughout the day and then multiple days

160
00:08:22.490 --> 00:08:26.620
a week, as Monday is different from
Thursday, is different from Friday.

161
00:08:26.620 --> 00:08:31.533
So understanding what's normal in your
network is a big part of being able

162
00:08:31.533 --> 00:08:33.760
to recognize these indicators.

163
00:08:33.760 --> 00:08:36.663
Because if I don't know what should be
there, if I don' know the way things

164
00:08:36.663 --> 00:08:39.570
normally behave,
I'm not gonna notice something abnormal.

165
00:08:39.570 --> 00:08:42.120
>> That's a great example because
you know how they found out,

166
00:08:42.120 --> 00:08:45.180
it ended up being their ISP called them
and said that they had hit their bandwidth

167
00:08:45.180 --> 00:08:48.120
cap in just a couple of weeks and
they knew they had months to go.

168
00:08:48.120 --> 00:08:49.753
And they have like a terabyte of data so

169
00:08:49.753 --> 00:08:53.124
they didn't know it until it was
an outside source saying, hey, we're gonna

170
00:08:53.124 --> 00:08:56.256
charge more money for bandwidth
because you've already used it all up.

171
00:08:56.256 --> 00:08:58.730
>> Yeah and in that case,
you're like, wait a second.

172
00:08:58.730 --> 00:09:03.305
And we've been with this ISP for how long,
and I've never had this problem before.

173
00:09:03.305 --> 00:09:05.440
We've never hit our cap before.

174
00:09:05.440 --> 00:09:07.440
Now all of a sudden we have,
that's a change.

175
00:09:07.440 --> 00:09:08.950
That's something out of the ordinary.

176
00:09:08.950 --> 00:09:11.460
It's like, hm,
that's an indicator that, hey,

177
00:09:11.460 --> 00:09:14.260
I need to do a little more digging and
see what is going on here.

178
00:09:15.520 --> 00:09:18.190
Off hours usage, would be another one.

179
00:09:18.190 --> 00:09:22.715
Why do I have a record of somebody logging
into this system at 11 o'clock at night?

180
00:09:22.715 --> 00:09:25.380
Or office is shut down at 5,
sometimes people work until 6,

181
00:09:25.380 --> 00:09:28.110
but there's nobody in
the building after 7 o'clock.

182
00:09:28.110 --> 00:09:33.022
And yet, I've got DNS queries going on
from our internal DNS servers at 11

183
00:09:33.022 --> 00:09:34.346
o'clock at night.

184
00:09:34.346 --> 00:09:38.140
Or I've got files being modified
in the middle of the night.

185
00:09:38.140 --> 00:09:43.390
Or I've got computer is being logged onto,
accounts being authenticated.

186
00:09:43.390 --> 00:09:45.260
