00:21:23.950 --> 00:21:27.630
capturing logon information,
passwords, what have you.

417
00:21:27.630 --> 00:21:31.700
It'll be a good example of rogue hardware.

418
00:21:31.700 --> 00:21:35.990
And not just that people could, if they
had physical access to your building like

419
00:21:35.990 --> 00:21:38.150
our building here has public access.

420
00:21:38.150 --> 00:21:41.760
People can come in, there's a coffee shop
in our lobby that people can access.

421
00:21:41.760 --> 00:21:44.080
There's other businesses in here.

422
00:21:44.080 --> 00:21:47.100
So there is some common areas.

423
00:21:47.100 --> 00:21:52.210
If the information was
valuable enough I can find

424
00:21:52.210 --> 00:21:57.730
several places that I could
leave a laptop or a smartphone.

425
00:21:57.730 --> 00:22:00.540
We can load up all kinds of
things on smartphones now.

426
00:22:00.540 --> 00:22:03.900
Get it connected, leave it somewhere,
maybe nobody finds it, and

427
00:22:03.900 --> 00:22:05.230
I start running scans from it.

428
00:22:05.230 --> 00:22:08.900
Or it gives me some kind of remote
access back into your network.

429
00:22:08.900 --> 00:22:12.530
I have read about attacks where
they crack open a computer case and

430
00:22:12.530 --> 00:22:14.660
throw an old phone in there,

431
00:22:14.660 --> 00:22:19.070
connect it up to one of the ports on the
board, close the case up and walk away.

432
00:22:19.070 --> 00:22:23.390
And now they can dial into that phone and
do what they need to do.

433
00:22:23.390 --> 00:22:25.910
So, physical security
is a big part of that.

434
00:22:25.910 --> 00:22:28.570
And rogue hardware in general,
we need to find it.

435
00:22:28.570 --> 00:22:30.662
Typically when we're talking
about rogue hardware,

436
00:22:30.662 --> 00:22:33.930
we are talking about
wireless access points,

437
00:22:33.930 --> 00:22:38.120
trying to slip rouge access points in
there to get people to connect to it.

438
00:22:38.120 --> 00:22:42.800
And it might be unintentional, it could be
that, hey I just wanted to play around I

439
00:22:42.800 --> 00:22:44.820
bought this wireless access point,
I brought it into work so

440
00:22:44.820 --> 00:22:47.390
that I could play with it a bit before
I take it home and configure it.

441
00:22:47.390 --> 00:22:50.600
I got it setup,
I didn't think it was any big deal.

442
00:22:50.600 --> 00:22:54.870
Yeah, it's blowing a hole through every
bit of security I have because you didn't

443
00:22:54.870 --> 00:22:58.240
set a password on it, people can connect
to it, and you plugged it into our work

444
00:22:58.240 --> 00:23:02.895
network, or like you said, it's providing
DHCP and it's not the right scope.

445
00:23:02.895 --> 00:23:06.525
It's causing denial of service because
people can not connect to our network cuz

446
00:23:06.525 --> 00:23:10.895
they are getting the wrong IP address or
the wrong subnet mask or what have you.

447
00:23:10.895 --> 00:23:15.985
So rogue hardware, definite indicator that
there has been some kind of compromise.

448
00:23:15.985 --> 00:23:18.365
So when we sum all this up.

449
00:23:18.365 --> 00:23:19.685
I mean, there's a lot of things.

450
00:23:19.685 --> 00:23:22.580
This list is not inclusive,
right, or not all inclusive.

451
00:23:22.580 --> 00:23:26.590
There's a lot of other things that we can
put on here that would indicate attack.

452
00:23:26.590 --> 00:23:30.130
But these are some of the common ones
that they call out on at least on this

453
00:23:30.130 --> 00:23:34.730
particular exam and these are things
that should make us think.

454
00:23:34.730 --> 00:23:39.190
That should make us start our
incident handling process.

455
00:23:39.190 --> 00:23:44.900
At least that investigation phase is
this the beginning of an attack or

456
00:23:44.900 --> 00:23:47.310
has there been a compromise?

457
00:23:47.310 --> 00:23:50.140
Many times you're gonna find
out that it's legitimate.

458
00:23:50.140 --> 00:23:54.450
Like I said, that developer decided
FTP was a better protocol to use so

459
00:23:54.450 --> 00:23:56.440
he's been using it, which was unusual.

460
00:23:56.440 --> 00:23:58.760
We didn't normally see
FTP traffic on there.

461
00:23:58.760 --> 00:24:03.225
We do our initial investigation and
we find that it's benign,

462
00:24:03.225 --> 00:24:05.860
right that it's okay.

463
00:24:05.860 --> 00:24:09.760
Like I said it doesn't always indicate
that there has been a compromise, but

464
00:24:09.760 --> 00:24:14.710
these are things that should trigger
us to take a closer look and

465
00:24:14.710 --> 00:24:16.870
see if there is a potential compromise.

466
00:24:16.870 --> 00:24:18.600
>> Seems like these
compromises can really,

467
00:24:18.600 --> 00:24:21.070
really weaken our security for sure.

468
00:24:21.070 --> 00:24:25.060
And it is good to know what
are we looking for, right.

469
00:24:25.060 --> 00:24:27.685
If we're the watchman on the wall,
we gotta know what beacons that

470
00:24:27.685 --> 00:24:30.545
we're gonna be looking at,
what flags, what alarms.

471
00:24:30.545 --> 00:24:33.185
So great job, Mike,
a lot of great explanations here.

472
00:24:33.185 --> 00:24:35.145
It does look like we're coming
to the end of another episode.

473
00:24:35.145 --> 00:24:38.615
But before we do, when it comes to
potential compromise and indicators,

474
00:24:38.615 --> 00:24:41.465
do you got any final words that you
might like to impart to our viewers?

475
00:24:41.465 --> 00:24:45.095
>> I will say, I think that we stressed it
enough that you have to have a baseline.

476
00:24:45.095 --> 00:24:47.555
Right, you've gotta know what
should be there, what's normal,

477
00:24:47.555 --> 00:24:52.530
what we expect to see for any of these
before we can see them as anomalies and

478
00:24:52.530 --> 00:24:54.640
something that I need
to investigate further.

479
00:24:54.640 --> 00:24:58.430
Some of this can be automated, some of
this is gonna be a very manual process.

480
00:24:58.430 --> 00:25:03.070
I need to do wireless surveys now to walk
around and look for rogue access points.

481
00:25:03.070 --> 00:25:04.590
But I can also have IDSs and

482
00:25:04.590 --> 00:25:07.720
IPSs that know what normal
behavior is on my network.

483
00:25:07.720 --> 00:25:10.780
And they can alert me that
there's a strange protocol, or

484
00:25:10.780 --> 00:25:13.129
an unusual amount of
bandwidth being consumed.

485
00:25:14.500 --> 00:25:18.000
We can monitor those
start up programs using

486
00:25:18.000 --> 00:25:21.250
different software that
looks at our machines.

487
00:25:21.250 --> 00:25:24.700
We can do white list and
black list to control software.

488
00:25:24.700 --> 00:25:27.750
So maybe try to prevent some of that or

489
00:25:27.750 --> 00:25:32.260
get an alert when somebody tries to
install some unauthorized software.

490
00:25:32.260 --> 00:25:35.770
So a lot of this is not,
what's a good way to say this?

491
00:25:35.770 --> 00:25:37.180
Some of it's gonna be very manual

492
00:25:38.660 --> 00:25:43.150
others we might be able to use tools to
help us notice these kind of indicators.

493
00:25:43.150 --> 00:25:44.900
>> All right a lot of
great information Mike,

494
00:25:44.900 --> 00:25:48.560
we do appreciate you being here
as always in the studios with us.

495
00:25:48.560 --> 00:25:50.400
And we do appreciate
the viewer watching but

496
00:25:50.400 --> 00:25:53.080
it looks like it is time
to wrap this one up.

497
00:25:53.080 --> 00:25:55.450
Signing out for
ITProTV I've been your host Wes Bryan.

498
00:25:55.450 --> 00:25:56.360
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

499
00:25:56.360 --> 00:25:57.937
>> And we'll see you next time.

500
00:25:57.937 --> 00:26:04.476
[MUSIC]

501
00:26:04.476 --> 00:26:07.842
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explain the importance of best practices in preparation for incident response. Watch as they cover topics like preparation and planning, the need for ongoing training, communication methods, documentation, escalation procedures, and industry standards.
episodes.title: Best Practices
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.310 --> 00:00:01.514
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.514 --> 00:00:08.386
I'm your host, Don Pezet- [SOUND]
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.386 --> 00:00:12.459
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.459 --> 00:00:14.241
>> All right, greetings everyone,

5
00:00:14.241 --> 00:00:17.010
and welcome to another
exciting episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:17.010 --> 00:00:18.808
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, and

7
00:00:18.808 --> 00:00:23.087
in today's episode we are back with more
of our CyberSec First Responder series.

8
00:00:23.087 --> 00:00:26.555
So hopefully that's what you've joined us
for, and I know a guy that has joined us

9
00:00:26.555 --> 00:00:29.429
today for that very endeavor,
our good friend, Mr. Mike Rogers.

10
00:00:29.429 --> 00:00:31.334
Mike, welcome back man,
how's it going today?

11
00:00:31.334 --> 00:00:33.454
>> It's going fantastic, Daniel,
thanks for having me back,

12
00:00:33.454 --> 00:00:34.486
excited to be here as always.

13
00:00:34.486 --> 00:00:35.746
>> Always a pleasure.
[LAUGH]

14
00:00:35.746 --> 00:00:36.317
>> Thank you, thank you.

15
00:00:36.317 --> 00:00:39.385
Yeah, so
more good old CyberSec First Responder.

16
00:00:39.385 --> 00:00:42.209
In this one, we're gonna be
taking a look at best practices.

17
00:00:42.209 --> 00:00:44.351
It's one of our objectives on our exam,

18
00:00:44.351 --> 00:00:48.708
explain the importance of best practices
in preparation for incident response.

19
00:00:48.708 --> 00:00:52.631
So, really, if I just need to explain
the importance of best practices,

20
00:00:52.631 --> 00:00:53.896
then I should just say,

21
00:00:53.896 --> 00:00:58.036
it's very important that you have
some best practices, no, I'm kidding.

22
00:00:58.036 --> 00:01:01.003
When we talk about best practices for
incident response,

23
00:01:01.003 --> 00:01:04.090
there's definitely a few things
that we wanna keep in mind,

24
00:01:04.090 --> 00:01:06.708
starting with preparation and
planning, right?

25
00:01:06.708 --> 00:01:11.503
This is probably one of the most important
parts, or one of the best, best practices,

26
00:01:11.503 --> 00:01:14.718
if you will, it's gotta be up
there on the top of the list,

27
00:01:14.718 --> 00:01:18.417
because really preparation and
planning is what it's all about.

28
00:01:18.417 --> 00:01:22.066
We have to be ready for
handling an incident.

29
00:01:22.066 --> 00:01:24.454
We can't just sit around and go, yeah,

30
00:01:24.454 --> 00:01:27.341
if we ever have an incident
we'll do something.

31
00:01:27.341 --> 00:01:30.488
And then when the incident comes along,
nobody knows what to do,

32
00:01:30.488 --> 00:01:34.626
who's supposed to do what, who's supposed
to contact whom, what tools do you use?

33
00:01:34.626 --> 00:01:38.391
They bring out tools, and they say,
we've got our toolkit ready,

34
00:01:38.391 --> 00:01:42.466
we've got all this stuff, we've
downloaded our license, or what have you,

35
00:01:42.466 --> 00:01:46.201
never used it before, never fired it up,
no idea exactly how to use it.

36
00:01:46.201 --> 00:01:50.020
And that's not the way to go about it,
because you're going to miss information.

37
00:01:50.020 --> 00:01:53.735
You're gonna miss evidence,
if you're gonna try to prosecute,

38
00:01:53.735 --> 00:01:57.117
you're gonna ruin evidence,
evidence is no longer valid or

39
00:01:57.117 --> 00:02:00.522
acceptable because of the way
you went about collecting it.

40
00:02:00.522 --> 00:02:03.068
There's just a number of things
that can go wrong, right?

41
00:02:03.068 --> 00:02:08.364
And we always talk about proper planning,
and just about everything we do, and this

42
00:02:08.364 --> 00:02:13.598
is no exception, so making sure that we
have that incident response plan in place.

43
00:02:13.598 --> 00:02:17.443
And if you need to create one,
then you go out to some organization,

44
00:02:17.443 --> 00:02:20.621
like SANS Institute, and
you get yourself a template.

45
00:02:20.621 --> 00:02:25.027
Or you talk to other organizations
that are in the same field as you, and

46
00:02:25.027 --> 00:02:30.179
you see what they have in place, and maybe
you borrow some stuff from that, right?

47
00:02:30.179 --> 00:02:32.686
We were talking about collaborating and
working together.

48
00:02:32.686 --> 00:02:36.781
We're not asking them to give up
corporate secrets, or anything like that,

49
00:02:36.781 --> 00:02:39.059
but let's share our security knowledge.

50
00:02:39.059 --> 00:02:43.600
And let's make sure that we can help
each other protect ourselves, and

51
00:02:43.600 --> 00:02:48.217
therefore protect your competitors,
if you will, from breaches, and

52
00:02:48.217 --> 00:02:50.347
from cyber incidents like this.

53
00:02:50.347 --> 00:02:54.742
We all work together, so planning and
preparation, however you go about,

54
00:02:54.742 --> 00:02:59.415
whether you're creating your template
from scratch, whether you're getting

55
00:02:59.415 --> 00:03:03.899
it from somebody and modifying it to
suit your needs, but having that is key.

56
00:03:03.899 --> 00:03:08.137
Some of the things that they specifically
call out in the exam objectives,

57
00:03:08.137 --> 00:03:09.559
up to date contact list.

58
00:03:09.559 --> 00:03:12.334
This is one that you definitely
have to stay on top of,

59
00:03:12.334 --> 00:03:15.612
because, as we all know,
things change in the organization.

60
00:03:15.612 --> 00:03:20.284
People move from one job role to another,
people leave the organization,

61
00:03:20.284 --> 00:03:21.999
new people are brought in.

62
00:03:21.999 --> 00:03:25.082
So when we made that initial plan,
and we set up that call list,

63
00:03:25.082 --> 00:03:29.093
had everybody's name and number and blah,
blah, blah, and now all of a sudden,

64
00:03:29.093 --> 00:03:30.807
those people are no longer there.

65
00:03:30.807 --> 00:03:34.190
You break out that list, you start
calling, and you get the doo doo doo, or

66
00:03:34.190 --> 00:03:37.465
hey, yeah, this is Bob, no,
I don't even work with you guys anymore,

67
00:03:37.465 --> 00:03:38.794
what are you calling me for?

68
00:03:38.794 --> 00:03:42.130
[LAUGH] Something like that, that's
not what you wanna have happen, right?

69
00:03:42.130 --> 00:03:46.465
So keeping that contact list up to date,
making sure we know who we're suppose to

70
00:03:46.465 --> 00:03:49.098
contact, and
that the number is still working.

71
00:03:49.098 --> 00:03:54.641
People change their phone numbers, you
wanna know internally, who am I supposed

72
00:03:54.641 --> 00:03:59.801
to contact, and in what order,
what priority, and at what level, right?

73
00:03:59.801 --> 00:04:03.000
There are certain things
that are gonna happen, and

74
00:04:03.000 --> 00:04:08.322
we don't immediately notify the C level
employees, right, or the C level officers.

75
00:04:08.322 --> 00:04:13.094
We notify our direct supervisor, and then
they make the decision of when it's time

76
00:04:13.094 --> 00:04:16.854
to notify whomever's next in that
chain of command, all right?

77
00:04:16.854 --> 00:04:19.195
As well as external
individuals to contact, and

78
00:04:19.195 --> 00:04:21.708
we always wanna work closely
with law enforcement,

79
00:04:21.708 --> 00:04:25.475
they have tools at their disposal that
they can bring into play, they probably

80
00:04:25.475 --> 00:04:28.761
have skilled employees working for
them that do this kind of thing.

81
00:04:28.761 --> 00:04:32.737
And it's gonna help me in the event
that we need to prosecute,

82
00:04:32.737 --> 00:04:35.195
because they will be working with me.

83
00:04:35.195 --> 00:04:39.570
And they will make sure that we don't get
any evidence that's gonna be compromised,

84
00:04:39.570 --> 00:04:43.821
or that we can't use in the court of law,
or making sure we don't forget anything,

85
00:04:43.821 --> 00:04:44.876
that kind of thing.

86
00:04:44.876 --> 00:04:49.821
Working with their experts, whether
that's local law enforcement, or state,

87
00:04:49.821 --> 00:04:54.192
or federal, or whatever your, or
country has, as far as that goes, but

88
00:04:54.192 --> 00:04:57.510
knowing who that is ahead of
time is gonna be the thing.

89
00:04:57.510 --> 00:05:00.708
You don't wanna be thumbing
through the phone book, or

90
00:05:00.708 --> 00:05:03.498
doing Google searches as
your data is flowing out

91
00:05:03.498 --> 00:05:07.800
of your network trying to figure out
who I'm supposed to call, all right?

92
00:05:07.800 --> 00:05:10.025
Up to date toolkits are important.

93
00:05:10.025 --> 00:05:11.160
We wanna make sure.

94
00:05:11.160 --> 00:05:14.057
We've talked about dozens and
dozens of tools.

95
00:05:14.057 --> 00:05:18.336
And there's more than we've talked
about out there that are available,

96
00:05:18.336 --> 00:05:22.697
commercial, open source, free,
that we wanna make part of our toolkit.

97
00:05:22.697 --> 00:05:25.133
We need to know,
we need to have tools available so

98
00:05:25.133 --> 00:05:27.279
that we can perform our incident response.

99
00:05:27.279 --> 00:05:31.729
But we need to make sure those are kept up
to date, what worked a few years ago might

100
00:05:31.729 --> 00:05:35.734
not work now, or even six months ago
when it comes to computers, right?

101
00:05:35.734 --> 00:05:38.082
>> My 98 boot disk isn't still relevant,
Mike?

102
00:05:38.082 --> 00:05:39.777
[LAUGH]
>> It might be, but

103
00:05:39.777 --> 00:05:43.733
you're not gonna run into too many
98 boxes out there, hopefully.

104
00:05:43.733 --> 00:05:46.488
>> I think it's probably not so
much looking backward,

105
00:05:46.488 --> 00:05:50.774
being able to support legacy stuff, it's,
do I have something that supports this

106
00:05:50.774 --> 00:05:53.181
brand new bleeding edge
piece of technology?

107
00:05:53.181 --> 00:05:56.618
Do I have something that will work
with UEFI, things of that nature?

108
00:05:56.618 --> 00:05:59.465
If I'm working on just old
BIOS type in my toolkit,

109
00:05:59.465 --> 00:06:03.659
I don't have anything that supports UEFI,
I need to update that toolkit.

110
00:06:03.659 --> 00:06:05.043
>> Absolutely, right?

111
00:06:05.043 --> 00:06:09.144
New file systems come out, you've got
Microsoft coming out with their resilient

112
00:06:09.144 --> 00:06:13.365
file system, you've got, as Daniel says,
new operating systems coming out, and

113
00:06:13.365 --> 00:06:16.527
what ran on Windows 8.1,
we've all dealt with it, right?

114
00:06:16.527 --> 00:06:19.870
What ran on 7, did it run on 8.1,
did it run on 10?

115
00:06:19.870 --> 00:06:23.274
If it ran on XP,
it might not run on any of that, and so,

116
00:06:23.274 --> 00:06:27.567
when these new operating systems come out,
am I gonna be able to, and

117
00:06:27.567 --> 00:06:31.062
maybe not being used as my
investigative tool, right?

118
00:06:31.062 --> 00:06:34.800
Because I've got my VM, I can choose
not to upgrade that, I suppose.

119
00:06:34.800 --> 00:06:38.256
But if I'm gonna be investigating machines
that are running these newer operating

120
00:06:38.256 --> 00:06:40.935
systems, can I contact them,
can I work with them the same way?

121
00:06:40.935 --> 00:06:43.210
Again, like file systems,
things like that.

122
00:06:43.210 --> 00:06:45.791
So keeping those toolkits up to date,

123
00:06:45.791 --> 00:06:51.208
especially tools like intrusion detection,
intrusion prevention systems.

124
00:06:51.208 --> 00:06:54.760
We've talked about antivirus software,
things like that, anything that's

125
00:06:54.760 --> 00:06:58.856
signature-based, definition-based, has to
be maintained, has to be kept up to date.

126
00:06:58.856 --> 00:07:02.500
When we're doing penetration tests,
or vulnerability scanners,

127
00:07:02.500 --> 00:07:04.650
those have to be kept up to date, right?

128
00:07:04.650 --> 00:07:08.098
We have to make sure we have
the latest and greatest definitions,

129
00:07:08.098 --> 00:07:11.996
when we're looking for exploits,
that has to be kept up to date, right?

130
00:07:11.996 --> 00:07:14.810
If we're not paying attention,
I mean, new exploits, or

131
00:07:14.810 --> 00:07:17.066
new vulnerabilities
are developed every day,

132
00:07:17.066 --> 00:07:20.186
or discovered every day,
new exploits are developed every day.

133
00:07:20.186 --> 00:07:24.898
We're gonna have to stay on top of that,
but, so keeping the toolkits up to date.

00:08:30.786 --> 00:08:36.209

00:08:36.209 --> 00:08:38.925

00:08:48.300 --> 00:08:51.495

00:08:51.495 --> 00:08:54.789

00:08:54.789 --> 00:08:58.450
