theoretical exercises,

361
00:20:06.730 --> 00:20:09.120
this is when you get around and
you play war games.

362
00:20:09.120 --> 00:20:14.260
You get everybody together in a conference
room and you have a mock attack and

363
00:20:14.260 --> 00:20:16.290
you break out your incident response plan.

364
00:20:16.290 --> 00:20:20.930
Everybody knows their roles, it looks
like actors sitting around reading their

365
00:20:20.930 --> 00:20:23.510
scripts before they go in and shoot.

366
00:20:23.510 --> 00:20:25.870
We wanna make sure everybody knows
what they're supposed to do,

367
00:20:25.870 --> 00:20:27.480
when they're supposed to do it.

368
00:20:27.480 --> 00:20:29.890
Wait, Daniel has done his part,
okay, that's my turn to step in, and

369
00:20:29.890 --> 00:20:33.140
now what I'm gonna do is this,
and this, and this.

370
00:20:33.140 --> 00:20:34.450
This does many things for us.

371
00:20:34.450 --> 00:20:40.020
These types of exercises are very,
very valuable in many respects.

372
00:20:40.020 --> 00:20:42.550
Because they help us do
that ongoing training.

373
00:20:42.550 --> 00:20:46.280
They keep me aware or

374
00:20:46.280 --> 00:20:50.490
keep it fresh in my mind that these
are my steps, this is my responsibility.

375
00:20:50.490 --> 00:20:54.725
Or what we're supposed to during
an incident, this is how we handle it.

376
00:20:54.725 --> 00:20:58.440
>> It's like a band practicing
music they're gonna play, right?

377
00:20:58.440 --> 00:21:02.840
They do that because, Tommy's gonna
play the high hat really heavy here.

378
00:21:02.840 --> 00:21:05.170
And I wasn't expecting that,
so it threw me off.

379
00:21:05.170 --> 00:21:08.476
But if you go through it and
you practice the song over and over again,

380
00:21:08.476 --> 00:21:11.277
I know exactly what each one of
my band mates is going to do.

381
00:21:11.277 --> 00:21:15.130
And therefore I'm prepared for it,
it doesn't catch me off guard and

382
00:21:15.130 --> 00:21:16.970
everybody's doing their part.

383
00:21:16.970 --> 00:21:19.450
If someone doesn't play their part,
it throws everybody else off.

384
00:21:19.450 --> 00:21:21.355
They're whoa,
you're supposed to do such and such.

385
00:21:21.355 --> 00:21:24.680
And not only do I know my part, but
I start to learn their parts as well, and

386
00:21:24.680 --> 00:21:27.000
now there's that cross
pollination of duty.

387
00:21:27.000 --> 00:21:28.950
Where if Mike's out of the picture,

388
00:21:28.950 --> 00:21:31.790
I might be actually able to fill in for
that position.

389
00:21:31.790 --> 00:21:32.359
You know what I'm saying?

390
00:21:32.359 --> 00:21:35.302
>> Absolutely, and so
he brings up some very good points there,

391
00:21:35.302 --> 00:21:37.970
cuz we get to see what
everybody else is doing.

392
00:21:37.970 --> 00:21:40.777
And most of us,
if you've ever done anything, heck,

393
00:21:40.777 --> 00:21:45.430
like what we're doing here, or
playing in a band, or anything like that.

394
00:21:45.430 --> 00:21:49.260
If Daniel and I are sitting around,
discussing what we're going to do, and

395
00:21:49.260 --> 00:21:53.020
I'm going through a lab and something
doesn't work, I'm like, didn't work.

396
00:21:53.020 --> 00:21:55.630
All right,
let's see what I can do to fix this.

397
00:21:55.630 --> 00:21:57.950
If the camera's rolling, and
that red tally light is on, and

398
00:21:57.950 --> 00:22:01.670
my lab doesn't work, sweat starts
dripping down the side of my head.

399
00:22:01.670 --> 00:22:03.117
>> It's real hot in here Mike [LAUGH].

400
00:22:03.117 --> 00:22:04.966
>> Yeah.
>> I think you need to turn the air

401
00:22:04.966 --> 00:22:06.022
up a little [LAUGH].

402
00:22:06.022 --> 00:22:09.142
>> I know you've played on stage before
and you hit a couple wrong notes and

403
00:22:09.142 --> 00:22:11.625
now, all of a sudden,
that's all you can think about.

404
00:22:11.625 --> 00:22:12.790
>> Right.
>> And so you can't think about

405
00:22:12.790 --> 00:22:15.060
the next note you're playing and
it gets worse and worse.

406
00:22:15.060 --> 00:22:18.610
And it's like this horrible,
horrible snowball effect that occurs, and

407
00:22:18.610 --> 00:22:20.350
you just run off stage crying.

408
00:22:20.350 --> 00:22:21.115
>> That's no [FOREIGN] [LAUGH].

409
00:22:21.115 --> 00:22:23.890
>> [LAUGH] That's no [FOREIGN] at all.

410
00:22:23.890 --> 00:22:27.920
So that's what this kind of thing can help
with, it can get us over those nerves.

411
00:22:27.920 --> 00:22:33.030
Because during the incident, when the
untrained people that are running around

412
00:22:33.030 --> 00:22:36.740
are doing the Chicken Little,
the sky is falling.

413
00:22:36.740 --> 00:22:40.110
We're calm, we're cool, we're collected,
we're not making bad decisions,

414
00:22:40.110 --> 00:22:41.500
we're getting what we need.

415
00:22:41.500 --> 00:22:44.880
We're helping other people stay calm and
cool, and collected, and

416
00:22:44.880 --> 00:22:45.660
that kind of thing.

417
00:22:45.660 --> 00:22:50.862
So it's very important to run through
these a few times to give us that sense

418
00:22:50.862 --> 00:22:56.409
of preparation, that sense of preparedness
I guess is the better way to say it.

419
00:22:56.409 --> 00:22:59.298
Not only that,
does it help with the employees,

420
00:22:59.298 --> 00:23:03.050
the incident response team itself,
it helps us suss our plan.

421
00:23:03.050 --> 00:23:07.550
We might find big gaps in our plan,
like we forgot to account for

422
00:23:07.550 --> 00:23:08.700
this all together.

423
00:23:08.700 --> 00:23:11.340
Cuz we sat and wrote this plan,
there wasn't an incident going on,

424
00:23:11.340 --> 00:23:15.450
we're following best practices,
we got our template, whatever it is.

425
00:23:15.450 --> 00:23:19.610
And we just forgot a page or we missed a
paragraph or we left something out that's

426
00:23:19.610 --> 00:23:22.720
unique to our organization that
needed to be put in there.

427
00:23:22.720 --> 00:23:26.300
I don't want to find out about
that during an incident response.

428
00:23:26.300 --> 00:23:29.929
But if I do a table top exercise, that's
a great time for those things to crop up.

429
00:23:29.929 --> 00:23:33.532
Cuz we can all say okay, time out, let's
do, no Titus, don't time out [LAUGH].

430
00:23:33.532 --> 00:23:35.471
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's our code for

431
00:23:35.471 --> 00:23:37.118
actually stopping recording.

432
00:23:37.118 --> 00:23:39.881
>> [LAUGH]
>> But as a team, we can say all right,

433
00:23:39.881 --> 00:23:42.450
look, look, we completely missed this.

434
00:23:42.450 --> 00:23:43.357
Let's stop and

435
00:23:43.357 --> 00:23:47.271
figure out how we can update our
plan to include this information.

436
00:23:47.271 --> 00:23:49.278
Also determining inner operability.

437
00:23:49.278 --> 00:23:53.655
And when we do these incident responses,
it's not just our team we're dealing with.

438
00:23:53.655 --> 00:23:54.750
Our organization.

439
00:23:54.750 --> 00:23:57.753
And most likely we're gonna
crossing organizational boundaries

440
00:23:57.753 --> 00:23:59.120
between departments.

441
00:23:59.120 --> 00:24:03.340
We need to deal with the development guys
to talk about the application that's being

442
00:24:03.340 --> 00:24:04.320
compromised.

443
00:24:04.320 --> 00:24:07.690
We need to deal with our database people
because we need to make sure that he or

444
00:24:07.690 --> 00:24:10.420
she can give us the information we need or

445
00:24:10.420 --> 00:24:15.460
can shut things off to limit
the scope of the attack.

446
00:24:15.460 --> 00:24:18.870
So we're gonna be dealing with other
departments during this and this is a good

447
00:24:18.870 --> 00:24:23.040
chance to test that interoperability,
make sure these other departments aren't

448
00:24:23.040 --> 00:24:29.410
directly part of the CIRT team,
know what their responsibility is.

449
00:24:29.410 --> 00:24:32.710
Or understand what you're doing when you
come down there and ask them for that.

450
00:24:32.710 --> 00:24:34.973
They're like, this is not new.

451
00:24:34.973 --> 00:24:37.330
I kind of knew you guys
would be asking me for this.

452
00:24:37.330 --> 00:24:37.890
Here it is.

453
00:24:37.890 --> 00:24:40.170
That kinda thing.

454
00:24:40.170 --> 00:24:44.190
So lots of good things come out
of doing tabletop exercises.

455
00:24:44.190 --> 00:24:45.630
Very, very important.

456
00:24:45.630 --> 00:24:48.720
Communication methods,
I think we've mentioned this a little bit.

457
00:24:48.720 --> 00:24:50.430
When it comes to communication,

458
00:24:50.430 --> 00:24:53.640
we've talked about one
having a communication plan.

459
00:24:53.640 --> 00:24:56.920
Who needs to be notified,
at what time during the incident.

460
00:24:56.920 --> 00:24:59.710
How it gets escalated, who notifies who.

461
00:25:00.930 --> 00:25:02.876
We need to discuss secure channels.

462
00:25:02.876 --> 00:25:05.730
In the event of compromise,
how are we gonna communicate?

463
00:25:05.730 --> 00:25:07.540
Because what if the bad guys
are still in my network?

464
00:25:07.540 --> 00:25:09.270
What if they're monitoring things?

465
00:25:09.270 --> 00:25:13.730
I might not want to email details of
what we're doing to stop the attack

466
00:25:14.910 --> 00:25:19.680
because the bad guys can see that and
now they can take steps to

467
00:25:19.680 --> 00:25:22.490
hide somewhere else and get out of
the way of what we're trying to do.

468
00:25:22.490 --> 00:25:25.810
It's like the movies,
they're always one step ahead of us.

469
00:25:25.810 --> 00:25:28.800
Well, that's because you're
using plain text and

470
00:25:28.800 --> 00:25:32.070
communicating across the network
that has already been compromised.

471
00:25:32.070 --> 00:25:36.020
So having secure channels of
communication to use during an incident.

472
00:25:36.020 --> 00:25:37.320
Out of bands communication

473
00:25:38.660 --> 00:25:43.080
using communication methods that are not
involving your computer network.

474
00:25:43.080 --> 00:25:45.350
Getting on the telephone and
calling people.

475
00:25:45.350 --> 00:25:48.140
Assuming that it's not VoIP or-
>> You learn Morse code and

476
00:25:48.140 --> 00:25:49.780
you tap it out on a little-
>> [LAUGH]

477
00:25:49.780 --> 00:25:51.430
>> It does make me laugh a bit,

478
00:25:51.430 --> 00:25:54.530
cuz sometimes you're like, what do
you mean, out of bands communication?

479
00:25:54.530 --> 00:25:56.400
I can either call him, or I can call him.

480
00:25:56.400 --> 00:26:00.370
The only way to get, I'm not gonna
drive across town, hey, you know what,

481
00:26:00.370 --> 00:26:01.385
in certain situations-
>> You use mail.

482
00:26:01.385 --> 00:26:03.878
[LAUGH]
>> That might be exactly what you have to.

483
00:26:03.878 --> 00:26:06.900
[LAUGH] So you'll get it next week,
hopefully, if the USPS-

484
00:26:06.900 --> 00:26:09.204
>> Don't kill the hostages.

485
00:26:09.204 --> 00:26:11.512
The communication's coming.

486
00:26:11.512 --> 00:26:13.230
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] The check's in the mail.

487
00:26:13.230 --> 00:26:15.044
I promise, Mr. Ransomer.

488
00:26:15.044 --> 00:26:16.372
It's in the mail.

489
00:26:16.372 --> 00:26:20.693
But having an advance communications
that are at our disposal,

490
00:26:20.693 --> 00:26:22.308
is gonna be important.

491
00:26:22.308 --> 00:26:28.320
And then, documentation,
because we have to have things documented.

492
00:26:28.320 --> 00:26:31.490
We have to understand what
policies we have in place,

493
00:26:31.490 --> 00:26:34.460
and our policies are what
guide our security.

494
00:26:34.460 --> 00:26:39.450
They are how we enforce our security or
I shouldn't say how we enforce it.

495
00:26:39.450 --> 00:26:43.555
But how we let our employees
know what we expect.

496
00:26:43.555 --> 00:26:47.253
And when it comes to incident response,
it's our playbook.

497
00:26:47.253 --> 00:26:48.370
This is what we break out.

498
00:26:48.370 --> 00:26:50.710
These policies help us go through that.

499
00:26:50.710 --> 00:26:52.540
The procedures that we
have to have in place,

500
00:26:52.540 --> 00:26:56.310
our incident response plan-
>> I always think of

501
00:26:56.310 --> 00:27:01.250
guys in like missile silos that used to
have keys that they turned and whatnot,

502
00:27:01.250 --> 00:27:04.450
they had a playbook that they
followed line by line everything

503
00:27:04.450 --> 00:27:08.750
had to be down the money because
we're talking nuclear war so

504
00:27:08.750 --> 00:27:11.280
it was very important that they
followed those procedures.

505
00:27:11.280 --> 00:27:15.040
Probably not as devastating if
you don't follow per se, but

506
00:27:15.040 --> 00:27:17.250
it could be really
devastating to your business.

507
00:27:17.250 --> 00:27:20.470
Could be really devastating to your
organization, whatever that case is so,

508
00:27:20.470 --> 00:27:24.610
coming up with a really well defined
step by step plan, that I can say I

509
00:27:24.610 --> 00:27:28.180
checked that list off as I go through it,
and say, I did what I supposed to do.

510
00:27:28.180 --> 00:27:29.280
Here it is right here.

511
00:27:29.280 --> 00:27:31.920
You're covered, their covered,
everything's accounted for.

512
00:27:31.920 --> 00:27:33.020
>> Exactly right.

513
00:27:33.020 --> 00:27:38.380
Cannot have enough practice and
planning, and policies and place.

514
00:27:38.380 --> 00:27:39.490
Escalation procedure,

515
00:27:39.490 --> 00:27:43.590
we do have to understand that that should
be part of our incident response plan.

516
00:27:43.590 --> 00:27:45.360
How we go about escalating it?

517
00:27:45.360 --> 00:27:50.860
If we suspect that there's
a password attack going on,

518
00:27:50.860 --> 00:27:52.900
do we call the CEO right then and there?

519
00:27:52.900 --> 00:27:55.630
And let he,
she know that this is going on?

520
00:27:55.630 --> 00:27:56.570
Probably not.

521
00:27:56.570 --> 00:28:01.280
It's probably something that we
notify whomever our supervisor is.

522
00:28:01.280 --> 00:28:06.094
If we're part of the incident response
team, we do our job, we go in and

523
00:28:06.094 --> 00:28:07.150
we contain it.

524
00:28:07.150 --> 00:28:11.852
Now, if during our analysis we find that
they were successful at this password

525
00:28:11.852 --> 00:28:15.500
attack, and
they were able to gain access to systems.

526
00:28:15.500 --> 00:28:17.606
That might change who we need to notify.

527
00:28:17.606 --> 00:28:21.690
If the system that they were able gain
access to had sensitive information,

528
00:28:21.690 --> 00:28:26.740
intellectual property for a organization
that if released could cause irreparable

529
00:28:26.740 --> 00:28:32.350
damage or causes monetary issues that
might change who we're supposed to notify.

530
00:28:32.350 --> 00:28:36.050
But there's definitely a chain of
command that we need to follow,

531
00:28:36.050 --> 00:28:39.160
that we should have already drawn out for
us, and

532
00:28:39.160 --> 00:28:41.670
everybody needs to be trained up on,
as well.

533
00:28:41.670 --> 00:28:46.310
Just having that in a plan somewhere
in a drawer is not good enough.

534
00:28:46.310 --> 00:28:48.800
Everybody needs to know
what that procedure is.

535
00:28:50.100 --> 00:28:54.740
So a lot of things to think about
when it comes to best practices for

536
00:28:54.740 --> 00:28:58.030
preparation for incident response.

537
00:28:58.030 --> 00:28:58.880
>> All right.

538
00:28:58.880 --> 00:29:00.410
Definitely a lot of material.

539
00:29:00.410 --> 00:29:03.520
It seems like a very easy topic to
go through, and it is kinda easy,

540
00:29:03.520 --> 00:29:08.840
it's just very broad, a lot of stuff
that goes into preparing for incidences.

541
00:29:08.840 --> 00:29:09.540
What do I do?

542
00:29:09.540 --> 00:29:11.090
What's my course of action?

543
00:29:11.090 --> 00:29:13.000
What's my guiding star if I don't have?

544
00:29:13.000 --> 00:29:18.960
A laid out plan per say,
what am I gonna do in those situations.

545
00:29:18.960 --> 00:29:21.500
You gotta have every
contingency covered at least as

546
00:29:21.500 --> 00:29:23.850
much as you can possibly think of to do.

547
00:29:23.850 --> 00:29:25.680
That's why it helps to
have a team of people,

548
00:29:25.680 --> 00:29:27.410
do table topping like
Mike was talking about.

549
00:29:27.410 --> 00:29:28.870
Very, very important things.

550
00:29:28.870 --> 00:29:32.730
Mike, thanks for explaining this for
us and going over those

551
00:29:32.730 --> 00:29:36.440
definite guidelines and ideas we need
to have implanted in the old noggin.

552
00:29:36.440 --> 00:29:38.553
But our time has run out for today.

553
00:29:38.553 --> 00:29:41.392
Good thing, as he just got to the end
of his list of things to talk about.

554
00:29:41.392 --> 00:29:42.740
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Thanks for joining us everyone,

555
00:29:42.740 --> 00:29:45.340
signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

556
00:29:45.340 --> 00:29:46.122
>> And I'm Mike Roderick.

557
00:29:46.122 --> 00:29:48.355
>> And we'll see you next time.

558
00:29:48.355 --> 00:29:54.507
[MUSIC]

559
00:29:54.507 --> 00:29:56.310
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike explain the concepts surrounding an incident response process a business will take when an incident has be identified. They will talk about identification, containment, eradication, recovery, post incident as well as reporting and documentation.
episodes.title: Incident Response Process
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.240
Welcome to ITPRO.TV.

2
00:00:01.240 --> 00:00:06.697
I'm your host Don [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.697 --> 00:00:08.392
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.392 --> 00:00:11.983
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.983 --> 00:00:13.456
>> Hello, and welcome to ITProTV.

6
00:00:13.456 --> 00:00:17.390
I'm your host Wes Bryan, and in today's
episode we got a great show for you.

7
00:00:17.390 --> 00:00:21.260
We're coming back with logical operations,
cyber sec first responder.

8
00:00:21.260 --> 00:00:23.890
And joining us back in the studios
is none other than Mr. Mike Rodrick.

9
00:00:23.890 --> 00:00:24.830
Mike, how you doing, sir?

10
00:00:24.830 --> 00:00:28.110
>> I'm doing fantastic, thanks for having
me back, excited to be here as always.

11
00:00:28.110 --> 00:00:29.140
And in this episode,

12
00:00:29.140 --> 00:00:32.410
we're going to be taking a look
at the incident response process.

13
00:00:32.410 --> 00:00:35.630
This whole course has really
been CyberSec First Responder.

14
00:00:35.630 --> 00:00:39.710
We're talking about being that
first responder in an organization.

15
00:00:39.710 --> 00:00:43.010
And we wanna talk about the basic
outline of the process here.

16
00:00:43.010 --> 00:00:47.260
And of course, it's gonna be fine tuned
to your organization's needs, but

17
00:00:47.260 --> 00:00:49.600
there is a process.

18
00:00:49.600 --> 00:00:52.330
If I use that word one more time,
I think I get the gold star.

19
00:00:52.330 --> 00:00:55.910
But process, there it is gold star,
that's going to the same.

20
00:00:55.910 --> 00:00:59.770
So let's talk about the main
phases of incident response.

21
00:00:59.770 --> 00:01:02.230
And the first one we're gonna
start with is preparation, right?

22
00:01:02.230 --> 00:01:06.580
And this probably one of the more
important parts as we always talk

23
00:01:06.580 --> 00:01:08.290
about with any process is, right?

24
00:01:08.290 --> 00:01:12.670
Getting ready, getting prepared,
is a very important part.

25
00:01:12.670 --> 00:01:15.920
Failing to plan is planning to fail,
right?

26
00:01:15.920 --> 00:01:18.570
Well, incident response,
it's even more so, I think,

27
00:01:18.570 --> 00:01:22.940
because when an incident occurs, people
are not gonna be thinking clearly, right?

28
00:01:22.940 --> 00:01:26.360
Panic ensues, people make snap decisions.

29
00:01:26.360 --> 00:01:28.910
They might or
might not be the right decisions.

30
00:01:28.910 --> 00:01:33.200
They get a little anxiety, my gosh,
the machine's going crazy.

31
00:01:33.200 --> 00:01:36.240
It's obviously been taken
over remote control.

32
00:01:36.240 --> 00:01:38.990
I gotta rip the cable from the wall,
I gotta throw

33
00:01:38.990 --> 00:01:42.700
the computer against the wall and smash
it a couple times to make sure it's dead.

34
00:01:42.700 --> 00:01:44.000
Obviously, I'm being a little extreme.

35
00:01:44.000 --> 00:01:47.400
But those are the kind of things
that we don't want to happen.

36
00:01:47.400 --> 00:01:50.250
Because we lose all evidence
if we ever wanna prosecute,

37
00:01:50.250 --> 00:01:52.885
if we wanna try to find out what happened.

38
00:01:52.885 --> 00:01:56.990
So we have to have a plan in
place of how this is gonna occur,

39
00:01:56.990 --> 00:01:59.980
because that way people know
what their responsibilities are.

40
00:01:59.980 --> 00:02:04.070
If they know what they're supposed to do,
and hopefully they can do that.

41
00:02:04.070 --> 00:02:06.670
They don't have to think at this point.

42
00:02:06.670 --> 00:02:10.563
So, preparation, which includes
planning and also practicing, right?

43
00:02:10.563 --> 00:02:12.598
Going through table top exercises so

44
00:02:12.598 --> 00:02:15.720
that everybody gets
comfortable with their role.

45
00:02:15.720 --> 00:02:19.820
We can discover any gaps in our
policies that we might've missed and

46
00:02:19.820 --> 00:02:22.900
we can fill those in before
an actual incident occurs.

47
00:02:22.900 --> 00:02:25.060
So when we talk about
the preparation phase,

48
00:02:25.060 --> 00:02:26.400
that's really what we're talking about.

49
00:02:26.400 --> 00:02:31.160
We're talking about our polices,
making sure those are in place.

50
00:02:31.160 --> 00:02:34.390
And we're talking about
getting our team together,

51
00:02:34.390 --> 00:02:36.800
deciding who's on
the Incident Response Team.

52
00:02:36.800 --> 00:02:38.770
You've got your call list,

53
00:02:38.770 --> 00:02:42.130
your procedures that you're gonna
use during the incident response.

54
00:02:42.130 --> 00:02:46.330
All of that is part of preparation,
getting everything ready.

55
00:02:46.330 --> 00:02:48.410
All the stuff we've been
talking about in this course.

56
00:02:48.410 --> 00:02:52.030
And then practicing it is
just as important, right?

57
00:02:52.030 --> 00:02:54.490
Because I can come up with
the best steps in the world,

58
00:02:54.490 --> 00:02:58.610
hang them on a clip board up on the wall
there, if we never look at it again and

59
00:02:58.610 --> 00:03:01.790
an incident occurs, you're still
gonna have the same level of panic.

60
00:03:01.790 --> 00:03:03.270
Who's got the clipboard?

61
00:03:03.270 --> 00:03:07.430
I mean, you've got to practice this kind
of thing, you've got to go over this.

62
00:03:07.430 --> 00:03:08.900
That's how you work out the kinks.

63
00:03:08.900 --> 00:03:12.310
That's how you get people comfortable
with what they're supposed to do.

64
00:03:12.310 --> 00:03:13.860
And then when the incident occurs,

65
00:03:13.860 --> 00:03:17.460
your first responder team is
the calm people that come in and

66
00:03:17.460 --> 00:03:22.130
take over and calm everybody else down and
go through the proper procedure.

67
00:03:22.130 --> 00:03:24.160
So preparation, big part of it.

68
00:03:24.160 --> 00:03:25.370
And then identification.

69
00:03:25.370 --> 00:03:28.090
The next phase would be identification
cuz once we're prepared,

70
00:03:28.090 --> 00:03:30.870
once we have everything set up,
all our tools in place,

71
00:03:30.870 --> 00:03:34.820
we've done all this, then we're gonna find
out that we've had an incident, right?

72
00:03:34.820 --> 00:03:37.950
Some kind of breach or infection or

73
00:03:37.950 --> 00:03:41.080
something that triggers
our first response.

74
00:03:41.080 --> 00:03:42.680
Well, we got to identify that, right?

75
00:03:42.680 --> 00:03:47.470
That might be manually looking through log
files, or noticing some strange behavior

76
00:03:47.470 --> 00:03:54.600
on the network or on a machine, or
IDS or IPS systems, sending out alerts.

77
00:03:54.600 --> 00:03:58.060
Something is gonna identify us to

78
00:03:58.060 --> 00:04:02.610
the fact that there's been some kind
of incident that we need to respond to.

79
00:04:02.610 --> 00:04:05.470
So we need to be able to detect it.

80
00:04:05.470 --> 00:04:09.250
We need to analyze it,
because it might be a false alarm.

81
00:04:09.250 --> 00:04:14.150
It might be that my IDS sent up
an alert saying there's excessive

82
00:04:14.150 --> 00:04:17.980
FTP traffic coming from a subnet that
doesn't normally have FTP traffic on it.

83
00:04:17.980 --> 00:04:22.680
And we get to, the response team goes and
does what it's suppose to do.

84
00:04:22.680 --> 00:04:27.670
We go down there, we look, we analyze,
and we realize that hey they're using

85
00:04:27.670 --> 00:04:32.730
a new way to upload files to some
server and they're doing FTP and

86
00:04:32.730 --> 00:04:36.220
it was different from our base line,
so it triggers some kind of alert.

87
00:04:37.480 --> 00:04:41.910
So identification not only of
when there is an incident, but

88
00:04:41.910 --> 00:04:45.340
when there's not an incident, right?

89
00:04:45.340 --> 00:04:48.230
Being able to analyze some
kind of occurrence and

90
00:04:48.230 --> 00:04:50.390
determine whether it's an incident or not.

91
00:04:50.390 --> 00:04:53.040
>> So Mike, make sure, right,
ahead of time, we're prepared.

92
00:04:53.040 --> 00:04:57.560
So we're not proverbial run around
like chickens with our heads cut off.

93
00:04:57.560 --> 00:05:00.450
Just like any kinda professional boxer
would practice before they go into

94
00:05:00.450 --> 00:05:02.640
a fight, we do our identification.

95
00:05:02.640 --> 00:05:04.160
Now, once we've identified,

96
00:05:04.160 --> 00:05:07.310
we do have some kinda incidents,
what's the next step?

97
00:05:07.310 --> 00:05:08.550
Where do we go from there?

98
00:05:08.550 --> 00:05:12.680
>> Yeah, o our next phase would be to,
well, kind of in between phases.

99
00:05:12.680 --> 00:05:15.800
They have it listed with identification,
with the analysis and

100
00:05:15.800 --> 00:05:20.870
collection, like I was saying,
deciding if this is an incident,

101
00:05:20.870 --> 00:05:22.930
if it is something that we need to pursue.

102
00:05:22.930 --> 00:05:25.720
But then containment would
be the next thing, right?

103
00:05:25.720 --> 00:05:28.840
If you determine that,
hey, this is an infection.

104
00:05:28.840 --> 00:05:31.850
This machine has got malware on it.

105
00:05:31.850 --> 00:05:33.510
It's listening on a certain port.

106
00:05:33.510 --> 00:05:36.088
It has a back door.

107
00:05:36.088 --> 00:05:41.530
Or it's exfiltrating data off
of the company's network,

108
00:05:41.530 --> 00:05:44.070
or whatever the case may be.

109
00:05:44.070 --> 00:05:45.710
You're gonna have to contain that.

110
00:05:45.710 --> 00:05:49.370
And the containment phase,
few things we wanna worry about.

111
00:05:49.370 --> 00:05:52.430
First and foremost,
that we always wanna think about.

112
00:05:52.430 --> 00:05:55.930
Ensure the safety and
security of personnel, right?

113
00:05:55.930 --> 00:05:57.290
Human life comes first.

114
00:05:57.290 --> 00:05:59.830
Data is replaceable for the most part.

115
00:05:59.830 --> 00:06:02.090
Systems are replaceable.

116
00:06:02.090 --> 00:06:03.930
You gotta make sure your people are safe.

117
00:06:03.930 --> 00:06:07.110
Now, you might be thinking, well,
talking about cyber incidents.

118
00:06:07.110 --> 00:06:08.540
How dangerous is this?

119
00:06:08.540 --> 00:06:11.900
It's not like we're the bomb squad and

120
00:06:11.900 --> 00:06:14.490
going and pulling out,
I don't know, whatever.

121
00:06:15.800 --> 00:06:20.130
What if you worked in one of those
powerplants that got hit by Stuxnet or

122
00:06:20.130 --> 00:06:21.720
something like that?

123
00:06:21.720 --> 00:06:26.390
So it's not out of the realm of
possibilities that human life

124
00:06:26.390 --> 00:06:27.760
could be in danger.

125
00:06:27.760 --> 00:06:31.850
They trigger your fire suppression system,
and god forbid, you're still using some of

126
00:06:31.850 --> 00:06:36.010
those old chemicals that kill people,
cuz theysuck up all the oxygen in the air.

127
00:06:36.010 --> 00:06:38.960
>> And speaking of Stuxnet, if I remember
right, I mean, it was attacking things

128
00:06:38.960 --> 00:06:42.659
like the PLCs, those programmable
logic controllers on a major system.

129
00:06:42.659 --> 00:06:44.646
And those control things like valves, so

130
00:06:44.646 --> 00:06:48.140
you very well could be in a situation
where human life is in jeopardy.

131
00:06:48.140 --> 00:06:51.170
>> Yeah, if they start getting a meltdown
because the cooling system's been shut

132
00:06:51.170 --> 00:06:54.150
down, you work for some power plant or
something like that,

133
00:06:54.150 --> 00:06:59.320
or any number of things, there's a fire
in the building and they've remotely

134
00:06:59.320 --> 00:07:03.380
controlled your electronic door locks and
they don't fail open, they fail closed.

135
00:07:03.380 --> 00:07:08.400
I mean, there's a lot of possibilities and
I don't wanna guess what could happen, but

136
00:07:08.400 --> 00:07:13.460
the point is we've gotta consider
humanly life, our employees, everybody.

137
00:07:13.460 --> 00:07:17.180
Their safety and
security personnel, comes first.

138
00:07:17.180 --> 00:07:19.540
Remove the devices from the network
would be the next thing, right?

139
00:07:19.540 --> 00:07:24.021
We wanna contain this, we want to isolate
it from the rest of the network to

140
00:07:24.021 --> 00:07:27.368
minimize the impact,
the damage that it's causing.

141
00:07:27.368 --> 00:07:29.491
We've got a machine that's infected.

142
00:07:29.491 --> 00:07:31.310
And if it's a worm,

143
00:07:31.310 --> 00:07:34.930
it's probably already too late, it's
probably already spread across my network.

144
00:07:34.930 --> 00:07:38.250
But if it's, what we try to do is try
to minimize the impact on the rest of

145
00:07:38.250 --> 00:07:41.150
the network,
limit where that infection can spread.

146
00:07:41.150 --> 00:07:45.340
And that means disconnecting that from
the network, at the bare minimum, right?

147
00:07:45.340 --> 00:07:47.270
Isolating it out.

148
00:07:47.270 --> 00:07:51.520
Disabling communication between
network devices if we need to.

149
00:07:51.520 --> 00:07:53.530
Disabling network user accounts possibly.

150
00:07:53.530 --> 00:07:55.930
If we know what account was used for
the breach,

151
00:07:55.930 --> 00:08:00.080
making sure that account can't reach out
and touch anything else on the network.

152
00:08:00.080 --> 00:08:02.053
Disabling e-mail accounts.

153
00:08:02.053 --> 00:08:06.879
Limiting access to affected subnets For
example, again,

154
00:08:06.879 --> 00:08:10.264
isolation, whatever means necessary.

155
00:08:10.264 --> 00:08:14.891
Notice what I didn't say was
power off the machine, right?

156
00:08:14.891 --> 00:08:18.720
Although, certain circumstances,
that might be warranted.

157
00:08:18.720 --> 00:08:23.500
But if we are planning on
gathering evidence, we think about

158
00:08:23.500 --> 00:08:28.830
the rules of volatility and the fact, that
if I power that machine down, I lose RAM.

159
00:08:28.830 --> 00:08:34.870
I lose caches, temp file, possibly,
of browsers, clear temp files on exiting.

160
00:08:34.870 --> 00:08:35.580
Things like that.

161
00:08:35.580 --> 00:08:37.730
If you just go and
yank the power to that thing,

162
00:08:37.730 --> 00:08:40.570
we could definitely lose that information.

163
00:08:40.570 --> 00:08:43.770
There's also the possibility
that you alert the attacker.

164
00:08:43.770 --> 00:08:45.340
Maybe you're trying to
gather more evidence.

165
00:08:45.340 --> 00:08:48.240
That's why I say,
it kind of depends on what your goal is,

166
00:08:48.240 --> 00:08:52.330
what your policies,
your incident response plans dictate.

167
00:08:52.330 --> 00:08:54.390
Do we wait and
see if we can gather more evidence, or

168
00:08:54.390 --> 00:08:58.150
do we immediately remove it from
the network to isolate the damage?

169
00:08:58.150 --> 00:09:02.960
But the next phase is containment and

170
00:09:02.960 --> 00:09:06.550
then treat the compromise
system as a crime scene.

171
00:09:06.550 --> 00:09:08.070
Another important thing.

172
00:09:08.070 --> 00:09:12.970
All right, because again, we've got
evidence that we want to capture.

173
00:09:12.970 --> 00:09:18.790
Me going up there and
just unplugging cables, moving paperwork,

174
00:09:18.790 --> 00:09:22.410
closing the laptop lid,
all of that is changing the crime scene.

175
00:09:22.410 --> 00:09:28.870
You are potentially invalidating,
if that's the right word, evidence, right?

176
00:09:28.870 --> 00:09:29.820
You're corrupting evidence.

177
00:09:29.820 --> 00:09:32.770
So it's no longer gonna be
valid in a court of law, or

178
00:09:32.770 --> 00:09:35.100
you've just lost the ability
to collect that.

179
00:09:35.100 --> 00:09:40.460
I remember, one of my first practices
of doing an incident of response.

180
00:09:40.460 --> 00:09:46.650
They've got a computer set on the table,
a couple USB sticks laying around there.

181
00:09:46.650 --> 00:09:50.059
And they say, okay you go in,
what is your first step?

182
00:09:50.059 --> 00:09:52.880
And so I immediately go in and
I'm looking at the computer.

183
00:09:52.880 --> 00:09:57.050
And I go to move, I think I moved
one of the thumb drives, and

184
00:09:57.050 --> 00:09:59.080
the guy was like nope, stop.

185
00:09:59.080 --> 00:10:01.550
Right, first failure already,
you haven't even got there yet and

186
00:10:01.550 --> 00:10:03.640
you've already failed.

187
00:10:03.640 --> 00:10:06.771
Pictures, take document,
everything, it's a crime scene.

188
00:10:06.771 --> 00:10:10.380
You've all seen the TV shows,
you tape it off with caution tape.

189
00:10:10.380 --> 00:10:14.420
You put little numbers next to everything
you find, you take pictures, right.

190
00:10:14.420 --> 00:10:17.160
Until we get that documented,
we can't collect that evidence.

191
00:10:17.160 --> 00:10:20.540
So, it is gonna be treated
like a crime scene.

192
00:10:20.540 --> 00:10:24.690
It's a little different with a computer
granted a lot of the evidence is gonna be

193
00:10:24.690 --> 00:10:29.050
in the computer itself, but
what's around it is just as important.

194
00:10:29.050 --> 00:10:32.850
You've got a charging cable still
plugged into the computer, but

195
00:10:32.850 --> 00:10:34.280
nothing at the other end of it.

196
00:10:34.280 --> 00:10:37.130
You've got a USB cap but
no USB stick, right?

197
00:10:37.130 --> 00:10:41.626
These are the kinds of things that
might mean something later on.

198
00:10:41.626 --> 00:10:44.420
What ports they were actually connected
to in the back of the machine.

199
00:10:44.420 --> 00:10:47.670
You know, they're taking that
cable out of that wall and

200
00:10:47.670 --> 00:10:50.660
plugging it into a rogue
wireless access point.

201
00:10:50.660 --> 00:10:53.320
Little things like that that
you might not think about.

202
00:10:53.320 --> 00:10:54.420
Taking screen shots,

203
00:10:54.420 --> 00:10:59.700
taking pictures of what's currently on the
screen when you walked in is a good thing.

204
00:10:59.700 --> 00:11:01.110
Screensaver's gonna kick in,

205
00:11:01.110 --> 00:11:04.185
things change,
might as well grab that information.

206
00:11:04.185 --> 00:11:07.475
>> Mike, it sounds like another concept
and I know that you've told us before.

207
00:11:07.475 --> 00:11:09.086
It sounds like chain of
custody search right away.

208
00:11:09.086 --> 00:11:13.978
I mean, you got to document the whole
area before you even start moving things,

209
00:11:13.978 --> 00:11:16.774
before you take things
out of the scene here.

210
00:11:16.774 --> 00:11:19.850
Because ultimately,
when it goes into a court of law,

211
00:11:19.850 --> 00:11:24.620
right, whoever the, defense attorney could
say, well that's not my information.

212
00:11:24.620 --> 00:11:30.790
That certainly wasn't the way my client,
if you will, handled the information.

213
00:11:30.790 --> 00:11:32.429
And now we just can't use it anymore,
right?

214
00:11:32.429 --> 00:11:34.540
>> Yeah, all they'd need is
a shadow of a doubt, right.

215
00:11:34.540 --> 00:11:35.460
Reasonable doubt and

216
00:11:35.460 --> 00:11:39.030
we can get it thrown out or
the judge says no you can't use that.

217
00:11:39.030 --> 00:11:41.380
You can definitely damage your case.

218
00:11:41.380 --> 00:11:44.540
Also keep in mind too that
when we say a lot of this,

219
00:11:44.540 --> 00:11:48.540
we're not talking about doing
forensics analysis at this point.

220
00:11:48.540 --> 00:11:51.030
We are cyber seg first responders.

221
00:11:51.030 --> 00:11:53.960
We're gonna go in,
we're the first ones on the scene.

222
00:11:53.960 --> 00:11:57.610
We're gonna make sure that we
contain the incident, if we can.

223
00:11:57.610 --> 00:11:59.950
We're gonna document everything we see.

224
00:11:59.950 --> 00:12:03.376
And then, at some point,
we'd make that decision.

225
00:12:03.376 --> 00:12:05.567
Do we go further or do we call in?

226
00:12:05.567 --> 00:12:09.712
Maybe we have a third party that we
have on retainer that comes in and

227
00:12:09.712 --> 00:12:11.428
does the actual forensic.

228
00:12:11.428 --> 00:12:14.271
We might gather up all the evidence,
bag and tag it and all of that.

229
00:12:14.271 --> 00:12:17.620
And then shift it off to somebody if we
plan on using it in the court of law.

230
00:12:17.620 --> 00:12:20.200
We do have to keep in mind
what our skill sets are.

231
00:12:20.200 --> 00:12:23.876
And if I'm not trained up in forensics,
I'm not going to attempt it.

232
00:12:23.876 --> 00:12:26.317
I'll do everything I can to
get the evidence ready for

233
00:12:26.317 --> 00:12:28.150
that forensic investigation.

234
00:12:28.150 --> 00:12:32.140
But I won't actually do it, because I
can end up tainting the evidence and

235
00:12:32.140 --> 00:12:33.350
making it inadmissible.

236
00:12:34.870 --> 00:12:37.780
But maybe as a small organization,
maybe you're the first responder and

237
00:12:37.780 --> 00:12:39.360
the forensics investigator.

238
00:12:39.360 --> 00:12:40.210
You do it all.

239
00:12:42.090 --> 00:12:43.160
So we contain it.

240
00:12:43.160 --> 00:12:48.540
We've tried to limit the damage and the
amount of damage infection that we have.

241
00:12:48.540 --> 00:12:49.840
And then we eradicate it, right?

242
00:12:49.840 --> 00:12:52.550
Once we identify the systems
that are affected,

243
00:12:52.550 --> 00:12:58.000
we try to remove the malware,
if that's what it is.

244
00:12:58.000 --> 00:13:00.127
Like I said it really depends
on what kind of incident,

245
00:13:00.127 --> 00:13:01.481
kind of changes this a little bit.

246
00:13:01.481 --> 00:13:03.150
But that's all in your plan, right?

247
00:13:03.150 --> 00:13:06.500
This has all been decided ahead of
time in your incident response plan,

248
00:13:06.500 --> 00:13:08.180
what you're gonna do if it's this.

249
00:13:08.180 --> 00:13:11.320
What you're gonna do if it's you
know scenario B, for example.

250
00:13:12.610 --> 00:13:13.330
This and scenario B?

251
00:13:13.330 --> 00:13:16.330
I could say scenario A and
scenario B, this and that.

252
00:13:16.330 --> 00:13:17.620
I don't know, one of them.

253
00:13:17.620 --> 00:13:19.035
Anyway, so yeah, eradication.

254
00:13:19.035 --> 00:13:21.320
Identify the systems that are affected.

255
00:13:21.320 --> 00:13:24.530
Our whole goal here is to
get things back to normal,

256
00:13:24.530 --> 00:13:27.990
although that really kind of goes under
the recovery phase, which is the next one.

257
00:13:27.990 --> 00:13:29.125
But removing it.

258
00:13:29.125 --> 00:13:31.930
How do we eradicate it?

259
00:13:31.930 --> 00:13:33.430
Well it depends on what the incident was.

260
00:13:33.430 --> 00:13:37.830
If it was malware on a system, maybe we
reimage the system once we've gathered up

261
00:13:37.830 --> 00:13:40.770
all the evidence that we want to analyze.

262
00:13:40.770 --> 00:13:44.240
We might do post analysis to
determine how they got in,

263
00:13:44.240 --> 00:13:46.110
how we can better protect our network.

264
00:13:46.110 --> 00:13:51.804
We'll talk about the last
phase here in a second.

265
00:13:51.804 --> 00:13:58.450
But we want to, if we have to reimage a
machine or remove malware from the system.

266
00:14:00.030 --> 00:14:04.720
Replace hardware if they've done
an attack that is damaged hardware.

267
00:14:04.720 --> 00:14:08.280
Trying to think of some other examples.

268
00:14:08.280 --> 00:14:12.110
Restoring data from backup,
if they've encrypted or

269
00:14:12.110 --> 00:14:17.340
deleted data, or possibly modified data,
so that we've lost integrity.

270
00:14:17.340 --> 00:14:19.760
We might be restoring data from backups.

271
00:14:19.760 --> 00:14:23.250
All of this is part of the,
really the recovery phase.

272
00:14:26.130 --> 00:14:29.330
Reboot servers,
if they've had a denial of service attack.

273
00:14:29.330 --> 00:14:32.990
>> Mike, it sounds a lot like this process
here, these last two phases, they're a lot

274
00:14:32.990 --> 00:14:36.270
like when we're doing, you mentioned
malware, like malware quarantine, right?

275
00:14:36.270 --> 00:14:38.860
We do a quarantine and
then we do the remediation of the system.

276
00:14:38.860 --> 00:14:42.710
Boy, these terms really sound like
they're close to synonymous with

277
00:14:42.710 --> 00:14:44.290
that type of process, as well.

278
00:14:44.290 --> 00:14:45.610
>> Yeah, absolutely.

279
00:14:45.610 --> 00:14:47.290
And yeah, we gotta watch that guy, Don.

280
00:14:47.290 --> 00:14:50.550
He was commenting in the chat room there
for those of you watching the recording.

281
00:14:50.550 --> 00:14:52.420
He was in here earlier with a laptop and
an access.

282
00:14:52.420 --> 00:14:55.410
You never know what that guy's up to.

283
00:14:55.410 --> 00:14:56.460
All right, let's see what else.

284
00:14:56.460 --> 00:14:57.550
We talked about recovery.

285
00:14:57.550 --> 00:14:59.650
And again, it might be wiping the system.

286
00:14:59.650 --> 00:15:02.910
A root kit, for example,
we don't know If we've got it all,

287
00:15:02.910 --> 00:15:05.880
we just wipe the system and restore it.

288
00:15:05.880 --> 00:15:08.795
And then you've got your
post-incident process, right?

289
00:15:08.795 --> 00:15:12.552
After the recovery and
we've got things back to normal.

290
00:15:12.552 --> 00:15:17.350
Everybody's like, okay,
we're done, we're back to normal.

291
00:15:17.350 --> 00:15:19.600
Then we go in and
we do what we call our lessons learned.

292
00:15:19.600 --> 00:15:24.297
And that's when we're gonna review
everything, the steps that were taken.

293
00:15:24.297 --> 00:15:28.720
What we accomplished,
how we win about the restoration process.

294
00:15:28.720 --> 00:15:31.676
And we've review it, so that we can hey,

295
00:15:31.676 --> 00:15:37.350
was there anything I could have done that
would have made this easier or better?

296
00:15:37.350 --> 00:15:40.046
Is there something we missed in our plan?

297
00:15:40.046 --> 00:15:43.848
Like I wish we would have done this
because, in that eradication face it would

298
00:15:43.848 --> 00:15:47.100
have been really beneficial
to have that information.

299
00:15:47.100 --> 00:15:48.370
This is our chance.

300
00:15:48.370 --> 00:15:50.720
Learn from what we've seen.

301
00:15:50.720 --> 00:15:51.880
Document.

302
00:15:51.880 --> 00:15:54.450
Adjust plans if necessary.

303
00:15:54.450 --> 00:15:56.213
How did the team react?

304
00:15:56.213 --> 00:15:58.110
Well, everybody except that Mike guy.

305
00:15:58.110 --> 00:16:02.879
Mike was panicked, you could see the sweat
on his forehead, we need more training for

306
00:16:02.879 --> 00:16:03.485
that guy.

307
00:16:03.485 --> 00:16:06.349
Again, should we respond differently?

308
00:16:06.349 --> 00:16:08.585
Do I need to update my security policy?

309
00:16:08.585 --> 00:16:13.117
Come to find out, the user was doing
something that caused this infection but

310
00:16:13.117 --> 00:16:14.938
they didn't know any better.

311
00:16:14.938 --> 00:16:20.440
And we never identified that
vulnerability in our acceptable use or

312
00:16:20.440 --> 00:16:22.980
whatever it might be.

313
00:16:22.980 --> 00:16:23.640
So they didn't know.

314
00:16:23.640 --> 00:16:25.770
So now we need to update
our security policies.

315
00:16:25.770 --> 00:16:29.280
To include that information something
we learned that we didn't think about

316
00:16:29.280 --> 00:16:30.360
before the incident.

317
00:16:30.360 --> 00:16:32.150
So post-incident processing or

318
00:16:32.150 --> 00:16:36.560
lessons learned is an extremely valuable
part of the incident response plan.

319
00:16:36.560 --> 00:16:38.720
>> Mike, I know you've stressed
the first responder here,

320
00:16:38.720 --> 00:16:43.530
in any kind of situation like this,
we educate our users, right?

321
00:16:43.530 --> 00:16:44.461
And that's an ongoing things.

322
00:16:44.461 --> 00:16:46.149
So a good part of lessons learned,

323
00:16:46.149 --> 00:16:48.660
being maybe a new lesson
that we weren't aware of.

324
00:16:48.660 --> 00:16:50.259
That we now need to
teach to our employees.

325
00:16:50.259 --> 00:16:52.786
In the example where a user might
have been doing something that they

326
00:16:52.786 --> 00:16:54.438
didn't intentionally do anything wrong.

327
00:16:54.438 --> 00:16:56.270
But it certainly caused
problems nonetheless.

328
00:16:56.270 --> 00:16:57.220
>> Yeah, that's a great point.

329
00:16:57.220 --> 00:16:59.820
Yeah, you might update your user training.

330
00:16:59.820 --> 00:17:04.480
You might say, we need to add a lesson
in clicking on links in emails.

331
00:17:04.480 --> 00:17:09.430
Or how to look in the header feed of
the email to see if it's actually from

332
00:17:09.430 --> 00:17:13.121
somebody in our domain,
whatever the case may be.

333
00:17:15.211 --> 00:17:16.180
Yeah, absolutely.

334
00:17:16.180 --> 00:17:20.580
So it might be something that we can
incorporate into our policies or

335
00:17:20.580 --> 00:17:23.330
into our training program
to prevent in the future.

336
00:17:23.330 --> 00:17:27.936
And that's the whole goal, is to make sure
that we can figure out what happened,

337
00:17:27.936 --> 00:17:29.992
why it happened, clean things up.

338
00:17:29.992 --> 00:17:33.256
And then hopefully figure out
a control that we can implement

339
00:17:33.256 --> 00:17:36.090
to prevent it from happening again.

340
00:17:36.090 --> 00:17:39.300
That would be ideal, so
those are the big phases.

341
00:17:39.300 --> 00:17:41.640
When we talk about again,
logical operations,

342
00:17:41.640 --> 00:17:44.050
they want us to talk about
the incident response process.

343
00:17:44.050 --> 00:17:46.980
So preparation, getting everything ready.

344
00:17:46.980 --> 00:17:50.170
That means coming up with our policies and
our procedures, and

345
00:17:50.170 --> 00:17:52.110
then our incident response plan.

346
00:17:52.110 --> 00:17:56.503
And defining that, working out
the kinks in there, practicing that.

347
00:17:56.503 --> 00:18:01.309
Running through dry exercises,
tabletop exercises are fantastic for

348
00:18:01.309 --> 00:18:02.680
this kind of thing.

349
00:18:02.680 --> 00:18:03.760
Getting everybody together,

350
00:18:03.760 --> 00:18:08.200
brainstorming, trying to see if there's
anything we've missed in our plan.

351
00:18:08.200 --> 00:18:12.330
We forgot, nowhere in here is it notifying
the CEO that there's been an incident.

352
00:18:12.330 --> 00:18:16.650
Oops, probably a big no-no, so
I need to include that information.

353
00:18:16.650 --> 00:18:20.610
And then the identification
phase where we try to, or

354
00:18:20.610 --> 00:18:22.810
where we determine there
has been an incident.

355
00:18:22.810 --> 00:18:25.847
Hey, everybody's been going along their
daily routine, everything's good.

356
00:18:25.847 --> 00:18:27.991
All of a sudden that
IPS throws up an alert.

357
00:18:27.991 --> 00:18:31.987
When a user calls you up and says, hey,
my mouse is moving across my screen and

358
00:18:31.987 --> 00:18:34.525
it's opening up files and
I'm not touching it.

359
00:18:34.525 --> 00:18:36.680
Something is wrong here.

360
00:18:36.680 --> 00:18:41.160
So somehow we've got to detect or realize
that there has been a potential incident.

361
00:18:41.160 --> 00:18:43.190
And we have to analyze that.

362
00:18:43.190 --> 00:18:44.450
Is this an incident?

363
00:18:44.450 --> 00:18:46.560
Or is it the case of
your desk is crooked and

364
00:18:46.560 --> 00:18:50.470
your mouse was kind of sliding down there
and just looks like somebody's moving it?

365
00:18:50.470 --> 00:18:52.790
Maybe, so

366
00:18:52.790 --> 00:18:58.260
identifying that there is indeed to reason
to call out the incident response team.

367
00:18:58.260 --> 00:19:00.580
And then containing it,
making sure that we first and

368
00:19:00.580 --> 00:19:05.640
foremost, protect our personnel,
our employees, our guest, whomever it is.

369
00:19:05.640 --> 00:19:07.670
Making sure that there's no harm or

370
00:19:07.670 --> 00:19:11.110
that we can remove any safety concerns for
them.

371
00:19:11.110 --> 00:19:14.240
Then we're gonna go about
the business of isolating it,

372
00:19:14.240 --> 00:19:18.270
trying to contain the incident.

373
00:19:18.270 --> 00:19:19.840
Preventing malware from spreading.

374
00:19:19.840 --> 00:19:24.830
Preventing somebody from bouncing
from one server to the next and

375
00:19:24.830 --> 00:19:28.720
gaining access to more information.

376
00:19:28.720 --> 00:19:32.640
Whatever the case may be, limiting
access to the subnet that the infected

377
00:19:32.640 --> 00:19:35.750
machine was on and
treating it as a crime scene, right?

378
00:19:35.750 --> 00:19:38.590
Making sure that we do what
we can to preserve evidence.

379
00:19:38.590 --> 00:19:42.960
Whether we are or not the forensics
team that's going to actually do

380
00:19:42.960 --> 00:19:45.790
the forensics analysis which
is post incident, right.

381
00:19:45.790 --> 00:19:47.660
Once we've done our containment.

382
00:19:47.660 --> 00:19:50.030
We've gathered our evidence.

383
00:19:50.030 --> 00:19:55.194
Making sure that we do what we can
to preserve any possible evidence.

384
00:19:55.194 --> 00:20:00.120
In the immediate area of where the breach
occurred or incident occurred.

385
00:20:00.120 --> 00:20:01.784
>> You're talking about first responders,
Mike.

386
00:20:01.784 --> 00:20:04.301
Would an outside like law enforcement,

387
00:20:04.301 --> 00:20:07.860
if you're talking about
treating it like a crime scene.

388
00:20:07.860 --> 00:20:10.620
We learn that there is some kind
of crime that's gone on here,

389
00:20:10.620 --> 00:20:12.331
could part of that first response be.

390
00:20:12.331 --> 00:20:15.430
Hey, we need to call the authorities in
here and we need to bring them in here.

391
00:20:15.430 --> 00:20:18.456
Cuz they need to be aware what's
going on inside of this incident or

392
00:20:18.456 --> 00:20:19.956
wherever it's happening.

393
00:20:19.956 --> 00:20:20.733
>> Yes for sure yeah,

394
00:20:20.733 --> 00:20:23.759
that's one of the things that we talk
about with incident response team.

395
00:20:23.759 --> 00:20:27.361
Is you gotta know ahead of time
this would be in your planning,

396
00:20:27.361 --> 00:20:30.230
at what point do we look for outside help?

397
00:20:30.230 --> 00:20:32.320
Who makes that determination?

398
00:20:32.320 --> 00:20:34.320
Is that the end user?

399
00:20:34.320 --> 00:20:36.150
That their mouse is moving
strange on the screen.

400
00:20:36.150 --> 00:20:37.519
They're not calling 911, right?

401
00:20:37.519 --> 00:20:39.870
We've gotta make sure that doesn't happen.

402
00:20:39.870 --> 00:20:42.220
So somebody on my
incident response team or

403
00:20:42.220 --> 00:20:44.790
somebody that we notify
makes that decision.

404
00:20:44.790 --> 00:20:48.210
But yes, there is nothing wrong
with bringing in outside help.

405
00:20:48.210 --> 00:20:51.480
If you don't have the qualified
personnel to deal with it.

406
00:20:51.480 --> 00:20:54.013
If you know that this
is gonna be prosecuted,

407
00:20:54.013 --> 00:20:56.354
you wanna get law enforcement involved.

408
00:20:56.354 --> 00:20:59.405
Because they're the ones trained in this,

409
00:20:59.405 --> 00:21:03.710
they're familiar with the court
systems and all of that.

410
00:21:03.710 --> 00:21:05.770
I might be going to federal resources.

411
00:21:05.770 --> 00:21:10.890
And there might be third party
private corporations that provide

412
00:21:10.890 --> 00:21:14.060
services that we've got a retainer
with that we can call in.

413
00:21:14.060 --> 00:21:18.160
But absolutely we have
a list in our communications

414
00:21:18.160 --> 00:21:22.100
plan of when we need outside personnel,
when we're gonna bring that in.

415
00:21:22.100 --> 00:21:25.800
If it's something like, it'd have to be
something crazy like child porn, right.

416
00:21:25.800 --> 00:21:29.550
This something where now I've gotta
get the federal authorities in here.

417
00:21:29.550 --> 00:21:31.350
And if I don't I can be in trouble.

418
00:21:31.350 --> 00:21:33.930
So we've got to make sure we understand
when we're supposed to notify those

419
00:21:33.930 --> 00:21:35.320
outside people.

420
00:21:35.320 --> 00:21:38.630
Eradication, getting rid of it,
cleaning it.

421
00:21:38.630 --> 00:21:42.037
Maybe we've duplicated the hard drive,
we've done a memory scrape.

422
00:21:42.037 --> 00:21:45.065
We've gathered up all of the evidence,
we've photographed everything.

423
00:21:45.065 --> 00:21:46.725
Now I've got to get that
system back online.

424
00:21:46.725 --> 00:21:48.765
We've got our evidence,
it's bagged and tagged.

425
00:21:48.765 --> 00:21:52.015
Now I've gotta get this system back
online, I get work back flowing so

426
00:21:52.015 --> 00:21:55.285
that we can resume our daily business.

427
00:21:55.285 --> 00:21:59.275
So that's the recovery phase, and then
again going through that lessons learned.

428
00:21:59.275 --> 00:22:04.220
So that is your basic breakdown
of the incident response process.

429
00:22:04.220 --> 00:22:05.920
>> All right a lot of
great information there.

430
00:22:05.920 --> 00:22:09.713
Definitely seems like we should have this
in place before an incident happens.

431
00:22:09.713 --> 00:22:13.726
So we know what to do and again we are not
running around pulling our hair out

432
00:22:13.726 --> 00:22:16.560
saying, hey well, we should have prepared.

433
00:22:16.560 --> 00:22:18.440
>> I forgot something to mention.

434
00:22:18.440 --> 00:22:19.810
>> Reporting and documentation.

435
00:22:19.810 --> 00:22:22.990
>> I did.
How did I miss that I don't know.

436
00:22:22.990 --> 00:22:24.080
We do have to make sure.

437
00:22:24.080 --> 00:22:27.420
I mean, I kinda lump it in with
the lessons learned because we're gonna be

438
00:22:27.420 --> 00:22:30.360
going through all of
the documentation that we had.

439
00:22:31.800 --> 00:22:36.600
But yes, that is a phase of the incident
response process is reporting and

440
00:22:36.600 --> 00:22:37.300
documentation.

441
00:22:37.300 --> 00:22:39.260
So don't let me leave that one out.

442
00:22:39.260 --> 00:22:43.050
Extremely important that we document
everything that we are doing because

443
00:22:43.050 --> 00:22:44.800
this is gonna to help me the next time.

444
00:22:44.800 --> 00:22:48.237
All right when we're doing that lessons
learned, this is really what we're doing.

445
00:22:48.237 --> 00:22:49.807
Is we're looking at our documentation and

446
00:22:49.807 --> 00:22:51.740
we're seeing what we could
have done differently.

447
00:22:51.740 --> 00:22:52.600
What worked?

448
00:22:52.600 --> 00:22:53.680
What didn't work?

449
00:22:53.680 --> 00:22:57.850
We are gonna need reports to maybe
give to the c-level executives.

450
00:22:57.850 --> 00:22:59.250
So they can see what happened.

451
00:22:59.250 --> 00:23:00.650
And we can ask them for

452
00:23:00.650 --> 00:23:04.380
money to implement new controls to
prevent this kind of thing in the future.

453
00:23:04.380 --> 00:23:05.400
So yeah, sorry,

454
00:23:05.400 --> 00:23:08.512
don't let me forget to include the good
old reporting and documentation.

455
00:23:08.512 --> 00:23:12.360
>> Yeah, absolutely, we were glad that you
did throw that in there cuz we want you to

456
00:23:12.360 --> 00:23:14.400
be, well, exam complete.

457
00:23:14.400 --> 00:23:15.320
In case they ask you on that

458
00:23:15.320 --> 00:23:17.290
exam you'd like to have that
answer ready and waiting.

459
00:23:17.290 --> 00:23:20.384
Now does look like we're coming to
the end of another episode Mike.

460
00:23:20.384 --> 00:23:24.293
But before we do, any final words when it
comes to things like incident response.

461
00:23:24.293 --> 00:23:29.220
And how are we gonna implement
this inside of our organizations?

462
00:23:29.220 --> 00:23:30.320
>> Like I said I think for

463
00:23:30.320 --> 00:23:35.620
me the biggest thing is doing
the preparation phase, and the practice.

464
00:23:35.620 --> 00:23:39.450
Right cuz that's really what is
gonna make everything go smooth.

465
00:23:39.450 --> 00:23:42.178
Because I'm gonna get a chance
to try these tools out,

466
00:23:42.178 --> 00:23:43.668
to understand how they work.

467
00:23:43.668 --> 00:23:45.044
to see what I get back.

468
00:23:45.044 --> 00:23:49.563
We're gonna practice this stuff so
that when the actual incident occurs and

469
00:23:49.563 --> 00:23:51.480
I'm called upon to do this job.

470
00:23:51.480 --> 00:23:53.672
I will feel comfortable about it.

471
00:23:53.672 --> 00:23:55.260
And I'll be able to use the tools.

472
00:23:55.260 --> 00:23:56.801
I'll be able to pick the right tool for

473
00:23:56.801 --> 00:23:58.920
whatever job it is cuz
I've seen it before.

474
00:23:58.920 --> 00:23:59.780
I know what it does.

475
00:23:59.780 --> 00:24:01.510
I know what its output is.

476
00:24:01.510 --> 00:24:05.390
And I'll just be a better
incident responder for that.

477
00:24:05.390 --> 00:24:08.930
So preparation, spend a lot of time there.

478
00:24:08.930 --> 00:24:11.920
>> Practice makes perfect,
words of wisdom from Mr. Rodrick.

479
00:24:11.920 --> 00:24:14.241
Mike, as always, we appreciate
you being here in the studio.

480
00:24:14.241 --> 00:24:16.700
And we do appreciate you,
the viewer, watching.

481
00:24:16.700 --> 00:24:19.550
Looks like we're gonna go ahead and
sign out here for ITProTV.

482
00:24:19.550 --> 00:24:20.562
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

483
00:24:20.562 --> 00:24:21.623
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

484
00:24:21.623 --> 00:24:23.138
>> And we'll see you next time.

485
00:24:23.138 --> 00:24:30.158
[MUSIC]

486
00:24:30.158 --> 00:24:35.139
Thank you for watching ITProTV

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explain general mitigation methods and devices. They start by looking at methods like system hardening, blocking known malware sources, and DNS filtering. They also discuss other methods like Blackhole Routing, System/App Isolation, Mobile Device Management
episodes.title: Mitigation Methods

And of course, joining us yet
again, that's right,

There's websites set up and then you've
got all these phishing scams and

00:12:37.630 --> 00:12:40.280
things like that that try to

00:12:40.280 --> 00:12:44.390
Well, if those servers are known, because

00:12:44.390 --> 00:12:45.600

we're infected with malware from
we need to log those, right or

do your research,

00:12:59.720 --> 00:13:02.690
If you had an attack in your system,

00:13:02.690 --> 00:13:06.740
incident, you see where

00:13:06.740 --> 00:13:09.770
So not more of your employees go out and

00:13:11.230 --> 00:13:15.290
Data is filtering is one of

00:13:15.290 --> 00:13:19.180
And when we say block known malware sites,
well how do I do that?

00:13:19.180 --> 00:13:22.310
I don't walk around all my employees or
pass out a list hey don't go to this site,

00:13:22.310 --> 00:13:24.560
and don't go to this site,
we prevent them from.

00:13:25.830 --> 00:13:27.020
We use DNS.

00:13:27.020 --> 00:13:31.920
And so, when they try to resolve that

00:13:31.920 --> 00:13:36.960

00:13:36.960 --> 00:13:40.850

256
00:13:40.850 --> 00:13:45.150
do not go there and

257
00:13:45.150 --> 00:13:50.270
So restrict what kind of look up requests

00:13:50.270 --> 00:13:51.820
Give them that block message.

259
00:13:51.820 --> 00:13:54.490
That's one thing I will say

00:13:54.490 --> 00:13:58.360

make sure you have a message set up.

00:13:58.360 --> 00:14:01.930
It's like, don't block it and

00:14:01.930 --> 00:14:04.550
then it comes up with a page not found and

00:14:04.550 --> 00:14:06.770
all they're gonna do is try

00:14:06.770 --> 00:14:09.650
Or they're gonna go to another machine,

00:14:09.650 --> 00:14:12.800

00:14:12.800 --> 00:14:14.505

00:14:25.730 --> 00:14:27.453

00:14:27.453 --> 00:14:31.709
>> [LAUGH]
>> Using DNS to give them

00:14:31.709 --> 00:14:35.910
a message of some kind at
least to let them know hey,

00:14:35.910 --> 00:14:40.530
this is blocked for

00:14:40.530 --> 00:14:45.280
If we're investigating an incident,

00:14:45.280 --> 00:14:49.410
I'm gathering up all of my indicators

00:14:49.410 --> 00:14:52.330
And I see IP addresses outside that

00:14:52.330 --> 00:14:57.810
it looks like that's where the malware's

00:14:57.810 --> 00:14:59.900

00:14:59.900 --> 00:15:03.770
We wanna contain, we wanna prevent

00:15:03.770 --> 00:15:06.890
they could be spreading

00:15:06.890 --> 00:15:12.050

00:15:12.050 --> 00:15:16.310
Easy to apply, I mean honestly it's

00:15:16.310 --> 00:15:18.370

00:15:18.370 --> 00:15:22.100
Keep in mind it won't

00:15:25.630 --> 00:15:28.750
There is a downside, or not a downside,

00:15:28.750 --> 00:15:30.690
It's not the silver bullet.

00:15:30.690 --> 00:15:32.970
It's not gonna keep my

00:15:32.970 --> 00:15:35.010
Think about what we're doing.

00:15:35.010 --> 00:15:38.770
We're using DNS to prevent

What if they're not using your DNS server?

00:15:45.148 --> 00:15:48.202
Well, then your rules aren't

00:15:48.202 --> 00:15:53.416
So if you have users that

00:15:53.416 --> 00:15:57.907
They might change their IP address

00:15:57.907 --> 00:15:59.730

00:15:59.730 --> 00:16:04.390
Malware, sometimes,
we can limit bots have to reach out, and

If we can block that,

00:16:10.202 --> 00:16:14.900
then we can prevent those bots from

304
00:16:14.900 --> 00:16:17.729
We'll do something called

00:16:17.729 --> 00:16:22.559
sink hole routing, where known bad sites

00:16:22.559 --> 00:16:26.786
in a null interface, and then it go

00:16:26.786 --> 00:16:29.932

00:16:29.932 --> 00:16:33.120
the bots can't reach out and

00:16:33.120 --> 00:16:37.765
Works great unless the bots

00:16:49.164 --> 00:16:53.987
do anything, so just keep that in mind,

314
00:16:53.987 --> 00:16:56.515
I've used the terms blacklisting, and

00:16:56.515 --> 00:17:00.760
I should mention the term whitelisting

00:17:02.300 --> 00:17:08.520
Blacklisting is when we are setting

00:17:08.520 --> 00:17:12.460
So we know these sites are bad either

00:17:12.460 --> 00:17:16.930
other organizations, or from our own

00:17:16.930 --> 00:17:20.310
We can then turnaround and
we can block those using blacklists,

00:17:21.910 --> 00:17:24.730
useful in responding to malware threats.

00:17:26.350 --> 00:17:30.840
One of the things you wanna be careful

00:17:30.840 --> 00:17:36.240

00:17:36.240 --> 00:17:40.720
We might try to say this entire subnet is

00:17:40.720 --> 00:17:44.520
especially when you're dealing with public

00:17:44.520 --> 00:17:51.000
these organizations or the registrars

00:17:51.000 --> 00:17:55.970
You can't say the whole class just

00:17:55.970 --> 00:18:00.050
was a Class B address, I can't say that

00:18:00.050 --> 00:18:02.970
I don't wanna block that whole thing

00:18:02.970 --> 00:18:07.720
valuable resources or resources I
need to get to on that same IP range.

00:18:07.720 --> 00:18:10.520
So do be careful with that, so
that's what we call collateral damage.

331
00:18:10.520 --> 00:18:14.473
You end up trying to block a range of
address and then, all of a sudden,

332
00:18:14.473 --> 00:18:18.906
my users can't get to legitimate resources
that they used to be able to get to.

333
00:18:18.906 --> 00:18:22.270
And what you don't know
can still hurt you, right?

00:18:22.270 --> 00:18:25.670
The thing about blacklists is you're
taking all the stuff you know

00:18:25.670 --> 00:18:28.010
that's bad and putting it on there.

00:18:28.010 --> 00:18:30.220
But do you know everything that's bad?

00:18:30.220 --> 00:18:32.580
You don't, you can't, most likely.

00:18:32.580 --> 00:18:35.660
So, it's a constant updated thing.

00:18:35.660 --> 00:18:40.370
We have to keep putting our research in,

00:18:40.370 --> 00:18:43.410
>> Now, Mike, for those times
when things have gotten so bad,

00:18:43.410 --> 00:18:49.120
it's easier to create a list of good

00:18:49.120 --> 00:18:50.835
That's when we have whitelisting,

00:18:50.835 --> 00:18:53.770
>> Yes, exactly right, and
that's just as Daniel said,

00:18:53.770 --> 00:18:55.650
it's just the opposite approach.

00:18:55.650 --> 00:18:57.920
Instead of trying to say,
everything's good,

and I'm gonna specify what's bad,

00:19:07.130 --> 00:19:09.670
And it can keep you much,

Because now if we don't know about it,

if it's not on the list

Only the things we've added to

00:19:17.140 --> 00:19:18.160
that is whitelisting.

00:19:18.160 --> 00:19:21.431
>> So, I guess a good way to think about
it when it comes to blacklisting versus

00:19:21.431 --> 00:19:22.279
whitelisting.

00:19:22.279 --> 00:19:26.455
Blacklisting is an implicit allow

356
00:19:26.455 --> 00:19:29.436
and then whitelisting,
the opposite of that,

357
00:19:29.436 --> 00:19:32.880
is going to be an implicit
deny with an explicit allow.

358
00:19:32.880 --> 00:19:33.546
>> Yeah.

00:19:33.546 --> 00:19:34.410
>> So that's a good way to think about it.

00:19:34.410 --> 00:19:39.180
>> Exactly right, exactly right, and
it's a lot of work trying to come up

00:19:39.180 --> 00:19:44.049
with all the known bad sites, or trying to

as soon as you put it in place,

Hey, we can no longer do this,

00:19:48.310 --> 00:19:51.080
This application is no longer working,

00:19:51.080 --> 00:19:53.190
And they're just things

00:19:53.190 --> 00:19:56.930
That application has a dashboard, it has

00:19:56.930 --> 00:20:01.560
server to populate that information,

00:20:01.560 --> 00:20:05.462
So now, it's just a constant

369
00:20:05.462 --> 00:20:07.930
Now eventually, right,
you'll get to the point where,

370
00:20:07.930 --> 00:20:11.900
okay, we seem to be pretty good,
we're not having any more issues.

00:20:11.900 --> 00:20:14.810
Just about everything we need
is now on that whitelist, and

00:20:14.810 --> 00:20:18.340
now it's just gonna be new things that pop

00:20:18.340 --> 00:20:23.000
Whitelists are usually used in highly
secure environments where I've just have

374
00:20:23.000 --> 00:20:27.600
to make sure that you're
only going to known,

375
00:20:27.600 --> 00:20:31.900
good or authorized sites or resources.

376
00:20:31.900 --> 00:20:36.720
Can be very restrictive,
constantly needing fine-tuning on that,

377
00:20:36.720 --> 00:20:39.912
what else, so yeah, that's whitelisting.

378
00:20:39.912 --> 00:20:44.434
Black hole routing, I mentioned that term
earlier, yeah, this is when we set up

00:20:44.434 --> 00:20:48.500
basically a black hole or sink hole

00:20:48.500 --> 00:20:52.130
Drop traffic before it reaches out,

00:20:52.130 --> 00:20:55.190
So, we might have as I was

382
00:20:55.190 --> 00:20:58.710
you've got maybe your system got infected,
bots were loaded up on them,

383
00:20:58.710 --> 00:21:00.950
zombies, whatever you

00:21:00.950 --> 00:21:03.770
And they're supposed to reach out and

00:21:03.770 --> 00:21:04.740

00:21:04.740 --> 00:21:08.390
If they can't, then they're just gonna

00:21:08.390 --> 00:21:09.130
that's a good thing.

00:21:10.590 --> 00:21:16.450
So, it's a little less overhead as well

389
00:21:16.450 --> 00:21:18.050
Because with the filtering,
with whitelisting,

390
00:21:18.050 --> 00:21:21.350
with blacklisting, things like that,
I've gotta inspect the packet,

00:21:21.350 --> 00:21:23.190
I've gotta look at that source and

00:21:23.190 --> 00:21:28.240
Sometimes I have to take a deeper

00:21:29.270 --> 00:21:33.090
which can be a little more

00:21:33.090 --> 00:21:35.080
blackholing everything where

00:21:35.080 --> 00:21:38.270
It sees the destination, and

00:21:39.270 --> 00:21:43.870
But it is another thing, again,

00:21:43.870 --> 00:21:47.820
And we have to be really careful when

00:21:47.820 --> 00:21:50.550
end up getting that
collateral damage again, and

00:21:50.550 --> 00:21:52.620
blocking sites that should be allowed.

400
00:21:54.230 --> 00:21:57.040
System and
application isolation is another

00:21:57.040 --> 00:21:59.670
mitigation technique that we
need to be familiar with.

00:21:59.670 --> 00:22:02.150
We need to understand that
when we have an incident, or

00:22:02.150 --> 00:22:06.620
a potential breach, we wanna isolate

00:22:06.620 --> 00:22:10.130
remove it from the network,

00:22:10.130 --> 00:22:14.720
It's funny cuz you think about terms like
viruses, and it's very similar to what

00:22:14.720 --> 00:22:18.110

00:22:18.110 --> 00:22:20.750
But if somebody is sick like that,

00:22:20.750 --> 00:22:24.690
You isolate them, you prevent them

00:22:24.690 --> 00:22:27.250
You try to get them better,

00:22:27.250 --> 00:22:29.660
But one of the first things you

00:22:29.660 --> 00:22:32.600
>> You look for the little monkey that

00:22:32.600 --> 00:22:34.160
a ventilator and everything, it's awesome.

00:22:34.160 --> 00:22:35.800
>> I've seen that video,
yeah, that's a good one.

414
00:22:35.800 --> 00:22:37.813
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Yeah,

415
00:22:37.813 --> 00:22:40.011
we don't want an outbreak of viruses,
right?

416
00:22:40.011 --> 00:22:47.180
But we can isolate systems using VLANs,
if we need to.

417
00:22:47.180 --> 00:22:51.620
We can use VMs to isolate applications,
and figure out what's going on, and

418
00:22:51.620 --> 00:22:55.100
prevent that VM from talking to the rest

419
00:22:55.100 --> 00:22:58.230
we can do our analysis if we need to.

00:22:58.230 --> 00:23:01.990
When it comes to mitigation techniques,
again, same concept.

421
00:23:01.990 --> 00:23:06.226
If we talk about isolation,
by isolating targets,

422
00:23:06.226 --> 00:23:09.691
right, we can, if they are compromised,

423
00:23:09.691 --> 00:23:14.720
maybe contain that within that
isolated part of our network.

424
00:23:14.720 --> 00:23:17.413
Typically, like I said, using VLANs,

425
00:23:17.413 --> 00:23:23.039
again we had this conversation I know this
morning, we were talking about subnets,

426
00:23:23.039 --> 00:23:27.810
routers, switches, VLANs, and
how we could use these to segregate.

00:23:27.810 --> 00:23:32.320
And what we've gotta keep in mind is
subnets on their own really are no

00:23:32.320 --> 00:23:34.595

00:23:34.595 --> 00:23:37.665
But rules that we create on the router

00:23:37.665 --> 00:23:39.893

00:23:39.893 --> 00:23:43.511

It'll just take that traffic and

00:23:49.289 --> 00:23:53.830
broadcast traffic but That's not what
we're trying to do, VLAN same thing.

00:23:55.730 --> 00:23:57.755
It can help us isolate that traffic,

00:23:57.755 --> 00:24:03.860
prevent subnet from

00:24:04.910 --> 00:24:07.195
What else?
Mobile device management,

00:24:07.195 --> 00:24:11.203
big part of our job today when

00:24:11.203 --> 00:24:14.726
trying to protect against attacks and

00:24:14.726 --> 00:24:19.136
We've gotta have a plan for our mobile
devices, because unless your organization

00:24:19.136 --> 00:24:23.168

00:24:23.168 --> 00:24:26.400
Most likely you've got mobile

00:24:26.400 --> 00:24:30.122
whether they're part of

00:24:30.122 --> 00:24:31.555
They're gonna be attaching
to your network,

445
00:24:31.555 --> 00:24:36.110
they're going to be potentially doing
work from or contain work data.

00:24:36.110 --> 00:24:38.130
So we've gotta have a plan of action for

00:24:38.130 --> 00:24:40.900
Typically when we look at

00:24:40.900 --> 00:24:42.510

00:24:42.510 --> 00:24:45.190
There are certain things

00:24:45.190 --> 00:24:47.610

00:24:47.610 --> 00:24:51.050
At a minimum, I need to make sure

Or they're prevented or limited, at least,

So making sure we can enroll these

457
00:25:07.930 --> 00:25:09.680
Remote locks and wipes,

458
00:25:09.680 --> 00:25:15.350
another big part of MDM is being able
to do that, cuz it's gonna happen.
