00:25:15.350 --> 00:25:19.390
One of your employees is gonna leave
that phone in the back of the cab, or

460
00:25:19.390 --> 00:25:23.660
at the counter at the restaurant, or
in the bathroom, or what have you.

461
00:25:23.660 --> 00:25:26.420
It's gonna get lost,
it's gonna get stolen.

462
00:25:26.420 --> 00:25:30.500
On that phone is company information,
now what do we do, right?

463
00:25:30.500 --> 00:25:33.970
Well, we should be able to reach out and
wipe that phone.

464
00:25:33.970 --> 00:25:35.430
And that way, who ever stole it,

465
00:25:35.430 --> 00:25:39.720
if they do get access to it,
they're not gonna get company information.

466
00:25:39.720 --> 00:25:42.111
They're not gonna be able
to VPM back in the network,

467
00:25:42.111 --> 00:25:44.926
cuz how many of you have mobile
devices that you've set up RDP or

468
00:25:44.926 --> 00:25:48.050
some sort of VPN software so
that you can reach back into work?

469
00:25:48.050 --> 00:25:51.280
Because you know you're gonna get a call
after hours, and on your day off, and

470
00:25:51.280 --> 00:25:53.850
many times I don't have to go
into the network physically,

471
00:25:53.850 --> 00:25:55.470
I can do it from a remote location.

472
00:25:55.470 --> 00:25:57.940
I can be out on the golf course and
I can remote in and

473
00:25:57.940 --> 00:25:59.860
take a look at what the system is doing.

474
00:25:59.860 --> 00:26:02.750
That means if somebody steals it and
they get access to my phone,

475
00:26:02.750 --> 00:26:06.030
they can very well click the icon and
gain access to the system, right?

476
00:26:06.030 --> 00:26:07.070
So being able to reach out and

477
00:26:07.070 --> 00:26:12.280
wipe those devices, most of these systems
now can segregate personal and work.

478
00:26:12.280 --> 00:26:15.070
So that when you do reach out, let's
say you've got an employee that leaves

479
00:26:15.070 --> 00:26:18.490
the organization, not just a stolen phone,
but Daniel leaves.

480
00:26:18.490 --> 00:26:22.676
He's taken his phone with him, it was his
phone, but he was doing work with it.

481
00:26:22.676 --> 00:26:27.250
I wanna wipe it, but I can't wipe his
entire phone because he might get

482
00:26:27.250 --> 00:26:30.790
a little upset with that, and there could
be some liability to my organization for

483
00:26:30.790 --> 00:26:32.330
wiping his personal information.

484
00:26:32.330 --> 00:26:35.370
He's already mad that we've let him go and
now we wiped his phone,

485
00:26:35.370 --> 00:26:36.250
what are you gonna do, Daniel?

486
00:26:36.250 --> 00:26:39.650
>> I wouldn't be too thrilled with that,
I'll be honest with you.

487
00:26:39.650 --> 00:26:44.540
But when you get a little thing that
says do you agree that these people,

488
00:26:44.540 --> 00:26:47.490
because you're attaching to their network,
they can wipe your phone.

489
00:26:47.490 --> 00:26:51.660
And you have to say yes, and
it'd be an interesting court battle,

490
00:26:51.660 --> 00:26:52.750
I gotta be honest with you.

491
00:26:52.750 --> 00:26:56.815
But I'd probably be up here with
buckets of gas and matches going.

492
00:26:56.815 --> 00:26:57.327
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

493
00:26:57.327 --> 00:26:59.260
>> I'm gonna burn you out,

494
00:26:59.260 --> 00:27:00.935
you done wiped my phone too.

495
00:27:00.935 --> 00:27:03.925
>> That's what I was thinking,
I would never, I know Daniel's armed and

496
00:27:03.925 --> 00:27:04.904
I'm not going to.

497
00:27:04.904 --> 00:27:07.146
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

498
00:27:07.146 --> 00:27:10.155
>> You see the guns on this guy over here.

499
00:27:10.155 --> 00:27:11.995
So, yeah-
>> It's the guns you don't see, Mike.

500
00:27:11.995 --> 00:27:15.990
>> That is right, yeah, the guns I
don't see, exactly, all right, so

501
00:27:17.070 --> 00:27:21.190
looking at devices through GPS,
many phones support this now.

502
00:27:21.190 --> 00:27:24.080
We can get usually pretty darn close,
they're pretty accurate.

503
00:27:24.080 --> 00:27:26.540
I remember when these first came out,
it kinda gave you a proximity.

504
00:27:26.540 --> 00:27:30.258
But, I remember somebody was trying to
find their phone in their house, and

505
00:27:30.258 --> 00:27:32.470
it It's like,
it's not quite that accurate.

506
00:27:32.470 --> 00:27:35.540
It'll show you your house but it's not
gonna tell you it's in the bedroom.

507
00:27:35.540 --> 00:27:39.480
But they're getting better, but
maybe we can use that as an organization,

508
00:27:39.480 --> 00:27:40.310
if somebody comes to me and

509
00:27:40.310 --> 00:27:43.890
says, hey I've, I can't locate my
phone I think I left it in a cab.

510
00:27:43.890 --> 00:27:47.004
We've called the cab company, they say
say there's no sign of it in there.

511
00:27:47.004 --> 00:27:50.595
Well, Ken do I have a website that I can
pull up and I can ping your phone, and

512
00:27:50.595 --> 00:27:51.398
see where it is?

513
00:27:51.398 --> 00:27:54.410
And maybe go locate it?

514
00:27:54.410 --> 00:27:58.357
The ability to push out updates,
our users might not be as thorough or

515
00:27:58.357 --> 00:28:02.780
as consistent as we'd like when it comes
to keeping their device up to date.

516
00:28:02.780 --> 00:28:06.130
Can we push updates out to that device?

517
00:28:06.130 --> 00:28:07.242
Microsoft Intune and

518
00:28:07.242 --> 00:28:11.193
things like this allow you to do this
kinda thing, well if it's running on,

519
00:28:11.193 --> 00:28:15.720
even if it's not running Microsoft OS,
they've got some tools for that.

520
00:28:15.720 --> 00:28:18.820
Preventing root access, all right,
especially on your Android systems,

521
00:28:18.820 --> 00:28:19.890
things like that.

522
00:28:19.890 --> 00:28:23.300
Can I limit what that user
has access to on that phone?

523
00:28:24.370 --> 00:28:28.210
That's a tough one, it depends if
it's a company issued device or not.

524
00:28:28.210 --> 00:28:31.490
I would have a hard time with
an organization saying hey,

525
00:28:31.490 --> 00:28:35.230
we know that's your phone, but we're gonna
take away your root access on that phone.

526
00:28:35.230 --> 00:28:40.000
Yeah, probably not gonna go over to well,
but if it's a company issued device,

527
00:28:40.000 --> 00:28:43.100
well, then,
there's not a lot I can do about that.

528
00:28:43.100 --> 00:28:48.222
Constructing encrypted containers,
many devices nowadays allow us to, if not

529
00:28:48.222 --> 00:28:53.360
encrypt the entire device, at least create
part of the storage to be encrypted.

530
00:28:53.360 --> 00:28:56.790
And we can make sure that any work
related stuff is going in to there.

531
00:28:56.790 --> 00:28:57.720
And that way, again,

532
00:28:57.720 --> 00:29:02.270
if somebody gets that device maybe we can
keep them from gaining access to that.

533
00:29:02.270 --> 00:29:05.950
Restricting features possibly
on these devices, so

534
00:29:05.950 --> 00:29:09.100
lots of things we can do with
Mobile Device Management.

535
00:29:09.100 --> 00:29:12.380
Application whitelisting is
another thing that we can do.

536
00:29:12.380 --> 00:29:15.900
I know, Daniel, we're getting ready to run
out of time here, I'll wrap up with this,

537
00:29:17.270 --> 00:29:20.370
application whitelisting is
just like DNS whitelisting.

538
00:29:20.370 --> 00:29:24.050
If we have applications that
are known good, we can allow them.

539
00:29:24.050 --> 00:29:28.360
Other applications do not get installed
on those mobile devices, right.

540
00:29:28.360 --> 00:29:32.700
I don't want you installing these games,
and this and that and the other.

541
00:29:32.700 --> 00:29:35.270
Only stuff that's work related or
approved,

542
00:29:35.270 --> 00:29:37.770
at least,
should be allowed to go on those devices.

543
00:29:37.770 --> 00:29:39.689
So that's one thing about
application whitelisting,

544
00:29:39.689 --> 00:29:41.416
and that's not just mobile devices,
actually.

545
00:29:41.416 --> 00:29:46.412
That could be on your desktops,
your laptops, those are well.

546
00:29:46.412 --> 00:29:50.920
We've all got the Windows Store,
the Apple stuff,

547
00:29:50.920 --> 00:29:54.420
the Google stuff,
we wanna control what apps.

548
00:29:54.420 --> 00:29:58.590
Because those organizations
really do try to do a good job

549
00:29:58.590 --> 00:30:02.040
of vetting those applications
before they're in their stores,

550
00:30:02.040 --> 00:30:05.130
because it's their reputation
that they're protecting.

551
00:30:05.130 --> 00:30:10.070
They don't want you downloading an app,
and then your device becoming compromised,

552
00:30:10.070 --> 00:30:12.220
and starting to talk to you or whatever.

553
00:30:12.220 --> 00:30:15.565
And you're gonna blame it on them,
they don't want that reputation either so

554
00:30:15.565 --> 00:30:17.621
they do what they can,
they can't catch everything.

555
00:30:17.621 --> 00:30:22.555
It's obvious we have had cases where apps,
bad apps have slipped through the cracks,

556
00:30:22.555 --> 00:30:23.245
and gone out.

557
00:30:23.245 --> 00:30:28.135
But as an organization maybe we
want to prevent them from even

558
00:30:28.135 --> 00:30:31.495
going to those stores or at least saying
these are the only apps you can install.

559
00:30:31.495 --> 00:30:34.470
>> Yeah it's definitely
the way of the future people,

560
00:30:34.470 --> 00:30:38.450
we don't want you downloading things
that would be potentially harmful or

561
00:30:38.450 --> 00:30:42.730
exposing of your device or
to our organization through your device.

562
00:30:42.730 --> 00:30:46.370
So that's just one of the things that you
gotta get used to in this day and age.

563
00:30:46.370 --> 00:30:48.700
Mike, I know we got, like you said,
a few more things to go down.

564
00:30:48.700 --> 00:30:55.320
We'll have to make a small part
two to round out this very topic.

565
00:30:55.320 --> 00:30:57.760
But Mike, thanks for joining us here
on part one, thank you guys for

566
00:30:57.760 --> 00:30:58.990
watching us as well.

567
00:30:58.990 --> 00:31:01.950
Hope to see you in that part two, as for
this one, though, we're signing off.

568
00:31:01.950 --> 00:31:04.190
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

569
00:31:04.190 --> 00:31:04.988
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

570
00:31:04.988 --> 00:31:07.763
>> We'll see you next time.

571
